Cowichan

General Correspondence
Somenos R.C. School
Kamloops, B.C.
Oct 12th 1899.

Sir,

I received today your communication No. 2037 in my application for Government Support to reopen the Somenos Indian Day School.

I regret that you cannot recommend my application to the Department, because you do not consider that there are enough children of school age in the neighborhood.

At the request of the Somenos Indians, however, I will reopen the school on the Somenos Reservation on Monday Oct 23rd just an Indian house having been given me for the purpose.

I wish hereby to inform you of the fact.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant

Geo. C. Van Boekhoven

Signed,

W. Thomas Esqre
Indian Agent
Okanagan, BC
Kamloops, Oct. 31st 1879

Sir,

I have the honour of acknowledging receipt of your communication (P.M. 3) dated October 10th last and in reply I wish to state that I regret Mr. Lomas did not think it right to recommend my application for Government aid to reopen the Similkameen Indian Day School, upon the ground that there are not enough children of school age in the neighborhood indicated. I wrote to Mr. Lomas expressing my regret, however, as the Similkameen band upon reopening their school, having given me a house for that purpose, I have decided to comply with their wish, on Monday October 25th inst., trusting that the future will produce sufficient evidence in support of either Mr. Lomas or my statement regarding the number of children, to warrant the Government expenditure required, and then my intention to make a second application.

You will greatly oblige me by forwarding my application to the Department, pending Mr. Lomas' opinion if you see fit.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

C.W. Novell Esq.,
Victoria,
B.C.
Quamichan B.C., Sept. 28th, 1899.

Sir,

I have the honour hereby to apply for a Government grant to enable me to open the Sonomas Indian day-school on the Sonomas Reservation, here myself to teach or to provide a suitable teacher.

You are aware that a school was opened on the Sonomas Reservation two years ago, and the teacher received Government support. After a few months the teacher, a certain Mr. Nicholas transferred the Sonomas School to the Shuswap Indians Reservation, abandoning it after a few weeks' trial, not, I understand, for want of children of school-age, but because the Cowichan Christian Indians being Roman Catholics absolutely refused to send their children to a school taught by a teacher of the Methodist persuasion.

W.H. Thomas Esq.,
Duncan's,
N.S.C.

[Seal]

OCT 2 1899
About that time the Indians held several meetings at your office claiming their rights to a catholic teacher in accordance with the Indian Departmental Regulations.

Trusting my application will duly be forwarded and recommended to the proper authorities at Ottawa,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant

Geo. B. Van Wart

Quamichan B.C. Oct 13th 1899

Sir,

I have the honor to make duplicate copies of an application for a grant to enable Rev. Father Newbether to reopen Somunno's Indian Day School.

I have notified the Board of Education that I cannot advise the expenditure as I do not think there are enough children of school age in the neighborhood, several being now at Rupert Industrial School.

I have the honor to be,
(signature) W. A. Lomas
Indian Agent

H. W. Howell Esq.
Indian Superintendent
Victoria
Sir,

I have the honour to submit hereewith for your information the following correspondence having reference to the re-opening of a day school at Somenos in the Cowichan agency namely:

- Letter from the Rev. & Father Van Gaethen to Mr. Agent Lomas dated 28th Sept. 1899
- "Copy" Letter from Mr. Agent Lomas covering the Rev. & Father's letter and dated 5th Oct. 1899
- "Copy" Letter from the Rev. & Father Van Gaethen dated 15th October 1899

In this connection I beg to state that the Agent is directed to point out to the Rev. & Father the inexpediency of his pressing his application until he can demonstrate that the majority of the Somenos Band is in favour of his action and that there are sufficient children of a school age available at Somenos to render this project feasible.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent BC

Ottawa
OTTAWA, 30th October, 1899

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, forwarding copies of correspondence in reference to the contemplated re-opening of the Roman Catholic day school at Somos in the Cowichan Agency. In reply I beg to say that the Department approves of the action taken by you in this matter in awaiting definite information as to the number of children of school age available at that place.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLEAN
Secretary

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLEAN

Hon. Clifford Lipton,
Minister of Interior,
Ottawa.

Sir,

Some time ago there was an Indian school at Somers conducted by Methodists. This school received government aid. The Indians of this locality are largely Catholic, & understand for this reason that the Methodist school was not a success & was closed. The Catholics have had a school among the Indians there since last October & have secured an average attendance of 20 pupils.

I beg to recommend
Ranaimo, B.C.,

that this school be assisted by the Government by allowing a teacher its usual amount.

Ottawa, 11th January, 1900.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letters of the 23rd ultimo I would say that I have looked into the question of the day school upon the Semenos Reserve. I find that the Department has estimated contribution of the usual amount to a day school upon the Reserve, and I have directed that the amount be paid to the school which is being conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, as the papers show this to be in accordance with the desire of the Indian Band.

Yours very truly,

W.V.B. MuInnes, Esq., R.F.,
Nanaimo, B.C.

OTTAWA, 13th January, 1900

Sir,

In connection with previous correspondence on the matter of the re-opening of the Roman Catholic day school at Sosenee in the Comichan Agency I am directed to say that the usual grant of $500.00 will be paid to this school on receipt of the quarterly returns.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Note:
For previous correspondence relative to the establishment and management of this school see file 129635-1.

A.V. Vowell, Esq.
Indian Supt.
Victoria, B.C.
Ottawa, February 16th, 1910.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of Mr. Inspector Green's report on the Somenos Indian day school, from which it appears that the Indians have been very negligent in the matter of sending their children to school, the average during the past six months having been only two.

You will be good enough to advise the Indians that, if subsequent reports do not show an improvement in the attendance, the Department will have to consider the question of closing the school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

W. R. Robertson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duncan's Station, B.C.
Ottawa, February 9, 1928.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge yours of the 17th ultimo, referring to the education of the Indian children on the Cowichan reserve. I have noted that there are 60 children of school age in the Quamichan, Comoxen, Kaneson, Clamslalute, Semence and Kokeliah bands.

As you may know, at one time there were two day schools for the Quamichan band, under the auspices of the Roman Catholic and Methodist churches. These were closed in 1917 and 1918, respectively, because of poor attendance. There was a Roman Catholic school for the Semence band which met a similar fate in 1910. There remains now the one Kokeliah Indian Day School, with an average attendance of about 10.

I have noted that you have made a careful study of the educational needs on the Cowichan, and the Department is giving earnest consideration to your suggestions. As soon as funds can be provided, we will endeavor to build a day school on the north of the river, between the Quamichan and Comoxen bands. You might inform the Department if we own any school buildings in the vicinity and if any school equipment, such as desks and blackboards, is available. The Department's policy is to allow a church to have the supervision over these day schools, and it is thought that this school to the north of the river should be conducted under the Roman Catholic auspices.

For the requirements of the children to the south of the river, you have recommended the moving of the Kokeliah Indian Day School. In reply I wish to state that we have taken up with the Methodist Church authorities the advisability of moving their school to a point near the Kokeliah railway station. I believe it would be advisable to have it continue under their auspices. Would you give an estimate of the cost of moving this building and intimate to the Department if its condition would permit of such moving. I understand that it was erected in 1918 and is the property of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Alfred H. Lomas, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B. C.
SOMENOS DAY SCHOOL.

This school has been closed for sometime, but it might be re-opened under R.C. auspices as from the 1st of April, 1923, upon the recommendation of the Agent. The equipment at the old Glenclermaluts school could be used. Seven hundred and fifty was suggested as a salary.

R.J.F.
Supt. of Indian Education.
EXTRACT FROM LETTER SIGNED BY REV. FRANCIS BOSHOUWERS,
OF DUNCAN, B.C., AND ENDORSED BY HIS LORDSHIP
THE BISHOP OF VICTORIA, B.C., DATED SEPT. 1922.
ADDRESSED TO DEPUTY SUPT. GENERAL.

Original on File 295667-1.

May I ask the Department that a school under Catholic auspices be built next spring on the Somenos Reserve, near Duncan. On that reserve there are today 21 (twenty-one) children of school age, all Catholic children, of those only five or six attend at times the Kokeliah school. Again, these same children are continually exposed to danger: for to reach the school they are forced to climb over half a dozen fences, cross the railway track and the railway bridge. In case of accident, who will be held responsible?

(Sgd.) Rev. Francis Boshouwers,

I endorse the foregoing application.

(Sgd.) Alexander MacDonald,

Bishop of Victoria.

General Correspondence

Skulkayn School
Office of
THE INSPECTOR OF INDIAN AGENCIES.
Southwestern Inspectorate.

No.169/G. Victoria, B.C., 1st May, 1913.

Sir:

There are also some children on the Tsachteen and the Yuk-kwe-kwi-oose reserve who might be able to attend the school, though these two reserves are about two miles distant.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) W. E. Ditchburn.
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
I beg to inform you that during the present month when visiting the Indians at Chilliwack in company with the Royal Commission on Indian Affairs the Indians of Skulkayn, Yakweakwicose, Tseachten and Scowahlie Reserves requested that they should be supplied with Indian day schools.

In dealing with this matter I may say that when at Chilliwack on the 24th April, 1913, when looking into the necessity for the establishment of the day school on the Skwah Reserve, the Indians from the reserves before mentioned informed me that they also would like to have a school built for them. I informed them at the time that the establishment of more day schools in that section would depend entirely upon the success had with the school then under consideration and that if I found that a good average attendance was kept up in this school and it was impossible for the children of their reserves to attend the one on the Skwah Reserve I would consider the advisability of recommending one for them.

A glance at the plan of the Chilliwack Reserves will show that Skulkayn Nos. 10 and 11, Yakweakwicose No. 12 and Tseachten No. 13 are at least three and one half miles from the Skwah village where the new day school is situated, serving as it does the Skwah, Skway, Squiala and Kwawkwawapilt villages. This school has proved so satisfactory that I am now prepared to recommend the establishment of another day school for the Skulkayn, Yakweakwicose and Tseachten Reserves.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
The Indians have supplied me with a list of the available pupils who are at present getting no school. This list shows that there are 28 children who should be at school of ages ranging from six to fourteen years. These children are of mixed religion, there being 17 Catholics and 12 Protestants and I would say that if a school should be established it should be an undenominational one. The Indians have promised to set aside sufficient land on one of the reserves for school grounds and teacher's residence.

The Soowahlie or Cultus Lake Reserve is still another four miles further on and on this reserve there are 14 Protestant children and one Catholic, their ages being from six to sixteen years. On this reserve the Indians also wish to have a school but the number of pupils available is not sufficient to warrant the building of a new school and teacher's residence as well. There is, however, a small Methodist church building on the reserve which might, with a small outlay, be made suitable for school purposes. The difficulty here would be to find a place for a teacher to reside in though this might be overcome by the building of a small house if a suitable place could not be found amongst the white settlers where the teacher could board.

If you are disposed to giving my recommendations favorable consideration the matter can be taken up further with the Indians and the details worked out. The Indians guarantee that if schools are established they will see that the children go to school regularly.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Report of Inspector Ditchburn for the month of January, 1915.

Southwestern Inspectorate, B.C.

Sir:

I have the honour to report—

At the Chilliwack Indian Day School on the Skwah Reserve I found a fine attendance and the register showed that the average for the last quarter had been an excellent one. Mr. Grimshaw, the teacher, is making very good progress with the pupils and I am of the opinion that the establishment of this school will be of great benefit to the Indians of the Skwah, Squiala, Skway and Kwawkwa̱pit bands. The Indians of the Skulkaym, Tscheachten and Yakweakwiioose, which are four miles distant from the present school are now desirous of having a day school. This matter will be dealt with in a separate report.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Ditchburn

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Inspector Ditchburn reports that when visiting Chilliwack in company with the Royal Commission on Indian Affairs the Indians of the Skulkayn, Yakweakwioose, Tzeachten and Soowahlie Reserves requested that they be furnished with day schools. He states that the school established at Skwah village on the Chilliwack Reserve serves the Skwah, Skway, Squiala and Kwawkwawapilt villages, but that the four reserves previously mentioned are too far away from the school for the Indians to attend. He says that there are 25 children of school age and they are about equally divided between the Protestant and Roman Catholic churches and if the Department decides to establish a school it would have to be conducted as an undenominational one. The Indians will set aside sufficient land on the most suitable reserve for school grounds and a teacher's residence. The school on the Skway Reserve is well attended and the pupils are making good progress and Mr. Ditchburn gives it as his opinion that the establishment of another school for the four northern reserves would be of great benefit.
2.

benefit to them. In case the Department decided to give them a school a building and teacher's residence would have to be erected. Attached you will find a blue print showing the location of the reserves referred to.

Mr. Ditchburn also states that there is another reserve at Cultus Lake, which is too far from any school facilities and that there are fourteen Protestant children and one Roman Catholic child of school age and that the Indians have also asked for a school there. He states that he does not think the attendance would be sufficiently large at present to warrant the Department in going to the expense of erecting a building, but that there is a Methodist Church on the reserve, which might, with a small outlay, be made suitable for school purposes. The difficulty would be to find a place for the teacher to reside.

I think if the Department is in favour of Mr. Ditchburn's recommendations the preference should be given to the four northern reserves and the Cultus Lake Reserve might stand for a time until it is seen what progress is made at the other school.

[Signature]
March 1st, 1915.

Dear Mr. Ditchburn -

Your letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to the establishment of a day school for the Indians on the Shulkayn Reserve No. 10 and No. 11, Yakweakwicose Reserve No. 12 and Tsawchton Reserve No. 13, has been referred to me. There would appear to be necessity for a day school to serve these reserves, and there are sufficient children of school age, if the mixed religion of the Indians would not interfere.

I am aware that there are no separate schools in the Province of British Columbia, but notwithstanding this, I would like to have more definite information before undertaking the expenditure called for. If we established a non-denominational school in which no religious instruction would be given, would it meet with the approval of those in charge of the mission work on these reserves?

W. E. Ditchburn, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Victoria, B.C.
I would like you to look more fully into this phase of the matter before we take further action. In any event I am not aware as yet what appropriations we will get during the coming year for building purposes, and there will be time to give the matter more consideration.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.
Department of Indian Affairs

Vancouver

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of 30th inst., No. 153-6-1, I hasten to thank the Department for granting a salary of $600 per annum to the teacher in charge of the day pupils at Squamish Mission Boarding School.

I need not tell you how grateful the Sister Superior is. It will surely tend to lighten the heavy burden which has been carried in the management of this school.

Yours very respectfully,

J. Willet.

No.32/E

Victoria, B.C., 29th January, 1915

Sir:

I beg to inform you that during the present month when visiting the Indians at Chilliwack in company with the Royal Commission on Indian Affairs the Indians of Skulkayn, Yakweakwicose, Tseachten and Seewahlie Reserves requested that they should be supplied with Indian day schools.

In dealing with this matter I may say that when at Chilliwack on the 24th April, 1913, when looking into the necessity for the establishment of the day school on the Skwah Reserve, the Indians from the reserves before mentioned informed me that they would like to have a school built for them. I informed them at the time that the establishment of more day schools in that section would depend entirely upon the success had with the school then under consideration and that if I found that a good average attendance was kept up in this school and it was impossible for the children of their reserves to attend the one on the Skwah Reserve I would consider the advisability of recommending one for them.

A glance at the plan of the Chilliwack Reserves will show that Skulkayn Nos. 10 and 11, Yakweakwicose No. 12 and Tseachten No. 13 are at least three and one half miles from the Skwah village where the new day school is situated, serving as it does the Skwah, Squiala and Kwawkwawapilt villages. This school has proved so satisfactory that I am now prepared to recommend the
establishment of another day school for the Skulkyn, Yakweawicose and Tseachten Reserves. The Indians have supplied me with a list of the available pupils who are at present getting no school. This list shows that there are 28 children who should be at school of ages ranging from six to fourteen years. These children are of mixed religion, there being 17 Catholics and 11 Protestants and I would say that if a school should be established it should be an undenominational one. The Indians have promised to set aside sufficient land on one of the reserves for school grounds and teacher's residence.

The Soowahlie or Cultus Lake Reserve is still another four miles further on and on this reserve there are 14 Protestant children and one Catholic, their ages being from six to sixteen years. On this reserve the Indians also wish to have a school but the number of pupils available is not sufficient to warrant the building of a new school and teacher's residence as well. There is, however, a small Methodist church building on the reserve which might, with a small outlay, be made suitable for school purposes. The difficulty here would be to find a place for a teacher to reside in though this might be overcome by the building of a small house if a suitable place could not be found amongst the white settlers where the teacher could board.

If you are disposed to giving my recommendations favourable consideration the matter can be taken up further with the Indians and the details worked out. The Indians guarantee that if schools are established they will see that the children go to school regularly.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) W. H. Ditchburn,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
March 1st, 1915.

Dear Mr. Ditchburn -

Your letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to the establishment of a day school for the Indians on the Skulkayn Reserve No. 10 and No. 11, Yakweakwioose Reserve No. 12 and Tseachten Reserve No. 13, has been referred to me. There would appear to be a necessity for a day school to serve these reserves, and there are sufficient children of school age, if the mixed religion of the Indians would not interfere.

I am aware that there are no separate schools in the Province of British Columbia, but notwithstanding this, I would like to have more definite information before undertaking the expenditure called for. If we established a non-denominational school in which no religious instruction would be given, would it meet with the approval of those in charge of the mission work on these reserves?

W. E. Ditchburn, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Victoria, B. C.
I would like you to look more fully into this phase of the matter before we take further action. In any event I am not aware as yet what appropriations we will get during the coming year for building purposes, and there will be time to give the matter more consideration.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) Duncan G. Scott.
Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith petition received by me from the members of the Tsawassen band of Indians, earnestly soliciting the Department to establish a day school on their reserve; formerly some of the elder children were permitted to attend the white schools in the vicinity, in order to make up the requisite number, but lately they are not allowed to do so, there being sufficient white children.

The Indians will provide a suitable building and guarantee an attendance of twenty pupils, if the Department will furnish the school supplies and pay the salary of a teacher. The Reverend William Chaput, Missionary to the Indians, who resides in the vicinity, informs me that he will teach the pupils if the school is established.

The Tsawassen Indians are an industrious hard-working people, and very anxious to have their children educated; they almost continually reside on the reserve and cultivate the soil. The Chief carried off the first prize for district exhibits at the Agricultural Exhibition held in this City the first of the month. In view of the foregoing facts, I would respectfully recommend to the Department that school supplies be furnished, and a teacher engaged in the usual way.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

The Indians on this reserve make their living solely by agricultural pursuits, hence, their children do not leave the reserve at fishing and hop-picking seasons, and will have a splendid opportunity to advance in their studies.

The day on which I visited this reserve, I was very agreeably surprised, on my arrival about 9 a.m., to find the children all lined up ready for school, in which there was a fire, making the place look warm and comfortable. In conclusion I may add that the Rev. Wm. Chaput is of course a highly educated man, and taking a great interest in the advancement of the Indians, and I believe that his daily presence at the school on the reserve will have a very beneficial effect on both the children and parents.

Your obedient servant

For the information of the Department,

I beg to report that I visited the school recently opened on the Tsawassen Indian reserve, by the Rev. Wm. Chaput as teacher, and found nineteen children present classified as follows:

One in the third standard, two in the second standard, three in the first standard, and the remaining twelve are just beginners.

The children in the advanced grades formerly attended the public school in the vicinity, but lately sufficient white pupils have been secured to make up the requisite number and of course the Indian children are in attendance no longer. I may add that this school is now closed and a new one opened a much greater distance from the Reserve.

The building in which the Indian school is being carried on was erected some three years ago for a church, but not finished, lately the Indians have put in the windows and doors, also ceiled and partitioned off a room 20 X 25 ft., which is quite large enough for the number of pupils attending. The furniture consists of four or five seats, each long enough to accommodate five or six children, a table about 14 feet long, with seats, at which the children do their writing, also a small table and chair for the teacher. Besides these articles I may say that the teacher has furnished some books, slates, pencils, chalk and blackboards at his own expense. The Indians are now arranging to have proper desks put in the school.

MEMORANDUM:

The Deputy Minister.

Enclosed is the letter from Most Reverend W. M. Duke, Archbishop of Vancouver, forwarded to me under cover of Mr. Pratt's memorandum of June 28th.

Both the Pemberton Meadows and the Tsawwassen Reserves are in the New Westminster Agency. Indian Agent Daunt suggested the establishment of a day school on the Pemberton Meadows Reserve in the year 1934, but, in order to start a school, a building would be required and, as no funds were provided for the purpose, no action was taken at that time. There are, approximately, 320 Indians in this Band and there are 78 children of school age, of whom 34 are attending the St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School. This leaves 44 on the reserve without educational facilities.

A day school was conducted on the Tsawwassen Reserve from 1913 to 1915, but was closed in the latter year owing to the small attendance. This Band has a membership of only 47 and the last census shows only eight or nine children of school age.

Inspector Barry is on holidays at the present time but he will return to duty about August 1st. A letter is being directed to Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, requesting him to have Mr. Barry visit these reserves early in August and make a survey and report to the Department regarding the feasibility of establishing day schools.

Acting Director.
Tsawwassen Indian Reserve Survey

General Remarks:

It is my opinion that as the Indian children are doing very well in their respective Provincial Day Schools any change at the present time would cause considerable opposition among the Indian parents.

The cost of operation of an Indian Day School on the Tsawwassen Indian Reserve would be considerable. In addition to the capital outlay for a suitable building, which would be between two and three thousand dollars at least, the salary of a teacher and her transportation would come to some twelve hundred dollars yearly.

The few available children are receiving an excellent education at not more than twenty dollars per year each. We are very fortunate here that the children are permitted to attend the Provincial Day Schools and any change would not be for the advantage of the pupils.

Recommendation:

I have gone into the whole of the matters reported above with some care, and would recommend that no Indian Day School be established on the Tsawwassen Indian Reserve till conditions have very greatly changed in this locality.

Further I would strongly recommend that the present system of sending the children as far as possible to the local Provincial Schools be continued, and if possible extended, till such time as the Provincial Educational Authorities object. I do not believe that any objection will be made at present as the Tsawwassen children are of a very good type and the custom of their attending Provincial Schools has been in force for a number of years.

I have seen some correspondence in the Indian Agent's office at New Westminster, and from this am under the impression that Mr. Indian Agent Daunt, who was not present during my visit to the Tsawwassen Reserve, has reached much the same conclusion as that expressed above.

On C.P. Princess Marguerite. Gerald H. Barry,
August 20, 1937. Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
SCHOOL SURVEY REPORT TSAAWWASSEN INDIAN RESERVE

Roman Catholic Church New Westminster Agency.

Date of Survey: The Tsawwassen Indian Reserve was visited on August 16th in company with Miss Dynes of the New Westminster Agency, who was kind enough to drive me to the above Reserve from the Indian Agent's Office in New Westminster and later to accompany me around the Reserve, where she introduced me to the Indians who were there at the time.

Purpose of Survey: The survey of this Indian Reserve was carried out on instructions from Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, and in accordance with the provisions of Departmental letter 153-28-1 of June 29th 1937. The special question to be reported on was the necessity or otherwise of further educational facilities for the Indian children living on the Tsawwassen Indian Reserve, and particularly the matter of the establishment of an Indian Day School on this Reserve.

Method followed: With the help of Miss Dynes a complete list of children of school age and under was made from the official records. This list which is given on the next page shows all children living on or belonging to the Tsawwassen Band. As those children living on the Reserve, but far under school age, are shown, this survey report may be considered to cover the question of the need for an Indian Day School for a number of years to come.

On my visit to the Reserve I spoke to a number of the children who were there at the time. It is true that a number were away fishing or on other seasonal work, but I am satisfied that the children seen were a fair sample of the whole group.

Appearance and Attitude of Children:

In general the children appeared very clean and neatly dressed compared with the usual Indian of the Coast. They were bright and answered questions quickly and with care. I may say that I was very well pleased with the response received to questions.

Some of the children, two at least in one group of six, appear to have highly developed mental powers for their age. They would no doubt be classed as students with high IQs. One said that she was leading her Grade Five Class and being promoted to Grade 6 in September, while the other was among the first few in her Grade. All the children seen appear to be well up in their respective Grades.

The children for the most part attend the Provincial Rural Schools. Those in Grades 1 to 6 inclusive attend the one room ungraded day schools of the Ladner Municipality, and upon promotion to Grade 7 transfer to the Ladner School which is organized to take the Junior High School Grades as well as the lower Grades. The children have attended the Provincial Schools for a number of years, and the Indian Affairs Branch pays for them at the usual rate of two dollars per month. They appear to be doing as well if not better than the "white" children, and are receiving a better education than they would get in an ungraded Indian Day School.

Tsawassen Indian Reserve Survey:

Statistical Analysis of Children:

There are in all 22 children of school age and under registered on this Tsawassen Reserve.

Of the above 22 children, whose names and ages are given on Page 2 of this report, three spend little time on the Tsawassen Reserve.

Of the 19 children who do live here for the greater part of the year some 13 are of school age and between six years of age and fifteen years, the remaining six children being under six and not available for an Indian Day School should it be decided to establish one here.

Of the 13 children of school age shown on Page 2 of this report some 8 attend the Provincial Rural Schools either at Ladner or in the Ladner Municipality, and 5 attend the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

At the moment it would appear that only three children of school age,
Marvin Joe Age 7
Robert Williams Age 9
Marjorie Williams Age 7
are not attending a school of some kind.

I understand that the Williams children may go to the Sechelt Indian Residential School when there is room for them, and the other child, Marvin Joe, will attend the Provincial Public school with his brothers next year.

Religious Teaching:

The children are members of the Roman Catholic Church. Those attending the Provincial Rural Schools do not receive religious teaching at such schools, and it is perhaps for this reason that the establishment of an Indian Day School on the Tsawassen Indian Reserve has been suggested.

A Sunday School in connection with the local Roman Catholic Church would appear to me to be all that is required here.

Buildings available:

I was not able to discover any building on the Tsawassen Reserve that could possibly be turned into an Indian Day School. The village extends over a large area along the coast some three to five miles south of Ladner. The Indians have quite extensive farms which they work with "white" men on share basis. In addition to the Ladner School the children attend at least two other Provincial Schools depending on their home location. The average distance the children walk to these small schools is about two miles each way. Those attending at Ladner cycle the four or five miles to school and home again in the evening.

If a school were erected on the Reserve the teacher would have to live in Ladner, and provision would have to be made for her transportation daily to the Reserve. A school with teacher's residence would not be suitable as the village is rather out of the way and no teacher should be forced to live at such a distance from other "white" people.

Date of Survey: The Tsawwassen Indian Reserve was visited on August 16th in company with Miss Dynes of the New Westminster Agency, who was kind enough to drive me to the above Reserve from the Indian Agent's Office in New Westminster and later to accompany me around the Reserve, where she introduced me to the Indians who were there at the time.

Purpose of Survey: The survey of this Indian Reserve was carried out on instructions from Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, and in accordance with the provisions of Departmental letter 153-28-1 of June 29th 1937.

The special question to be reported on was the necessity or otherwise of further educational facilities for the Indian children living on the Tsawwassen Indian Reserve, and particularly the matter of the establishment of an Indian Day School on this Reserve.

Method followed: With the help of Miss Dynes a complete list of children of school age and under was made from the official records. This list which is given on the next page shows all children living on or belonging to the Tsawwassen Band.

As those children living on the Reserve, but far under school age, are shown, this survey report may be considered to cover the question of the need for an Indian Day School for a number of years to come.

On my visit to the Reserve I spoke to a number of the children who were there at the time. It is true that a number were away fishing or on other seasonal work, but I am satisfied that the children seen were a fair sample of the whole group.

Appearance and Attitude of Children:

In general the children appeared very clean and neatly dressed compared with the usual Indian of the Coast. They were bright and answered questions quickly and with care. I may say that I was very well pleased with the response received to questions.

Some of the children, two at least in one group of six, appear to have highly developed mental powers for their age. They would no doubt be classed as students with high I.Q.'s. One said that she was leading her Grade Five Class and being promoted to Grade 6 in September, while the other was among the first few in her Grade. All the children seen appear to be well up in their respective Grades.

The children for the most part attend the Provincial Rural Schools. Those in Grades 1 to 6 inclusive attend the one room ungraded day schools of the Ladner Municipality, and upon promotion to Grade 7 transfer to the Ladner School which is organized to take the Junior High School Grades as well as the lower Grades. The children have attended the Provincial Schools for a number of years, and the Indian Affairs Branch pays for them at the usual rate of two dollars per month. They appear to be doing as well if not better than the "white" children, and are receiving a better education than they would get in an ungraded Indian Day School.

Dear Major MacKay:

In accordance with your instructions and with reference to Departmental letter 153-28-1 from the Indian Affairs Branch Ottawa dated June 29th 1937, I have made an educational survey of the Tsawwassen Indian Reserve, New Westminster Agency.

Though Mr. Indian Agent Daunt was away on vacation, his stenographer, Miss Dynes did everything possible to help me.

It is a pleasure to visit an Indian reserve where the children are making such good use of the educational facilities available. From an educational point of view it would be a very great mistake to make any change in the present arrangements for the children on the Tsawwassen Reserve.

The erection of an Indian Day School on the Tsawwassen Indian Reserve could not possibly be justified. There are not sufficient Indian children available of school age and very few of under school age. It is difficult for me to understand why even the possibility of an Indian Day School here should have been considered by the Catholic Church authorities, unless it may have been to make it possible for the children to receive daily religious instruction.

There are many places in British Columbia where Indian Day Schools are required as soon as there are funds for such a purpose, but the Tsawwassen Indian Reserve is not one of such places.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

In the case of Bonaparte reserve, this is another point at which I would recommend the establishment of a day school. Some of the children were drafted to the Industrial school at Kamloops, but, as you will have noted, the desire of Bazile the chief is to have a day school on the Reserve.

May 4th, 1908.

Sir:

I have the honor to report that, having received letters and a petition from the chiefs and Indians of the "Gouteau" or Thompson River Tribes requesting that I should meet them at Spence's Bridge on April 17th, in council, to consider the matter concerning the education of their children; after consulting with Mr. Superintendent Vowell, I arranged to Meet Mr. Indian Agent Irwin at that point.

And on the 17th ultimo we met some seventy-five Indians at 1 P.M. in council which continued till 6 P.M. Six chiefs were present and made very reasonable speeches, the point of all being that they wished their children to be taught like the children of the white people, instead of growing up in ignorance.

We found there were twenty-eight children of school age belonging to the Indians present, but only seven of these of Cook's Ferry Band live at Spence's Bridge. Seven live at "Pamyncoos" nine miles from Spence's Bridge; five live near Ashcroft twenty-five miles away; and nine live at "Potato Gardens" sixteen miles distant. Hence I explained to them the difficulty of a Day School as the children were so widely scattered. They then proposed that they would bring all of the children to Spence's Bridge and the Chiefs there would take charge of and look after them in the Indians' Houses, so that they could attend a Day School, but that proposition would not work out satisfactorily.

The seven children at Spence's Bridge live within a quarter of a mile of a Provincial School for white children, where some eighteen are in attendance.
It appears to me that if some satisfactory arrangement could be made by the Department with this School, by which these seven Indian children would be permitted to attend the White Bay School it would meet the case, and satisfy the Indians who live at Cook's Ferry. The Chief claimed ten children of School age at this place, but as three are half-breeds and the Indian Mother is married to a white man I did not count those.

Regarding the other places; "Potato Gardens" has nine children whom they wish to attend School, but this is too small a number to insure the success of a Day School on their Reserve.

They all spoke well of the Lytton Day School and desired a similar one in each village.

I advised those, who with their children, live where it is impossible to have Day Schools at present, to send the children to one of the existing Boarding or Industrial Schools.

I have the honor to remain

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

We received your communication some time ago and have since explained same to our people, and to some of the chiefs of other bands. We are very glad to hear a doctor will be given to us very soon, and the many sick among us will at last be able to receive proper medical treatment. We have required the aid of a doctor for a long time. We are also glad to hear the school question is receiving your earnest attention. We are anxious to have our children schooled and the great majority of us favor day schools. There is difficulty in some places owing to an insufficiency in the number of children. For instance on the Thompson River between Ashcroft and Spencer Bridge there is not sufficient children at any one point for a school, but we think a day school might be started at Spencer Bridge and the people from up the river would send their children by making arrangements with friends at Spencer Bridge to board them. It is not our fault there are so few children in most places, all along many children have been born amongst us, but they mostly die in infancy or early childhood. Some women have had nine and ten children and none remain alive. This calamity has largely been brought on us by the whites, and right along we have had no proper medical attendance nor any instruction regarding these matters. The Indian agent has been here with a proposition that as there are so few children for the people should send their children to the white school, but we do not favor this. An odd one of us has been able to secure
Some education in this way before, but as a rule this system does not work. It was once tried here at Spence Bridge years ago through the efforts of Mr Murray and possibly also the late Indian agent. Neither the whites nor the Indians care to have their children mixed up when still young and foolish. Each claims it is injurious to the other. As a rule white girls do not care to associate with Indian girls, and white boys are too rough and often nasty in their treatment of both Indian boys and girls. When Indian parents see their children are not treated well at school by the whites, they take their children away. Also on the other hand white parents take their children from school when they see Indian children attending the same school. They do not wish their children to associate with Indians. Knowing these things we have no desire to send our children to the white school at Spence Bridge. Thanking you for your interest and help in our affair, we beg to remain

Yours very Truly,

John Whiteman (Chief)

Ottawa, June 13, 1919.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a complaint regarding the lack of educational facilities for the Indian children on the Upper and Lower Nicola group of reserves. It would appear that there is some foundation for this complaint. The last census returns show that there are 467 Anglican and 26 Roman Catholic Indians with about 60 or 65 children of school age on the Lower Nicola Reserves and on the Upper Nicola there are 180 Indians all of whom are Roman Catholic with about 35 children of school age.

To meet the educational needs of these children there is only a day school under the auspices of the Anglican Church in the Lower Nicola group at Sholus and there are several children in both the Lytton and Kamloops Industrial Schools. These two residential schools are the only schools of this class to which children from these reserves could be sent. The majority of the children are receiving no education.

The last returns received show that the Kamloops Industrial School has an enrolment of 61 children and the per capita grant only provides for 60. The Lytton school has a grant for 100 pupils with an enrolment of 90. The Sholus day school had an enrolment during the past year of from 10 to 16 children.

The Department would like you to look into this question of providing educational facilities for the Indian children on the Upper and Lower Nicola Reserves and forward a full report giving your views as to the best means of providing these facilities. It would, no doubt, be found impossible to build day schools, suitably located,

A. Macrae, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Vernon, B.C.
to provide for the attendance of all these children within a reasonable distance of their homes. It might be possible to arrange for the Indian children living near white schools to attend such schools. You will be good enough to state whether arrangements could be made to have this done. The Department has no information regarding the number of children of school age on each of the various reserves in the Upper and Lower Nicola groups. This information should be given if possible.

Mr. Bent Smith, of the Kemloons' band, is also being written to regarding this matter and you might after consultation with him, be able to recommend to the Department a feasible scheme whereby reasonable provision could be made for the education of the Indian children on these reserves.

It is hoped that you will be able to look into this question at an early date and forward to the Department a report containing your views and suggestions regarding this matter.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) A. F. MacKenzie.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.
Office of Inspector of Indian Agencies

Sir,

I beg to report that in obedience to instructions contained in the Department's letter of June 13th, concerning complaint in reference to lack of educational facilities for Indian children in the Upper and Lower Nicola:

I went into the Nicola on July 2nd, accompanied by Mr. J. F. Smith, Indian Agent, and Dominion Constable Dallin.

To determine whether the complaint was well-founded it was obvious that the first thing to be got at was to ascertain accurately the number of Indian children of school age in the Upper and Lower Nicola.

The Indian Agent told me that he had always found it very difficult to obtain this information owing to the reticence of the Indians and the air of suspicion with which they often regarded any inquiries of that kind. For that reason he was not satisfied that previous enumerations could be depended upon. I therefore decided to go to representative Indians as well as to others who might be in a position to give accurate information and had the Indian Agent accompany me. Many of the Indians were away from home and had their children with them; but in every case where I could I went to the Chief and had him get his head men to assist him in taking the

Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Ottawa.
families one by one and giving an enumeration of the children with the ages as accurately stated as could reasonably be expected under the circumstances, and the result showed how little ground there was for the complaint after all.

LOWER NICOLA.

Petit Creek, was the first visited and the first enumeration was obtained from Mrs. Fraser, wife of the local store-keeper. The Indians all trade at the store and she knows each Indian family and could judge fairly well as to their ages. Her estimate of the number of Indian children between 6 and 16 was five. There is a white school at Canford, a mile distant, and no reason to believe that either the trustees or the parents in the school section would offer any objection to attendance of any of the Indian children of this band.

A meeting of the Indians of the band was arranged for next day, when the Chief and principal Indians of the band were present and again the various families were counted over and the number of Indian children of school age counted and they could only make it six, which shows how accurate the first estimate made by Mrs. Fraser really was, for one of the children counted by the Indians was a visitor from another band, and was counted because there was reason to believe that this child is likely to remain at Petit Creek.

To obvious and only reasonable solution in this instance would be for the Indian children of this band to attend the white school at Canford.

At Potato Illahie the Chief, Billy Nakalst and his captain, John Henry, with the assistance of the Chief's wife made the enumeration and all the Indian children of school age left in the band totalled 4. A year ago there were possibly more than twice than number, but this band
suffered heavily from the "Flu" and many of the victims were children. The nearest white school is at Spencer's Bridge 15 miles north or at Canford about the same distance south. With so few children it would be unreasonable to expect that a school should be established and a teacher maintained. The only course therefore in this instance would be to send the children from this band to the Industrial school at Lytton, for these Indians are Anglican.

At Shulus there is a day school established in connection with the Anglican Mission and the Indian Department pays the teacher, furnishes school supplies etc. There is on the roll 12 pupils of school age with an average attendance for the last term of 5 and there are only 5 other children of school age in the band who are not on the roll. The trouble here is the lack of interest in the school on the part of Indian parents and also the inherent selfishness of these same parents in putting their own convenience first and making the education of their children a secondary consideration. The teacher showed me a memorandum he had kept of the reasons why children had been kept out of school and they were most trivial in the majority of instances. Rigorous enforcement of compulsory education would seem to be the only solution here.

UPPER NICOLA.

Coldwater possibly should not be classed with Upper Nicola insomuch as the Coldwater River upon which the Reserve is situated comes in from the south and empties into the Nicola River at a point which might rather be considered as a part of Lower Nicola; but the Coldwater Indians have more in common with the Upper Nicola Indians of Douglas Lake and Quilchena. At the Coldwater reserve we had the assistance of Chief George Sandy and his principal Councillor, Nicola Captain. These men went
carefully over the members of the Coldwater Band family by family, and gave as a result of their count, a total of ten children of school age. The nearest white school is at Olean, 6 miles distant. These Indians are Roman Catholic, but none of their children are attending the Industrial School at Kamloops. There was one attended last year but took sick and had to be brought home. The Chief was of opinion that a day school would be of benefit to them and the Indians would like to have it. There is no building available on the reserve at present and as the nearest white settler is about three miles distant, which would make it difficult for a white teacher to obtain boarding accommodation, the better plan would be to make provision for living quarters for the teacher in a portion of the school building as had been done so successfully at Boothroyd in the Lytton Agency. The reserve is in a lumber region with mills and logging operations in comparatively close proximity and the Merritt branch of the Kettle Valley Railway passing through the reserve, so that it would be easy to obtain lumber; and if the Indians will give their labor a suitable building for school with teacher's living quarters might be secured for about $400.00 or $500.00. With ten children of school age for whom educational facilities could thus be obtained such expenditure would be justified and I am of the opinion that the Indians of this band would show their appreciation by taking an interest in the school.

At Douglas Lake the Chief was away and the census figures in the agent's office had to be relied upon. These showed the number of children of school age to be 32, with 14 at Quilchena. There are four Douglas Lake children attending the Industrial school at Kamloops. Deducting these it is seen that there are at Quilchena and Douglas Lake 42 children who are receiving no education but these two reserves are 11 miles apart and two schools
would be necessary to accommodate them. There is no white school in the vicinity, but no difficulty would be experienced in obtaining boarding accommodation for a teacher, if a white teacher were employed.

The two greatest drawbacks to Indian day schools are irregularity in attendance and the difficulty experienced where the teacher has no knowledge of the Indian language of that particular tribe. The remedy for the former would be to create a greater interest in education on the part of Indian parents, and for the latter would be to have the Industrial School train some of the larger Indian girls as teachers. This latter should be taken up with the principals of these Industrial Schools, but as very few of them are in favor of Indian day schools at all, they may not be disposed to grant very cordial support to that idea.

To summarise, there are therefore only three cases in the Nicola Valley where the number of school children who are receiving no education, would warrant the expense of opening up day schools, and these are at Coldwater, Douglas Lake and Quilchena.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) A. Mcgraw.

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,

Ottawa.
Ottawa, August 22nd, 1919.

Memorandum:

UPPER NICOLA,

1. Coldwater Reserve, - 10 children. These are K.O. Indians. If Indians would give their labor, a suitable building with teacher's living quarters attached might be built for $400 - $500.

2. Quilchena, - 14 children of school age.

3. Douglas Lake, - 32 children of school age, of whom 4 are attending Kamloops Industrial.

These latter two reserves are 11 miles apart and 2 schools would be necessary but no difficulty would be experienced in obtaining accommodation for teachers.

In closing his report Inspector Megraw says:
"There are only three cases in the Nicola Valley where the number of school children would warrant the expense of opening day schools, namely, Coldwater, Douglas Lake and Quilchena."

(Sgd.) P. Phelan.

Ottawa, February 7th, 1910.

Sir,

The establishment of a school for the children of the Lower Kootney reserve, near Creston, has been recommended by the Rev. Mr. McDougal and the Department is disposed to favourably consider the request of these Indians.

There are at present under course of preparation plans and specifications for a school-house to accommodate 25 to 30 pupils, which it is thought would be suitable for this reserve.

The Department would like to know whether a suitable site is available; what material would be used in construction; the best method of providing for heating; approximate cost of materials and labour; and to have any information that will enable it to come to a decision as to the most suitable kind of school-house to meet the needs of these Indians.

You will be good enough to report fully, giving also your opinion as to the most satisfactory way of having the work done, whether by contract or by day labour.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Secretary.

R. L. T. Galbraith, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir,

Have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 35193, dated Feb. 7th, 1910, in connection with the establishment of a School on the East Kootenay Reserve, as to a site, cost of material and heating.

In reply I may say, that there are several sites available but it would not be well to decide until the Chiefs are consulted as it is necessary to have their influence and support, it should however be as near the village as the surroundings will permit.

Submit herewith the list of material which is likely to be used in construction, which I obtained from Messrs. Maclellan of Cranbrook, who usually supply the Department.

I would suggest a frame building upon a foundation of cement as it is the cheapest, sand and gravel can be got about a mile from the village, the walls should be stained (stucco), slated and plastered.

The basement could be used as a toilet, heating and dressing room, as I believe that it will be necessary to give (at least for a time) some good meat a day, as the Indians on the Reserve are moving towards hunting and fishing.

The best way to heat is by a furnace in the basement, which will make the building clean and comfortable.

In selecting a site care must be taken that there is near (within from a spring or well) a good supply of pure water.

I would strongly advocate that the building be erected by contract, as they labor is sometimes
not satisfactory. The contract should be made short
up to the terms of the Agreement.

I ought also suggest that when the School
is opened for the reception of pupils, that it be placed
under the care of the Sisters of Charity, who have
done such successful work at the Pointe-aux-
Saumons School for the last thirty years.

This would make a residence for the Sisters
near the School, or in the Village, where their influence
amongst the Indians would do great
good.

Should the Department wish further advice
wanted, I will be pleased to give it,

Your obedient servant,

R. L. Macdonald,
Inspector.

In reply, I may inform you, that I found upon inquiry, that the Sisters Superior of the Kootenay Indian School had gone to Portland, Oregon, toward the North Provincial and would not return until about the 24th, so I was not able to ascertain whether the Sisters of Charity wrote undertaking the Educational Work at the new School, and the accommodation they would require.

Referring to your letter of the 24th instant No. 36733, re
new school building at Briston, I beg to say, that I had a
long interview with the Sister Superior on her return from
Portland, Oregon, and learned from her, that she had talked
the matter of taking charge of the School, with the Mother
Provincial, who promised to refer it to the Superior General
of the Order in Montreal.

I also gathered from the Sister, that the Order always
had a Hotel who acted as Captain at certain places where they
undertook Mission, Hospital or Teaching Work, and as
there was none at Briston at present, this might be an
objection to their taking over the School; she also pointed
out, that it would be necessary to have the approval of the
new Bishop (Dr. St. John) who is expected from the East
shortly.

During the course of conversation, I learned, that the
Society was much disappointed, that no decision had been
arrived at by the Department about a new building for
the Root Lake Industrial School, and that owing to the dis-
sipated condition of two of the buildings, it made even be
impossible to go on with the work, and if they had no assurance
that something would be done in the very near future,
they might withdraw their staff elsewhere, and take up
Hospital Work, as there were requests for institutions
of that character throughout the North. I should deeply
regret if they decide to do so, as the work done at the
Industrial School has helped greatly to change the habits
for the better, and has aided in making them law-abiding
and self-supporting.
I wrote suggest, that newspapers in which the advertisement for tenders for School should be inserted are the Granbrook Herald and the Victoria Times.

Cape Mudge Boarding School.
Sir:

The Indians of the Cape Mudge Band have spoken to me several times about having a Boarding School established here as in the best interests of their children's education. In speaking of the matter to Mr. Halliday, the Indian Agent for this District, he asked me to write you for particulars as to the steps necessary to bring such an institution about, and added that I might say to you that he recommended its Establishment.

I shall be indebted if you will let me have a copy of the Act Respecting Indian Education, and if you will advise me as to what steps should be taken to further the founding of the school. I believe the Indians will assist financially and with a grant of land, subject to your approval. The Church will also help in the undertaking.

Awaiting your esteemed reply, and thanking you in anticipation, I am,

Yours Sincerely,

[Signature]

Missionary of the Methodist Church.

Rev. A. Barner,
Wesley Buildings,
Toronto, Ont.

Dear Bro. Barner:

As directed by the Conference Standing Missionary Committee I beg to bring the following particulars regarding our Cape Mudge work before you, for presentation to the General Board, as it would seem that the time is ripe for a declaration of policy, and the undertaking of what may seem in the best interests of the people.

As I was given to understand, the recommendation of the Committee appointed to investigate the Cape Mudge situation, was that a sum of money be spent for plant, consisting of boarding school, church and mission house, of which the Indians were to provide one-third. Several times they have approached me on the matter and I have not been able to give them a decided answer as to what the Church was going to do. As you can understand, this is unsatisfactory both for them and myself. Just after the rise of District Meeting, I received a letter from Miss Wright, saying that Chief Assu had been to see her and had asked her to write and say that his people would give $10,000 from their capital account for the building of a boarding school, their previous offer was ten acres of land (which I expect holds good still) and one-third the cost financially; the Church and the government to share equally the remaining two-thirds. Just what hope there may be of the government's taking its share, you and Dr. Ferrier may know best, but the number of new schools built for the Roman Catholic Church would seem to show that the Church which pushes her case at Ottawa, dictates the action of the government.
As I see it, the situation is this. We have 90 people at Cape Mudge and over 60 at Campbell River, which with a few at the Salmon River and Philips Arm Indians brings the total number to 175. We have 14 pupils on the day school roll and about as many more ready to attend in a year's time, with the same number still younger, or about 60 in all, over and above those attending at Alert Bay and Coqualeetza. Then there are Indians to the south of us on Vancouver Island who would be available and our own Bella Bella, Bella Coola and Rivers Inlet, Indians, and others to the north, so that with the Anglican School at Alert Bay full, and our own Coqualeetza Institute over-crowded, it would seem that there is a field for us, without in the least encroaching on the territory of any school established or proposed. Then the $10,000.00 from our own people is a telling argument. Our Indian Agent recommends it and Mr. Cairns informs me that if we had a boarding school established we would have every chance of getting the government per capita grant for maintenance. I believe the Presbyterian Church has such a school operating at Ahousat with great success. They have also a government paid nurse whom they furnish with room and board. She takes care of the children at the school and acts as a District Nurse. It would be our aim to secure such a person at Cape Mudge, and the benefit to the district would be incalculable.

Further, our Indians at Campbell River are too few in number to expect a day school started among them, and what are their children to do? The best of them try to gain access to the public school at Campbell River, but were refused. They cannot attend our Cape Mudge day school either. We tried that last fall by having their children stay with our Indians during the week, but it was a failure. I do not see why, if our Cape Mudge Indians put up the
Money for the building, the government should object to pay the per capita grant, and the Church to furnish the staff at least.

Again, our Cape Mudge Indians are beginning to scatter and locate on various parts of the Reserve, so that for them a day school may not be so satisfactory in the near future as it is now. However, we have a splendid development in the matter of better homes among some of the younger people, and I cannot say just to what extent the tendency to scatter may go.

Now as to a Church. We have never had during all the years of missionary work at Cape Mudge, a building set apart for the worship of God, and it does seem that a Church dedicated to that end would be a most necessary and effective step in the spiritual development of our people. I would suggest a building of say 30 x 40 ft. with a full sized basement which could be used for community purposes, recreation and night school activities among them. It would be magnificent if the Church should supercede the Potlatch House as the clearing station for the life of the people. I trust that some pronouncement may be made as to the policy of the Board toward Indian Missions in general, and to our own Cape Mudge people in particular. You can understand how unsatisfactory the situation is. Our teacher wants a home of her own but we cannot press the government to that end if we are looking toward a boarding school. Then again, we must meet the offer of the Indians fairly, and really unless we can induce the Campbell River people to unite at Cape Mudge, a boarding school with accommodation for say 40 pupils would be the better. If the two bands can be united and a permanent village established, aside from the migratory habits of the Indians a day school might carry on. I am most hopeful of our Cape Mudge people; they are regular and faithful in their attendance at the services and the younger people are trying to break away from
the bondage, financial and spiritual, of the Potlatch system. Two of
the younger men have built splendid homes this last year, one or them
better than the Mission House, as it is now, and another house is in
the process of erection. They mean business and I am anxious that the
Church which has done so much for them already, and to which they now
look for help, should not disappoint them, as they take the first
steps toward the new and larger life. The materialistic socialist of
the logging camps is demanding a place for his doctrines as our boys
join the lumber workers union of the O.B.U. in order to obtain em-
ployment. I am trying by word and deed to show them the better way
but so long as the loggers can point to better wages through their
joining the union, and I can point to no corresponding gain through
the avenues of the Church in their midst, the mind of the average
Indian will not be convinced, either of the worth of our ideals or
the unselfishness of our example. We certainly need a Church that
will stand for Jesus Christ in all their life - individual and social,
and I think we should have a boarding school; it will meet our local
need better than any other type of school and there is room for service
to Indians farther away who are not attending a school of any kind, so
I am informed.

I am praying for guidance for all concerned and trust that
your decision may point the leading of God's hand in the matter.

With kind regards, and best wishes for a profitable session
of the General Board, I am,

Yours sincerely,

P.S. 

The above will explain itself. I send it to
you for information, and trust you will be
guided in connection with your fellow officials
in the way, but for myself yours—P.B.
October 13th, 1920.

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Dear Mr. Scott:-

I enclose a copy of a letter that is written by Mr. Scott our missionary at Cape Mudge, B.C. It deals with the need of a boarding school at that point and an offer of $10,000 from the funds standing to the credit of the Indians at that place. I would like very much if a deliverance of the Department could be given on this communication as it involves a very important element in the policy which we pursue in regard to the erection of schools. In other words, if we have from a Methodist point of view a large Industrial School at Coqualeetza and another at Port Simpson which is already before the Department in the form of a petition signed by the Indians at Port Simpson, the question then is as to the wisdom of building smaller schools at other points where those that are interested locally desire it.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

Sir,

I have the honor to report that two deputations of Indians from the Nakwakh Tribe, Kwawkweith Agency, have waited on me, asking that a Day School be established on the reserve in their village at Blunden Harbour. They have twenty children of school age, and others that will soon be old enough.

This band has long been noted for being wild, and the majority of them great thieves, and have not had the advantage of any missionary or teacher, but the Methodist Mission boat "Homespun" has visited them three or four times during the past two years. Captain Oliver of the boat called to see me a few days ago, and confirms the Indian's report that a school is greatly needed.

None of these Indians have any education, but are very anxious that their children should be taught. They state that they live ten months of the year at Blunden Harbour, only going to Rivers Inlet for the months of June and July. Chief Charles says his people wish to abandon their old wild ways and become civilized, and in order that their children may be taught they ask for a day school, and declare that they will see that the children attend.

Blunden Harbour is about twenty-five or thirty miles north of Alert Bay, and being isolated this tribe only mingle with other Indians when at the Rivers Inlet Fisheries, a couple of months each year.

I consider this is a strong plea for a school, and many are surprised that these wild Indians should ask for one. I would recommend that a school be granted opened, and that an Indian house in the village be secured for a time for school purposes. I think a suitable male teacher could be secured for six hundred
dollars a year.

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of 21st Nov., File 398665 with reference to the establishment of a day school at Blunden Harbor for the Nakwakto Indians.

In reply I beg to state that while at all times I do what I can to encourage the Indians to send their children to school, in so far as this agency is concerned, the day schools have been almost a failure. There are several reasons for this. One reason is the apathy of the Indians towards the education of their children. When a school is first established there has always been a good attendance of children but as soon as the novelty wears off it is almost impossible to get an attendance.

The second reason is the fact of the nomadic habits of the Indians, who do not live any length of time at one place. This is particularly true of the Nakwakto Band. Their chief village is at Blunden Harbor where they spend probably 4 months of the year altogether. They all move to this reserve when they get their winter fish cured which is generally about the first week in December. In March they scatter, some going to the Storm Islands, some to Deserter's Islands and some to Seymour Inlet. They gather again for a week or two in the beginning of June and then go off to the salmon fishing at Rivers Inlet getting home about August 10 to 15.

J.D. Mclean Esq.
Secretary Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
This year there was a new cannery built at Seymour Inlet and the fishing does not begin there until about the end of August and lasts until the end of October. Then the Indians scatter again to different places, curing and smoking salmon for their own use.

A third reason for the failure of day schools is the fact that the pay is so small that teachers of any ability can do much better teaching in the public schools where the minimum salary is about $60.00 per month. It is difficult enough to obtain the services of a good teacher even at that salary, and it requires a particularly good teacher to keep Indian children at school.

Native teachers have so far not had force of character enough to keep up the average at the schools.

No one would be more pleased that I, if any system could be devised to bring the children regularly to school, but under the circumstances I have not arrived at any satisfactory conclusion as to the method of procedure.

I have no doubt that a building could be obtained temporarily at Blunden Harbor and the school would be intermittently attended during the four months or thereabouts when the children are in the village. I will be visiting this village, all being well, shortly after the new year and will take the matter up with them in public meeting and will advise the Department after my return. I fear however that the school would end in failure.

My last census returns show 14 children of school age with 20 under that age several of whom however might attend. There are no industries of any kind near them to induce them to remain at home any longer than the winter months, and the nearest settlement is at Hardy Bay about 16 miles across the gulf.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

at Blunden Harbour the whole year around. Mr. Scott,

With reference to the request for the establishment of a day school for the benefit of the Indian children residing on the reserves in the vicinity of Fort Rupert in the Kwakwala Agency, I beg to say that the Fort Rupert group consists of six small reserves, as follows—Tsa-kis, Kippase, Shell Island, Tsulquate, Thomas Point and Kaogh.

From the analysis of evidence taken before the Royal Commission on Indian Affairs for the Province of British Columbia it is stated that there are 118 Indians residing on these reserves. Their chief occupations are fishing, trapping, boat building and working for wages. There was a general complaint made by these Indians of inadequate educational, hospital and medical facilities. In answer to your letter of January 27th regarding a request for the establishment of a Day School for the benefit of the Indian children residing on the reserves in the vicinity of Fort Rupert in this agency, I beg to inform you that yesterday I visited Fort Rupert and went thoroughly into this matter.

I found after careful investigation that there were in all twelve children of school age belonging to the Indians who are resident more or less in the vicinity of Fort Rupert. Of these children the parents of two of them are living at Hardy Bay on Tsulquate Reserve and they are attending the public school at Hardy Bay. Of the ten remaining ones one is almost the full age of eighteen while another one has only just turned five.

With regard to the Indians from Blunden Harbor uniting with those of Fort Rupert to form a joint school I would inform you that Blunden Harbor is about eighteen miles in a direct line from Fort Rupert and that the two points are separated by the lower end of Queen Charlotte Sound which in stormy weather is a very dangerous piece of water and could not be traversed in bad weather so that a union of the two villages to form one school would be absolutely out of the question.

Of the children residing at Fort Rupert I find that there are only resident at Fort Rupert about seven months in each year. There is one white family by the name of Cadwallader living at Fort Rupert who operate a store there and Mrs. Cadwallader is a blood relation of three of the parents of the
Indian Children who are eligible for the school. Mrs. Cadwallader has six children of school age and two under school age, and while I could not recommend that an Indian Day School should be established at Fort Rupert I would recommend that the matter be taken up with the Provincial Educational Authorities in the person of the Superintendent of Education at Victoria and see if an arrangement could not be made by which a joint school could be opened and maintained at Fort Rupert. There are no other children either white or Indian within distance to supplement the attendance so that they would be entirely dependent for attendance on the children already mentioned. I think if the matter was taken up with the Provincial Authorities they would be ready to meet us halfway, and an average attendance of at least ten children combined white and Indians could be expected.

There are no school buildings of any kind at Skutz Fort Rupert, but there are two Indian houses which are at present empty which could be rented at a very reasonable figure for a school room, and Mr. Cadwallader informed me that if any such arrangement could be made he would become responsible for the supplying of a building for the school. The only expense in fitting either of these buildings for a schoolroom would be the desks and a stove.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

The Department has received a request for the establishment of a day school for the benefit of the Indian children residing on the reserves in the vicinity of Fort Rupert in the Kwawkweith Agency.

This matter was taken up with Mr. Agent Halliday, who now states that, after careful investigation, he finds that there are twelve children of school age belonging to the Indians who reside more or less in the vicinity of Fort Rupert. He states that these children with their parents are only resident at this point about seven months in the year, and besides there are six or seven white children of school age who could attend, if a school were established.

Mr. Agent Halliday recommends that this matter be taken up with the provincial educational authorities in the person of the Superintendent of Education at Victoria with a view to arranging for a joint school for the Indian and white children.
