The only expense in fitting up either of these buildings for a school-room would be the supplying of the desks required and a stove.

The Department would like you to take this matter up with the Department of Education for the Province of British Columbia and ascertain from them whether they would be prepared to establish a school at Fort Rupert, provided this Department contributed its share of the cost of teacher's salary and maintenance. I am in receipt of your letter of February 24th, dealing with my report regarding the establishment of a school at Fort Rupert.

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter I beg to report that yesterday before receipt of your letter I returned from Blunden Harbor from a visit to the Indians there. I found only a few of them at home amongst them being two children of school age. The difficulty with establishing a school of any kind at Blunden Harbor, is, that the Indians are only there from about the middle of November until sometime in February or March according to weather conditions. During the rest of the year they are scattered and could not attend at any school. I have told them several times that their best plan is to send their children to the Industrial school and Girls Home respectively where they will receive proper care and attention. Another difficulty arises in connection with these schools owing to the fact that the Industrial School is full and a number of applicants have to be refused admission. A number of the pupils in both these schools come from other agencies and I have tried to impress on the principal of the school the fact that these schools were built primarily for the Indians of this agency and that their needs must receive the first consideration with which view he fully concurs. Each year he has held vacancies open to allow children from this
Agency to be placed on the membership roll, but they have not come and not wanting to allow any vacancies in the school he has afterwards allowed other children who were on the spot to be placed in the school. In some instances three months after the school has resumed operations after the holidays some of these who wanted to attend have come along but found there was no room. Under present conditions I could not recommend any Day School at Blunden Harbor, but I will take every opportunity to impress on them the necessity of being in time so that the children can be placed in the Industrial schools.

At the present time there are no industries of any kind at Blunden Harbor to give employment to the Indians at or near home, but, it is quite possible that in a few years time that industries will be established there such as saw mills and shingle mills and when the Indians can get employment they may remain at the village for a greater length of time.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

Thank you for your prompt reply to my telegram for school supplies. They will be forwarded promptly from this office as soon as they arrive.

We started Miss Cadwallader at the school at the beginning of the year. The school will be small to start with as it takes time for the Indians to settle down to it. We got a few home-made desks and other supplies for her from the other Indian Village Schools, so that she was able to start.

I am hoping that one good result from this school will be to encourage the Indian women to stay at home during the fishing season, and look after their children. The custom of the whole population of a village leaving home and camping in hovels near the canneries is, perhaps, one of the greatest detriments to the advancement of the Indian, morally and in every other way. Children are left, whose mothers are working in the cannery, unfed and unattended, with the result that the mortality amongst them in summer, chiefly from mal-nutrition and its effects, is appalling.

If the schools in years, can manage to help the women at home in their villages, they will do a great thing for the Indian. I am more and more confirmed in my conviction that this effort of developing the Indian by Primary Schools in their own villages, combining medical attention, nursing and social work generally, is going to have more effect than any other movement now on foot for the welfare of the Indian.

Thanking you for your very kind interest, I am

Yours sincerely,

Miss Victoria Alexandra Cadwallader. Age 24. $750 per annum.

Qualifications:- No Certificate; states she has one year High School (By correspondence). I am unable to verify this, though I have tried to do so.

Success:- This school is in a most unsatisfactory condition.

On April 20th, when Mr. Indian Agent Halliday and I visited the school, there were no children present. The teacher was behind the counter in the store. We told her that we must have some of the children at school in the afternoon. There were, I understand, only four children then in the village. Of these, three came to school in the afternoon.

The school is so unattractive that I can see no reason why children should want to attend.

The only furniture consisted of four new single desks and five old home made desks of no value. The four single desks seem to be the four missing from Mamallililikulla. I am informed that Mr. Antle of the Columbia Coast Mission moved these desks to Fort Rupert. No permission for their movement was given by the Indian Agent.

The schoolroom is the back room of a store. The store is owned, I understand, by the teacher's brother. The schoolroom is about 14 ft. by 16 ft. with a stairs up to an attic. It is quite unsuitable for school purposes. The room is half-filled with all sorts of store goods, old clothes, mattresses, hardware, etc. Light is from two windows. There is a woodburning stove.

General Remarks:- I do not consider that Miss Cadwallader has any qualification of any sort which would make her retention as a teacher under the Department of Indian Affairs desirable.

She is partly Indian, has no professional training whatever, and her non-professional standing, if we are to take her own statement, of only one year at high school quite inadequate.

There are far too few children in this village to make up a fair average attendance for a day school.

I beg to strongly recommend that, after the end of the present school year, no further grant be made for a teacher's salary at Fort Rupert.

The four new desks in this school should be returned to Mamallilikulla Indian Day School to which they appear to belong.

Dear Mr Ferrier,

I was sorry not to have met you while in Ottawa in May, but I want to say that I appreciate very much the reception I received at the hands of your staff, especially in the matter of the school at Fort Rupert; which had been reported adversely by the inspector. I have not been able to see the inspector yet but have no doubt that he will understand, as your staff did, the answer to his objections. The two points made by him were the unsuitability of the room and the lack of qualification of the teacher.

My answer to the first is that the Cadwallader living room while it lacks much that might be desirable in the way of a school, is a large and airy room with fireplace and good ventilation, and above all being the big house of the village, (Mrs Cadwallader is an Indian Princess the halfbreed, is well educated and highly respected) the children look upon it as a privilege to be able to go to the house. At Kingcome Inlet before the new school was built, an old ramshackle deserted house was used, far inferior to that now used at Fort Rupert. But it was a beginning and resulted as I hope this beginning at Fort Rupert will result.

With regard to the teacher's qualification, Victoria Cadwallader has received a good common school education quite sufficient for the work she has to do, which is entirely primary and chiefly preparation for the big school at Alert Bay. Her great qualification is that she speaks the language, which is a great help in preparing the children for the big school. Before these day schools were established the pupils went up to the big school without knowing a word of English which made it difficult for the teachers to grade them. Now they can be graded as soon as they arrive. In my opinion this qualification is more important for this work than any other qualification. I would hesitate to put a girl graduate of the normal school in a position of this kind. The shortness of the teaching season would make it impossible to get qualified teacher to accept such a position anyway.
Some good has come out of the report. I have visited the village, and have spoken to the chiefs, and they are very much concerned. I am hoping it will mean the building of a small school room and in a special effort being made to keep the women and children away from the canneries. This year's pilgrimage of women and children to the canneries, in my opinion, is an obstruction to Indian progress both educationally and morally, and I am doing what I can to combat it. If one only had the backing of the Indian Agent instead of the opposition, this condition might be soon eliminated.

The Department has in the past paid fuel bills for the school at Kingcome River. This year the Indians helped with wood, but wood is so difficult to get in that district that we were compelled to send them coal. I am enclosing bills in duplicate.

With apologies for so long a letter,

I am,

Yours sincerely,

REPORT ON INVESTIGATION INTO THE NECESSITY FOR AN INDIAN DAY SCHOOL AT FORT RUPERT.

Reason for Investigation:

Since making a survey report on the need for an Indian Day School at Fort Rupert, which report was dated March 15th 1932, I have been requested again and again by Anglican Ministers to reconsider my recommendation that there was no need for an Indian Day School at Fort Rupert.

This matter has again been brought up by a suggestion from the local Anglican Minister at Alert Bay, the Reverend O. Hodgson, made to me verbally, that an Indian Day School was required for the children at Fort Rupert. A small Anglican Church has lately been erected at this point. The Reverend Mr. Hodgson informs me that he is paying out of his own pocket the salary of a local girl, apparently unqualified as a teacher, to teach two or three Indian children at this place.

As I am certain a request will sooner or later be made to the Department of Indian Affairs to either re-establish the Indian Day School at Fort Rupert, or to give a grant towards the salary of a girl or Missionary employed by the Anglican Church, I wish to lay the facts of the case before the Department.

Procedure:

I took the opportunity while in Alert Bay recently to discuss the matter with the Indian Agent, Mr. M.S. Todd. On March 8th last Mr. Todd and I went through the whole roll of the Fort Rupert Band, as given in the 'Band Book'. Each child of school age, or near school age, was separately considered by the Indian Agent and myself. We had the help of two local Indians who were well acquainted with the families in this Fort Rupert Band and with the present location of each Indian and child. I also had a roll of the St. Michael's Indian Residential School showing names of children in that school, with the name of the Band or location from which the child had come.

The Department was not put to any cost whatever by my carrying out this investigation in this way. It also aided the Indian Agent to have my views, and I was glad to hear his on the matter.

I also was able to speak to Mr. F.E. Anfield about some of the children, and to obtain his CONFIDENTIAL views on the establishment of such a school as has been requested by Church authorities in the past.

Recommendations:

I am quite unable to see the need for an Indian Day School at Fort Rupert. It is obvious that the attendance would be very small. I could not possibly recommend that a qualified girl should be appointed to such a school if it were established, as I am not satisfied that she would have a proper place to live or enough protection.

An Anglican might be appointed as a MISSIONARY TEACHER. We would no doubt attempt to carry on a small school in the new Anglican Church. The Anglican Church would like to have the money from the Department no doubt, but I could not possibly recommend the establishment of a small school at Port Rupert. The available children for such a school should in my opinion be provided for at St. Michael's Indian Residential School. Unless an average attendance of ten children could be guaranteed, and it is quite impossible to do this at Port Rupert, I do not believe that an Indian Day School should be started. I should not care to recommend a Day School with a lower average than fifteen, which would mean about twenty local children not otherwise provided for available to start with.

The whole of the above is submitted with respect in the hope that it may be of help to the Department of Indian Affairs should they be requested to open an Indian Day School at Fort Rupert.

Dear Sir,

A strong desire has been expressed by the Council of Wossset, approved by the Indian Agent, for the establishing of a Boarding School at Wossset. Our missionary Rev. Wm. Hogan also favors this.

Since the closing of the Metlakatla Industrial School and the correspondence I had at that time with the Department of Indian Affairs, I have understood that the present policy of the Department was in favor of the Improved Day School and against the establishing of any new Boarding Schools. I have endeavored to loyally support the Department in this matter.

I understand that Skidegate is applying for a Boarding School. The arguments used by the Wossset Council against sending their children away would apply equally to Skidegate which is bordering on both Prince Rupert & Metlakatla.
Boarding School to be established Graham Island it should certainly be at the larger village, Massett rather than at Skidegate.

It is simply loyalty to the Government's policy that prevents my pressing for a Boarding School combined with past experience of the difficulty of financing a Boarding School on a per capita basis unless there is a large attendance of children.

While I feel deeply the force of the arguments used in favour of a Boarding School I am still of the opinion if it were possible to house and feed the children during the period the parents are away fishing the problem would be solved.

To take say 30 children in a village away from their parents and put them in a Boarding School in the same village, free the parents for eight years from all responsibility as to clothing feeding training may have been a wise policy in the days of degraded heathenism but it cannot be a wise policy now when many of the parents are intelligent well-behaved good living people.

If the Government has changed its policy think it is due to me to be informed and that do my utmost to make a Boarding School at Massett a success.

F.H. DuVernet Bishop of Caledonia

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of Dec. 4th ultimo, respecting Boarding and Industrial Schools, and, in reply, would state:

"In the Queen Charlotte Agency, we have no Boarding or Industrial Schools. The nearest institutions of the kind, to which a number of the boys might go, would be Coqualeetza Industrial School, at Chilliwack, The St. George's Industrial School, at Lytton and the Alert Bay School. We have a few, at the Coqualeetza School, which, like the Lytton School, is on the Fraser River, many hundreds of miles from these islands. The Indian parents are averse to sending their children so far from home. During the Winter months, we have communication with the outer world, but twice a month. Telegrams and letters only reach us on a steamer, from the mainland, and, should the children become ill, or die, the parents would know little or nothing about it, for many weeks. We have two Bands, of very intelligent Indians, and the Day Schools are well attended, during the Winter months; but the children are taken to the fishing grounds, and the canneries, during the Summer, and we cannot reach them. Last year, the Teachers followed the Indians to Naden Harbour, and Aliford Bay. We induced the cannery owners, at Naden Harbour, to give us a good schoolhouse; but the attendance fell off, as usual.

If we had a Summer Boarding School, on the Queen Charlotte Islands, at a central point, the children of the Massett and Skidegate Bands would attend it. In the Winter, the Teachers

Frank Pedley, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
could open day schools, on the two reserves, where all of the Indians have their homes, to which they return, after the fishing season.

This would keep the children away from the canneries and they would be learning to take up some other occupation.

The exodus, to the canneries, means now, all of the Indians men, women and children. The cannery towns ruin all alike. The men obtain whiskey; the women are debauched, and the children are put to work and they learn nothing good, when at the age to understand and when they should be in the schoolroom. I do not state, or desire to be understood, as meaning that all of the Indians are immoral; but the life in the cannery towns of the West is doing more to keep back our Indians than anything else. On their reserves, we have them under control. We keep trespassers away from them, and the last year, under police supervision, has shown us that we can handle them as never before. Mixing with Whites and Chinese, in the same camps, the Indian learns and practises things that does not contaminate them, when at home.

We have a problem, in the Indian, that requires a great deal of judgment to solve. I have been among them for over half-a-century, in the cannery towns and on their reserves; also in the cities, from here to the confines of the Province.

It is asserted, and I believe, with good reason, that we have, in this Agency, the most enlightened Indians in the Dominion. The best of them were educated in the Industrial School, and they came home, with ideas and ideals that were perfect. They stood high, among the Indians of their Bands; but it was when they were isolated and before numberless Chinese, Whites, Japanese and others brought with them that which goes to kill off the Indian.

When...
When we preach, and teach, morality and sobriety, the Indian now points to the issuing of liquor licenses and the immorality surrounding them. They speak of their grievances and the restrictions placed on them. They go and come; some live with the Whites, and women bring their half-breed children home, when the White man deserts them. They marry Whites, and, when the husband dies, back they come to the reserve life.

On these isolated islands, the Indians have no opportunity of marrying, only among themselves, and there is a relationship among them that has a deterring effect. The older, uneducated Indians, consider the ways of the past generations, and we often hear them wondering whether the inroads of the Whites brought advantages. In many ways, they try to keep up the old tribal customs, and the height of their ambition is lower than that of any class, although it appeared good enough when the survival of the fittest, among their thousands of inhabitants, was the main consideration.

In this Western country, where there are so many Indians, and where the carrying out of the law is so difficult, there are Whites and Indians who go to the limit of the law, and many go further, when under the effect of intoxicants. Add this to the innate suspicion, inborn in both Whites and Indians, of each other, and the difficulties encountered by the Indian Agents will be understood.

Will education eliminate the disadvantages under which the Indians suffer? I feel sure it will, if the Indian is taken from his environment and is handled by those who are working for the uplifting of the natives; this can only be done, in our case, by erecting Industrial Schools, and keeping the Indian children away from the home of the cannery towns, and neighboring towns and cities.

We
We know that the Indian Day School is not a success, for the reason that Indians are nomadic. There is no Industrial School in this Agency, and I feel that one is required. The Indians of this Agency are not dying off, as in other places, and are more than holding their own. One industrial school will do for both of the large Bands, the Massetts and the Skidegates. The members of the Dominion House, who take an interest in the Indians, know that there is but one hope for the Indian. The member for this District, H.S. Clements, M.P., visited the islands, and was impressed with the necessity for a Boarding School.

With the Day Schools, the best is being accomplished that is possible; but we feel sure that the Boarding School would turn out pupils that would astonish the most skeptical, even as the Indians of this Agency do at the present writing.

In music, business ability, workmanship and sobriety, they have been examples for the other Indians of the Pacific Coast.

When I visit the Massett School, and find over fifty children in attendance, it shows that there are influences at work for their betterment; but the Indians must work, to live, and, when Summer comes, and on finds the schools almost deserted, it means that there is but one way, to advance the children, and that is for the Department to take full control of them, for a period, until they are fitted to take a place with others on the same footing.

Your obedient servant,

Thomas Deasy,
Indian Agent.

I have the honour to submit the following report on the Queen Charlotte Agency for the month of August, 1914:

In my opinion the summer vacation of the Boarding Schools, in other places, is at the wrong time. Dear Sir:

We, the Council of the Massett Band, on behalf of the Indians of the Queen Charlotte Agency, hereby place before you our humble petition, with the faith in our endeavors to advance our Indians, especially the generation now growing up among us.

Almost fifty years ago, when the Dominion Government took over the management of Indian Affairs in our Province, we were uncultured and only starting on the road to progress.

About the same time, the negroes of the United States were given their freedom, and they now form a part of that great nation, with all the rights and privileges of free men. They had been slaves, up to that time, and were bought and sold, like any chattels.

Unlike them, we always were free to roam over the lands of this country; but were considered wards of the government, like unto children, although taking the part of men and women, in earning our living and abiding by the laws of the land.

Fifty years makes a difference to the Indian, as well as to other human beings, and you have given us the free schools and other agencies, to advance us in the path of civilization.

The Missionary and the School Teacher, with the Indian Agent and the White settler has been among us for many years. They knew, and you know, whether we have taken advantage of the programs of the west, and kept pace with
your teaching.

Our Bands, on the Queen Charlotte Islands, have thanks to give for the progress we have made; but we look for results.

We are ambitious, as all men should be. We have our well built towns; our young men studying music; our wives and children growing up among us, learning also to be good subjects, and we are all ambitious to be something more than the ordinary Indian is looked upon to be. Otherwise, what use in endeavouring to advance?

Other Indians, who are not shewing advancement have their Boarding Schools. We have none. From the scattered Bands of Indians, over the Province, Indians are taken to fill up the Boarding schools on the mainland of British Columbia, hundreds of miles away from our homes. We have, among our people, over one hundred children of school age, and we desire to have them taught in a way that will be creditable to us and to the young under our care.

If we remained at home, during the Summer, we could take advantage of Day Schools; but we fish for our living and must take the children to our scattered camps. If we had a Boarding School, on Queen Charlotte Islands, we would leave our children there for the whole year, and we would soon have them learned in bettering their condition.

We are willing to give any part of our reserves, for a school. We are willing to do anything to have a school, and we find it difficult to induce our people to send their children so far away from home, to the mainland schools, although we sent a large number, last year, to Sequalletza Industrial Institute. We, sometimes, want to see our children, and the expense of sending them to outside schools is great.
It must be further remembered that our Haida Nation is not a part of the Indian tribes of other portions. In the days of old, we lived a race apart from the other Indians. We claim to be progressive, and our young men are doing all they can to prove our contention.

In all work, whether of Church or State, we endeavour to be examples of what can be done with a class that will help to build up a country.

The Port Simpson Indians have an appropriation for a Schoolhouse. On the mainland and at Alert Bay are Boarding Schools. Would it not be possible to give us a Boarding School, this year, we have asked you again and again for this favour, for the good of our children.

Will you please bring it before the Indian Department once more and we will ever pray.

Councillor — Pete Hill
Councillor — Robert Bennett

Honourable Sir;— We, the undersigned, send you the following petition.

We beg your influence in assisting us in obtaining a boarding school on Massett Reserve. Our Church (Anglican) is prepared to take up this work, and the matter is now under the consideration of the official heads of our Church. We are afraid that one large home will be built on the mainland. This would not help our children.

In the first place, any point on the mainland would be one hundred miles from Massett, which entails expenses in travelling, going, coming, and holiday time.

Secondly, the Haidas (Massett) are a separate tribe, having nothing in common with mainland natives, either in language or customs. Our experience in the past is that deceases are caught by intermingling.

Thirdly, very few people would care to send a child so far from home, whereas, if a boarding school were built on the Island, every child of the proper age would attend.

There are a hundred children on the roll at day school, but under the existing conditions, apart from the school not being able to open more than eight months of the year, comparatively few get more than a month's or two's schooling. It means that the children go wherever the parents go, fishing, canneries, sawmills, etc. Whereas, if there were a home in Massett, the children could be placed there and their studies be uninterrupted.

We are anxious that our children be given a chance to prepare themselves to compete with others in earning a livelihood. Education is the one great factor that is lacking among our people, and we feel that something must be done more than the present school system.

We trust therefore that this will appeal to your department, and that something will be done this year.

I have gone into this matter very fully, to show the absolute necessity for an Indian Boarding School, in this Northern country. Last year, we had over one hundred children attending the Massett Indian Day School. Today, forty are in attendance. The Skidgate Indian Day School has an attendance of thirty.

Chilliwack is some six hundred miles away, from these islands, and is the only Boarding School available for the children of this Agency.

The Massetts attend the Anglican Church. The Skidgates, in this Agency, attend the Methodist Church. The Massetts must, necessarily, attend the Boarding School, supervised and controlled by the Methodist Church.

We guarantee that at least one hundred children would attend a Boarding School, within a short distance of this Agency. The Indians are eager that their children should be educated; but they object to sending their children to school, so far removed from their homes. The children of the Haidas are taking a great deal of interest and are also eager to learn.

The majority of those returning from Chilliwack, have not proved worthy, and the report of the Medical Officer of the Band will show that several of the returned boys are suffering from a disease that is dangerous and shows their unworthiness. The children now sent, are of parents who desire to get rid of them, for the reason that it is difficult for them to provide a living for them. In sending the children to Chilliwack, it means expense, to the parents, which they cannot afford. Meanwhile, the children are taken to canneries and camps, where they learn nothing useful, and the Day Schools remain closed, for many months in the year.

If, as we believe, education is the salvation of the Indian, such a large number require a Boarding School, in this Northern country. When children are, for eight or ten years removed from their parents, and away from intercourse with their own people, they have little in common with them, when they return.

The "Haidas" are considered the most advanced of the Indians of the North. In my opinion they are; but I am also of the opinion that they are retrograding. The younger people are not what they ought to be, and the fault is they are not receiving the education they should have for the reason that the Indians move from place to place and take their children with them.

Dear Sir,

The Indians of Massett are very keen on having their children educated. There are at present on the roll at Massett School, one hundred and six, and the average attendance is higher, I think, than ever before. "We notice in the recommendations of the Special Joint Committee of the Senate and the House of Commons, that the sum of one hundred thousand dollars be voted annually for the purpose of technical education etc. We appreciate this, and beg to petition as follows,

That the Department put a Residential School on the Queen Charlotte Islands. We believe that Massett would be the most suitable site, as there is already a large new day school here with over one hundred on the roll. With the addition of another room, it would accommodate one hundred and fifty children. This would take care of all the suitable children from both the Reserves on the Islands."

I also received a communication from Rev. Westgate of the Anglican Canadian Church Missionary Society, wanting my views regarding a Boarding School in Northern B.C. Re-Boarding School, Nassett.

Dear Sir:

In a conversation with the Commissioner while I was in Victoria, regarding a boarding school, it was suggested that I make a report in this matter giving my ideas.

My firm belief is that the Indians can best be advanced by educating them the same as white children. This can be seen by observation of those who have already had some education. They are the best behaved people in the village, and it is possible to reason with them, not only because they understand English, but because their minds are more developed. Under the present system their opportunity for schooling is limited on account of the life they live, having to move away from the villages at different seasons to gain a livelihood. Their custom is to take the whole family. The Boarding Schools of the Province have helped considerably, but to my mind, judging from results among the children on the Queen Charlotte Islands, the time spent at the School has not given them the amount of education they should have. This is on account of so much time being given to instruction in farming, etc., which is of no practical use to the people of these Islands.

My suggestion is that there be a semi-boarding school, that is a place where the parents could leave their children when they leave for the fishing season, etc., particularly to take care of the children between the ages of six and twelve. If this were carried out, I see no reason why they could not pass their Entrance at the usual age for white children. If any wanted to go further than this, encouragement could be given. As an illustration of how the children can advance when given the opportunity, I would refer to Miss Shopland's class in the Nassett school. The children who began in 1927, and attended regularly showed remarkable improvement, and compare favorably with the white children in the same grade at New Nassett. These children are between six and eight years.

I would suggest that the semi-boarding school be built at Nassett where there already is a three-room day school. With the addition of another room to take some children from Skidegate, this would then be sufficient for teaching purposes. I would think the residence would need to be large enough to accommodate one hundred children. At present there are one hundred and three on the roll at Nassett and forty at Skidegate. The apartment already has sufficient land around the school, the old Hudson Bay land and part of the Mission property. The three teachers at Nassett live in the Mission house which is rented from the Church, and it is just possible that this could be purchased or rented indefinitely for the staff. Only one more teacher and a Matron would be needed; as kitchen help, etc., can be secured in the village. Some of the girls have had good training at Coqualeetza and could help with the domestic work in connection with the residence, and they could be hired when needed.

I would suggest that the school be undenominational,

W.E. Ditchburn, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Victoria, B. C.
and qualified teachers chosen irrespective of Denomination as long as they were Protestant, but preferring those with a Missionary spirit.

The Queen Charlotte Indians have the name of being the most progressive of those on the Pacific Coast. The people are certainly keen on education, and I feel sure they would support a Boarding School when erected, by helping to supply such food as they could to the children when at the home. The people begin to scatter here in March, and the full number are never in the school before about November.

I would like to have the Commissioner's opinion on these ideas, and if favorable steps taken to have the building erected by September 1930.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Canon Gould:

When forwarding requests for Indian Education Estimates, you have represented that there was need of a residential school for Anglican Indian children somewhere in the neighbourhood of Prince Rupert. I recently learned that, on the 30th instant, there will meet in Vancouver representatives of the Church of England and of the United Church, for the purpose of discussing the education of Protestant Indians in northern British Columbia. I feel you will be glad to have an expression from the Department concerning the possibility of securing funds for the establishment by the Government of such schools in this locality.

I believe that only two new residential schools should be considered during the next few years, one on the mainland and one on Queen Charlotte Islands. As the United Church is pressing for a residential school in northern British Columbia, it is probable that we will offer each of the churches mentioned one school when funds can be provided.

Our latest census of the Indian population shows 400 Church of England and 245 United Church adherents on the Queen Charlotte Islands. In the vicinity of the Nass and Skeena rivers, there are 1,064 adherents of the Church of England and 1,365 of the United Church. The United Church conducts a small boarding school for girls (22 pupils) at Fort Simpson. It was erected by the church authorities.

I am not at all satisfied that Queen Charlotte Indians should be educated on the mainland or that mainland children should be sent to a school on the Islands. The

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D., D.D., D.C.L.,
General Secretary, M. S. C. C.,
604 Jarvis St.,
Toronto 5, Ont.
people are very different and their early relations cannot be called cordial. It is my opinion that one residential school should serve the Queen Charlotte Island children. No doubt, separate instruction in religion could be arranged. Such a school could be offered to one of the churches. The other church could be offered a large institution on the mainland, provided that Protestant Indians generally on the mainland would be recruited.

In this way, the establishment of two schools would solve the problem for some years to come. The erection of four schools would mean much greater capital expenditure, which cannot be favourably considered by the Department, and, secondly, the pupilage at each would be comparatively small and the costs of maintenance, correspondingly high.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Chief Henry Edenshaw, of Massett, visited the Department on the 26th instant and urged the establishment of an Indian residential school for the Queen Charlotte Indians. He was of the opinion that such an institution should be established between Skidegate and Massett and should draw pupils from both. He felt that the proposal to establish a boarding house for Indian children during those months of the school year which were in the fishing season was but a temporary measure and that when the Department is planning for the future we should not stop short of a regular residential school, with good vocational training.
Slave-Hunting Indians Yield to Christianity

Indian Missionary Recalls Days of Piracy on Pacific Coast

The conquest of Christianity over slave hunting and piratical Indians on the Pacific coast was the theme for a Tribune on Sunday by Henry Edensaw, chief of the Haida Indians on Queen Charlotte Island, and a missionary to the Anglican Church of England recently held in Toronto. Mr. Edensaw spoke the day in Windsor, where he was born at Massett, on the island, after the first trip he had ever made east of the Rockies.

In the first half of last century, the island, which is about 150 miles long by 50 broad, was inhabited solely by Indians who raided the mainland for slaves and plunder. In the year 1823 the schoolmaster Thomas Roney, Captain Roney, was captured by the natives and killed. Mr. Roney's father, afterwards named Albert Edward Edensaw, one of the leaders of the Haida tribe, returned back to the cabin in which the captain had been killed and rescued and saved their lives, though the schoolmaster's wife and child were taken prisoners.

Procured Release

Later he procured their release and was given a certificate of his bravery and generosity by Captain Roney's widow. Mr. Edensaw became a faithful friend to all captains trading on the coast.

In the year 1833 the island was visited by Her Majesty's ship "Volunteer," under Captain Prévost, afterwards Admiral Prévost. Captain Prévost engaged Mr. Edensaw as his pilot and used him in that capacity during the whole of the expedition. On his return to England he recommended Mr. Edensaw to the mission of the Church of England authorities, who called for a volunteer to go to the island.

The volunteer chosen was a young man named Henry, who had experienced a promising career in England and was eager to serve the Indians. He first established a church on the island at Massett, where he lived and taught for nine years. Then came the end of the era of the traders of selling liquor to the Indians. Mr. Edensaw, known as Methilakta, followed by the greatest of the traders, built a sawmill and built a town, and later, when he moved north to New Brunswick, he took with him once more. That was the beginning of civilization among the Indians on the Pacific coast.

Continued Study

The elder Edensaw was a man of property at the time of his death, but, by the custom of his tribe, his estate property and his rank descended to his nephew in the same manner as to his son Henry, in turn, got his rank from his uncle.

At the age of 18 he entered the service of the Hudson's Bay Company as a lad in their store on Queen Charlotte Island, scarcely able to read or write. For 14 years he stayed in the store, educating himself by constant reading.

HENRY EDENSAW

After leaving school with the company he offered himself to the church as a teacher, and three students went with him during the week while he accompanied the minister on Sundays, actually preaching his sermons to the natives. Mr. Edensaw has now bought a few acres on Saturday afternoons.

At the same time he was acquiring property, though the same was small. With the civilization of the west came the opening of training schools for Indians on the mainland, and Mr. Edensaw's family and other young Indians from the island went there to get an education.

Trips To Get School

At the end of 18 years Mr. Edensaw gave up teaching, having been licensed in the diocese of Caledonia. As he realized that he could not make a living on the mainland, he decided to try and make a living on the island. He went to Ottawa to try and secure a position as a missionary on Queen Charlotte Island, and he has hopes that this will be successful.

The chief occupation of the natives on the island, formerly engaged in trapping for furs have made trapping not worth while, there being plenty of seal, sea lion, and other animals on or near the island. The land is beautiful, with woods of hemlock and jackpine, and it has many rivers and streams. The climate is fine, with a mild winter and warm summer. Mr. Edensaw has mail at Massett once a week in the summer and twice a month in the winter. Mr. Edensaw, a strongly built man of excellent appearance, was delighted with his trip to the east, where he met the people of Ottawa, and especially with the kindness and hospitality shown him everywhere.

I have the honour to report that a change is taking place at Massett Reserve which will mean a great deal to the Indians of the Massett Band and also to the School.

A company is erecting a cannery at Naden Harbour, or Virago Sound, about twenty miles from Massett, and is employing the Indians in clearing the ground and on construction work. In the spring the Indians will fish for the cannery and work in the buildings.

I have the honour to submit the following report with reference to the Massett Indians, now at Naden Harbour, Virago Sound, where Cannery buildings are in course of erection and where a large majority of the members of the Band are now located:

After consulting with Rev. W. Hogan, the Anglican clergyman here, and with Mr. Gilmour, who is in charge of the work of erecting buildings, it has been decided to recommend the erection of a building by the owners of the Cannery, to be used as a Church and School. The Cannery owners are willing to erect a building and, when Mr. Hogan's health permits, it is the intention to go over there, with him and select a site. Few children are now attending the Massett School and, on the erection of a building, arrangements should be made to have a Teacher go there. Whether the Teacher of the Massett Day School should take up this work is for the Department and His Lordship Bishop DuVernet to determine. The Indians leave here, in the Summer, for the Canneries, and the school, at Massett, is closed, for some months. If we should find the attendance at the school, in Naden Harbour, is good, the Teacher should remain there, until the Cannery closes. I feel sure that

a large number of the children will remain at Naden Harbour Cannery during the fishing season, returning to Massett periodically, and making Naden Harbour their home, for the Summer months. Dear Sirs:

On behalf of the natives employed here we wish to approach the Department in regard to establishing here a school for the native children.

We have here at present time twenty-one children a list of whom is attached. This number is consistently maintained during the months of March, April, May, September, October, and November, these months being our operating season. For some time back the Natives here, who find their children growing up with practically no education whatsoever, have been after us to assist them to obtain school here for these months of the year. In midwinter we are closed down and the natives go to Massett, where the children can go to the Massett school for about two months. We have been operating here for five years but we have put off requests for a school until we were reasonably sure of our operating months and the number of natives we are likely to keep employed.

Our present plans are for a gradual expansion of our activities here which will involve probably the hiring of more natives as we go along in addition to maintaining employment for the present force. We have employed the natives from Massett for twenty years and find them very satisfactory on the whole, faithful and hardworking and it would probably be a steadying influence and a help to them if their children could have access to primary education for the long period they are here each year.

We understand that the Department will not consider constructing a school on private property and there is no Indian Reserve property at convenient distance. We would suggest therefore that we will construct such a school including suitable quarters for the Teacher sufficiently large for the present and future needs and rent the building to the Indian Department at a rental of $10.00 per month for the time the school is in session, the Department to install the necessary equipment such as Desks, blackboards, stove, etcetera.

Our budget for the does not permit us to construct the school at once but if arrangement can be worked out this arrangement can be worked out we believe we can build the school in the winter in time for the opening of our spring season, in the latter part of February. Meanwhile we would appreciate hearing from the Department as soon as possible on the matter.

Yours very truly,

To the Secretary of the Dept of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter No. 343016, dated Feb 5th, in which you say that the Department will be glad to hear from me in regard to several matters relating to Indian Schools.

Will you allow me to say first of all that the Government's long delay in giving a decided answer to the Indians in regard to the land question is having a most disastrous effect upon our educational and religious work among the Indians. Our Church of England missionaries in this Diocese of Caledonia (Northern B.C.) have steadily counselled the Indians to be law abiding. In consequence of this the Indians say that we are servants of the Government trying to get their land from them. Our Indians have been stirred up by agitators. They have been asked to raise a large sum of money to carry their case to the Privy Council. Money is being freely given for this purpose. Our Missionaries hold aloof from this telling the Indians that if they will only wait patiently the Dominion Government will see that they are treated fairly. Not very long ago Indian Delegates from all parts assembled at Vancouver to arrange to carry their claims to England. I think the Department should inquire who presided at this meeting. I am informed that it was an official of the Indian Department. Since then the attitude of our Indians towards our Missionaries is more marked. Our missionaries are loyal to those in authority while at the same time telling the Indians what will be best for them in the end.
To give a specific example of what I mean:

Our Nassett Indians were not in the least agitated about the land question, they were quite contented in mind until they received a letter from Rev. Mr. Tait a Methodist Missionary more than 500 miles away. He and the Rev. A.R. Green seem to be the chief movers in this matter. Rev. A.R. O'Meara, Church of England, does not belong to this Diocese, and has no authority from me. No doubt some of our missionaries think that the question of the Indian Title should be authoritatively settled but as a Body we hold that the Indians being wards of the Dominion Government, this Government should have the question settled without this most unwise stirring up of the Indian mind. This is by way of introduction to what I have to report.

1. With great difficulty and at much expense I secured a male teacher for Gitladamika, the uppermost Indian village on the Nass river. Mr. R.J. George has an expert knowledge of gardening and farming & has an earnest desire to show the Indians of this village how to cultivate their rich lands. Accompanied by Archdeacon Collison, who knows the language well, I took him up the river last summer and introduced him assuring the people that he was not after their land, but only wished to teach them and do them good. They received him most kindly until the delegate from this land conference returned from Vancouver. Now Mr. George writes me as follows: "At a Council meeting at Gitladamika to consider the matter of setting apart a piece of land for the mission house they were so undecided that they came to no decision. I inquired the cause and was told they considered me the thin end of the wedge. They summed up the situation thus. The Bishop, the Archdeacon, Mr. McCullagh and myself are the servants of the Government and are seeking to deprive them of their land. Seeing that I am regarded as a traitor by them..."
I have concluded after prayerful consideration that the only thing for me to do is to leave the river.

Mr. A. R. Smeath, our School teacher at Iakkalzap on the same river, writes by the same mail in much the same strain. I shall endeavour to persuade these men to hold on, but you will see how this land agitation is upsetting all our work. The feeling up the Skeena has been intense but is a little easier now. Our Missionaries urged the Indians to wait patiently till the Commissioner came from Ottawa. He came but only to repeat the same message which had so often been given before—"I will report to Ottawa all you have to say". The Indians have great respect for authority. All that is needed is a decided answer.

2. In regard to Nassett a new industry has developed at North Island a fishing Company is erecting a station there with a steamer carrying fish to Prince Rupert. In consequence of this large numbers of the Nassett people have gone from the Village. What Rev. Mr. Hogan recommends is that Miss Edenshaw should continue teaching the little ones at Nassett and that Mr. Sherwood should follow the bigger children to North Island and teach school there. If the Department will make a grant of rough lumber 3,000 ft at $17.50 per thousand, with shingles so the natives will put up 30 x 30 with a "lean-to" at back for teacher to live in.

I wrote about this to the Indian Agent, Queen Charlotte Islands, but as Mr. Perry was leaving about that time the letter may be waiting for the new agent, whoever he may be to arrive. I hope the department will make this small grant. It will be seen from this that owing to this new move on the part of so many of the people the question of tents must be deferred for another year. This will show the Department what we have to contend with in trying to carry out any plan.

3. I asked Mr. Fuller the Carpenter to whom I referred to in my previous letter if he would undertake the work of teaching the Indian young men & older boys carpentry but he sees too good an
opportunity for work in Prince Rupert to accept such a position. I think that this is a matter which the Indian Agent should take in hand.

Let me say in closing that I fully appreciate the difficulty in connection with the Indian Title and the dispute between the two Governments but there is no denying the fact that our whole Indian work is suffering because of the lack of a decisive answer from those who represent "The King."

I remain

Yours faithfully

(sgd) P. H. Du Vernet

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your communication of the 31st ult., (No. I22723/1) with reference to the delay in connection with the erection of a School Building at North Island—now named "Langara Island."

I am more convinced than ever the erection of a school building there would be a great mistake. The Indians go there for a short time, to catch Spring Salmon, and are scattered along the beach. Even the Indians feel as I do on this matter.

I might state that no expenditure was made on this account. After going into the matter with all concerned, I did not purchase any lumber.

Sir,

In compliance with your instructions, and in order to carry out the requirements of the Census Commissioner, I visited North Island (now called Langara Island) and will now submit a report on the question of a Schoolhouse there, a matter which has been under consideration for some time:

Left Massett on the 3rd inst., on a launch, and called at the new Whaling Station, on Virago Sound. All of the Indians formerly employed there have gone—not one Indian remaining and little prospect of their returning—which I feel sure they cannot be blamed for doing, considering the low wages they received and the unwholesome stench from the bodies of the whales treated there. Proceeded to "North Island," arriving at Massett Reserve at 1 o'clock a.m. on Sunday morning. Found "six" families camping there. Remained until Monday morning, 5th inst., and went to four other camps, along five miles of rocky sea-coast.

It would be practically impossible for children to walk from one camp to the other and I cannot understand how anyone would suggest the construction of a schoolhouse there. The Indians left Massett on the 15th May, for "North Island." They will return on or about the 20th June, to prepare for the cannery work. Not one Indian will remain and none will return there until the next year. It is a bleak, desolate coast, away from all lines of communication and the Indians only go there for a short time each year.

Telegraph Creek, B.C.
August 22nd 1925

The Superintendent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Re a Boarding School for the Catholic Indians of the Stikine Agency, British Columbia.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit the following report asking for a boarding school for the catholic Indians of the northern interior of British Columbia, in the Stikine Agency.

Number of school age children.— A thorough investigation, made personally by the undersigned, this summer, reveals that there are actually easily one hundred children of school age, born of catholic Indians, around Telegraph Creek, Atlin, Dease Lake, Macame and Liard Post, receiving no education whatever.

Attitude of the parents.— Everywhere, the parents have been as willing as possible to request the Department at Ottawa to build for their children a school in the north. Some had heard of the residential school at Lejacq, B.C., and wanted me to bring their children there. They were told that there were already more children in that district that the school could afford accommodation for, then the cost of transportation would be too high to allow many children to be taken down. Furthermore, a great number would undoubtedly object sending their children that far, the Lejacq residential school being, for some of them, over one thousand miles away.

Boarding School.— A boarding school would be the only possible way of educating and civilizing the Indians of the northern interior of B.C. They are of the nomad type. Very few live in log cabins; most of them live under tent all the year around. During the summer they gather or move as they please around some of the above mentioned trading posts. The rest of the year is spent in the mountains. Under those conditions, a day school would be a failure and a waste of time and money.

However, a school that could afford accommodation for about eighty children would be sufficient as a start.

Location.— Telegraph Creek, on the Stikine river, is actually the terminus of the transportation facilities and the commercial center for the Cassiar and Liard districts. During the summer, supplies are easily taken in by a boat from Wrangel, once a week.

If my memory does not fail, there is no proper location reserved yet for an indian school around Telegraph Creek. But I am confident that it could be done if wanted. There are some good spots for an institution of the kind, six, eight, ten and twenty miles below Telegraph Creek, right along side the river. Some of them, like the six mile lot that I have personally visited, have a large and ever running creek going through, which would be a great convenience both for the school and the land.
Re a boarding school for the catholic Indians of the Stikine Agency.

There are again a few good locations around Dease Lake some seventy two miles from Telegraph Creek. But perhaps the cost of hauling supplies in there would be too high.

However that matter of the location could be looked over again. Herewith I have attached a sketch of the six mile creek lot, which, I understand, is now Government Reserve.

Great Need.— It would be useless for me to try to point out to the Department the necessity of providing immediately education facilities for those Indians of the northern interior of British Columbia. It has become the outspoken cry of the white who have heard of the superstitious and inhuman customs, such as witchcraft, still prevailing amongst some of them. Others are still given to polygamy. Amongst those who have met with the white man or rather gather around his camp, evil influence is more easily followed than good. It was the missionary's sad experience to notice how this evil influence manifested itself by blasphemy, debauchery and the frequent breaking of the marriage bonds.

Is it not true that the only remedy to those deplorable evils is education?— And now that those Indians show good dispositions towards the sending of their children to a boarding school would it not be wise to take into account those dispositions. And now that they ask themselves for a boarding school would it not be fair to grant them one immediately.

However, the undersigned is not writing for himself. He is a missionary who has at heart the advancement of the Indians. He is ready to do his share as he has done before. He only wishes and hopes that the Department will see its way to grant his request for the good of the Indians of the northern interior of British Columbia and their children.

I have the honour to be, sir,

Yours sincerely,

E. Allard, L.M.I.
Prince Rupert, B.C. Sept. 24th, 1925.

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Scott,

You are no doubt aware of the fact that 5 Liard Indians were tried before an Assize Court in Prince Rupert last August for the murder of one of their own young men. The trial naturally attracted wide attention and occasioned a good deal of inquiry and comment on the habits of the Cassiar natives. On finding that the crime had been committed as a result of superstitious convictions still alive among those Indians many officials and prominent citizens have expressed to me a desire that I should send missionaries to them in order to prevent the recurrence of such abominations.

As a consequence I have sent Fr. E. Allard to visit the Dease Lake and Liard Indians in order to ascertain the best that could be done for them. On his return he has submitted a report written for the Indian Department, indicating that the only adequate remedy to cope with existing evil would be the establishment of a Residential School in that vast district. I earnestly concur myself in making the same recommendation, realizing, as I do, that the want of proper education is the root of the deplorable disorders that have existed among those Indians in the past.

I know that such school is costly but it must be remembered also that the trial referred to cost almost the price of a school.

And what about the future?

Atlin Day School.

Moreover having accepted that charge, I must convey to the Department the incessant request of the Atlin Indians for a day

(over)
school. They want to learn how to read and write. Their constant dealings with white people make them realize this need. They claim they feel ashamed to appear so ignorant. In fact they have more reasons for that feeling now than they had in the past. Atlin has become a Summer resort of considerable importance. The numerous tourists who come there inevitably visit the indian village, inquire about their school, deprecate the want of it &.

Hence, I hope, that a school that will cost so little and satisfy so many will readily be granted by the Department. It would be sufficient to run it 6 months in the year, viz: from the 15th. of April to the 15th. of October, the period of time when most of those indians stay in their village at Atlin.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing a letter from the missionary of the Church of England at Telegraph Creek which explains itself. I believe it is not the policy of your department to build boarding schools for Indians to be run on interdenominational lines but that you co-operate with the church which is carrying on the missionary work among the natives where the school is desired.

In any case the district including and adjacent to Telegraph Creek has been for many years supervised by the Church of England. The Roman Catholic Church never has had a missionary in that field except for long separated visits and for many years the Presbyterian Church which at one time had a work there has withdrawn its missionary.

There is absolutely no justification for a Roman Catholic school in that locality; nor is there for a Roman missionary over which point you have no control. There is a small Roman Catholic native mission at Atlin about two hundred miles distant where there is not even a regular day school. That Church might do something in a small way there and not encroach upon the ground where the Church of England has been doing faithful and costly work for many years.

As administrator of the Diocese of Caledonia I sincerely trust that no favorable consideration will be given to an appeal which I believe has been sent into your department that a Roman Catholic boarding school for Indians should be built in that district. There are not a half dozen real R.C. Indians in the whole district.

I have the honor to be,

Yours truly,

I consider that "tying up people as Witches" is now no longer practised by the Liard Indians but there is no doubt that the belief in witchcraft is still prevalent, and always will be, among the elders.

It would do a great deal of good if a School Teacher could be sent into the Post every year, coming in on the first H.B.C. boat and returning with the last one. The children here are bright and there are a lot of them, including quite a few Half-Breeds. If this teacher had, in addition, a slight knowledge of medicine, he would find plenty of use for it.

The Indians are now much more friendly and talk to us about their many troubles. There is occasional mention of the "Ipsheot" (presumably the Devil, or at any rate a very evil spirit) but there is much more talk of the Big Chief who tried Mie and Big Alee (Mr. Justice D.A. Macdonald). The trial made a very great impression on the Lots and their description of it to the other Indians has evidently been graphic. In the Summer Mie often came to the Detachment for a talk (and something to eat) and always referred to the Big Chief. "No more kill witch" she said. "You tell him I good now."

Our Eddie is a great wonder to them but I am afraid that it is regarded as part of the "Ipsheot's" work.

Both these Priests spoke against witchcraft but as I have reported several times already, the elder are pretty hard cases. A school for the children is the only solution. It was unfortunate that there were so many deaths among the Loots this winter. (Fortunate perhaps that we were here.) I am sure that the old Loot Mother thinks there is a "witch" loose somewhere. After the girl, Betty Loot, had started to bleed at the nose, Glen Loot went over to the camp of a white trapper, Carlson, and asked if his sister had not had a cup of coffee there just previously. On hearing this I went to the Loot camp and spoke to them all very strongly, perhaps using words that the Bishop and Father Allard cannot.

In spite of Sergt. Paton's instructions the girl would not lie down, and we had perpetual calls for assistance. Bribery having proved useless I made her relations use force.

Dear Sir:-

Re the question of an Indian Industrial School for this district, I would inform you that I have had considerable correspondence with the former Agent on this matter, with the approval and complete sanction of the Ecclesiastical Authority of this Diocese.

In my former appeal for consideration of this matter I most distinctly and emphatically stated that I considered an undenominational School was essential, for there is no doubt that the religious controversies are a most terrible handicap to the religious advancement of the Natives in all the mission fields at the present time, and that this is being now recognized more than ever is shown by the advancement towards unity of the Churches, particularly in the Mission Fields. I personally consider that the selection of religion should be kept out of the matter, and the school should be free of all ecclesiastical interference, the sole religious instruction in the School being confined to the simple Gospel teaching to which there can be no objection by any denomination who have the welfare of the children at heart. Should a service be required by the teachers at the School, the resident minister at Telegraph Creek could be applied to, observing that the Anglican is the only permanent clergy in this District and that the district itself was first visited by Anglican clergymen, before even the Roman Catholics penetrated into the district of Telegraph Creek, Dease Lake and Liard.

As a site for the School I would personally recommend 6 Mile for the following reasons:-

1. In convenient reach of Telegraph Creek for telegraphic and mail communication.

2. Convenient for transport by water to and from the Coast in the season of navigation.

3. A considerable amount of arable land where vegetables, etc. could be grown for use and excellent drinking water and is healthy and free from contamination with all whites or natives and can easily be reserved for privacy.

4. Dry climate similar to what the native here is used to.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) O.T. Hodgson.

Sir,-

Residential School. Indians.
Stikine Agency.

I beg to submit the following information in regard to the above subject and reference.

The necessity of a Residential School for this Agency has been under discussion for some years, and now with the increase of children, suitable for instruction in such a school, it is becoming a vital and much talked of question amongst the Indians themselves.

This has been due mostly to the Roman Catholic Fathers engaged in mission work in the Agency, and partly to the general trend of affairs, by which the Indians see that it is to the advantage of their children to have them read, write and add figures. Eaton's catalogues have also had a lot to do with this line of thought.

At all points of the Agency, during my rounds the matter has been advanced and questions asked, hence the mention of the subject in my reports.

The total number of children of school age mentioned in your letter dated August 6th, viz. 112, has now grown to bigger numbers, and a correct return will be rendered later on, but in this district, as per the attached sheets, there are 155.

In Atlin, under Father Godfrey's care, there must be at least 25; he has compiled a list for this purpose, and at Teslin, under Bishop Stringer's care, there is at least another 30, making in all a conservative total of 210 children.

The Roman Catholics have the greater total in this district and in Atlin, but the Anglicans have an advantage at Teslin and Telegraph Town.

The School Report just rendered will speak for itself. Whilst at Teslin, the school was being run by a young gentleman who had no control over the children, and the school was looked upon as rather a joke by the Whites, and also by the Indians who are most intelligent. Otherwise there is no tuition for Indian children in the Agency.

Carcross Indian School has been drawing a few children from Atlin and Teslin Lake, but it is gathered that the Natives would much rather send their children to a school somewhere located in the Stikine Agency and south of Teslin Lake.

As Rev. Hodson was here, and also Father Allard, the attached letter was written, but a meeting could not be arranged, and so they were asked to reduce their views to writing, which same is also attached.

It would
It would seem that a Residential School is desirable and that if located in or around Telegraph Creek, the Indians would be pleased to send their children for school training.

It also came to notice during several talks with them that the education of their children was really more important than the religious aspect of the case to them, and that it did not matter so much where they went, so long as the children were looked after and taught.

The matter of location has been gone into, and at first Dease Lake was chosen, but looking into the matter it is found that a far and away better location would be at 6 Mile Creek down the Stikine from Telegraph. To the Indians it does not matter so much, anywhere will do providing its in the dry belt and that they are able to get to the school, at anytime, overland.

It is admitted that Dease Lake is more centrally located, and easier to get to, for the Indians, but against that there is the cost, etc. of getting supplies in, etc. and being away from the route of travel.

The location at 6 Mile, although at present a British Columbia Government Reserve, has a fine site, good water, salmon fishing. It is much drier than Dease Lake, and above all is on a main line of travel and supplies can be got in at a reasonable rate and would be in connection with the town of Telegraph Creek, the Dominion Government wire, and it is hoped a resident doctor.

Moreover, crops can be grown at this point, it is not subject to the early frosts that have this year killed all crops in and around Dease Lake and nowhere in the Agency can a school be built cheaper than at this suitable point.

If the necessity of a school is warranted, the construction of same can be gone into, but it is thought that suitable sand and clay is there, if not a saw-mill could be arranged for, and failing that lumber could be obtained at a fair price from the mills in Wrangell, at the mouth of the Stikine River.

All of which is respectfully submitted for your consideration and is as much data as can be gotten together in the limited time at my disposal.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) Harper Reed.

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re-School in Stikine Agency.

As the matter of erecting a residential school in the Stikine Agency becomes more desirable from time to time, I feel it is of sufficient importance that I furnish you with some correspondence I have had with Mr. Indian Agent Harper Reed, of Telegraph Creek, on the subject, he having stated in his report for July last, after a visit to the Atlin and Teslin Lake Indians that, "in both places the crying need is for schooling. They are all willing to help but do not want religion taught, or at least, they wish more learning of a practical sort given their youngsters."

You remember we discussed this matter when you were in Victoria and the decision was come to that unless the Anglican and Roman Catholic parties could agree upon an undenominational school it would be impossible to erect one as there were not sufficient children of either denomination to warrant the building of a school for each. I am not at all satisfied with the figures given by Mr. Indian Agent Harper Reed which he has received from the Missionaries, and I am asking him to forward to me with as little delay as possible a complete list of the Indian children between the ages of seven and sixteen years taken from his census, showing the bands they belong to and the religion they profess.

In conclusion I may say I am of the opinion that it would go very far in satisfying the Indians of the Stikine Agency, who do not in any event give us any trouble, if an undenominational school was erected for the education of the Indian children in that district.

I was wondering in view of the suggestion of the Rev. Father Allard if the matter was referred to Rt. Rev. Bishop Bunoz, of Prince Rupert, whether you would feel inclined to write to him on this subject pointing out not only the desirability of the children becoming educated but also that a school would afford far better opportunities of permitting Christian Doctrine being given to the Indian children after school hours than can possibly be the case in such a scattered district.

Dear Sir:

In this connection I beg to inform you that Rt. Rev. Bishop Buonoz, O.M.I., of Prince Rupert, called at my office on the 30th ultimo when this question was discussed and I pointed out to him that in view of reports so far to hand there did not appear to be sufficient children of school age in the Agency to warrant the building of two schools, one for those of the Catholic denomination and the other for the Protestants, and it would be much more satisfactory if an understanding could be arrived at between himself and the head of the Anglican Church that a non-sectarian school should be erected.

The Bishop, however, did not see his way clear to concur in such a proposal as he considered it would only lead to endless trouble and he put forth the suggestion that each church build its own school with some financial assistance from the Department by way of a grant towards the building and the guarantee that the regular per capita grant would be paid, and I stated I would lay this point before you for your consideration. I may say I have not so far received from Mr. Indian Agent Reed the information I requested from him on August 6th last with regard to the actual number of children of school age in his Agency with the religious belief they adhered to, but when this comes to hand I will report further on the subject.

Bishop Buonoz also spoke to me with regard to the school at Atlin at which it is extremely difficult to obtain a teacher for the salary the Department is paying. Dear Sir:

Re-Residential School in Stikine Agency.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo enquiring whether I have received a report from Mr. Indian Agent Harper Reed with reference to the actual number of children of school age in his Agency, showing the religious denomination of each.

In reply I beg to say that after a fairly reliable checking up by the Indian Agent, it appears there are in the Stikine Agency 181 children of school age, 86 of which are male and 93 female. As to their religious beliefs the Agent states there are 65 Protestant and 104 Roman Catholic, with 12 pagans. These are located as hereunder:

| Band          | No. | Males | Females | Prot. | R.C. | Pagans |
|---------------|-----|-------|---------|-------|------|--------|
| Telegraph Creek | 64  | 31    | 33      | 35    | 26   | 3      |
| McDames-Liard | 78  | 36    | 42      | 7     | 62   | 9      |
| Atlin-Teslin  | 39  | 21    | 18      | 23    | 16   | -      |
| Totals        | 181 | 86    | 93      | 65    | 104  | 12     |

There is apparently good reason for establishing a residential school for the accommodation of from 75 to 90 pupils of the Roman Catholic denomination at an early date. Possibly at a later date a smaller school might be established for the Protestant Indians, though for the time being the Protestant children of Telegraph Creek can be educated at the Day School at that place.

The matter of location of such a school is an important phase of the question and I note in your letter that the Rev. Father Allard is desirous of having one situated at Telegraph Creek, but I beg to inform you that there is no suitable land at that place for such an institution. There is, however, a piece of good land on the Stikine River six miles below Telegraph Creek, a part of which would be eminently suitable for our purposes in every way. This is known as Lot 1, Cassiar District, and comprises 320 acres; it is under reserve by the British Columbia Government at present for possible townsite purposes. Today I had an interview with Mr. Cathcart.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Cathcart, Superintendent of Lands for the British Columbia Government, to see if it would be possible for our Department to acquire about 50 acres or so of this Lot for school purposes and he informed me that in all likelihood his Department would give sympathetic consideration to an application in this direction. This Lot is an above state, six miles below Telegraph Creek on the Stikine River and there is on the Eastern portion some good land suitable for agricultural purposes on which could be grown sufficient vegetables for the use of the school. I would say that 50 or 60 acres ought to be sufficient for, of course, cereals cannot be grown in that Northern district nor would it be possible to keep many cattle, if any.

In conclusion I beg to say within the last few days Mr. Boyd, Manager of the Hudson's Bay Company store at Telegraph Creek called on me and I asked him about a possible location for a school in that district. He informed me that the Lot above mentioned is the only logical place on which to locate as all other land along the river is of a precipitous rocky formation. You will understand, of course, it is most desirable to have such a school located somewhere on the Stikine River as it would be on the regular line of communication with the outside. In a letter of Mr. Indian Agent Reed, of 29th August, 1928, he also favors this site as also did Rev. Commander Hodgson. A copy of the Agent's letter will be found on your file as I forwarded the same to the Deputy Minister on October 24th, 1928.

Attached hereto will be found the Agent's returns showing the number of children of school age in the various bands of the Stikine Agency.

Your obedient servant,
