EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. C. C. PERRY, ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER FOR BRITISH COLUMBIA, DATED AUGUST 30/30, HIS NO. 45/18704, forwarded under cover of Commissioner Ditchburn's #45/18751, dated September 5, 1930, addressed to Deputy Superintendent General.

EDUCATION:

There has been a long standing controversy between the representatives of the Roman Catholic and Protestant Anglican Churches, respectively, as to which church merits an ascendency in regard to residential school facilities as a result of the advent from time to time of their respective Missionaries. In response to my request, Reverend Father Allard, O.M.I., of the R. C. Church and Reverend Commander Hodgson, Anglican Minister, agreed to come together at the Indian Office with the Agent and myself with a view to going over the Agency census and determining what Indians were reputed to belong to either of these churches, in other words to determine who are considered to be Roman Catholics and who are deemed to be of the Protestant faith. This action was thought necessary as a preliminary step in the direction of deciding what recommendation should be made to the Department with respect to Indian education in this large district; a residential school having been asked for during my visit by the Reverend Father Allard, O.M.I., for the accommodation of 92 children stated by him to have been baptized into the Roman Catholic Church. A list of these children was submitted by Father Allard.

Reverend Commander Hodgson of the Anglican Church had also submitted a list of families which embraced many of the children in the R. C. list.

A frank and fair discussion of the matter went to show that Indians baptized many years ago by the Anglicans had been rebaptized later with their children into the Roman Catholic Church and vice versa.

The Agency official census book was examined, Family by Family, and agreement was reached between the two Church representatives in regard to each, subject, of course, to the acceptance of such status by the respective Family heads.

A distressful aspect was the division, through baptism, by the respective clergy, of families. In some cases, the fathers would be pagan, the mothers Catholic and the children Protestant. In other cases the father is Protestant, the mother Catholic, part of the children of one Church and part of another. Many old Indians were baptized by the Anglicans years ago and had lapsed into paganism, some of whom were now claimed by both Catholics and Protestants.

A decision was reached as to the status of
Extract from Asst. Commissioner Perry's Report (continued)

the Indians as understood by the clergymen. A subsequent numerical checkup shows as follows:

In the vicinity of Telegraph Creek, Tahltan and Dease Lake, including Bear Lake migrant visitors, there are,

Roman Catholics 120.
Anglican 150.

In the McJames and Liard districts there are claimed by the Roman Catholic clergyman 320 Indians, one-third of these are said to be nomads and are not claimed by the Anglicans. The Roman Catholic Church therefore expects to register these 320 Indians as Roman Catholics.

In the Atlin and Teslin districts at least two-thirds of the Indians, who in total number 222, are adherents of the Anglican Church. It was admitted that the work of the Anglican Church is increasing there while that of the Roman Catholic Church under Rev. Father Allard, O.M.I., is not extensive. Rev. Father Allard, O.M.I., stated that his Church would be willing to give up any religious activities that might be prejudicial to the Anglican interests there, especially if the Department would be willing to make provision for a residential school for say 50 of 92 Catholic children of school age at a place called Six-Mile point which is on the right bank of Stikine River about 6 miles below Telegraph Creek. On the other hand, Rev. Commander Hodgson, of the Anglican Church, at Telegraph Creek, has suggested that if the Roman Catholic Church would be willing to vacate their Telegraph Creek Mission (where Rev. Father Allard has recently erected a church for the Indians in what the Anglicans believe to be their territory) the Anglicans might give up any claim they may have to Missionary territory around McJames Creek and Dease Lake where however the Anglicans have no established or organized missions. The Anglicans may offer some objection to the establishment of a residential school for the Roman Catholic Church near Telegraph Creek as they consider the district an Anglican Missionary territory even though there is some lack of appreciable Missionary activity along educational lines on the part of the Anglicans in this district, the latter through Rev. Commander Hodgson claiming not to have any funds for such purpose. It should be pointed out that despite the past religious work of the Anglicans at Tahltan (now abandoned) and Telegraph Creek, the Roman Catholic Indians have erected new churches at Telegraph Creek and at McJames whether the Anglicans like it or not and the priest has decided to press for the education of the Indians who identify themselves with the Roman Catholic Faith, and hence is asking that a departmental residential school be established under the supervision of the Catholic Church for Catholic children within the territory for which they have established these churches.

The Department will be aware of a medical
Extract from Asst. Commissioner Perry's report (cont'd.)

survey made in 1928 by Dr. Wride of the Indians in Stikine Agency, in view of which I pointed out to the clergymen concerned that a medical report of the present resident medical officer Dr. Edgelow as to the physical fitness of the 92 R.C. children to enter a residential school would appear to be necessary before consideration could be given to the request for a residential school. This suggestion met with approval, and Dr. Edgelow has promised to make a careful medical examination of the children whose names appear on the list of Rev. Father E. Allard, O.M.I.

Should a medical report on these children prove satisfactory, it would then be desirable that the Department give consideration to the question as to:- whether

1. A residential school should be provided.
2. Whether such school should be denominational, undenominational or inter-denominational.
3. Whether or not the Anglicans' view that the Catholics are usurping their recognized Missionary territory or sphere of influence should be endorsed in view of the limited nature of the present Missionary work of the Anglicans and the recent more active work of the Roman Catholics in this district.

It seems to me that it might be reasonably deduced from the foregoing observation that as the Roman Catholic Church claims adherents numbering 440 and the Anglicans 372 - (total population of Stikine Agency is 812) there would appear to be reasonable grounds on the part of the former to ask for separate educational facilities for at least 50 of their 92 children, particularly as the Anglicans have a residential school at Carcross, Y.T., which is near the center of their larger church activities and which has at present some accommodation and which might be extended if necessary in order to accommodate the Anglican children who might in future be found available for admission thereto. It is thought that an extension of educational facilities for the Anglican Church at Carcross by the Department for the accommodation of Anglican children should fully compensate them for any obviously questionable loss they may claim to have sustained by the advent of the Catholics into their Missionary territory which at present is showing very slight signs of either religious or educational activity. The children of the district around Telegraph Creek are attending the Provincial public school, while the Mission at Tahltan is deserted and practically abandoned. Should the Department be inclined to recognize the claims of the Roman Catholics to a
residential school for Catholic children, it is recommended that such a school be established at 6-mile Point where acreage of sufficient area might be obtained from the Provincial Government which is understood to have placed a reserve on it for educational purposes. I have examined the site and believe the same to be quite suitable for this purpose. It is further recommended that a special inspection be made at the Carcross Indian Residential School which at present seems to bear an unsavoury reputation in the North, with a view of bringing it to a higher degree of efficiency and in order that the children of Anglican families in the Stikine Agency may be given suitable and satisfactory residential school accommodation and supervision. Of course, this recommendation is made subject to a satisfactory report being made by our medical officer respecting the physical fitness of the applicant pupils.

I should advise you that your suggestion to have a joint undenominational school for Stikine Agency while approved by Reverend Hodgson for the Anglicans, is not received with satisfaction by Reverend E. Allard, O.M.I., of the Catholic Church.

It should further be pointed out that the erection of a residential school at McDames, or Dease Lake for the Catholics as suggested by Rev. Hodgson would be fraught with great expense; while such a school if erected on the bank of the Stikine at a proper elevation would cost a great deal less as freight could be landed close to the proposed site. Moreover it is believed that the Stikine River will always be a main artery into the Cassiar country even though a public highway may be made into Dease Lake and Alaska from the south in the future. Moreover there is a beautiful creek and splendid fishing right at this proposed school site where fish food could easily be obtained for the use of the pupils.
Extract from estimates submitted by the Indian Agent of the Stickine Agency for the fiscal year 1931-1932.

A Indian Residential school to include all children disregarding to what faith they or their Parents belong, is sadly needed. This would be the very best and most helpful way of bettering the Indians of the Cassiar, and practically the only way. The Carcross School is quite all right in its way, but to reap a full advantage, the School will have to be conducted by The Indian Department itself.

Dear Sir:

Working on the favourable report you made two years ago about the necessity of a boarding school for Indian children to be erected at Telegraph Creek or in the vicinity, I have been trying ever since to find a community of Sisters that would be willing to take over an institution of that kind. I am now glad to announce that the General Chapter of the R.R. Sisters of St. Ann has finally accepted and that four Sisters will be available for September 1933.

It takes a long time to find a staff that will qualify for such a venture and be permanent. Other places had to wait longer. Now that there are helpers willing to come to Telegraph Creek, will you be kind enough to let me know what can be expected from the Indian Department in the way of assistance. The R.R. Sisters, I believe, would also be ready to take hospital work. I have not been able to meet the members of the local hospital board who are all out in the woods just now, but from what was said before I am confident they would be too pleased to have the Sisters take care not only of the Indian patients but also of the white patients.

You know the conditions around here, Mr. Ferry: over one hundred children of school age between this place only and the Liard and no school; nobody to look after the crippled ones, sick and orphans; much cruelty, superstition, etc., still going on amongst the tribes. Proper education and training of the young generations would, I believe, assure the betterment of the race.

It is too late now to start anything but I would like to know as soon as possible what the Indian Department would be willing to do for next spring. If it was impossible for Ottawa to accept to build themselves perhaps they could give a grant let us say of $20,000.00 and let the church do it. His Excellency, Bishop Bunoz is away in Europe for perhaps a couple of months more but I thought I would let you know as soon as a staff had been found for Telegraph Creek and ask your assistance for the realization of our plans.

I remain, Sir,
Yours sincerely,

Dear Superintendent General,

As this is the time when the Estimates are being prepared I consider it my duty to remind you of my demand made last November of a residential Indian school for the Stikine Agency. As you know there is no school in that immense district of Northern British Columbia. Yet a school is just as necessary there as in any other part of the Dominion, perhaps more so, in order to aid in the civilization of those natives who so far have had no chance to get an education and who are inclined to be troublesome at any time, as was the case rather recently. For you may remember that in 1926 five Indians charged with murder and witchcraft had to be brought from Liard river to the Okala prison near Vancouver and again several witnesses had to come from that distant place to Prince Rupert for the assizes. The trial cost the Government an enormous sum. What has happened then may happen again unless something is done to prevent it. The best prevention of that evil, I think, is to give those wild natives a good education which will convey to them knowledge and respect of the law. This would be an invaluable blessing for a region so far away from police officers, prison and court house.

To secure these advantages for natives and whites I have offered and still offer to put up the school building and supply a good teaching staff provided the Government supplies a per capita grant for about fifty children. This is an offer which I am sure, the Government cannot turn down even in time of depression.
Prince Rupert, B.C.

The children to be admitted to the school will be carefully chosen among the most healthy and fittest to profit by that special training intended to qualify them for the exercise of a beneficial influence on their fellow natives.

Inspection Report No.4, Stikine Agency.

EX'D.

This is a very pressing question in this agency, the Indians so far being practically uneducated. On the other hand, to send them out to boarding schools would be fatal, as they then lose touch with woodcraft and wild life, which is and can be their only source of livelihood. As long as a majority of the children can learn to read, write and figure up to even as low as grade 5, and are not kept at school for too long periods, or until thirteen years old, this should be sufficient for a long while to come.

In fact a period of winter or summer schools in the most favourable positions is probably the best way. Further, it must be borne in mind that wherever the women and children are assembled together for the children's period schooling, provision will have to be made for hunting for food, and possibly anyhow in the winter schools, some sort of buildings for them to live in. Further, too, anyhow at winter schools, teachers will have a pretty hard time and I should think require some extra pay, as they will have to outfit themselves specially. Summer school teachers too will have to contend with the curse of mosquitos and flies, besides in both cases, the high cost of reaching their destination and getting out again.

G. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
LIARD POST, B.C. For the past few years the matter of a Summer day school for this far-away Hudson Bay Post has been mooted, and much correspondence passed as to the best method of procedure. As quite a few children at this point were half-breeds Bishop Bunoz was requested to find out from the B.C. Provincial School Authorities, exactly what they were prepared to do in the way of assistance were a school started. Up to the present His Lordship has not replied giving such data but has sent in Father Dream O.M.I., with Father Poulette, O.M.I., as his Assistant. This summer they have constructed a very fine Church-School House, also living quarters. Much of the material they brought in with them, and the buildings stand on their own owned compound, side on to the Indian Reserve.

The Department has not assisted in this case at all. The number of children at this point that might attend such a school is about half Indian and half halfbreed, it might be that the Indians have slightly more than half at certain times when the nomads come down to this Post. However Father Dream requested to know if he could obtain assistance for the summer of 1936, and he was promised that the Department would be written to in regard to school supplies. As the school is just starting a full equipment would be required, the same as allowed to Mc Dames School on its first opening. Salary for the Teacher was carefully avoided, but if same is to be paid the sum of $150.00 is considered reasonable in this most expensive locality. A School is certainly needed here, and the very fact that two Fathers are residing at the Post will tend to lift the general moral tone of the Camp. Father Dream was asked if he intended going up to Francis Lake in the Yukon, his reply being "that he might do so, but not this Fall" As the Hudson Bay Company has recently bought up a Trader's Store on Francis Lake, it is quite expected that the R.C. Mission will establish some kind of small Mission house there also. Photographs of the above mentioned buildings at Liard will be submitted later. May this Agency be advised as to further action, if any, that the Department considers correct.

KLAPPAN WINTER DAY SCHOOL. The location of this school is out in Klappan District, south of Telegraph Creek. It serves a whole lot of nomads and acts as a concentration camp for the very large families during the winters, when the head of the family has to travel long distances for trapping purposes. The school ran all last winter in one or two very good cabins erected for this purpose—it is on a Reserve near-by a Lake. The school was successful from its start, and good progress was made by the children. Through its establishment more fur for the families was obtained, and this winter they will reap its full benefits. Requirements have been met, for this winter and from now on it needs only worn out school supplies restocked. The Salary allowed the Teacher is $100.00 (158-7-1) and Father Bosse O.M.I., conducts this during winters and the Bease Lake School during the summer time. However this winter Father Bosse has with him a certain Mr Moran, most capable person, and he in turn has brought up as an extra help, a certain Halfbreed named Mac Stephens. It is thought that this lad will be going out again next spring.

CARIBOU HIDE NATIVE SCHOOL. This school has never been officially started, but Cripple Jimmy, a member of that Band has, on his own been conducting a very primitive school of his own. The matter was up for consideration upon Inspector Parnells visit to these parts, but it was impossible to reach this very distant Band of Indians. This Fall The Department has been kind enough to allow a supply of school material, which has already been forwarded to them. (Dept. letter - July 31-36 158-7-1) There is little doubt but what Father Bosse will this winter pay a visit to these Indians and start up a little school. This should be able to run along until such time as correct arrangements can be taken up and settled. This is a very fine bunch of Indians and deserve help, but their location is about 200 miles from anywhere, and are obliged to stay where they are for trapping purposes. A teacher for this location will have to go in by Plane.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The School requirements of the Agency appeared to be pretty well covered, except at Telegraph Creek and possibly Teslin Lake, insofar as location is concerned. The school buildings, except Tahltan, leave much to be desired, but under existing circumstances it will presumably be impossible to deal with this situation entirely at one time. The chief difficulty, apart from lack of funds, is the very high cost of transporting material, often several times its value. The schools can be dealt with one by one, each being put into fairly good condition or replaced, or a certain amount of improvement carried out each year on the entire group, until they are as satisfactory as local conditions will permit; and this will no doubt be found the most feasible procedure after the ownership question is definitely settled and the Churches quit claiming financial interest in them. The Agent should place a suitable and reasonable amount in his estimates for this purpose. Subject to foregoing remarks regarding individual schools, I am satisfied of the necessity of continuation of the schools and would recommend, subject to further investigation by Mr. Sampson, that consideration be given to extending the teaching period, provided competent tuition is given.

I am most definitely not satisfied that the tuition in any of the schools is even anywhere near the Department's requirements, despite the fact that I was unable to check the children's work. I feel that investigation will show that they are more mission than school and that the stipends are actually more in the nature of mission assistance than educational expenditures. Five of the six teachers speak very imperfect English and none of them, so far as I am aware, have even a rudimentary training in Educational work; Father Carpentier being the most successful.

If the present set up is to be continued, and trained teachers are hard to get in this country where living costs are abnormally high, I would recommend that the Inspector of Schools visit the district during the summer months, when the summer schools are in session, and report on the work in detail endeavoring to give what instruction is possible to these missionaries. In this he will meet all the teachers as they also cover the winter schools during that season. The Stikine Indians are bright and intelligent and there is an urgent necessity that they be given a reasonable educational program with efficient teaching. Meanwhile, Mr. Sampson has been instructed to secure report forms from the Department and visit the schools as frequently as possible, insisting that our requirements be met.

Unfortunately we have been led to believe by Mr. Reed that the Stikine Indians are a low type of nomadic Indians, here today and miles away tomorrow. This idea has been strengthened...
The School requirements of the Agency appeared to be pretty well covered, except at Telegraph Creek and possibly Teslin Lake, insofar as location is concerned. The school buildings, except Tahltan, leave much to be desired, but under existing circumstances it will presumably be impossible to deal with this situation entirely at one time. The chief difficulty, apart from lack of funds, is the very high cost of transporting material, often several times its value. The schools can be dealt with one by one, each being put into fairly good condition or replaced, or a certain amount of improvement carried out each year on the entire group, until they are as satisfactory as local conditions will permit; and this will no doubt be found the most feasible procedure after the ownership question is definitely settled and the Churches quit claiming financial interest in them. The Agent should place a suitable and reasonable amount in his annual estimates for this purpose. Subject to foregoing remarks regarding individual schools, I am satisfied of the necessity of continuation of the schools and would recommend, subject to further investigation by Mr. Sampson, that consideration be given to extending the teaching period, provided competent tuition is given.

I am most definitely not satisfied that the tuition in any of the schools is even anywhere near the Department's requirements, despite the fact that I was unable to check the children's work. I feel that investigation will show that they are more mission than school and that the stipends are actually more in the nature of mission assistance than educational expenditures. Five of the six teachers speak very imperfect English and none of them, so far as I am aware, have even a rudimentary training in Educational work, Father Carpentier being the most successful.

If the present set up is to be continued, and trained teachers are hard to get in this country where living costs are abnormally high, I would recommend that the Inspector of Schools visit the district during the summer months, when the summer schools are in session, and report on the work in detail endeavoring to give what instruction is possible to these missionaries. In this he will meet all the teachers as they also cover the winter schools during that season. The Stikine Indians are bright and intelligent and there is an urgent necessity that they be given a reasonable educational program with efficient teaching. Meanwhile, Mr. Sampson has been instructed to secure report forms from the Department and visit the schools as frequently as possible, insisting that our requirements be met.

Dear Sir:

I have had before me for consideration for several days the report submitted to you by Inspector Coleman, immediately following his recent inspection of the Stikine Agency.

The inspection of this agency, undertaken and carried out by Inspector Coleman, appears to have been both thorough and comprehensive, and his report, while somewhat disturbing, contains very valuable information.

At this time I am anxious to discuss Inspector Coleman's references to the educational facilities of the agency. In his general summary the Inspector states:

"I am most definitely not satisfied that the tuition in any of the schools is even anywhere near the Department's requirements, despite the fact that I was unable to check the children's work. I feel that investigation will show that they are more mission than school and that the stipends are actually more in the nature of mission assistance than educational expenditures. Five of the six teachers speak very imperfect English and none of them, so far as I am aware, have even a rudimentary training in educational work, Father Carpentier being the most successful."

You are aware, of course, that the Government has never at any time accepted responsibility for missionary effort amongst any Indians anywhere in the Dominion. Missionary effort on Indian reserves, looking toward the Christianization of the Indian population, has always been assumed willingly by the Churches. It would appear that in the Stikine Agency, however, there is very close relationship existing between missionary effort on the one hand and educational effort on the other. I do not feel that we should take any serious objection to this, provided that the missionaries, in addition to their regular missionary work, act as school teachers and are fully qualified teachers in a professional sense. Inspector Coleman informs us that none of these teachers are so qualified, and I feel confident that our officials in British Columbia responsible for the administration of Indian affairs, the Department itself and even the Churches would be subjected to a great deal of severe criticism if the facts submitted in Inspector Coleman's report became the subject of discussion in Parliament or in the Press. With the burden of taxation in Canada becoming increasingly more onerous, the taxpayers

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B. C.
in the future are likely to demand that every dollar authorized by Parliament is spent on the program for which the Government is responsible.

It appears to me that we should first of all decide very definitely what these Indians in the outlying districts of the country should be actually taught. Districts such as the Stikine district are becoming more and more accessible, as the result of improved transportation facilities, particularly aeroplane travel. If such is the case, these Indians should be, if they are going to be even partially assimilated, instructed in English. They should be taught Arithmetic to the extent that they will be able to undertake simple business transactions, and above all they should be taught how to take care of their bodies and how to use their hands. It may be that a thorough survey of the district should be undertaken by a qualified educationist, preferably Inspector Barry, if he is physically fit and has the time at his disposal to undertake the task. The investigator should be called upon to submit a curriculum designed to meet the needs of these people. He should report on school buildings, their number and exact location. Indian day schools, in my judgment, should be the property of the Department and should be used exclusively for educational purposes. Inspector Coleman's suggestion, that a school be built at Telegraph Creek and an undenominational teacher employed, would not, I feel sure, be acceptable to the Churches. My experience here has been that there is no such thing as an undenominational teacher; a teacher is either Catholic or non-Catholic. It is just possible that at Telegraph Creek two schools should be built, just as soon as funds are available for such buildings.

The officials here are disposed to think that it is a sheer waste of time and money to keep schools open and in operation unless these schools are under the direction of fully qualified teachers. However, in view of the difficulty that we may experience, for the time being at least, in getting fully qualified teachers, it might be worth while considering the advisability of securing a fully qualified, experienced teacher and putting him in charge of two schools in the agency, spending approximately six months at each, and allowing him a three week holiday period. I suggest this as an inducement that might be held out to teachers who would not be prepared to go in for such an extended period. It might also be possible that we might, by the payment of a higher salary, induce a fully qualified and experienced teacher to take charge of one of our schools and at the same time assume responsibility for the inspection of other schools in the district. It is difficult for me to persuade myself that we can hope for worthwhile results from these schools until our inspection is more regular than it is at the present time or is likely to be at any time in the future, in view of the large number of schools for which Inspector

Barry -
Barry is now responsible.

I have referred to the emphasis that should be placed in the curriculum on the care of the body and the use of the hands. It might be worth while, as an experiment, to employ - if they can be secured - fully qualified nurses with normal training and pay such teachers a much higher salary than we have been paying to the teachers in charge of our seasonal schools.

You are aware that at the present time our building program has been suspended. We have not at any time within the last couple of years constructed Indian day or residential schools anywhere in the Dominion. However, this period of suspension cannot, in my judgment, last indefinitely. Our Indian school population is increasing at the rate of 300 per annum, and unless funds are available for the construction of schools in the immediate future, our schools are likely to become congested and overtaxed. When a building program is undertaken in the Stikine Agency, care should be taken to recommend the construction of a school with ample living accommodation for the teacher - quarters that will be comfortable and satisfactory in every sense. The average teacher will hesitate to undertake work in an outlying district such as this, unless there is assurance of comfortable living accommodation and reasonable remuneration.

I am anxious that you should discuss the subject matter of this letter not only with Inspector Barry and Inspector Coleman, but with the Roman Catholic and Anglican Bishops. The Director, with whom I have discussed Inspector Coleman's report very fully and in detail, is not at all sure that we should continue to keep our day schools in the Stikine Agency open and in operation unless the bishops are prepared to nominate fully qualified teachers. I feel confident, however, that you will find the Bishops very willing and very anxious to co-operate with us in the establishment and conduct of better schools. They must be convinced, as we are, that present conditions, from an educational standpoint, are wholly unsatisfactory and cannot continue. When I intimate that you should discuss this letter with the Bishops, I base this suggestion on the assumption that these Bishops visit Vancouver from time to time. It would be highly desirable, of course, if you could discuss the matter with them when Inspectors Coleman and Barry are at the same time. In view of the critical times in which we are living, it is just possible that we may not be able to do much in the construction of better buildings for the time being at least. I do feel, however, that we should do something at the earliest possible date to supply qualified teachers for these schools. Apart from any investigation that may be undertaken by Inspector Barry or an educationist in the future, there is sufficient evidence -
evidence in Inspector Coleman's report to justify us in taking immediate steps as far as the teachers and courses of study are concerned.

I should welcome any comments you may care to send forward on these suggestions, just as soon as you have had an opportunity to discuss them with your officials.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

MAY BE MILITARY HOSPITAL

Ottawa Takes Over Victoria Normal School for War Aims

(By Daily Province Staff Correspondent.)

VICTORIA, Feb. 4.—Victoria's Normal School has been requisitioned by Ottawa for war purposes, it was stated in the Legislative Assembly today by G. Perry, minister of education.

It was while he was speaking that estimates that the minister was handed a note by Premier Hart. "I have just been informed by the Premier," the minister stated, "that Ottawa requires the Normal School in Victoria."

The purpose to which the old building will be put were not indicated, although unofficial reports say it will be a military hospital.

The announcement came as the minister was discussing the suggestion of Mrs. Dorothy Steeves, of North Vancouver, that the two Normal schools be merged.

"I do not know anything about the Victoria school," she said, "but I do know that many people in Vancouver consider that the graduates from the Normal School in this city are better trained as teachers than those who graduate from the University."

E. T. Kenney, Liberal, Skeena, was of opinion that normal fees should be reduced to encourage more young people to enter the teaching profession. Better provisions should be made for rural students. At present they were trained in the country districts and then went to the cities. The reverse should be the case.

Fifty of the 70 students in the Victoria Normal School will be transferred to Vancouver for the completion of their courses, according to tentative plans. NO INCREASE IN SALARY SCALE

CLOSE 23 SCHOOLS; NO TEACHERS

Temporary Certificates Granted Partially Trained Teachers

By R. A. McKELVIE
Daily Province Staff Correspondent.

VICTORIA—Such is the shortage of teachers in British Columbia that present that 23 schools have had to be closed, Hon. H. G. Perry, minister of education, told the Legislative Assembly Tuesday.

In order to obtain teachers to meet the crisis "between 25 and 40 temporary certificates have been issued recently. These have been given to persons who may need teachers but who haven't obtained the requisite certificate in the past."

Advocacy of setting up a "training teachers course in high schools was advanced by Mrs. Grace MacInnis, C. C. F., Vancouver."

The suggestion was welcomed by the minister who said he would discuss it with the superintendent of education.

E. T. Kenney, Skeena, told of the difficulties confronting rural districts in obtaining teachers. Opportunities should be made by school inspectors instead of rural school boards.

NO SALARY INCREASE

The government "reluctantly" has decided against making provisions for increasing grants for teachers at the current session, the minister reported.

The B. C. Teachers' Federation had asked that the minimum salary for rural teachers be advanced from $780 to $900 a year and that city salaries be raised in proportion.

The government already was supplying grants up to $680 for rural teachers and was unable to increase its assistance at present. It was not prepared to place an extra burden on school boards by ordering an increase in the minimum wage, explained the minister.

SPEEDING UP PLAN

Hon. Mr. Perry said he would "take into consideration" a suggestion by Alex Paton, Conservative, Vancouver-Point Grey, that the education system be "speeded up" in view of wartime labor shortages.

Mr. Paton said he understood that during the depression period the training needed for students was extended by one year "to keep children in school as long as possible."

Continuance of this extension when young men and women were eager to complete their educations as quickly as possible was adding unnecessary expense to the educational system, providing an added burden for parents, and proving a hardship to students.

Dear Major MacKay:

I have given considerable thought to the views of the Superintendent of Welfare and Training as expressed in Departmental Letter 158-1-1 of January 28th last, this letter being returned herewith.

You have asked me to let you have my views on the various points raised. This has been done to the best of my ability in the following paragraphs, the matters to be discussed being taken up in the order in which they are mentioned by Mr Hoey.

It is a fact that a very close relationship exists between missionary effort and educational effort in many of our Indian day schools. I have never expressed any adverse opinion on this, except in those cases where the missionary teacher was obviously quite unfit for the work of a teacher and where he held no professional qualifications acceptable to a Provincial Department of Education in Canada.

The Department will be well aware that again and again I have objected to the retention in the schools of Anglican mission teachers in the Diocese of Caledonia where such teachers were not giving satisfactory service as such in their schools. Reference to the files on such schools as Hazelton, Gitlakdamix, and Kitkatla will confirm this. My actions during the past ten or eleven years in this regard have led the Rt. Rev. G. A. Kix, Bishop of Caledonia, to express a very critical view of my services, and this is quite understandable as when the Department terminated the services of unsatisfactory teachers as a result of my reports the Bishop lost at the same time one of his Missionaries, the greater part of whose salary we were paying.

It would appear from Inspector Coleman's report that in the Stikine Agency none of the teachers or missionaries in charge of schools are in fact qualified by any sort of professional training or certification, and I for one consider that the retention of such persons as teachers of even seasonal schools could not possibly be justified even in less critical times. I have never met any of these men to my knowledge, their appointments having been made by the Department without any reference to the Vancouver office of the Commissioner. I do not remember having had any request from these Missionary teachers for professional advice, courses of study etc. It is true that a former teacher at Klappan Seasonal Indian Day School did call on me once in Vancouver, but this visit was in relation to a dispute that he had with the Indian Agent then at Telegraph Creek.
Seasonal Indian Schools Stikine Agency:

With reference to a suitable course of study for the Indian children in seasonal Indian day schools, and in particular the children of the Stikine Agency, I may say that I see no reason why the course now being taught in the Primary and Junior Grades of our regular day schools should not prove highly satisfactory.

The truth of the matter is that I have adapted the B.C. Programme of Studies to our schools and all teachers visiting my office for assistance, as well as those teachers who on first appointment can arrange for a conference here, are given three or four hours detailed instruction here. This instruction covers the limits of work to be taken up in the various Grades, notes on the texts to be used, and very detailed advice as to the methods to be employed in teaching the key subjects, Language, Reading, Spelling, Writing, Arithmetic. The use of the work Books supplied by the Department is explained, and remarks made with regard to the instruction to be given in Health and Physical Training, Memory and Singing, Nature and Science, History and Geography, Vocational subjects in general. Teachers as a rule leave this office with many notes taken during my conference with them.

When schools are inspected the suggestions made to teachers in Vancouver are repeated when necessary, amplified, and demonstration lessons given to cover the more important points or those parts of the course not so well understood by the teacher. This work has been undertaken for years and has proved a very great strain on me, though it has been the means of obtaining a fairly satisfactory general level of teaching throughout British Columbia, with the exception of those Seasonal Schools in northern parts of the Province which I am unable to visit and whose teachers have not sought assistance by calling here.

I very much doubt that any advantage whatever would result from an educational survey by a professional man.

I have never found that untrained teachers, that is teachers lacking both university education and also professional training, gained much from my visits. While it is true that a School Inspector may be in a position to note much that an Indian Agent would perhaps overlook, the information now required with regard to the schools in the North is hardly of a professional nature.

We wish to have particulars of the number of children of school age, and below school age, available for each school. We no doubt wish to know just which months these children would attend the school. We need some particulars of the buildings used for schools, their ownership in particular and if used for other purposes as well as that of a school. Particulars with regard to accommodation for a teacher are also necessary. All of this and much more would be well known to the local Indian Agent.

The absence from Vancouver for any lengthy period of either Inspector Coleman or myself simply means greatly increased work here for the Inspector remaining in Vancouver. A further report following that of Inspector Coleman on the present condition of the Stikine Indian Seasonal Day Schools if this involves expenditure of time and money, as it would if I were to go to that part of the Province later this year, could not, in my opinion, be justified.
Seasonal Indian Schools, Stikine Agency:

The whole of the information suggested as necessary with regard to the Stikine schools by Mr. Doucet would no doubt be available in the Indian Agent's office at Telegraph Creek, with the exception of a suggested curriculum.

In general and even in a seasonal school we should make use of the B.C. Programme of Studies, though this should not of course be followed in detail. My adaption of the above Programme for Grades 1 to 6 inclusive has never been reduced to print or even typed out. It would be necessary to employ the services of a teacher stenographer for several days at least to get the instructions given to teachers here into a form which they might be reproduced. While Mr. Doucet and I were in the St Paul's School classrooms last year I made an effort to have one of the school staff reduce my remarks and instructions to typescript, but the result was so poor that the notes were useless. An untrained teacher simply does not understand the technical terms and when these have to be explained in simple language the time taken is lengthy and the resulting notes more or less useless.

I understand from Inspector Coleman's report that five out of the six teachers now in charge of the seasonal schools under review speak very poor English. This coupled with the lack of even rudimentary training in educational work would make a visit from me a complete waste of time, for I am perfectly certain they would be unable to understand even the simple instructions I give to teachers taking up appointments for the first time.

I regret to say that my health is failing very rapidly. My own doctor has been doing his best to keep me going till I am 55 years of age as I had intended to retire then, but though I am now on a daily allotment of Calcium and vitamins I am simply not equal to the constant travelling, inspection work, and in particular the daily worry of office work (conferences, preparation of reports, and correspondence) in an office where electric light has to be used almost the whole day. I shall be 53 next July and I propose to ask at the close of the present Fiscal Year for a Medical Board so that I can retire at the end of the 1942-43 academic year. My application for such retirement will of course form the subject of separate correspondence, but I am forced to mention the matter here as it must be quite apparent to the Department that I am in no fit state to undertake a journey to the Stikine schools. If I can complete the inspection of the schools south of Prince Rupert, and I somewhat doubt my ability to do this, this year, I shall have completed the programme I considered essential.

It is quite possible that an Indian day school is now required at Telegraph Creek. This should probably be conducted in much the same way at the school at Koksilah, Cowichan Agency, that is as an undenominational school. A properly qualified teacher would be necessary and of course a residence of such teacher as part of the school buildings.

The teacher at Telegraph Creek might be asked to take an interest in the other schools and assist the teachers of these schools, but I do not believe that such a teacher should be asked to report on the other schools. Supervising Principals not Inspectors sometimes get into serious trouble through making adverse reports on teachers, particularly when such reports lead to the dismissal of such teachers, and in this case differences of Church affiliation would complicate the situation greatly.
Mr. Hoey states that the officials in Ottawa are disposed to think that it is sheer waste of time and money to keep schools open and in operation unless these schools are under the direction of fully qualified teachers.

I have found that certain persons can be given sufficient instruction here say in one or two days to enable them to operate an Indian day school in a successful manner, but such persons are somewhat difficult to find. I am at the moment thinking of such a teacher as Mr. Barre of the Pemberton Indian Day School, New Westminster Agency, who after short instruction here and later at his school has made a very great success of his work in the Primary and Junior Grades.

In general however I am in perfect agreement with the other officials and consider that seasonal schools at least should be closed and kept closed till certificated teachers are available to take charge of them.

Mr. Hoey's idea that a nurse teacher would be suitable for the work in a Stikine school or schools is of course perfectly sound and in fact an ideal set up, but I have no hope whatever of finding a nurse teacher for even one of the best of our schools near Vancouver say till after the present war. In fact I do not know where we shall find certificated teachers for the regular schools next year. Attached is an extract from the Vancouver Province of February 4th which may be of interest to the officials in Ottawa.

Would it not be possible for Mr Doucet to come out to B.C. for at least a month or better two months say April and May and make a survey of the present schools on the coast including a few of the residential schools in the Fraser Valley. I would very much like him to visit the schools before I retire and this would give him a chance of working out with me a Programme of Studies for the Indian schools based on the work I have found possible and the present wishes of the Department.

I trust that you will find some suggestions in this letter of assistance, and that if means can not be found to improve the Stikine Seasonal Schools very greatly they be closed at least during the period of the present war. I regret that I know so little of them or of the seasonal schools in the Stuart Lake Agency as in neither case were we consulted in Vancouver either as to their establishment or as to the appointment of teachers.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Gerald H. Barry.
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.
Dear Sir:

I have to refer to the Department's letter of January 26th, your file 158-1-1, regarding the seasonal Indian Day Schools operated at Departmental expense in the Stikine Indian Agency.

The matters dealt with by Mr. Hoey have been fully discussed with Inspector Barry whose report on the various points raised is enclosed herewith. It will be found that Inspector Barry has dealt quite fully with the important items and in the order in which they occur in the Department's letter.

This office had very little information with regard to the Indian Schools in the Stikine Agency until the submission of Mr. Coleman's report on his inspection of this Agency in August, September and October of last year, the arrangements in connection with the appointment of teachers and the operation of these schools having been made directly by the Department with the classes concerned, without reference to the Commissioner's office. This has also been the procedure followed by the Department with respect to the seasonal schools in the Babine and Stuart Lake Agencies regarding which we have practically no information here.

The policy followed by the Department in this regard has no doubt been entirely responsible for the opinion frequently expressed by Inspector Barry and accepted by myself, that we have little, if anything, to do with the operation of these schools, particularly in the matter of the appointment of teachers. This does not apply to the seasonal school at Ulkatcho, which was authorized by the Department following representations made by Mr. Indian Agent Christie through this office, or
to the seasonal schools in the Kwawkewlth Agency. So that although the Department may have considered it the duty and responsibility of the Commissioner to report on the seasonal schools in the remote northerly sections of the Province, the policy pursued by the Department with respect to these schools worked against the acceptance of such responsibility by the officials here. I mention this not as a criticism of Departmental policy, but to make it quite clear that there has been no disposition on the part of the staff of this office to shirk responsibility with respect to the matter under review.

Apart altogether from other causes which may have contributed to the backward condition of the seasonal schools visited by Mr. Coleman, I think it is fairly obvious that the lack of properly qualified teachers could be rightly regarded as the most important factor leading to their present unsatisfactory state. Nor have we the right to expect conditions to improve greatly until certificated teachers are placed in charge of these schools.

It will be noted from the Inspector's report that he intends to apply at an early date for retirement, on the grounds of ill health, and even if Captain Barry should decide to remain longer in the service than his present intentions would suggest, his condition is such, that he could not possibly undertake the difficult journey which an inspection of the Stikine Agency Schools would entail.

The suggestion that a fully qualified teacher be placed in charge of two of the Stikine Agency Schools with partial supervision over the remainder, appears to have considerable merit. Before definite arrangements in this respect were made, however, a decision should be arrived at in advance regarding the localities of the two schools mentioned, in order that suitable accommodation for both teacher and pupils could be provided.

It is my intention to deal further with this subject following a discussion of its various divisions with the Roman Catholic and Anglican Bishops concerned. To do this it may be necessary for me to visit Prince Rupert, as Bishop Bunoz seldom comes to Vancouver. In the meantime, you will have Inspector Barry's views on the subject before

I enclose for your information clippings from certain local newspapers on the difficulties being encountered by the province in securing qualified teachers for the provincial schools.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant and to thank you for the information contained therein. The comments made by Inspector Barry in his letter to you dated February 10, 1942, have also been carefully noted.

We are anxious that you should communicate with us again, immediately following your interview with the Anglican and Roman Catholic Bishops. We are frankly of the opinion that unless qualified teachers can be secured it is a waste of public funds to keep these schools open and in operation, and the Bishops should be so informed. It is just possible, of course, as Inspector Barry intimates, that the church authorities might be able to secure the odd individual who, though lacking professional training, would be fairly successful as a teacher. This individual, in our judgment, should have a thorough knowledge of the English language and be in a position to teach it and of course he should also be a British subject, by birth or naturalization.

While our building program has been suspended for the time being, it has occurred to us that the agent now in charge of the Stikine agency might review the educational needs of these Indians and in due course select sites where buildings might be established. We are still disposed to think that a fully qualified teacher might be placed in charge of two schools and that one teacher in the agency might, in addition to his teaching duties, be given nominal supervision of the other schools. I regret to state that owing to the demands now made upon his time it will not be possible for Mr. Doucet to visit the Pacific coast at any time in the immediate future.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

Whitehorse, Yukon Terr.

September 23, 1942

Mr. Phil Phelan
Welfare and Training Service
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Upon returning, along with Father J. Rousseau O.M.I., our general Inspector, from a lengthy visit of our Indian Missions of the Yukon and Northern British Columbia, I beg to submit to the Department some of our findings and suggestions.

1. Dease Lake and Iskut Lake (or Klappan) Day Schools. The winter day schools of Dease Lake and Iskut Lake, conducted under very hard circumstances, without adequate help from the Department in regard to suitable accommodation, wood supply and appropriate furniture, have accomplished a considerable amount of good in those two camps; the devotedness of the local missionary in charge, Father Cl. Carpentier O.M.I., is above all praise, and according to the testimony of all desinterested persons who have seen him at work, we readily think that it would be hard to find a better qualified man for the task. These two schools must, by all means, be continued.

2. Cariboo Hide Winter Day School. The winter day school at Cariboo Hide could not be conducted last winter on account of the extreme difficulties of communication with that point and the lack of adequate accommodation. Father J. Plaine O.M.I., one of our most zealous missionaries, was ready to undertake the task, but owing to inadequate means of transportation, I could not allow Father Plaine, who is not of a very robust health, to undertake again, as he did the previous year, at the peril of his life, a journey of 250 miles on foot in January, in order to reach his school. After the various attempts made during the past five years to conduct a day school at Cariboo Hide during the winter months, we came to the conclusion that no teacher will ever be found to go and teach at such a place unless proper housing accommodation is arranged by the Department and transportation is provided by airplane.

3. McDame Summer Day School. The Summer Day School at McDame had a better attendance this year than during the two previous years; a very capable teacher was dispatched directly from Ottawa last May in order to conduct the school; this name is Father B. Arsenault O.M.I.; he gave himself wholeheartedly to the work of teaching these very primitive children; the extreme misery prevailing in the camp, along with the poor state of health and condition of halfstarved band of most children, did not favor on the part of the pupils a response corresponding to the zeal and devotedness of the teacher. The camp gives to every stranger the impression of being sadly neglected by the local Officials of the Department; more adequate clothing and rations should be provided to this fast disappearing tribe which has experienced a very high mortality rate last winter.

owing to the lack of medical attention and proper nourishment, a very special attention and generous expenditure should be provided to that small band of Indians if they are to survive and benefit by the school. The School should, therefore, by all means be maintained along with all encouragement and help possible on the part of the local Officials of the Department.

N.B.—In regard to the above mentioned schools, I beg to submit to the Department the names of the school teachers for the School Year 1942-1943:

Dease Lake—Father G. Garnetier O.M.I., (four months winter school)
Iskut Lake or Klappan—Father B. Arsenault (four months winter school)
McDame—Father P. Arsenault O.M.I., (three months summer school)

4.—Lower Post Summer Day School.—We were amazed to hear that the new Acting Indian Agent of the Stikine Agency had no knowledge of a Summer Day School being conducted at Lower Post until he arrived there by boat in June; if the gentleman had only perused his files, he would, no doubt, have seen many letters referring to the Summer Day School at Lower Post; and since no official announcement of its closing had been given to him, and no new teacher appointed, it was self evident that both school and teacher were being maintained; at any rate, if he had entertained in his mind any doubt on the matter, surely he could have written to us and inquired.

As you may know from past reports, the conduct of the Day School at Lower Post has been fraught, all along, with great difficulties, on account of the very primitive and nomadic spirit of the Indians calling at the post, and who are probably the most backward Indians of North America. The various war undertakings carried on in that part of the country this summer have still added to the ordinary difficulties; the excitement of the children on seeing so many white men with their strange and noisy machinery, and the various war works which their parents were called upon to perform in widely scattered areas away from the school, made the attendance of the children more unsatisfactory than ever; and so little encouragement did Father P. Poulet, the school teacher, receive from the local Acting Agent, at the occasion of his visit, that he decided right there and then to follow the latter's suggestion and stop the school altogether. We hope, however, that Father P. Poulet O.M.I. will be compensated over and above for the work he has done during a full month previous to your agent's visit.

It is firmly believed that, owing to the special features of the Lower Post and Frances Lake bands of Indians, the children should be sent to a Boarding School located within a reasonable distance from their home and wherein they would be kept under close supervision for a few years.

With the Alaskan Highway now connecting Lower Post with Teslin or Tagish Lake, the realization by the Department of our long cherished project of an Indian Residential School and Preventorium at Teslin Lake or at Tagish Lake would afford a considerable help for the education and civilizing of the Indians of Lower Post and Frances Lake moreover, destitute, backward orphan children from other parts of the Stikine Agency and the Yukon Territory could also greatly benefit by such a school.

5.—Teslin Lake Summer Day School.—We have felt unfairly treated by the Department over the school question in Teslin Lake, especially after the favorable report forwarded to you last winter by the then acting Indian Agent, Mr. G.A. Jeckell, concerning the work done by Father A. Dream at that point. Father A. Dream O.M.I. is a very capable teacher and had a good school attendance during the Summer of 1941; the parents of the catholic children who attended school were unanimous in stating that their children had learned more in one summer under father Dream than during the previous years under any other school teacher.
CATHOLIC MISSIONS OF THE YUKON AND PRINCE RUPERT

After such an earnest endeavor on the part of our missionary to give to our Catholic children the Catholic education they are entitled to by the Indian Act, I must admit that Father Dream felt quite discouraged this year over the little recognition given to his work by the Department; under the circumstances I dispensed him from conducting the school on a regular schedule until the Department do justice to our cause; nevertheless Father Dream has carried on this summer end is still at present teaching school as faithfully as his other occupations with the American troops allow him. We earnestly beg once more that our Catholic Summer Day School at Teslin be recognized by the Department.

A Catholic Boarding School requested by many other Indians of Northern British Columbia and the Yukon. Finally I must say that we have been approached time and time again by the Indians of Atlin, Teslin, Carcross and Whitehorse for a Catholic Boarding School where they could in all security send their children for a Catholic education; as you are well aware, several of our Catholic Indian children had to be sent to the Anglican school of Carcross in the past, much to their detriment; lately again some of our Catholic Indians camping at Carcross complained to me that the Officials of said school were annoying them trying to induce them to frequent their school... notwithstanding the fact that all the Indians of Carcross and Whitehorse are officially registered as belonging to the Anglican Church in the Official Census of 1892, I must state here that several of those Indians belong to the Catholic Church, others have never been baptized in any Christian church, and a certain amount of them, from ten to fifteen at Whitehorse, regularly attend our services and have severed all connections with the local Anglican Church.

All the Indians referred above, as well as many members of the white population of the North, wonder why there are in the Territory three day schools and two boarding schools supported by the Department at a total expenditure of $31472.12 for a grand total of 79 boarders (half-breeds included) and 42 day pupils belonging to the Anglican Church, while nothing is being done for the children of the Catholic Indians of the Yukon, and so little is done for the Catholic Indians of the Stikine Agency, as can be easily verified from the Report of the Indian Affairs Branch for Year ending March 31, 1941, pages 166 and 169.

Our American Allies, actually working throughout the territory referred to, are themselves amazed at such conditions.

May I add that no medical Official of the Department has been seen this year in any of the camps mentioned, though in some instances the physical condition of the Indians was simply deplorable; under the circumstances some of the American army doctors asked authority from Washington to attend to the physical welfare of our Indians, feeling in duty bound to do something for those at least whom they met along the Alaskan Highway, now under construction; one of those American doctors confided to me that in one Indian camp alone he had performed operations and rendered services which normally should be valued at more than $400.00.

We rely on the spirit of Justice and Fairmindedness of the Officials of the Indian Affairs Branch to see that a better treatment be granted to the Indians of the North, and we dare to insist especially that Justice be done to our Catholic Indians, through a more

Yours sincerely

Ottawa, October 8, 1942.

My dear Bishop Couder:

Your letter of September 25, addressed to Mr. Philip Phelan, has been passed on to me for consideration and comment.

It is my intention to ask Mr. Phelan to communicate with you direct in respect to the schools which in the judgment of the Department should be kept open and in operation during the present academic year. I am sending forward your communication also to the Acting Superintendent of Medical Services.

I am, of course, particularly interested in the operation of the schools and in the educational facilities provided for the Indians of the Stikine Agency and the Yukon Territory. The Stikine Agency was inspected by Inspector Coleman during the months of September and October of last year. His report was very carefully reviewed by the officials of this Branch and was later sent forward to the office of the Minister, for the information of the Minister himself and his officials. Later, I sent a letter to the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia, Major D. M. MacKay, in which I expressed certain views in regard to an educational program that might be provided for the Stikine Agency, just as soon as times become normal. In this letter I expressed the hope that the Indian Commissioner would find it convenient to discuss this matter with the Bishops concerned. A copy of this letter is enclosed, for your information. I trust that he will have an opportunity to interview the Bishops before any definite action is taken.

I am sending you forward also a statement showing the number of Indian residential schools in Canada, the number operated under the auspices of the Catholic Church and the number operated under the auspices of the non-Catholic denominations. You will readily see that while no Catholic residential school has been established in the Yukon, the number of Catholic schools in operation in the Dominion indicates that there has been no discrimination on the part of the Government at any time in the establishment of residential schools - certainly no discrimination against the Catholic Church.

Yours sincerely,

Enc.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Right Reverend J. L. COUDERT, O.M.I.,

Sir;

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated Oct.8, and enclosed copy of your letter to Major D.M.McKay, dated Jan.28, regarding the school situation in the Stikine Agency.

So many misstatements and harmful insinuations are contained in the latter document that I feel it to be my duty, for the sake of justice and truth, to address to you the following corrections.

1.-Regarding our School Buildings.—Our Mission buildings were graciously put at the disposal of the Department for school purposes; all our buildings at McDame, Lower Post, Klappan and Dease Lake, were built by our missionaries' own hands, and at our own expenses, and primarily for our own purposes. A small allowance was, at times, given by the Department in order to help us make said buildings serviceable for school purposes, but such donations all counted would not even make a decent rent as a compensation for the use of our buildings during the past five years, during which schools have been conducted on a regular schedule at McDame, Lower Post, Klappan and Dease Lake.—The Department must realize what a nuisance it is to have all the year round our private dwellings thus constantly open to the public for so many purposes and free of charge, and far from criticizing us for such conditions, your Officials should have apologized to us for having encouraged such conditions by neglecting to build in those various camps the special school buildings the Indians were entitled to have.

2.-Regarding our School Teachers.—For several years with much difficulty we endeavored to secure the help of so called "qualified teachers" for our catholic day schools of the Stikine Agency, but owing to the high cost of living, the extreme difficulties of communications, the total absence of social life in those camps, and finally the constant misunderstanding arising between said teachers and the local Officials of the Department, our missionaries were urgently asked by the local Agent, Mr. Harper Reed, to perform the duties of common school teachers.

I personally represented to Mr. Reed the difficulties our missionaries would have to reconcile their duties as priests with those of Government teachers, but your Agent insisted that our fathers were the only qualified men to be found for the work in such a difficult country, where only men of high moral character and real devotedness, with a thorough understanding of the particular mentality of those primitive tribes could possibly succeed.
The Department must admit that, owing to their religious and psychological training, as well as due to their thorough knowledge of the country and its inhabitants, our missionaries are by far the best qualified teachers the Department could possibly find for such regions.

Moreover, any one who is somewhat familiar with the course of studies followed by all priestly students during a period of twelve years after they have completed their grammar school, will readily acknowledge that our missionaries ought to be somewhat superior, as teachers, to those whom you decorate with the pompous title of "qualified teachers". All our missionaries teaching in the Stikine Agency have gone through a course of studies corresponding at least to the one gratified in this country with a diploma of B.A., and M.A.; they also possess the current use of the two official languages of Canada—a qualification which, much to the dismay of very few, is termed "qualified teachers", and Department Officials possess here in the West—and finally their work as priests make them particularly well fitted to grasp the mind of these Indian children and have the necessary authority and control over them in a classroom where most of the younger pupils do not understand a word of the English language.

As a matter of fact, all cultivated and non-prejudiced strangers who have ever visited our northern wilds and have seen our missionaries at work in the Indian day schools were amazed to see such highly cultured and educated gentlemen humbling themselves to the humble functions of common school teachers.

Therefore, far from being afraid of having such conditions becoming, in your own terms "the subject of discussion in Parliament or in the Press", we would feel that no greater advertisement could be made in behalf of our missions; and we dare to state that the scandal caused would not be coming from the lack of qualification of our fathers as teachers of your schools, but from the niggardliness of the Department in securing at such a cheap price the services of so highly cultured men as teachers, simply because they are men of self-sacrifice, and no ordinary teacher could possibly be found to accept working for the wages offered by the Department.

5.—Regarding Inspector Coleman's proposed Day School.—Finally I must point out here how illegal and impractical is the plan suggested by your Inspector Coleman to have an undenominational day school built at Telegraph Creek. The gentleman shows here a thorough ignorance of the local conditions.

Why should our many Catholic children of the Stikine Agency be compelled to frequent an undenominational school when by right they are entitled, according to the Indian Act, to a Catholic School? At a time when all right-minded men are clamouring for an urgent need of religious and moral training of our youth in schools, advocating a large introduction of religion in the curriculum as the only solid basis of future reconstruction and as an antidote against the fast spreading pagan spirit of the age... the suggestion of Inspector Coleman to do away with religion or religious influence in our Indian schools, is baffling, unpatriotic and highly insulting to our religious feelings.

And where in the world will be found the benevolent flyer willing to bring in every day, in his flying bus, the children of the Stikine Agency to the proposed "Telegraph Creek Indian Day School" from such distant camps as Klappan (60 miles), Dease Lake (30 miles), Cariboo Hide (200 miles) etc., etc.? The suggestion is too ridiculous to be dwelt on any longer. If the officials of the Department are in any way familiar with the travelling conditions prevailing between the actually existing day schools of the Stikine Agency, they will readily see from the most modern "restricted maps" that not the slightest improvement has so far been made in that region, which lies hundreds of miles away from the chain of modern airports and the Alcan way.

Conclusion.—The only logical solution of the school problem in that region is the one we have constantly advocated for the past five years and suggested to the Department, along with the local Indian Agent:

a.—the erection of decent day school buildings right where our missions actually stand in Dease Lake, McDame, Dease Lake, Klappan and Cariboo Hide.
b.—the defraying of the travelling expenses of the school teachers from Telegraph Creek to the various schools of the Agency and back, along with a reasonable allowance for their wood supply, in case of winter schools.

c.—the erection of a Boarding School and a Preventorium in a central place whereto destitute and neglected children, as well as T.E. cases, would be sent from the various parts of the Stikine Agency and the Yukon Territory, from Cariboo Hide and Klappan as well as from Atlin Lake and Lansing Creek, often suggested Teslin or Tagish Lakes, which are both located on the boundary line of northern B.C. and the Yukon Territory, and which two points are now easily accessible through the Alcan way running right through them.

A more recent suggestion might still prove a better one, viz Lower Post or Watson Lake, according to a recent survey made by the U.S. Army Doctors, the Indian population needs a very close supervision, if it be allowed to survive; Lower Post being the point of intersection of the Alcan way and the proposed Fairbanks Railway, would be a central point both for a Preventorium and for a Boarding School serving the whole Indian population of Northern B.C. and the Yukon.

Pardon me, Sir, for this lengthy report, but since you declared in your letter that you were particularly interested in the operation of the schools and in the education facilities provided for the Indians of the Stikine Agency and the Yukon Territory, I thought that these practical suggestions would be agreeably received by your Department, especially in view of the fact that they are coming from one who also claims to be deeply interested in the welfare and training of said Indians.

I have openly and in all sincerity expressed my views on the whole question in an objective way as was possible, claiming to have a fair knowledge of the country referred to, its local conditions and its inhabitants. You may be sure that I have done so with no other desire save that of having the Officials of the Department better acquainted with the actual conditions and needs of the North Country and of its native population; I also intended thereby to show our willingness to work to the welfare and training of the Northern Indians not as an organization independent from the Government, but as a religious body always anxious to cooperate in a friendly way with the Officials of the Department for the best possible treatment of the Indians entrusted to our common care. It seemed strange to us that, after having been accused a few years ago of making opposition to your local official in Telegraph Creek, our missionaries are now faced with an accusation of too close a relation between their missionary efforts and the educational efforts of your agent; I may be mistaken, but in isolated districts as the one covered by the Stikine Agency, I dare to maintain that a good "entente cordiale" between the Church and State over the education of the Indians should by all means be fostered and encouraged by both sides; you may be assured that our most constant efforts will be directed towards the continuation of such friendly relations under the present Agent, and the same attitude will be expected from him in his dealings with us.

Yours sincerely,

Bishop J.L. Couderc O.M.I.,
