Dear Sir,

The Indians at Mc Dame, B.C., number this summer 147; the children of school age (7-14) 44. Those people have requested me since 1925 to petition the Department on their behalf for a boarding school. Reports upon reports have been sent to the Department both by myself and Mr. Harper Reed, the Indian Agent at Telegraph Creek, and also by Mr. Ditchburn at Victoria. But nothing yet has been done for the children of those Indians or for the children of the Indians in the other parts of the district. Indeed, the Department realize how badly a school is needed even if it was only to help prevent those people from being exploited because they know neither to write nor to read. True that I spend over a month at Mc Dame and at Liard Post every summer teaching the Natives besides Christianity, sanitary habits, discipline and cleanliness, but a school would also be a great benefit to the future generations.

However if the Department cannot grant a boarding school for next year would it not be possible to give a grant of $500.00 to bring a day teacher and the necessary equipment to Mc Dame for next summer. With the help of the Indians of that locality a little church has now been built on the Indian Reserve at Mc Dame. It could be used for a school as an experiment.

Hoping that the Department will be able to do something and let us know beforehand so that we will have the time to find a teacher and have the equipment ready for the opening of the school,

I beg to remain,

Yours sincerely,

Rev. E. Allard, O.M.I.
On the other hand, Rev. Commander Hodgson, of the Anglican Church, at Telegraph Creek, has suggested that if the Roman Catholic Church would be willing to vacate their Telegraph Creek Mission (where Rev. Father Allard has recently erected a church for the Indians in what the Anglicans believe to be their territory) the Anglicans might give up any claim they may have to Missionary territory around McQuesten Creek and Dease Lake where however the Anglicans have no established or organized Missions. The Anglicans may offer some objection to the establishment of a residential school for the Roman Catholic Church near Telegraph Creek as they consider the district an Anglican Missionary territory even though there is some lack of appreciable Missionary activity along educational lines on the part of the Anglicans in this district, the statement being made by Rev. Commander Hodgson claiming not to have any funds for such purpose. It should be pointed out that despite the past religious work of the Anglicans at Tahltan (now abandoned) and Telegraph Creek, the Roman Catholic Indians have erected new churches at Telegraph Creek and at McQuesten whether the Anglicans like it or not and the priest has decided to provide for the education of the Indians who identify themselves with the Roman Catholic Faith, and hence is asking that a departmental residential school be established under the supervision of the Catholic Church for Catholic children within the territory for which they have established these churches.

In the McDames and Liard districts there are claimed by the Roman Catholic clergyman 320 Indians, one-third of these are said to be nomads and are not claimed by the Anglicans. The Roman Catholic Church therefore expects to register these 320 Indians as Roman Catholics.
Ottawa, September 6, 1930.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter No. 158-3-I of September 6th last. It was delayed having been sent to Telegraph Creek that I had already left for Stuart Lake.

While I am glad to learn that the Department is giving a favourable consideration to my request for a day school for the summer months at McDame I do not think that the allowance, that is $150.00 per month for the salary of the teacher is sufficient. There is no teacher in the district. He will have to come from outside, a long distance from McDame. Travelling expenses alone both ways, will come close to $150.00 if not more. Then there is the cost of food in a place where supplies are taken in at the price of .20¢ a lb; and the teacher could not perhaps teach more than two months or two months and a half at the most, because the Indians do not stay around the post more than a couple of months. So I would suggest the Department to pay travelling and food expenses as well as the salary of the teacher or otherwise to give a straight allowance of $150.00 per teaching month.

But since your letter of September 6th, perhaps the Department got some further information on the situation and on who is who around Telegraph Creek and in the district above, Dease and Liard rivers, etc., Mr. Perry from Victoria was in Telegraph Creek in the latter part of August this summer. From what he saw and said may we not hope to see something going up around Telegraph Creek, but for the whole district, that would be better an experiment than a summer day school only at McDame. I would be interested to know.

Sincerely yours,

Rev. E. Allard, O.M.I.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of a "Copy for Agent" of a letter addressed to Rev. E. Allard, O.M.I., regarding an allowance for Teacher for his school at Mc Dames Creek, B.C., and also submit his letter to this office on the same subject.

There is no doubt that the cost of travelling and freight etc. to Mc Dames is very heavy, and I beg to humbly suggest that the Teachers salary be advanced to $150.00 per teaching month, which it is understood will not include the time taken to arrive at Mc Dames Creek. If a summer school is opened at this point it will certainly do a lot of good, and the new Church building, recently constructed by the Indians there, could be used to no better purpose.

In the Rev. Father's letter mention is made of some boards required, but the list is excessive, and would cost too much. If the Indians can erect a Church they could also whip-saw a few boards, and save that expense.

Sir,

Re: Mc Dames R.C. Mission School - REPORT.

I beg to submit a report covering a visit to the above newly appointed Mission School.

At Mc Dames Creek, on July 10th 1931, a visit of inspection was paid to the Mc Dames R.C. Mission School for which purpose the New R.C. Mission Church, on the Reserve, is used - pro temp.

This Indian School was started this Spring under Rev Father E. Allard, with Mr Letchford, under Salary of $120-00 per month, as teacher, during the summer months.

I found the school, or rather Church Building, in a very clean state, altho the pest of Flies were such that a low steady drone was audible constantly, and interfered with work undertaken. The Lumber kindly granted by the Dept, for use of desks etc., had not yet arrived, and the scholars were proceeding with their work, on the floor. Thirty children were present, and upon examination, the results obtained were beyond expectations. After school, in spite of flies these scholars continued their studies outside the building, busy still with pencil and papers.

Mr Letchford shows great interest, and enjoyment, in his difficult work, and with the sanction of the Department, hopes to next year make a much better showing.

That the School is short equipment already, is most apparent, and therefore the Teacher was requested to list out what he thought necessary. This list is herewith submitted in requisition form with the hope that the Department will see their way clear to grant the same.

Indians of the Cassias are Nomadic in character, and Mc Dames Creek is their central meeting place, and there is no better way of helping these people than by the formation of Schools for their use.

Father Allard has already forwarded to the Department, his return for Month June 1931, therefore a duplicate was made and same is submitted herewith in correct order.

Father Allard mentioned that he thought a School House should be erected, and asked for help. He was informed that at the present time, the present arrangement should be held to, but that later perhaps, the Department might consider some further help. The Father thought that he could get the whole thing done, by free labour, if the Department would allow him to draw provisions, so that he could supply meals to the Indians whilst at work. His request is reasonable, for at present they are living at the back end of the Church, and have no place of their own.

In conclusion, it is respectfully stated that the venture seems to be a success, and for the future there is no reason why it should not be more so.

The Secretary.
The Dept Indian Affairs. I am. Sir.
Ottawa. Your obedient servant.

Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,-

The first summer school at McDame's Creek, B.C., is closed for the season. The Indians that come to trade and meet the missionary and Indian Agent in that locality had not a good catch of fur last winter and the price they got for it was so low that after paying for what they got on credit from the H.B.Co., the fall before, they had very little coming to them and so had to leave earlier this year for their respective hunting and fishing grounds where they can always find something to eat without having to contract debts for it. But as it was, sufficient interest was manifested in the school as may be seen by the large attendance of the pupils and the progress made was as much as could be expected for such a short period the school was opened.

I regret to say that the lumber allowed by the Department for making tables and benches was late to be sent and so were the drugs which are so badly needed when all the Indians are around. It was finally dispatched from Telegraph Creek by Mr. Indian Agent H. Reed with the aid of a special carrier; otherwise it is possible that it would never have been sent at all this summer.

I have to ask the Department to make an allowance to help build a school at McDame next year. We used the church this summer to see how a school would take with the Indians. But now that the experiment is successful separate quarters have to be built not to interfere with the church work. A suitable site has to be cleared, logs have to be hauled, some of them whipsawed for lumber for the roof, floor, windows and door frames. Mosquitoes are an awful nuisance up at McDame, at work day and night. Only those that have to put up for over two months with their painful vexations will know what it is. But this situation could be much improved by draining the swamp going through the Reserve, source of all the trouble. For all the work to be done an allowance of a thousand dollars ($1000.00) is necessary.

Hoping that my report and present request will meet with the approval of the Department,

I beg to remain,

Yours sincerely,

E. Allard

Sir,

I beg to submit, herewith the final report of the R.C. Mission School at Mc Dames Creek, B.C. Also is attached a letter from Rev. Father M Allard, upon the subject, and the liberty is taken of enclosing a photograph of the present building that is used for the school. It is much regretted that delay has occurred in rendering this report, but inspection trips have intervened.

As previously reported, it is now most apparent that school training is required for the many Indian children that come to the Mc Dames Creek Hudson Bay Post, each summer, and the results obtained by Father Allard, this year has in every way justified the expenses gone too. To carry on this work successfully, a school building, is an urgent necessity at the present time.

Mention is made by the Rev. Father of a sum to the extent of a thousand dollars ($1000.) but if a grant, not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.) were allowed the mission, with which he could feed the Indians whilst construction was in progress, and only to those Indians that gave their services "free," a more concise working agreement would be obtained, and value received for money spent. It would seem that if the parents have been willing to build a Church for their own use, there should be no reason why they could not exercise the same efforts for the schooling of their children. This arrangement would be most suitable for next summer, for it is thought that the Indians winter fur catches will hardly cover their trapping expenses, and the above arrangement would act, also, as a relief measure during the summer months. Therefore it is most respectfully submitted that the Rev. Father Allard be allowed this grant.

Also in the letter attached, mention is made of the pest of Mosquitoes, this is indeed very real, and interferes greatly with school work. This annoyance could easily be handled with the use of two barrels of suitable oil, spread over the swamp at high water, at the same time cutting and burning the brush, and it is again most respectfully submitted that this reserve be allowed this relief.

In a separate letter received from Father Allard he mentions that he forgot to order Slates for school use; in the order now delivered at Mc Dames Post awaiting next spring's opening of the school, therefore a requisition for these supplies, under separate cover has been forwarded to the Department.

In conclusion, it is correct to mention that the school at Mc Dames has been the subject of much good talk amongst the Indians of this end of the Agency, and in every way has had good effects.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant.

Dear Sir:

Now is the time to look for a teacher for the Indian Summer School at McDame's. I beg to offer myself for the position. I have no ordinary teacher certificate but my full college course, not mentioning others, enables me, I believe, with my 15 years of missionary work in British Columbia, to fill the place satisfactorily.

It is difficult to find a man to come so far only for a three months' salary. Besides, as the only building now available to carry the class room work is the same building (under construction yet) that is being used for a church, there is always something broken if I am not there myself. Another thing; since the Department has not been able so far to give me any assistance towards the construction of a separate building at McDame's, the teacher's grant will help me some to continue what I started off my own last summer.

You will kindly remember that the teacher's salary for the past two summers was $120.00 per month and it is hoped that it will not be lowered. The conditions have not changed up there. It is still the same distance; over a thousand miles from here, a very costly trip and a great deal to do. Besides teaching school there is also all the work of a field matron to do. Last summer I had to walk through mountains and bush nearly a hundred miles only for two sick calls.

I hope the School Requisition for the coming term sent in through the Indian Agent at Telegraph Creek last September has been forwarded to the Department.

May I ask also that the grant be restored to $120.00 per month as it was originally. You have no idea how costly a trip and a sojourn of three or four months up there. I understand there is a special allowance for Indian Welfare Work for the Yukon because of the distances and the high cost of transportation. The Cassiar, and particularly Liard and McDames, is in that way every bit as bad as the Yukon.

Another thing. Now that there is a Doctor at Telegraph Creek, he will likely be asked next summer to take a trip down to Dease Lake, McDames and Liard Post. Unfortunately he will stay only a day or so in each place and the result of his efforts will necessarily be minimized. If a nurse would spend, let us say a couple of weeks at Dease Lake and Liard and the rest of the summer at McDames where the largest group of Indians is, the money spent by the Department, I think, would be well justified. I would be glad to try to find a nurse and help her along if the Department could only pay her travelling expenses which would be in the vicinity of $200.00 for the summer.

As it takes a considerable time to arrange things up here I am writing you this early hoping that it will meet with your approval.

Very sincerely yours,

Rev. E. Allard, O.M.I.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated May 8th, in regard to the establishment of Schools, for the coming summer months, at Mc Dames Creek - Liard Post, and Telegraph Creek, under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church Mission of these parts.

Submitted, herewith, is a letter from the Rev Father E. Allard, O.M.I., in which he informs the Department that, as last year, he intends to carry on the work of a teacher for the Mc Dames Creek Summer Mission School.

His Lordship Bishop Bunoz will arrive in Telegraph Creek, it is now understood, or or about July 4th, and of course he wishes to meet all his Indians and rather Allard must be present at that time. Therefore it will be impossible for the Mc Dames School to be opened, this year, until the arrival of the Bishop with rather Allard at that point. It will be opened as soon as possible.

At Liard Post no school will be conducted this season, again the Bishop will look the matter over, and come to some arrangement with the half-breed families, who should be the back-bone of such a school. It will then be possible to report upon the Indian side of the question.

At Telegraph Creek, again no school will be conducted, this important matter will be closely gone into by the bishop Rev Father Allard, the Indian agent, and all the Klappan Indians concerned. It is generally conceded, by everybody concerned - Indians, Townspeople, and Stores, that the school, if started must be outside the Town District, and there is now every reason to think such will be the case, with no more trouble.

The interview held with Rev. Father Allard, on the 26th inst was most satisfactory in every way, due it is thought to the practical contents of the Department's letter, and the Rev Father has called at the Office several times since, and is being assisted in every way possible.

Since 1930, he has contended that a water System should be allowed Dry Town, where his Mission is situated, and that the Department should assist. This meant a Grant of $800-00, to carry a water supply from the casca reserve, some distance back, to his Mission. At the interview it was explained that now the Indians were leaving the Town, owing to hard times, the project was rather expensive, so he has now decided to undertake the water supply, himself, and perhaps rent out connections here and there. This saves the Indian Office a lot of expense and trouble.

Therefore the matter of Schools will again rest in abeyance until His Lordship's arrival, and will be reported upon in due course.

I am.

The Secretary,

Dear Mr. Boss:

At this point your Indians are very few, a little over one family, but at times inside Indians rest awhile on this Lake during summer time. On the Reserve has been constructed a very decent little Cabin, which is used by your Mission each summer, when passing through to the Inside.

Mc Dames Creek. Here has been established a full going Mission Church and a Mission School in operation within the Church, up to now. In 1934 a School Building was constructed, quite large with living quarters upstairs. This building requires some finishing touches but can be used for school purposes right away. The School has been well equipped with school material, and is now only lacking, Scribblers, crayons, odds and ends. There have also been supplied picks and shovels for teaching purposes, i.e., drainage of Reserve. For this reason Teachers Salary will be granted, as requested, which should be from June 1st to September 15th. It is high time then for the Indians to return to their winter camps. The Department will be requested to again allow a small grant, to be used by the purchase of provisions, to drain the Reserve frontage. This Grant should be around the value of $50-00 and would act as summer relief to large families, under the supervision of the Teacher. It is requested that His Lordship Bishop Bunoz be asked to forward the name of the proposed Teacher, as soon as possible. The Teacher here will be fully engaged all the summer time. The attendance at this summer school is expected to be, not so good as in times gone by, for several families have gone towards Liard Post, where fur is still plentiful.

Liard Post. At this point your Mission has only been able to give occasional visits, but the intention was to construct a building of some sort, and use same as The Church and School. To this end a small waterfront Lot was obtained and marked out. Also Anderson the Trader was instructed to have some lumber cut, which he did, but later on, it is thought, sold the Material. We decided to allow this area to "wait" until at least until you can personally visit the point and see what is actually required. Therefore a Teachers Salary will not be requested for this point. It is correct to mention that the Indians visiting this locality are on the increase, owing to the fact that more fur is obtainable in the District. It is also easily arrived at from the lower reaches of the Muddy River, and drains some of the fur from Francis Lake, to the North.

Francis Lake District. It is a question as to if this Lake has ever been visited by your Mission, from Liard Post, but the Indians have come down to Liard Post and have been given attention by your Mission there. Upon visiting Francis Lake this summer it was found that nearly all the Indians with their children have been receiving attention from the English Church authorities visiting Belly Banks & Ross River Trading Posts. The Doctor and Agent were shown cards to that effect dated as recently as 1934. However a H.B.C. Post has now been established on Francis Lake, and perhaps the Indians will reside there permanently, but this is not expected by this Office. We decided that this area will also rest in abeyance until visited by yourself when it will be possible to take the matter up again.

This, it is thought covers the Indian work of your Mission in these parts, and has been gone over in detail, as you are totally unacquainted with the Interior, and is submitted only as an outline of matters, and might be of some little value. It is desired to state in conclusion that if at any time, or in any way, this Office can be of any service towards helping along the strenuous and good work being strived at by your Mission, it is entirely at your service.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Harper Reed, Indian Agent.

Dear Father Boase', at the request of the Indian Office, you were good enough to come up, on the evening of the 4th inst., and together we went into the matter of your Mission's future work, in this part of the Stikine Agency; this letter is to confirm the decisions then arrived at. It was found that your Mission work covers the following Districts - Telegraph Creek - The Klappan Band of Indians - The Caribou hide band of Indians - Dease Lake Indians - Mc Demos Creek Indians - Lizard Indians, and some few Indians now residing up at Francis Lake Y.T. In all a huge district for the correct regulation of which, assistance will have to be afforded you. Taking the districts in turn we start with:

Telegraph Creek. This is the Headquarters of your Cassiar Mission and your Church House here serves the Indians of the Town, with also those of the Klappan Band, who arrive here during the short summer season, for fishing purposes etc. Also some few Indians that come in from Shesley way, to the north of this Town. The good work done will be continued.

Klappan Band of Indians. We both agreed that during the last few years these Indians have not much improved in their ways of living, and that the less they are around the Townsite, the better for them all. Two sample cases were spoken of, i.e., those of Isobell Reid, and Ida Cocks Girl - Mary Ann.

However it was thought, that as they will come in during the Spring time and live on the Reserve across the river, that their children might as well receive some schooling; which we also thought would be interesting in its way. Therefore the Grant of a Salary by the Department, for a Teacher here, should be accepted, and His Lordship Bishop Bunce requested to supply the name of a Teacher for the summer months of May-June, July & August. The Department is also to be requested to supply the necessary school material; i.e., the same as that of Mc Demos Creek, but that no desks were required at present. We would then observe how this arrangement proceeds. Meanwhile you were kind enough to offer to go out to the Klappan winter Camp sometime soon, and see these Indians and find out, whether or not they would establish a permanent winter Base, in some good spot, where their families could gather, a school started for their children, which would free their men to earn a living from trapping, their only real main supply of revenue. To aid this idea the Indian Office agreed to supply wages for Dog Team and necessary provisions for trip.

Caribou Hide Band. This Band, being so remote, little could be arranged at the present time, but it was hoped that a visit by the Indian Agent would be paid them this winter, and their affairs gone into. Perhaps it would be possible to join them up once more with the Klappan Band, especially if a winter Camp or Village is started.

Which total is a most respectable amount for one Mission. However, when looked at closely, it is found to contain some little Relief work, but more especially, the settlement of a nomadic band of Indians, who are fast increasing in numbers, and who can and will increase their fur revenue, if some settlement is brought about.

The Mission's work at Liard Post B.C. is at present most uncertain, as stated, it will have to be personally inspected by Father Bosse; and even after that inspection it is fancied that not much action will be taken around this District.

With further regard to the Affairs of the R.C. Mission Schools, in these parts, as instructed under the above references; heresunder is submitted further progress for your kind consideration.

Last summer all Mission work came to a sudden halt with the drowning of the late Father E. Allard O.M.I., but His Lordship, Bishop Bunoz, carried out an inspection of his Missions here, and obtained a comprehensive knowledge of matters generally.

The result of all this being that late in the fall, the Rev. Father Leo Bosse' O.M.I., arrived to take charge of all the work hereabouts. We have worked together ever since, and it is wished to state, that Father Bosse's views in regards to the betterment of the Indians, coincide exactly with the views held by the Indian Office. The Father was quite unacquainted with the interior, and his work generally; so we met, came to some working arrangement, a "resume" of the meeting will be found attached, in copy letter form.

It will be observed that the Mission wish to operate two Summer Schools, one at Telegraph Creek, within the Church building - the other at Mc Dames Creek, to be carried on as usual. Two teachers will be requested from Bishop Bunoz to carry on these schools, for Father Bosse' will only supervise the Mission's work, during summer times.

The copy of letter attached covers all details, but Father Bosse' considers it absurd to fancy that a school during the summer months, within this Townsite, will achieve success. He states that he is not willing to teach such a school, but, that as His Lordship Bishop Bunoz thinks it is correct to make a trial of same, this could be tried. The Department would be requested to fully supply this school, and should it not meet with success, the school material could be used elsewhere.

The letter attached mentions a visit to the Klappan Band of Indians by Father Bosse' this winter. This has been accomplished. The very Indians who signed a petition for a Summer School, as above, now sign a new petition to have a village established out in their trapping district, and a Winter School established next winter. This Father Bosse' is most willing to undertake and conduct. To here, in the fall, could be sent the school material ordered for the town trial summer school, which we consider will be poorly attended, if allowed.

The visit to Klappan Indians by Father Bosse' was very successful, not only have they started to cut logs for a School House, but they have in addition, decided to construct a "work-shop" in which Father Bosse' will give wood-cutting instruction.

Sir,

The Mc Dames R.C. Mission is situated in the middle of the Cassiar, to which point transportation is rather lacking towards the end of the summer—there is no mail to this point.

This means that the Schoolmasters Returns are delayed and consequently his Pay Cheque is also behind hands.

Several years past, they have finished their work inside and have appeared at the Indian Office requesting an advance of cash, to see them down the B.C. Coast, as their Cheque had not arrived. Two years ago this was granted, but it was six months ere a return of the loan was made. This year Mr Anglin is requesting information regarding the arrival of his August Salary.

Therefore may the Authority be granted to the Stikine Indian Office to pay such salaries at the end of the season from the Office direct, and same to be treated and vouchered for, as repayable to the Indian Agent, as is now being done with ordinary cash payments from this Office.

Were this favour allowed, it would help these young Schoolmasters to a great extent, as it is almost impossible for them to save any of their Salary after a season in this expensive district.

I am,

Sir:

I beg to submit hereunder, a special report on the progress accomplished by the R.C.Mission with their various schools etc throughout the southern part of this agency.

MCDAMES CREEK

On the reserve at this point is a very excellent Church and some ways away, on higher ground stands a more excellent school house. A fresh school teacher seems to arrive for duty here, every year. However for 1938 it is thought that Father Poulette, now at Liard Post, will take over the charge of this summer school. The salary allowed for this school is $110.00 (158-3-1), owing to the higher cost of provisions. For the past summer Mr. Anglin (late British soldier-service in Soudan) was in charge, and much good work accomplished. He was however a little too earnest in his efforts with the nomadic children, who could not respond to his requirements as soon as wished. Here again the Schoolmaster, who resides on the reserve, should be requested to keep order, or at least report disorder, whilst he is there, to the Indian office and police. School progress however was good. Requirements for season 1938 will be restocking the worn out school supplies.

Extract from letter dated July 27th, 1938, Indian Agent Harper Reed, original on file 160-5:

McDames Summer Day School. This was the Agency's first venture and was started by the late Father Allard - it was a success from the start, and went along fine until we lost Father Allard by drowning. Father Bosse then took charge and the change was noticed. Father Bosse gave this attention and also Liard Post visitations at the same time and it was really too much. Lately we have had separate teachers and the school has shown good results until this year. This season, owing to several reasons, the Indians have all side slip'd to Liard Post - there is more excitement at that point. Also owing to sickness in two families, and the fact also that they were questioned last summer in regard to the McDonald Murder charge, undertaken by Corporal Blatta of the R.C.M.P., these two families with a lot of school youngsters, have not reported in to McDames Creek this summer. It has all meant that the attendance is low. However, it is most certainly expected that all the McDames Indians will return again to that point - next summer. His Lordship thought that a winter school here also would be perhaps good. The office point of view is that it is not quite possible. Should this take place these real nomads would just come in to the Post and sit down, and beg rations - it would eventually be very expensive, and wind up in trouble with the Indians going away again to the "woods". McDames is the centre of the cartwheel arrangement of trapping grounds around that district, but is too large for Indians to be running in and out during the trapping season. This school should be retained as it is.
Telegraph Creek, B.C.
February 12th, 1939

Sir,

Re: Mc Dames Reserve Summer School, R.C. Mission.

I beg to submit herewith a Requisition for School Stationery that is required for the summer term of the Mc Dames Reserve School. Perhaps it might be remembered that this same list was forwarded last Fall for this school, but owing to delay in other school supplies - they were used elsewhere.

No word has yet been received from His Lordship Bishop Bunoz as to who he wishes as a Teacher for this School, but it is understood that Mr. J.A.M. Anglin (now teaching at Caribou Hide) will be sent to that point.

Last summer Mr. Anglin was in charge, his school term was from June 1st. to the end of August. His pay was at the rate of $110-00 per month, payable through this Office. It is respectfully considered that the same regulations should be observed this coming summer, and therefore may the necessary Authority be granted.

Mr. Anglin called at this Office ere returning to Caribou Hide last month, and the matter of attendance was taken up with him. We found that a possible 24 children could be in attendance at Mc Dames next summer, but it is thought that if a steady 18 youngsters can attend the school would be worth running. However some families bring in their children and "then lay down" and expect Rations, Mr. Anglin was told that he would have to watch out for such actions and perhaps send a family "out" now and again to either fish or hunt meat. However should the Indian Families return from their trapping and gather at Liard Post, then perhaps the attendance at this school would be very low, but in any case, the families living around the Mc Dames Post alone would turn in over ten children.

No Grant for extra equipment is required here, the excellent school house is complete, but perhaps an allowance for Trenching, and perhaps a Drum of Thick Oil to reduce the Fly Pest (very bad at this point) might be considered. It is thought a hundred dollars would cover both items.

I am,

Sir,

Re: Mc Dames Creek, B.C., R.C. Mission School.

I beg to submit a Report on the above Seasonal Summer School, covering the summer of 1940.

Under the Authority 158-3-1, February and March 1940 permission was granted to open the above school, for the duration of three months. The Salary allowed was at the rate of $100.00 per month, and some extra school equipment was allowed, i.e., Fly Tox etc., along with the usual school material supplies; all of which was duly obtained and forwarded. The Rev Father O'Carpettier, O.M.I., eventually took charge, as Teacher for the summer and his school returns have been forwarded as received.

However his Returns cover only 23 months, his reason for the loss of half a month, is laid to the fact that fresh meat and fish are hard to obtain around and near the Post of Mc Dames, and the Indian families could not maintain themselves on "Store Provisions". Therefore the school closed early, and the Indians went off to the woods. It is his intention, if allowed, to open up the school next summer on June first, when he hopes to give a full three months teaching to these youngsters.

The Reports submitted show a good attendance, and the School is certainly worth the expenses incurred. It is drawn to the attention of the Department that some few children who have attended this last summer, do not belong to this Agency, but with their folks have wandered up from the Agency to the South, and are really Finlay River Indians. Father Carpentier's attention has been drawn to the fact that if these children are allowed to attend, bringing, as they do their parents with them; the Department should be first requested to grant permission for such actions. It is found that these families do not return to their Agency for the trapping season but rather hang around with the Mc Dames Indians and trap on our Registered Trap Lines. This brings hardship on our Indians, and they for their part do not like to protest, on account of "bad blood" between themselves. Father Carpentier states that "The Jack Abou Family when asked why they come up this way, state that the Game Wardens down on the Finlay River don't want us, and they say that we can go up north." These Indians were instructed to return to their own Agency, but it is understood that they have only returned half-ways.

The Liard Post School Report deals with trapping matters to some extent, and here, at Mc Dames Post, the same sort of affairs have an over-riding effect on the Mission School. This School was the original one opened up in the Interior of the Cassiar, and owing to its very central location, should be allowed to continue its good work. Whilst the Game and Fish are not as plentiful as in the years gone bye, yet there should be no need for the Indians to suffer for want of same during three summer months. Extract from Indian Agent Sampson's letter dated April 28, 1944.

The alternative to this suggestion would be to endeavour to purchase the Missions' share in the schools but I would definitely not recommend this course as I believe that it would be far less expensive, even over a period of years, to pay an annual rental of $75.00 in the case of the Dease Lake and Klappan schools and possibly Lower Post or McDevitt Creek if Fisher operates, than to purchase these crude log buildings and try to improve them. From past experience it seems that the operation of these bush schools is quite provisional, depending as it does upon whether or not the Indians camp at the location of the school during the usual term. At the present time it seems that any extensive outlay for establishing day school buildings would be unwise, especially in the more remote locations because it is evident that the Indians in this area as a whole are still not inclined to settle permanently in one location. Their houses in and near Telegraph Creek and the most used are used only as stopping over places between their trapping and fishing seasons. This has been more evident during the past fall and winter when these people have had to earn their living from the country, as they did prior to the freighting boom from 1941 to 1943 when supplies were going in by this route to Watson Lake Airport. It seems that the life-long habits of the Indians will not easily be changed, even to ensure the education of their children and the more or less temporary bush schools will probably have to serve, at least for the present.

**REMARRS AS TO PROGRESS, ETC.**

Due to most conditions the Indians of this Reserve had to pull out early in their land ground this fall, with the result of the close of the school 15 days before the regular end.

Four more children went out at the beginning of this month.

The others pulling out necessarily closed the school on August 30th.

To avoid the same inconvenience next summer, I obtained of those Indians the promise to come before June 1st, in order the children may have 3 full months of school.

It is evident these people can't stay any longer on the Reserve, the game has very scarce around and no work been allowed to them.

The Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

The summer school at McDames is closed for the season. As you may have already seen by the reports for June, July and August there was a very large attendance of children as soon as all the Indians got back from the woods. It would seem that with that second experiment it can be taken for granted that the Indians at McDames want a school for their children. The teacher, Mr. Bowrey, did very well in every way.

For two summers the school has been conducted in what is now the only building on the reserve. It is also used for a church and the missionary's residence during the two months or so of his work at that point. It is not yet completed and cannot be as long as it is being used for a school during the months that I am at that place. Would the Department kindly consider the inconvenience I have to put up with. I did not mind it as long the venture was in an experimental stage but now that it seems to be a success would not the Department give at least some kind of a grant towards a separate building for next spring.

Before leaving McDames this time I gave the contract to two men to haul the logs and whipsaw the lumber this fall so that it will be ready for next spring at the cost of $396.00. It will cost approximately another $400.00 to bring in windows, shingles or paper for the roof, plane the floor, window jams and casings (by hand) and put up the building. If not all of that sum perhaps a part of it could be given for next spring.

I shall return to Fort St. James for the winter in a couple of weeks. Will the Department kindly acknowledge this report and also send the teacher's cheque for August to Fort St. James, B.C.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

E. Allard, o.m.i.

I have your letter of the 10th ultimo, regarding the summer school at McDames.

A cheque in payment of the teacher's salary for the months of July and August will be sent you in due course.

Regarding your request for assistance to erect a school building, and stating the cost of the work which you are having undertaken in the hauling of logs and whip sawing the lumber and in the other materials required in finishing the building, I have to say that the Department is unable at the present time to state definitely what assistance, if any, can be provided towards the cost of the work.

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, enclosing a communication from Rev. H. Allard, O.M.I., requesting that the supplies mentioned by him be furnished for the use of the McDames Creek Indian Summer Day School, and also that the sum of $30 be allowed in order to dig a trench from the bank bench to the river bank—a distance of approximately 100 yards.

In this connection I have to say that, when you consider it timely, you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of 50 lbs. of Oakum, one brush hook, one pick, one wheel barrow, one quart Flit, 4 tins Bubac and one gallon of grey paint. You should forward a certified account, in triplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

Regarding the digging of the trench, the Department will allow an expenditure not exceeding $28.00 in the issuing of staple provisions to the Indians who do the work. The Rev. Father should see that the Indians perform the labour satisfactorily in digging the trench, which, it is noted, should be 5 ft. deep, with a 4 ft. bottom. You should also forward accounts, in triplicate, for the expenditure incurred in the issuing of provisions, the cost of which should not exceed the amount authorized above.

Your obedient servant,

During the visit of Inspection to No Dames Creek The Inspector (G.C. Fragnell, Esq.) went across the river and looked over the operations of this R.C. Mission. In charge of same was Brother Lou Boose' C.M.I., with Mr Fitzpatrick as schoolmaster for this summer. The New School Building is now being used; it is an excellent building and much credit must be given this Mission for building so fine a place. The Inspector took views of same and will be reporting on the subject, when time permits.

However the late floods came so high that the Mission lost all their books. Some equipment was washed away. To mend such a state of affairs, the Department have already been requested to re-stock the school material. A wheel-barrow, with two shovels has been sent from this Office, with also a grub-hoe and two picks. This is necessary in their reserve Drainage Works.

The Inspector ordered a heater for this school which is to be of the usual kind—50 wall was "run converted." This has been made up and is now enroute to that point. Books were requested, but for the time the usual "benches" will have to do.

All small necessities have been allowed this school, as instructed by Ottawa.

In the Estimates a sum of $30-00 is shown to cover just such an emergency as the late flood, and this sum will cover the extra equipment required, some of which has already been forwarded.

The liberty was taken of forwarding the above equipment, as the summers are so short, and the work was needed.

I am,

The Secretary,

Form No. 101
Dear Sir

Boat arrived today with letters, find enclosed paper in re my particulars.

Sorry that on my letter dated 17th ultimo I failed to express myself clearly, as to number of windows etc., likewise as to my intention. I had already priced fine wire at the local Hudson's Bay store, the same being (1) one dollar per yard on measuring its width. I found suitable to these windows in this school so I purchased (10) ten yards of same and have covered six windows four down stairs and two up, upstairs my living quarters.

The frames I made of slats of which I found a considerable number in the church here, these can be very easily detached in the fall before I leave here. Now all I actually wished to know was would the Indian department stand the price of the wire I have purchased.

Having windows covered has made a deal of difference and although the flies are bad we find none of them in the school.

July first has come and gone (sorry the soft balls and bats had not arrived at that time) we had a very good day here indeed, besides the ten dollars donated by yourself, the Hudson's Bay donated ten then Mr Meek and I went around the various whites here and with our own donations made it up to thirty-six dollars, this we spent in prizes and refreshments, all the prizes we purchased were for the school children. Some of the Indians thinking they would like to indulge in the sports collected certain monies and we organized events for them after the children's sports. One race being a four man relay race, Mr Wilms brought his crew down from the mine and we were able to get four teams in the relay which proved very effective in showing these people the spirit of competition.

After the races were over we had a soft ball game there being a ball we made a passable bat with a saplin. One game of Lacrosse completed the day, every one came away with the feeling of a day well spent.

My evenings are occupied in fixing a toilet for the school and making my quarters more habitable, am in a hurry to catch up with the remainder of my mail so wishing you a pleasant trip.

Submitted. Sir. as in connection Yours faithfully

with Mc Dames Day School Report forwarded last Mail.

Sir,

Re:- APPLIED FOR R.C. Mission Winter Seasonal School, JOHNSON VILLAGE S.TESLIN LK.

In an interview with His Lordship Bishop Couder O.M.I., in Atlin, B.C., February 25th last, at the suggestion of Rev Father Dreaan, O.M.I., His Lordship suggested that a winter School be opened up on the Indian Reserve at the mouth of the Jennings River - being at the south end of Teslin Lake. Again it is mentioned that the "Line" between the Yukon and B.C. cuts Teslin Lake in half - north and south. His Lordship stated that there were 56 people on this Reserve during the winter months.

Attention was given this application, or suggestion, but it was not reduced on paper as an Application.

It was pointed out that the Indians of that Reserve were mostly of the Church of England Faith, and that their children attended the Teslin Post school during the summer months. That nearly all the Johnston Family, who have houses at Johnston Village, took their families out trapping up the Jennings river, and were not at the Village all the winter long. Also that no children would go to school all the year around, and that the summer school at the Teslin Post was good and wanted, so that the children could have something to do, and keep out of harms way. No requisition has been received from the Indians as a Band, but that might be expected this summer, when the inspection of that point takes place. No doubt Father Dreaan has suggested such a movement, under favourable colours.

His Lordship was asked as to the number of Indians they considered of their Church, and as he did not know, Father Dreaan was given the Census List to mark, which he did. The result was that out of 149 persons at Teslin Post (or near abouts) he claimed 72 as R.C.'s and 19 doubtful - but that had stated they would be R.C.'s, leaving 58 to be considered as of the Church of England.

It was pointed out that ere he arrived in Teslin, all these Indians attended the Church of England Mission and all their children attend the school. This was not denied but an expressive shrug of the Rev Father's shoulders, was all the reply obtained regarding such a state of affairs.

Therefore it is considered that this suggested seasonal school, be laid in abeyance until Inspector Coleman can visit Teslin Lake and see for himself how matters stand. From the point of view of the Indian's correct living - that these children must be taught trapping etc - the summer school facilities now in operation at Teslin Post, or that could be arranged there, are sufficient for the time being.

The Secretary

In regard to opening a seasonal school under different religious auspices to that previously recognized for the Band in question, this would no doubt depend largely under the circumstances, but I am of the opinion that such defections should not be officially encouraged. The possibility of such general apostasy generally arises in this Province as a result of neglect by Protestant churches in their field of endeavour. Mr. Simpson will make a careful and unbiased investigation on the ground as soon as the Indians re-assemble and report on his findings with a recommendation.
Proposed Teslin Lake School.

While it was not brought to my attention by Mr. Reed, a perusal of the school files late in my inspection brought to light Department's letter of April 28th, 1941. File 156-10-1 stating that the matter would be investigated during my inspection visit and a report made in order that at some later date the advisability of conducting a seasonal school at this point may be investigated.

Apparently this is an Anglican mission and that the Indians are baptized into that faith, but that a Roman Catholic mission has opened up there claiming to have swung about half of the tribe over to their faith and that they wish the Department to open up a seasonal school under their auspices.

In the first place there are serious doubts as to the status of these Indians, whether they belong entirely or in part to this agency or to the Yukon Territory. If the latter it will necessarily be a matter for consideration and report by the Indian Agent at Dawson, as it is outside this Inspectorate. At the time of writing this report it is open to question whether I will be able to investigate the matter on the ground owing to the lateness of the season and that the Indians had scattered to their traplines before I arrived in the Agency. If any information can be secured this section of the report will be supplemented.

Investigating the status of Indians at Lower, or Liard Post I find fairly definite evidence that at least half of them are Yukon Indians and Teslin Lake is a similar boundary line problem.

Lower Post.

I have trouble in getting detailed estimates of the cost of buildings. As a matter of personal obligation I can get some local builder to give me a rough estimate of the probable cost but unless the Dept. is willing to pay for full plans and a detailed estimate, the estimate I have already sent in is about as near as I can get it. The cost is uncertain due to the fact that the Dept. sometimes asks for these estimates and does not authorize the expenditure until long afterwards when owing to increase in price of material or labour, the cost has materially increased. The cost of material was put at $250.00; labour, say $150.00; contingencies, say $40.00; probable cost of rafting the lumber round in the open sea from Clansone to Wyah, $60.00. If weather conditions were favourable, the latter might be done for $25.00. If the Dept. wished the school put up forthwith, it might cost $80.00 or the whole raft might be lost on the way, it being in the open sea.

The summer months would be the best time to erect it. If men went down there just now they might be carried past Goose for 3 trips, representing as many weeks before they were able to land.

The Nitinat, those of them who live at Wyah have been anxious to have a school for years so that their children might attend school but once started the attendance would not likely be any more regular than under similar conditions elsewhere, that is when the parents wanted to go to another reserve for business or plea-

The Secretary,

Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
Leisure, they would certainly go and take the children with them but at present I know they are really desirous to have their children go to school and the proposal to build only a school room at Wyah and let a male teacher walk over every day from Clarence and maintain another teacher at Clonese seems to me to be an reasonable and economical arrangement as could be made, provided of course that the Methodist Church agrees to this and undertakes to provide the second teacher.

I note that the Dept. asks for a definite recommendation from me on the subject. In that case I would say yes, build the school room and have another teacher but I would also say that the day school system in this Agency will never amount to much or do the best under the difficult conditions until the Dept. puts its feet down and insists that all teachers shall have a teacher's certificate to teach.

It is easier to teach white children than Indians and no white child in this Province is allowed to be taught unless by some one who has not only a teacher's certificate but also a normal school certificate showing that they have been taught how to teach.

The attendance being more irregular at Indian schools and as they speak a different tongue it would seem as if their teachers should certainly be as well qualified to teach as those who have charge of white schools. Some of the Churches seem to think any one will do to teach an Indian school. It would be invidious to give instances but the enforcement of a general rule that the qualifications of all teachers in Indian schools must be submitted to and approved by the Dept. before their appointment by the Church, would ensure that the teachers were at last qualified to teach.

My dear Mr. Scott:

A few weeks ago I had a letter from Mr. Neill of Alberni, B.C. stating that the Government were agreeable to building a school for the Indian children at Wyah. Replying to this I gave him my promise that we would furnish a teacher providing the Department would build a school and pay the salary. I have just had a conversation with Mr. Dockstader, the teacher who was there before Mr. Gibson, he informs me that the children are away from home from the end of June to October or November and that they are not many in number, also that is it impossible for a lady teacher to board with Mr. Gibson and get over to the school at Wyah, unless there has been a road built since his time. In view of this I have written Mr. Neill and also Mr. Gibson, stating that I could not give my consent to a scheme that is not feasible. You might look into the matter very carefully before going to the expense of building this school. From all I can learn I have serious doubts as to the wisdom of such a course.

At Kohsilah we have a little school house built on Methodist property off the Reserve. If a new site were secured on the Reserve and a building put on it about three-quarters of a mile from the present site, I believe that one of the best schools
on Vancouver Island could be built up at that point, while the Indians are not many, they are all living on farms and stay at home and I believe are more anxious than the average to have their children educated. You will see from the recent reports that the attendance has been greatly improved. I would rather a good deal that a school be built at that point. I may say we have no play ground whatever, in connection with our little building, when we fence the property, which we have to do this year in order to satisfy our neighbors. You might give this matter your consideration.

We had the meeting of our Commission re Indian Affairs in Alberta and have arrived at a definite policy. A copy of this report will reach you in due time.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a request for the purchase of the school building at Wyah. As you are aware, the school at this point has not been in operation for a number of years. We have very little information as to the value of the building, and as to whether there is any likelihood that it would be required in future for school purposes.

I shall, therefore, be pleased if you will inform the Department as to whether you would recommend that this old school building be sold, or whether there is any need or retaining it for school purposes in the event of it being necessary to re-open the school at a later date. We are writing you for this information as the Indian Agent resides at some distance from Wyah and may not be able to supply the information. You might state the number of children of school age at this point, and what provision if any is made for their education, also whether any of the children from this point are in attendance at residential schools. I shall also be pleased, if you are in a position to do so, if you will state approximately the value of the school building at Wyah.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter No.159-5-5 Mar.14th,

I may state that the school building at Whyac is in such a state that it would take nearly one hundred dollars to repair it into a condition suitable for school purposes. In 1920 school was held for two months in the building, since that date on account of the unsanitary condition of building and non-residence of people no school has been held there.

A. I would recommend the sale of the building, the proceeds to go towards providing desks for the school at $7.00 each.

B. Besides several Indians, one white man named Matthews wishes to buy the building; I would suggest that it be disposed to Indians only.

C. Seven children of school age in Whyac six attending residential schools.
D. During the fishing season the children stay at school at 65.00.

E. I would consider $75 as a fair price for the lumber the building contains. I would also suggest that the site be still reserved for school or community purposes.

F. One of the applicants, Morris Hicks, wished to take possession last fall. I would not allow it; so he ordered me to remove the building off the reserve at once, as he was acting Chief in his father's absence. The rest of the people ordered him off the reserve and he has not returned.

G. I would recommend that the offer of Ernest Johnson be accepted.

Sam [signature]

The Deputy Supt. General
of Indian Affairs.
the beneficial results of same. The attendance is of such an extremely intermittent nature that during long absence from school the half wild pupils are apt to forget the teaching of a shorter period.

As to the localities where it may be considered necessary to establish day schools in the future, that knowledge can only be acquired as settlement or civilization advances which in its course naturally produces openings for such institutions. These can easily be located as the occasion arises.

Whilst upon this subject I may mention what my experience has forced upon my understanding in regard to the efficacy of day schools as a means of educating to any practicable degree the native children.

As so often before stated these people are forced in their continual struggle for existence, being self-supporting, to move throughout the year from place to place, being obliged on such occasions to take their
their children and for the most part their belongings with them, consequently for the time being the children are, in many cases, removed from school for long periods, the latter being established as a rule at the winter villages.

The Industrial Indian School at East Kootenay meets the requirements of these Indians known as the upper Kootenays.

On the lower Kootenay there are in the neighborhood of 70 children having no school in their vicinity. An Industrial School might, with advantage, be opened there at some future time; although these are such a good-for-nothing class of Indians it is doubtful if they would profit much by it.

In conclusion I may state that the conviction is forced upon me that with the exception of the Alert Bay School all the Industrial Indian Schools should in the meantime be increased to a capacity of
of 50 pupils, and that later, if funds are available, other similar Industrial Institutions should be established.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Sir,

I have the honor to report that the Rev. Mr. Stone on behalf of the Methodist Church has applied to me to re-shingle the whole or half of the building on the Nitinat reserve at Cla-cose used as a school & church. I requested him to send in duplicate application giving prices but he has not done so.

For the whole roof he states it will require 16 M. shingles & 40 lbs of small galvanized wire nails. The putting on will cost $1.00 per M. He states that half the above quantities would suffice for one side of the roof & the other side might last a few years longer but one side must be done at once.

The Methodists have worked well there & Mr. Stone was for many years their representative there but I can not see any good ground why the Dept. should be asked to do this work. Mr. Stone bases his claim on the fact that when erected this building was paid for by the Dept. At least they paid $500.00 which I believe was the total cost & he therefore assumes that as the building is the property of the Dept. it falls on them to keep it up.

I fail to see it in this light, & regard the $500.00 payment more as a grant in aid of the building in the same way as the Dept. has given grants towards building Boarding schools but never with the idea of thereby creating an obligation to keep them in repair thereafter. A grant in aid of any the building of a day school is rather unusual & if this request is granted other day schools will be asking for the same aid & will take the position that the fact that they were built without aid from the Dept. should be an argument in favor of, rather than against, their getting aid from the Dept. to repair them.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A.W. Vowell

Indian Agent.

Sir,

In accordance with Department's letter of Dec. 3, No. 143578, I beg to submit the following report on the Nunkunus Indian Day School.

Formerly, the Day School for the Ohiaht Band was situated on the Indian Reserve at Dodger's Cove, but as all the families with children of school age have resided for some time past on the Nunkunus Reserve, the Dodger's Cove school has been closed, and one opened at Nunkunus.

The school building belongs to the Presbyterian Church and was built by Mr. Ross, now of the Ahousaht Boarding School, but formerly missionary to the Ohiaht Band, who held school and service in this building a few years ago. The present teacher, Tom Shewish, is an ex-pupil of the Alberni Boarding School, with an ordinary boarding school education.

He has been employed by the Presbyterian Church, under the supervision of Mr. Currie of the Alberni Boarding School. He has been supplied with school material, at different times from this school. The school is not opened regularly; sometimes owing to the teacher's absence, and very often to the absence of the children. Dear Mr. Scott:

You are aware that Dodger's Cove has for some time been neglected. It was not found possible to find a suitable person and besides when Mr. Ross left he felt that the habits of the Indians and the tendency towards Bamfield made it unprofitable investment of a life. There is a young Indian, named Joseph Samuel in the Indian School at Ahouscht, who has been a leader in the evangelistic movement in that village. Evidently he is proving a great blessing to his own people. Mr. Ross recommended that he be appointed as missionary and teacher to Dodger's Cove and undertook to take oversight of him if such appointment were made. He suggests that the salary should be $25 a month and that the engagement should be for short periods at first in order to properly test him. Our Committee has agreed to the suggestion, and with your approval would like to see Joseph Samuel tested in that way. He is evidently a lad of not only ability but of spiritual attainment, that is quite unusual amongst the Indians. Mr. Ross in a letter just received, states that a number of the pupils and three women were at the Rancherie when he was writing, asking for Christian baptism and he also stated that another young lad is ready to take Joseph Samuel's place as soon as he leaves. He would like to have him enter upon his duties upon the last of May. This is a development that is, I think, of peculiar interest and should it prove satisfactory, is along the lines we have often longed for. I shall be very glad to have your approval of this appointment.

I am,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Redley:

Mission work amongst the Indians in Dodger's Cove has been exceedingly embarrassing. The Band has been for years divided into two sections, - Nunkakamus and Dodgers. The frequent changes from place to place have necessarily impaired school work. Since Bamfield has begun to grow a section of the Band is moving there and all threaten to move. In addition to this the merchant who had a store at Dodger's Cove has moved to Bamfield and on that account the steamer that used to call regularly at Dodger's Cove has ceased to call. This leaves Mr. John Ross, the missionary, not only isolated, but unable to secure attendance at the school.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of 9th inst.,

No. 357280, asking for information re the school situation among the Chiat Indians, I beg to report as follows—

The Presbyterian Church have maintained, or have been supposed to do so, a teacher among this band for some ten years or so past. The teacher taught day school when the pupils were available. For long intervals sometimes lasting over a year and more at a time, there was no teacher and the work done was entirely lost. Then another teacher would be sent and another spasmodic effort made. If the work is to be continued along these lines, then certainly a Boarding school would be better as the Church would have to keep some kind of a staff continuously on the ground.

Some time ago when Mr. Ross was there he applied to the Church for permission to start a small boarding school and at that time I would have endorsed his application. Since then conditions have changed. Mr. Ross has gone away. There has been a change in the principalship of the Alberni school and the new principal, Mr. W.A. Hendry, since resigned, induced an Chiat man to sign in two of his children into the Alberni Boarding school. It is to be hoped that the ice once broken, others may follow his example.

As Alberni school has a grant for 50 pupils and has never been able to fill up to that number and as Alberni is only some 35 miles from the Chiat reserves and mostly inside, i.e., smooth water, it would seem as if it was the natural solution for the Chias to patronise the Alberni Boarding school, helped out by a

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
properly conducted day school on their reserves.

The number of children of school age among the Chiats is now about 28, two of whom are in the Alberni Boarding School. Of the 28, experience in similar cases lead one to expect that a local Boarding School would get about 17 or 18 pupils, which is rather a small number for a Boarding School.

The Church have now got two day schools and two teacher's houses on the Chiats reserves, one each at Dodger's Cove and at Kukumkamis. If they would pay salaries to induce competent people to undertake the work and stay at it, I think for the present at any rate under all the present conditions, that it would be as well to retain the day school system there and let the teacher try and induce the older children to spend a year or two at Alberni Boarding School.

I may mention here a constant source of trouble in connection with getting Indians to sign in their children into boarding schools.

By the rules of the Dept., a child can be kept in until it is 18 years old. That, in this Agency at least, is too long.

These people have lived for centuries in the open air. A child taken into a school at 8 spends ten years in the school. After that its constitution is so weakened that it has no vitality to withstand disease. These Indians come to maturity so much sooner than whites that it is like keeping white children in a boarding school until they are 22 or 23.

It leads to immorality among the children unless they are watched like convicts. It leads to all sorts of concealed bargains between Indian parents and principals who, anxious to get children in, are pressed to promise the parents that they shall get their child out in a specified number of years, often four or five.

Then if the parent has neglected or been unable to make this private arrangement with the principal, he will start when his boy or girl is about 15 years old and perjure himself and suborn all his friends to do the same in an effort to convince me that
the child is 18 years old and should therefore be discharged.

I think that all the school principals agree that 18 years is too old. If the Dept. would allow the children to leave when they are 15 or even 16 or better still allow the parents to sign them in for a specified time say five years or seven years according to age at admission, I am sure that more children would attend the Boarding schools, that less deaths would take place among the pupils, and more especially among the ex-pupils, and I think that for the first generation grown from what is practically barbarism, the children should learn enough in five years to fit them for life on their reserves as they will find it during their lifetime and the next generation can be taught more and longer.

I would also recommend that a quarterly inspection of each individual pupil be made by the medical officer, not a casual glance round the room full of children but have their lungs sounded on the first symptoms of tubercular trouble, let the child be sent on sick leave for a time, very often (at that early stage) ensuring complete recovery for the sick child and always, at the least, guaranteeing freedom from infection for the other children.

For the present therefore, I would recommend the continuance of the day school on the Ohiat reserves provided a teacher can be kept there regularly.

I note the appointment mentioned in the last paragraph of your letter of Miss Johnson as teacher there. Miss Johnson did good work in charge of the Alberni Boarding school many years ago but I fear she will find the position a very difficult one, a solitary woman alone among these Indians and with no white person within several miles and absolutely cut off by water from being able to communicate even with them in case of necessity.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Sir,

Some twelve years ago the chief of Cayugan sent a deputation of his Indians to the Roman Catholic Bishop requesting him to locate a priest in their tribe. This request was granted, and ever since, with the exception of a short interruption, a priest has resided here. A fine church and a missionary's residence were built on the land given by the chief. A few, who always were opposed to the chief, follow him; and cause disturbance where there was none before. This minister has rented a house on the Reserve in spite of my opposition, and he says he will build a house and church in spite of me. The enclosed letter I have written at the request of the chief of the Chippewas, who signed it, understanding that it has always been the policy of the government, as much as possible, to prevent two denominations from going to the same Indian tribe; and why, as far as the past history of this province shows, that the presence of two denominations in one tribe leads to endless troubles and difficulties. SIR,

I beg to report as follows in reply to your letter of 14th inst., No. 255855/1 re the proposal to grant for the Methodist day school on Opitseat reserve.

Re Miss Johnson the present teacher, I wrote to her asking for her teacher's certificate and she replies that it was sent to the Dept. about two weeks ago. She does not hold any nursing diploma. So far as Miss Johnson is concerned, there is very little to report. She no doubt did her best with the conditions as she found them. I am told she is likely to leave soon. In any case she might do so at any time as it is the conditions which prevail which most need to be considered in view of the request for a grant.

If the Dept.'s letter indicated also a desire for my report on the situation generally I would say that it would be against making any such grant.

The Methodists discontinued the day school early in 1908 and I had hoped that they realized that they would do far better by confining their attention to the medical part of the work and the hospital. Miss Johnson has only sent in one quarter's report since the school was reopened.

The census shows about 28 or 29 children of school age in the Clayoquot band. There is a large Industrial school of about 60 to 70 pupils within 3 miles from the reserve. It would probably be reasonable to suppose that at least ten to fifteen of these pupils come from the Clayoquot band. This would only leave 15 or 16 children to attend two day schools on the reserve. This number must be further reduced in view of the fact that the Opitseat

To The Secretary,

Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
reserve is only one of the many belonging to this band and while
the Opitsat reserve is the principal home, yet there is always
a considerable number at any given time who are not living
on the Opitsat reserve and very often the bulk of them are absent
for periods. There certainly not enough pupils to justify the
maintenance of 2 schools and very often not enough for one.
The consequence of two rival schools is bad for the work.
These Indians are far from civilised; as to the distinction between
the Roman Catholic and the Methodist faith, they knew little and
care still less. As one of them told me once, they think it is a
good thing to have two rival teachers on the reserve because it
is like having two stores, when they can't get a thing from the
one store or teacher they can play off the other store or preach-
er as the case may be. For instance if the Catholic priest were
to scold them on Sunday for getting drunk or to inform on
them, the attendance of their children would at once fail off,
they would deliberately send them to the rival school. I have
seen this happen both ways. Of course any attempt at exercising
discipline during school hours would have much the same effect.
Now when the Methodists reopened their school last fall, it was
alleged that they offered inducements to get the children to
attend. Either something of that kind was done or else the novelty
of a new teacher and a lady, or perhaps a combination of both
certainly proved successful for they got nearly all the pupils.
I have not a note of the exact figures, they would be seen on a
reference to the Dec. Q.R. report of the Methodist day school but
I knew the average was large and the enrolment much more so.
But the novelty has worn off, the average attendance for this Q.R.
up to date is 4.3 and for this last week, 1.6.
Miss Johnson herself admits that a Govt. grant under present
conditions is "quite uncalled for."
The Methodist church got a per capita grant for their hospital
at Clayoquet, which is close to the reserve. Unfortunately the
Church had to close it saying they did not get enough support.
This hospital was a success and was a blessing to many of the
Indians and I would heartily endorse a proposal to give such support to this branch of the work as would enable the Church to reopen it.

I am convinced that it would be in the best interests of the Indians to have only one school on the reserve and to encourage the hospital to keep open. I may explain that the hospital is of use not only to the Clayoquot band, but to the rest of the Agency which lies north and west of Clayoquot, comprising some 1500 Indians.

Possibly if the Dept. felt disposed to aid the Methodist church in an extension of their day school located at Clacose on the Nitinat reserve, they could arrange with the heads of the Methodist church to withdraw from the day school work at Clayoquot on condition of getting help at Clacose where they could do far more good. The circumstances of the situation at Clacose are set out in my letter to the Dept. under date of the 5th inst., letter no. 398-13.

Sir,

The room which I occupy at present in the Indian School is a room in my own house 18 feet long by 14 feet wide and 8 feet high. Dear Sir,

His Lordship the Rt. Rev. Bishop Secumus has appointed me permanently to the Mission of Clayoquot. I have the honor to inform you that I intend to reopen the school for Indian children on this Reservation; in fact I have reopened it already since four months, I am applying for the customary grant allowed by the government.

The Indians are very well disposed towards the school; they are anxious that it should be kept permanently and that their children attend regularly; at present I have an average attendance of 15; but with better accommodation and a new stock of school supplies, I am confident that during the two winter quarters (when all the Indians are here) I will have an average attendance of 25.

As to school supplies, since the school has been closed so long, I find none but an old dilapidated stock. Consequently the whole should be replaced by a new supply for at least 30 pupils. Some of my pupils are sufficiently advanced to begin with the second Reader; others can follow in the first Reader, while the majority are beginners.

I trust therefore that you will make such representations to the Department as will secure for my school the customary Government grant and have forwarded to me a full set of school supplies for at least 30 pupils; together with such information and instructions as are necessary, to carry on the school in accordance with the requirements of the Department.
