Hon. Sir,

A few weeks ago when holding an interview with the Indians of the Nootka tribe, West Coast, it was stated by the Indians that a Presbyterian Minister had come among them and that the minister had told them that he had been sent at your own suggestion, and with your personal instructions to establish himself in their midst. The Catholic Priest, as you are aware, has labored among the Indians for several years and should his methods not have proved successful and satisfactory, I venture to say that the Department, as well as the Indians themselves would have been served much better both materially and religiously, had the Priest in charge received a timely instruction to employ more effective means in bringing them under the influence of Christian civilization, than by the presence of an opposing minister. Giving due consideration to the principles of religious liberty, I am however constrained to say, owing to peculiar local circumstances and vacillating proclivities of these Indians that the presence of the minister will prove a detrimental experiment, not only from a religious but also a worldly standpoint. An impartial observer cannot but admit, upon a personal investigation of the case under consideration, the truth of what I have said. Recognizing the very grave responsibility I owe, as a citizen, to our Government for the civilization of these Indians, and impressed with the sacredness of my office regarding their eternal salvation, I endorse strongly and unreservedly the remonstrance of Chief Napoleon Aquinna enclosed. Dear Sir,

I have been informed this morning that some short time since a Presbyterian Minister commenced his labours, much to the disquietude of the Indians, amongst the Nootka tribe on the West Coast and that when remonstrated with against interfering with a people who had been cared for during the past several years by a Missionary of a different denomination, it being very properly urged that to do so would be unwise & not in the interests of the Indians or of religion, it was stated by the Presbyterian Missionary that he went there with my instruction & at my personal suggestion. Should I be induced to express an opinion in reference to such matters that opinion must certainly be in accordance with my convictions which are, after many years observation, opposed to the conflict, more or less, of religious denominations amongst the untutored Native races, as such a course is more apt to confirm them in their old superstitious beliefs than to convert them to the Christian doctrines.

Dear Sir:

Your letter re Nootka came to hand a few days ago, but owing to pressure of work I was unable to acknowledge it earlier.

I must say that I was very much astonished at the statement made to you on the authority of Indians at Nootka, that our Missionary said to them that he went to Nootka by your "instructions and approval". Our Missionaries are too intelligent to suppose it is part of your office to send out teachers to any field, and too honest to willfully state an untruth. I have no reason to believe that you knew that the Presbyterian Church had appointed a Missionary to any part of Nootka Sound, until you received the letter complaining of his presence there. I intended submitting the matter for your approval when I had all the data necessary for your information.

Mr. Oswald, one of the young Ministers of our church, went to Nootka only about three weeks ago, and the next boat after his arrival will not reach there until the 24th inst., so it is rather soon to make so much ado over the affair, in asking his removal.

Mr. Oswald went to Nootka with the instructions and approval of the Foreign Missions Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, by whom he was appointed. I may also say that I am the convener of the Foreign Missions Committee of the Synod of British Columbia, and that of the Presbytery of Victoria, in whose bounds Nootka is, and that Mr. Oswald had my approval, for he and I discussed the question when we met at the Synod in May last, and also when I saw him at Ahousaht on his way to Nootka.

Our Missionary may have said that he went to Nootka, with my "instructions and approval", which is correct, and the Indians never probably having heard my name before, and being familiar with your name, may have confounded my name with yours; for unless distinctly pronounced they are very similar in sound: - Vowell - Campbell.

The statement alleged to have been made by our Missionary you say is not true, I believe it is not true, and I furthermore believe our missionary never made the statement. It is made on the authority of certain Indians, and evidently is believed by your informant, but are Indians always to be relied upon in statements which they make? If so what does your informant think of the following Statements.
statements made by the Indians to our missionary on his arrival at Nootka? He says-"We are informed the Indians are unanimous in desiring to have a School and Teacher, but that the first Chief was afraid".

1st Because Father Brabant threatened to deprive him of his Chieftanship should he give his consent to our coming.

2 To take away the cattle the Cattle he gave to Chief Maquinna(recently died)and Napoleon Maquinna succeeded.

3 To allow the Indian Deprament to keep the money due him for rent of store." They also stated that Father Brabant said if they allowed Protestant Missionaries to come to Nootka their Children would die,and the Missionaries would stop their dances,Potlatches,&c.&c.

I am scarcely prepared to believe that Father Brabant would so far forget himself as to make these threats even to the scarcely semicivilized Indians of Nootka Sound,and yet the document which Chief Napoleon Maquinna sent you last week,a copy of which you kindly sent to me,in which,inter alia,he demands that our Missionary be ordered away from Nootka,seems to indicate that at least part,if not indeed the whole,of the above is true.

I forwarded your letter to our missionary,and in due time he will speak for himself,without fear or favor.

The policy of the Presbyterian Church has always been non-interference in fields occupied by another Church. This is clear to all who know the history of our Church in relation to the Indian work in Vancouver Island.

The fact that a Roman Catholic Missionary had been in a certain tribe at one time or another is surely not sufficient reason to protest against another Church taking up work there,when for years the Roman Catholic Church practically gave up the place,abandoned the work,and neglected the Indians. This has been the case in every place where our Church has taken up work among the Indians of Vancouver Island,viz. at Alberni,Ucluelet,Ahousaht,and Dodgers Cove.

Our Church was asked three years ago to send a teacher to the Indians at Nootka. She declined on the ground that she understood there was a Catholic Priest in that part of the Island. Again this year the representatives of forty families of the Nootka Indians,asked that we send them a teacher,saying that their children were not taught,their sick were neglected,and that Father Brabant was doing little or nothing for them. I and others refused at first to believe this,but on reading"Vancouver Island and its Missions-The reminiscences of the Rev.A.J.Brabant"-1874-1900"recently published, I was forced to conclude that all he did in reality was to celebrate Mass and Baptize the Children. This surely cannot be regarded as educating the Indians.Probably he was doing all he could for his Church had not given him the help she should have given to do the work as it should be done,and as the Government expects it to be done.

I am assured that all the Chiefs but one, and that Maquinna, wish our Missionary to remain at Nootka. Last June I myself was called on at Ahousaht by one of the Chiefs of Nootka, who said that they wanted our teacher, and if Mr. Oswald went to Nootka he would assist him to establish a School Mission, and would send his own children to the School, as Father Brabant was neglecting them. At Nootka Sound there are four tribes of Indians, extending over a large Sea coast, surely Father Brabant has not the monopoly of the whole of Nootka Sound, especially when the Indians are urgently calling for teachers from us, as the Roman Catholic Church has failed to do her duty to them.

What is the result of Father Brabant's work at Nootka? How many of the Nootka Sound Indians can read and write? Even Chief Napoleon Maquinna, the first chief of the tribe Father Brabant claims to have educated, signed his letter of remonstrance against our Missionary with "his mark". You would naturally ask, why do not your Church and the R.C. Church confer about the work among the Indians, and thus avoid friction through misunderstanding? When the R.C. Church takes down the wall she has built between us and her, or at least so lowers it, that we can more easily shake hands over it, our Church will be delighted and ready to confer with our Catholic friends, and move on together in the educating and christening of the Indians.

RE WEST COAST VANCOUVER ISLAND:

A couple of months ago, the Reverend Thomas Oswald, under appointment of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, proceeded to Nootka Sound with the purpose of establishing a mission in that locality.

Indians from various tribes in that sound had, for years, been requesting a Protestant teacher and a school, but until his arrival and survey of the field Mr. Oswald did not know which of the four tribes would be finally selected. In company with Mr. J.W. Russell, of Ahousaht, an experienced missionary, Mr. Oswald visited the various tribes, receiving invitations from the two largest to remain and open a school. Of these, the Cow-ach-ants, at Friendly Cove, seemed to be in the worst plight and his decision was to give them the preference.

There was, at Friendly Cove, a Roman Catholic Church, but the Indians claimed that the priest visited them but seldom—not oftener than once or twice a year—and that they had never had a regular school. These Indians are said to be generally illiterate. One of their number admitted to me, not long since, that they were a tribe of drunkards and gamblers. They are also much diseased in body and are utterly ignorant and superstitious. The Roman Catholics have apparently no control over the people, except through the first chief, who, for special reasons, as he has alleged on different occasions, favors that church.

As soon as the Roman Catholics learned of Mr. Oswald's intention to begin work at Friendly Cove, they at once took steps to prevent it. They started a school, applied to your Department for the usual school grant, and then approached the Department's office at Victoria in an effort to get Mr. Oswald ordered off the reserve.

As a result of this effort, I have a letter from Mr. Agent Guillod, of Alberni, dated August 8th inst., in which he says he is to notify Mr. Oswald that he is a trespasser on the Indian reservation at Friendly Cove.

Upon being asked the cause for so extraordinary an action as stigmatizing a missionary of the Presbyterian Church a "trespasser" on an Indian reservation, Mr. Guillod quotes from the Indian Act, "No person shall settle, reside, occupy or use any land without the license of the Superintendent General."

Referring to this matter, may I be permitted to point out:

1. The Rev. Mr. Oswald was not "settling, residing (upon) or occupying Indian lands in the ordinary sense of a 'trespasser.' He was asked by the Indians to remain with them and teach their children. As the Indian village occupies the only cleared land in the vicinity, the surroundings being rock, forest and water, in order to comply with the request, Mr. Oswald was obliged to secure temporarily a small house on the reserve until permission could be obtained from your Department to erect a suitable building.

2. The procedure followed by Mr. Oswald in this matter was the customary method in the past on the coast, and this is, so far as I am aware, the first instance of a Christian missionary having been ordered off a reservation as though he were there for some personal or evil purpose.
3.- Not only has it been the custom, in the past, to permit missionaries freely to preach the gospel to the Indians on this coast, but considerable leniency has been shown towards men who were on Indian reservations for other purposes than the welfare of the Indians.

I have personally known a white man of immoral repute to be on an Indian reservation almost within sight of the Agent's residence, and he was not molested until I objected (on moral grounds) to his presence. Even then, the Agent would not assume the odium of ordering him off himself, but sent a note to the constable saying that Mr. S. had complained, etc.

When the Ste. Cleveland went ashore in Barclay Sound, and a white man, who was married to an Indian woman, was seriously complicated with the Indians in looting the cargo, your Agent evidently considered the presence of this man on the reservation as a matter of course.

At another time, a man came to me and asked permission to remain on a reservation, claiming that the Agent would not interfere with him so long as I was satisfied. The store-keeper at Ohiaht remained on the reserve for years without having been ordered off, and it is difficult to understand why such a notice should have been sent to Mr. Oswald, except on the assumption that action was taken at the request of the Roman Catholic Bishop.

4.- Whilst we have no quarrel with the Roman Catholic Church, and believe that body to be entitled to the same consideration as any other, I desire to protest against its claim of special privilege in the natives of this coast being recognized by your Department's officials.

Your Department's Agent lays considerable stress upon the fact that the Roman Catholic priests have been on this coast for twenty-five years, have built several churches and baptized many children. And, in his reports (see p. 423 of No. 14-1900, An. Rep. Dep. of Ind. Affairs), he gives credit to the Roman Catholics of 560 converts out of a total of 2,421.

But, at the risk of being tedious, I desire to say -

(1) The Roman Catholics have not educated the Indians. Though they have been here so long, and have not been hampered by the stringent conditions regarding education enforced since the arrival of the Protestants, during my residence of over seven years among the Indians I have not seen one Indian who has been taught by the priests to read and write.

Nor would the Roman Catholics, even now, have been interested in educating the natives but for the fear Indian children might come under the influence of the Protestant schools. In the published Memoirs of the Rev. Father Erabant (Heshquah) he plainly states that the boarding school at Nisqually (which is subsidized by your Department) became necessary in order to save the Indian children from being educated by the Protestants.

(2) In reference to the moral improvement of the Indians, the position is much the same.

Of the buildings erected, those at Alberni, Ohiaht and Ahousaht have been abandoned, whilst that at Friendly Cove (from which Mr. Oswald is now ordered away) was only occasionally used until it was learned the Presbyterian Church contemplated beginning work in Nootka Sound.

The Indians, as a whole, do not show evidence of twenty-five years of Christian work. Except perhaps, at Heshquah, they are still practically heathen. They follow their old customs, practicing oomimitch and witchcraft and giving "potlatches" whilst their indulgence in drinking and gambling has not been materially checked by the prayers.
Nor is it likely the Roman Catholic Church would make a serious effort to put down these evils, in which the priests themselves indulge. For proof of this statement I beg to again refer to Father Frabant's Memoirs and to say that I have myself witnessed a Roman Catholic priest, the Indian Agent and two others engaging in a friendly game of cards, with a decanter of liquor on the table between them.

Nor is it simply in the evils of drinking and card playing that the influence of the priests has been on the wrong side. Apparently with the object of turning the natives against the Protestants, a Roman Catholic priest is said to have warned the Indians, on different occasions, that the Protestants or "Just Now" missionaries (as the Protestants have been named by the priests in ridicule) were seeking to put down potlatching, which is not only an ancient custom, but against which laws have been enacted by the Parliament of Canada!

For your information, I may say, the priest who thus encourages the Indians to break the laws of the land rather than permit the Protestants to secure an influence over them, is the one who has been on the coast for so many years, and who has so far won the admiration of your Department's Agent—the Reverend Father Embleton—of Hesquiat, at whose instigation Mr. Oswald is now being ordered off a reservation in Nootka Sound.

By further reference to Father Frabant's Memoirs, you may ascertain how so many Indian children were baptized by the Roman Catholics, and the basis of your Agent's report giving that church nearly a thousand converts on this coast. With such a system of counting converts the marvel is that any pagans are reported!

I have no doubt these reports have, at least to some extent, misled your Department as to the position of the Roman Catholics on this coast, and, unless they have been since altered, I would respectfully suggest an enquiry into the matter, and that a proper method be adopted of securing such information.

5.—Regarding the demand of your Department's Office at Victoria, that application be made for permission to reside on an Indian Reservation before any step is taken to open mission work, I may say, if this is insisted upon, it will place a serious barrier in the way of Protestant effort on this coast.

Men are not always available for mission work, and should application be made before the missionary is secured, the Church runs a risk of being unable to meet its engagement with the Indians. If application is made after a missionary is secured the delay may cause the loss of the missionary, who cannot be expected to wait for months until your Agent is able to interview the Indians, whose decision, in the absence of the missionary, is likely to be influenced by the Roman Catholic priests, who have free access to all the reservations and have only to impress the head chief in order to make their influence felt in the tribe.

Under these circumstances,—with which I feel certain you have not been made familiar,—I would respectfully suggest that instructions be given your Department's officials on this coast so to interpret the rules of your Department as to permit Protestant missionaries some latitude in their endeavor to preach the gospel to the Indians.

To the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,

OTTAWA, ONT.

(Over.)

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

M. Stewart

Re WEST COAST VANCOUVER ISLAND:

I beg to enclose copy of a letter written by your Department's Agent confirming my statement that your Department's officials here admit the claim of the Roman Catholic Church to a special propriety in the natives on this coast.

Ahousaht was occupied by the Roman Catholics many years ago for a short time. For one term - I think it was the Winter of 1889-90 - they conducted a school, and then they practically abandoned the place. About five years afterwards, the Presbyterians opened a school and work has been carried on by that Church ever since. The Indian children have been taught to read and write, and the tribe, as a whole, has been much improved.

Now, the priests are endeavoring to take the little girls away from the Protestant school and have them transferred to the Roman Catholic Boarding School at Claoquah.

Under ordinary circumstances, this evil would be rectified by reference to the Superintendent of Indian Agencies at Victoria; but when it is understood that this official admits the claim of the Roman Catholic Church to the whole West Coast, and has, only a few days ago, at the instigation of the Roman Catholic Bishop, and without interviewing the Indians, ordered a Protestant minister off a reservation, as a 'trespasser', you may realize that we, Protestant missionaries, tremble for the safety of our work.

I feel sure it is the wish of your Department to encourage the education of the natives, and that you will, as soon as you investigate this position of affairs on this coast, give the Protestants, who have been the means of securing to the Indians the opportunity to obtain an
education, at least equal rights with the Roman Catholic Church, which is proven by its twenty five years of unfruitful occupation of this coast to be incapable of elevating the Indian.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

RE WEST COAST VANCOUVER ISLAND:

On the 25th of August last I addressed a communication to you stating that one of our missionaries had been, at the request of the Roman Catholic Bishop, and without interviewing the Indians, ordered off a reserve as a "trespasser."

On Sept. 5th, I again wrote, quoting from a letter of your Department's Agent, in which he expresses the opinion that the Roman Catholics have a right to go anywhere on the coast, and to reopen stations long abandoned by them and held by us.

I also referred to the fact that Roman Catholic priests were endeavoring to take children from our Ahousaht Day school to their Claoquah Boarding school. Our missionary at Ahousaht appealed to Mr. Superintendent Vowell, Victoria, against this, enclosing declarations by parents that they were Protestants, and giving explanations as to the unfair method by which parents' signatures had been secured.

Mr. Vowell's decision - as anticipated by me in my letter of Sept. 5th - was adverse to us. Further, Mr. Vowell, in his reply, lays down the rule that "any difference that may arise as to the retention or discharge of this or any other pupil, or pupils, regularly admitted, should be settled between the school authorities and the parents themselves."

That is, - as I interpret this rule, -

1.- We are not to assist parents of Indian children even though (as is claimed in one of the Ahousaht cases) their consent to the removal of children has been obtained by misrepresentation. And

Sir,

Re West Coast Vancouver Island:

A couple of months ago, the Reverend Thomas Oswald, under appointment of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, proceeded to Nootka Sound with the purpose of establishing a mission in that locality.

Indians from the various tribes in that sound had, for years, been requesting a Protestant teacher and a school, but until his arrival and survey of the field, Mr. Oswald did not know which of the four tribes would be finally selected. In company with Mr. J.W. Russell, of Ahousaht, an experienced missionary, Mr. Oswald visited the various tribes, receiving an invitation from the two largest to remain and open a school. Of these, the Mow-ach-ahts, at Friendly Cove, seemed to be in the worst plight, and his decision was to give them the preference.

There was at Friendly Cove a Roman Catholic Church, but the Indians claimed that the priest visited them but seldom—not oftener than once or twice a year—and that they had never had a regular school. These Indians are said to be fearfully debauched. One of their number admitted to me, not long since, that they were a tribe of drunkards and gamblers. They are also much diseased in body and are utterly ignorant and superstitious. The Roman Catholics have apparently no control over the people, except through the first chief, who, for special reasons, as he has alleged on different occasions, favours that church.

As soon as the Roman Catholics learned of Mr. Oswald's intention to begin work at Friendly Cove, they at once took steps to prevent it. They started a school, applied to your Department for the usual school grant, and then approached the Department's Office at Victoria in an effort to get Mr. Oswald ordered off the reserve.

As a result of this effort, I have a letter from Mr. Agent Guillo, of Alberni, dated August 8th inst., in which he says
He is to notify Mr. Oswald that he is a "trespasser" on the Indian Reservation at Friendly Cove.

Upon being asked the cause for so extraordinary an action as stigmatizing a missionary of the Presbyterian Church a "trespasser" on an Indian Reservation, Mr. Guilled quotes from the Indian Act, - "No person shall settle, reside ......... occupy or use any land...... without the license of the Superintendent General."

Referring to this matter, may I be permitted to point out:

1. The Rev. Mr. Oswald was not "settling, residing (upon) or occupying Indian lands in the ordinary sense of a "trespasser. He was asked by the Indians to remain with them and teach their children. As the Indian village occupies the only cleared land in the vicinity, the surroundings being rock, forest and water, in order to comply with the request, Mr. Oswald was obliged to secure temporarily a small house on the reserve until permission could be obtained from your Department to erect a suitable building.

2. The procedure followed by Mr. Oswald in this matter was the customary method in the past on the coast, and this is, so far as I am aware, the first instance of a Christian missionary having been ordered off a reservation as though he were there for some personal or evil purpose.

3. Not only has it been the custom in the past to permit missionaries freely to preach the gospel to the Indians on this coast, but considerable leniency has been shewn towards men who were on Indian reservations for other purposes than the welfare of the Indians.

I have personally known a white man of evil repute to be on an Indian reservation almost within sight of the Agent's residence, and he was not molested until I objected (on moral grounds) to his presence. Even then the Agent would not assume the idiom of ordering him off himself, but sent a note to the constable saying that "Mr. S. ......... had complained &c.

When
When the Str. Cleveland went ashore in Barclay Sound, and a white man, who was married to an Indian woman, was seriously complicated with the Indians in looting the cargo, your Agent evidently considered the presence of this man on the reservation as a matter of course.

At another time, a man came to me and asked permission to remain on a reservation, claiming that the Agent would not interfere with him so long as I was satisfied. The storekeeper at Chiaht remained on the reserve for years without having been ordered off, and it is difficult to understand why such a notice should have been sent to Mr. Oswald, except on the assumption that action was taken at the request of the Roman Catholic Bishop.

4. Whilst we have no quarrel with the Roman Catholic Church, and believe that body to be entitled to the same consideration as any other, I desire to protest against its claim of special propriety in the natives of this coast being recognized by your Department's officials.

Your Department's Agent lays considerable stress upon the fact that the Roman Catholic priests have been on this coast for twenty-five years have built several churches and baptized many children. And in his reports (See p. 433 of No.14-1900, An. Rep. of Ind. Affairs) he gives credit to the Roman Catholics of 969 converts out of a total of 27,491.

But at the risk of being tedious, I desire to say -

(1) The Roman Catholics have not educated the Indians. Though they have been here so long, and have not been hampered by the stringent conditions regarding education enforced since the arrival of the Protestants, during my residence of over seven years among the Indians I have not met one Indian who has been taught by the priests to read and write.

Nor would the Roman Catholics, even now, have been interested in educating the natives but for the fear Indian children might come under the influence of the Protestant schools. In the
Published Memoirs of the Rev. Father Brabant (Hoshquaht) he plainly states that the boarding school at Claoquaght (which is subsidized by your Department) became necessary in order to save the Indian children from being educated by the Protestants.

(2) In reference to the moral improvement of the Indians, the position is much the same.

Of the buildings erected, those at Alberni, Ohiacht and Ahousaht have been abandoned, whilst that at Friendly Cove (from which Mr. Oswald is now ordered away) was only occasionally used until it was learned the Presbyterian Church contemplated beginning work in Nootka Sound.

The Indians as a whole do not show evidence of twenty-five years of Christian work. Except perhaps at Hoshquaht, they are still practically heathen. They follow their old customs, practicing oos-im-itch and witchcraft and giving "potlatches," whilst their indulgence in drinking and gambling has not been materially checked by the priests.

Nor is it likely the Roman Catholic Church would make a serious effort to put down these evils in which the priests themselves indulge. For proof of this statement, I beg to again refer to Father Brabant's Memoirs and to say that I have myself witnessed a Roman Catholic priest the Indian Agent and two others engaging in a friendly game of cards, with a decanter of liquor on the table between them.

Nor is it simply in the evils of drinking and card playing that the influence of the priests has been on the wrong side.

Apparently with the object of turning the natives against the Protestants, a Roman Catholic priest is said to have warned the Indians on different occasions that the "Christians" or Just Now missionaries (as the Protestants have been named by the priests in ridicule) were seeking to put down "potlatching", which is not only a heathen custom, but against which laws have been enacted by the Parliament of Canada.

For
For your information, I may say, the priest who thus encourages the Indians to break the laws of the land, rather than permit the Protestants to secure an influence over them, is the one who has been on the coast for so many years and who has so won the admiration of your Department's Agent - the Rev. Father Brabant, of Heshquaht, at whose instigation Mr. Oswald is now being ordered off the reservation in Nootka Sound.

By further reference to Father Brabant's Memoirs, you may ascertain how so many Indian children were baptized by the Roman Catholics, and the basis of your Agent's report giving that Church nearly a thousand converts on this coast. With such a system of counting converts the marvel is that any pagans are reported.

I have no doubt these reports have, at least to some extent, misled your Department as to the position of the Roman Catholics on this coast, and, unless they have been since altered I would respectfully suggest an enquiry into the matter, and that a proper method be adopted of securing such information.

5. Regarding the demand of your Department's Office at Victoria, that application be made for permission to "reside" on an Indian reservation before any step is taken to open mission work, I may say if this is insisted upon, it will place a serious barrier in the way of Protestant effort on this coast.

Men are not always available for mission work, and should application be made before the missionary is secured, the Church runs a risk of being unable to meet its engagement with the Indians. If application is made after a missionary is secured the delay may cause the loss of the missionary, who cannot be expected to wait for months until your Agent is able to interview the Indians, whose decision, in the absence of the missionary, is likely to be influenced by the Roman Catholic priests, who have free access to all the reservations and have only to secure the head chief in order to make their influence felt in the tribe.
Under these circumstances, with which I feel certain you have not been made familiar, I would respectfully suggest that instructions be given your Department's officials on this coast so to interpret the rules of your Department as to permit Protestant missionaries some latitude in their endeavour to preach the Gospel to the Indians.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sd. M. Swartou.

A couple of months ago, the Reverend Thomas Oswald, under appointment of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, proceeded to Nootka Sound with the purpose of establishing a mission in that locality.

Indians from the various tribes in that sound had, for years, been requesting a Protestant teacher and a school, but until his arrival and survey of the field, Mr. Oswald did not know which of the four tribes would be finally selected. In company with Mr. J.W. Russell, of Ahousaht, an experienced missionary, Mr. Oswald visited the various tribes, receiving an invitation from the two largest to remain and open a school. Of these, the Mow-ach-ahts, at Friendly Cove, seemed to be in the worst plight, and his decision was to give them the preference.

There was at Friendly Cove a Roman Catholic Church, but the Indians claimed that the priest visited them but seldom—not oftener than once or twice a year—and that they had never had a regular school. These Indians are said to be fearfully debauched. One of their number admitted to me, not long since, that they were a tribe of drunkards and gamblers. They are also much diseased in body and are utterly ignorant and superstitious. The Roman Catholics have apparently no control over the people, except through the first chief, who, for special reasons, as he has alleged on different occasions, favours that church.

As soon as the Roman Catholics learned of Mr. Oswald's intention to begin work at Friendly Cove, they at once took steps to prevent it. They started a school, applied to your Department for the usual school grant, and then approached the Department's Office at Victoria in an effort to get Mr. Oswald ordered off the reserve.

As a result of this effort, I have a letter from Mr. Agent Guillod, of Alberni, dated August 8th inst., in which he says
he is to notify Mr. Oswald that he is a "trespasser" on the Indian Reservation at Friendly Cove.

Upon being asked the cause for so extraordinary an action as stigmatizing a missionary of the Presbyterian Church a "trespasser" on an Indian Reservation, Mr. Guillod quotes from the Indian Act, - "No person shall settle, reside ....... occupy or use any land...... without the license of the Superintendent General."

Referring to this matter, may I be permitted to point out:

1. The Rev. Mr. Oswald was not "settling, residing (upon) or occupying Indian lands in the ordinary sense of a "trespasser." He was asked by the Indians to remain with them and teach their children. As the Indian village occupies the only cleared land in the vicinity, the surroundings being rock, forest and water, in order to comply with the request, Mr. Oswald was obliged to secure temporarily a small house on the reserve until permission could be obtained from your Department to erect a suitable building.

I have personally known a white man of evil repute to be on an Indian reservation almost within sight of the Agent's residence, and he was not molested until I objected (on moral grounds) to his presence. Even then the Agent would not assume the initiative of ordering him off himself, but sent a note to the constable saying that "Mr. S. ......... had complained &c.

At another time, a man came to me and asked permission to remain on a reservation, claiming that the Agent would not interfere with him so long as I was satisfied. The storekeeper at Chiaht remained on the reserve for years without having been ordered off, and it is difficult to understand why such a notice should have been sent to Mr. Oswald, except on the assumption that action was taken at the request of the Roman Catholic Bishop.

Dear Sir:

RE WEST COAST VANCOUVER ISLAND:

I take the liberty of enclosing copies of communications to the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, regarding the action of that Department in ordering one of the Presbyterian missionaries off a reserve as a "trespasser."

You will find a fairly complete statement of the circumstances in communication No. I. Mr. Oswald followed the custom in the past, and so far as I know this is the first time any objection has been taken to a temporary residence upon a reserve by a missionary. It is always understood that before buildings are erected application is to be made to the Indian Department, but even in this the rule, in the past, has tended towards leniency. But to order a missionary off a reserve, without investigating the circumstances, or permitting him to remain until the Indians could be interviewed, is, I believe, and hope, without precedent.

Nor is this all. The Roman Catholics, who never seriously attempted to educate the Indians before the arrival of the Protestants, have recently erected a large boarding school, and are now engaged in an effort to alienate our children from our day schools and have them transferred to their boarding school. Pressure is brought to bear upon parents, and their signatures are obtained to a document, the meaning of which they scarcely comprehend, and, later, when they do understand, there is no help for them - says Mr. Vowall - and we are forbidden to interfere.

The Indian Department, so far as the West Coast is concerned has been of little use to the natives. I have lived among the Indians for years, speak their language and know their troubles, and I know the history of the Indian Department on the coast.

In the great case of Behring Sea seizures, two crews of Indians,
who ought to have received at least $500.00 per man for extraordinary hardships suffered, received nothing on this account, because there was no one to represent them. The Indians did not know what was necessary to be done—and that was before the days of Protestant missionaries—so they suffered without recompense.

When these Receiving Sea Seizure monies were paid, although the Indian Department claims to have endeavored to assist the Indians, yet the Dominion Government refused to recognize any heirs of deceased claimants except wives and children, in the absence of such keeping the money itself, despite the fact there were fathers, mothers, brothers and sisters who felt they had a claim to the shares of their deceased relatives. This sore is still open, having taken place only this year.

When a crew of drunken sailors looted an Indian village in the temporary absence of the people, there was no redress. One of the culprits was caught, but was released on the most whimsical excuse that he should not be punished unless all concerned in the outrage were.

When the somewhat celebrated case of the Ohiacht Indians vs. Schooner Victoria was in dispute officials of the Indian Department not only did not give the Indians any assistance, but their sympathies were manifestly on the side of the schooner owners who were endeavoring to avoid payment of several hundreds of dollars wages due to the Indians.

And in all the conflicts with whiskey smugglers and other evils the Indian Department has been slow in giving material aid.

I have, in fact, for the past six or seven years, been doing work that should have been done by the Indian Department, and I am, today, suffering seriously from attacks upon my character made by sympathizers of those who have been forced to respect the rights of the Indians.

I may say I do not consider Mr. Guillod as the principal cause of the unsatisfactory condition of affairs. He is a kindly gentleman for whom I have always felt deep respect, as a man, but he has been altogether too weak as an official, while the system has been all wrong.

If you feel this is a case in which you can conscientiously lend your assistance, I would be very glad to have your valuable help in an
effort not only to secure equal rights for all religious bodies working among these Indians, but also in having better administration of the Indian Department's work on this coast.

I send you duplicate copies of correspondence, in case you may desire one set to Ottawa.

Possibly the Superintendent General may yet reply to my letters, but I think you kindly intervention would much facilitate the matter.

Trusting I am not unduly troubling you about this, I am, dear sir,

Yours truly,

Right Rev'd dear Bishop,-

The following is an account of the arrival at Nootka of a young man representing the Presbyterian Church and of the circumstances which led to it. Let us begin with the second point:

Some three years ago it was publicly known that serious difficulties and quarrels existed at the Presbyterian Home at Alberni, Bareley Sound. An investigation was made and Miss Johnson, the matron, was discharged and a married man and his wife were given charge of the Home.

This Miss Johnson, having lost her job, took the steamer and accompanied by a couple of young Indians, a boy and a girl, came to Nootka in search of a new field of labour. A number of Indians being assembled in the Chief's house she addressed them and proposed to establish a mission here. Although before so doing she had distributed to the Indians at least half a ton of articles of dress, candles, etc., etc., the Chief's reply was clear and unequivocal. He told her that she and any of her "class were too late; that the priest had a church and a house here these many years; and that he, the Chief, and his people received all the attention they were in need of. The priest had come here
when the Indians were bad, fighting and killing each other.......

"Now the Indians on the Coast were good; he could not see any use,
in fact it would create trouble if the Indians had more than one
guide. He did not want another "Leflet" - one was plenty, and he
would not allow any other "Leflet" to build on his reserve."

Miss Johnson, expecting to get a chance to come here herself,
must not have reported this to the Presbyterian mission
board; but that board acting on her report, according to Mr. Swart-
tout, at once tried to find a man to take charge of the Nootka In-
dians. This man they at last secured and having him on their hands
they have now forced him on the Mowachat Indians.

The news of his intended arrival preceded him by several
weeks; and Chief Maquinna, now dead, hearing of it sent a letter
to Mr. Russell of Ahouset warning him not to send the man in ques-
tion. However, the young missionary was to be disposed of at any
cost.

You will remember that when you were in Hesquiot we learn-
ed the news that Russell and his men had passed off Hesquiot per
canoe and had been refused admittance by the Nootka Indians. This
report was perfectly true; for the pair having arrived late at
night were compelled to sleep in their canoe on the beach; and the
following day, finding that they could not even receive a hearing
from the Indians, they secured a couple of men who, for a good re-
muneration, were to take them to Ehattisat." Just as they were about to leave, an Ehattisat Indian, who has the name of being very troublesome and who would not be allowed by the Indians to live here at Nootka only for his wife—who is one of the "Thee" women of the tribe, walked down the beach and began to abuse the two Indians who were taking the missionaries away; whereupon Mr. Russell and his men accompanied this Ehattisat to the house of one of the petty Chiefs, an opposition man to the real Chief, where the opinion was expressed by a couple of young men that opposition would not be made to the presence at Nootka of the new missionary.

However, Russell could not see his way clear, for the encouragement he was receiving amounted to very little; therefore he resolved to go to Ehattisat anyhow; but upon arriving there, finding that the Ehattisat tribe was not worth his attention, he resolved to return to Nootka.

He set to work at once to secure a suitable building for a residence of his burden, a school and church. He went from house to house, offering immense rent, but even those who he claims wanted him to stay here would not allow him to hold service in their house on the Sunday we arrived in Nootka! However, he managed to force his way into a small cabin, built by Stockham & Dewley, as a lodging-place for miners and prospectors, but since sold to a woman, known as being of very doubtful morality, and occupied by herself and her husband.
And here now resides the new missionary, whose presence, to say the least, is a source of great displeasure to the young Chief and his adherents.

I am told by the Indians that the day after the steamer left the young men went and began to clear land, where he intends to build, but the principal man here, after the Chief, went over to him and told him to stop; that the land belongs to the Chief and that the Chief objected to the missionary's presence here and would give him no ground to build upon!

He teaches school and has an average attendance of two and three children. The Nootkas are not a large tribe—there are forty children, including newly born babies; of these about fifteen are of school age, most of whom come to my school. This is a correct statement, for I know every man, woman and child in the tribe. In a year or two quite a few will have attained the regular school age.

The young Chief, following the conduct of the old Chief, and the advice of the principal men of the tribe, is determined not to grant any land of the reserve to build upon.

Really a man must be hard up for a field to exercise his zeal to come to this place of Nootka! where we have exercised the ministry since over a quarter of a century, baptized the children, and joined couples in wedlock! Where not one Indian objects
to us on religious or other grounds! All he can do here is mischief, divide the tribe by bribing with presents and promises, bring in trouble where there was peace! I am sure that if his superiors were to know the situation they would call him back at once and appoint him to a field where his labours might be useful in their own way of looking at matters.

Your humble servant,

Right Revd. B. Orth, D. V.

Right Revd. dear Bishop,

Before I left Victoria in 1875, to permanently reside on this coast and sacrifice my life for the conversion of the Indians, the late C. J. Seghers, then recently consecrated Bishop of this diocese, enjoined on me, among other things, to be sure to respect the position of the chiefs of the different tribes, help them to keep up their rights and see that their authority is respected except when they are up to mischief and badness. I have done this so much that in some cases it has been to the disadvantage of our work. But yet, I was carrying out my orders.

When Matkahaw, the Chief of Resquiat, had shot me I prevented the people from killing his sister; and as I learned that they wanted to do away with his boy, the future Chief, in a meeting of the whole tribe I upbraided the Indians for their evil designs, and I appointed guardians to see that the little fellow was not molested, stating at the same time that, when of age, he would be like his father the Chief of the tribe. Later on, as I discovered a "complot" of several men to kill [illegible] father of Matkahaw, who as everybody said had put up his son to
shoot me - and who, after the death of that son acted as chief -
I at once rose up in his defense and had him respected as chief
by the whole tribe to the last day of his life.

There is not a chief on the Coast that will say that I
ever interfered with his position of Chief.

And yet I am told that unscrupulous men now scatter the
news and accuse me of threatening the young chief of Nootka that
if he does do such and such a thing, I will have him deposed.

Anybody who has the least knowledge of the Indians of
this Coast will say at once that attempting to do anything of the
kind would be met by the utmost failure. The rank is hereditary.
The young Nootka chief is born "a chief," and the Indians even in
spite of all the attempts to the contrary - of Agents or Governors,
Friends or Bishops - will always consider and hold him as such.
Dr. Powell when Sup't. of Indian affairs made the attempt in Clay-
oquat and the Indians laughed at him behind his back. Dr. Powell's
"chief" remained an inferior Indian, and was treated as such by
all the natives, and the chief by right of birth remained chief,
and his daughter now succeeds to her father in the position.

Never have I gone to an Indian reserve and after being
politely refused by the chief to build and settle upon such reserve
then, in order to carry my point, try to undo the chief's authority by asking a number of inferior Indians to sign a paper entitling me to act in spite of the chief's prohibition, and, so it were, dispossess him of his title and rights as chief. I leave it to others to act that way. Such a blunder I have never made, and such an injustice I have never attempted to commit.

It is also rumoured that I threatened the chief with regard to some cattle that run about here. The truth is the cattle are mine pure and simple, and if tomorrow I took up a gun and shot them no one could say that I shot any but my own cattle. I did not make a present of them to the old chief and he never paid for them, and they remain mine till they are paid for.

The situation of the young Chief is this: His uncle died a short time ago, and like all Indians, left different instructions to his successor. Napoleon Maquinna follows those instructions. One of these instructions is to be true to the Catholic Priest who has attended to these Indians since 1874, and to allow no division to take place by admitting ministers of other denominations. The saying of the old Chief was one "let it be enough," and I am told that he got a Captain of a schooner to write this very saying to Mr. Quillod, and also he sent warning to Mr. Russell of Ahousat.
to that effect during the Chief's last illness.

As an item of news, I may mention that the young man who represents the Presbyterian church here, since a couple of months, is packing up and will leave this place per outgoing steamer. He sees that he has been imposed upon by those who sent him here. He has no followers whatever. He has no attendance at his prayer meetings, and since the last three weeks he has had only one little boy at his school, and that boy only went so that his relatives might collect the rent of the house used as a school-room.

There are other reports about me, but I can take no notice of them. The white residents on the coast and all the Indians know me. They know that during all the many years I am a resident here I have done nothing contemptible or small. Will they say as much of my accusers?

I am your Lordship's obedient servant,

"A. J. Brabant."

In answer to your letter of the 5th of last December 519 W 3 and referring to former letters of Nov 7th 135 W 3, July 26th 368 V 3 and July 19th 221 V 3 I have the honor to inform you that owing to my being engaged on the Dominion Census and other pressing business and the difficulty of travelling by canoe in the winter months owing to bad weather I did not meet Koottka till the 17th of December. On my arrival there the Koottka Indians showed so little interest with regard to the wish of the Presbyterian Church to give them a resident missionary and teacher that although I called a meeting particularly to consider this question no one attended and I had to take advantage of Chief Mogum's killing a beef to distribute among his tribesmen to address them on the subject. After I had explained to them the purpose of the meeting, that the Department wished to know their mind with regard to the coming of a Presbyterian missionary among them, that I was there not to take one
side or the other but I wanted them all to speak and say what was in their heart. Chief Illowana made a speech as follows:

"I told the Presbyterian missionaries last year that I did not want a new teacher at Nootka. I am Roman Catholic and Father Brabant is my friend and the friend of my people he has known us from the time we were children and has always looked after us, we do not want another teacher. Last spring when I was sick he gave me a letter to get a good doctor in Victoria who cured me of my sickness. I do not want another teacher."

Then asked the 2nd chief Captain Jack to speak but neither he or anyone present had anything to say except to the effect that the chief had spoken and given me their true heart.

The Nootka or Mowachat tribe number 178, of whom 86 called themselves Catholics, the rest pagans; the children number 42 of whom 20 are of school age, four of these twenty children are inmates of the Roman Catholic boarding school at Clayoquot, a few lads go sealing. The Rev. Father Brabant whom I saw at Hesquiat told me he had 12 children attending school at Nootka, a few of whom were Matchitlahs, and that he closed his school, when from some of the Indians moving from the village, the attendance did not warrant its continuance, he was intending to retire.
to Nootka in February at Chesterfield village. At a meeting of the Matchitlakits on the 26th of December, the chief woman asked for a Presbyterian teacher and a store. The tribe numbers 63 with 14 children, 6 of whom are of school age; it is a poor village site, situated behind Black Island. Nootka sound 8 miles from Nootka village and the Indians only reside there about three months in the year. Their fishing stations are up Chuckalot arm; the tribe are allied with the Nootka's and Hesquiat's and what they know of Christianity has been learned on visits to those places.

On the 25th of January I visited Oke village, Esperanza inlet, 24 miles from Nootka village. At a meeting of the Chattivatits held here Chief Joe said they wanted the Rev. Dr. Campbell of the Presbyterian Church to give them a teacher, that if one came he, the chief, would lend a house for present purposes and give a site for a schoolhouse on the Reserve wherever the teacher saw fit, that they would give all their children to the teacher, that they wanted a school where the children could sleep when the parents were away, if food was provided all right but if not the parents would help to provide food for their children at school, the tribe were unanimous in supporting what chief Joe said. Oke is the principal village where this band
reside in the winter months; in the summer, those who do not travel to the Fraser river & the American hop fields, stop at Chisenaus, Catala island at the mouth of Esperanza inlet, 8 miles from Ote. The Chilcotin band number 102, with 31 children of whom 16 are of school age.

The resident Roman Catholic Priest at Nyugnot pays occasional visits to these tribes.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that when inspecting schools in the West Coast Agency I visited "Yuquet Reserve" as I had heard the school there had been re-opened. But I found it closed, the teacher Rev. E. Sebray informed me that he opened the school for three weeks, but he only had an average of three, so he closed it again. There are sufficient children but the parents take no interest in their education. Mr. Sebray states that unless compulsory attendance is required a school cannot be kept going. The Indians on this coast, although the first to be visited by the white men are in a very primitive and dirty condition. I saw old Indian men cutting wood on the beach with not a stitch of clothing on, and their only object appears to be dancing and potlatching.

I consider that the men who visit "Heetka" to take records and photographs of the potlatches and the old ways of the village (drawn to it because it was the first place visited by Captains Cook, Vancouver, and Quadra) are largely responsible for the poor condition of these Indians; the people are paid to go through all the old forms of dances, etc., and encouraged to keep them up. At the time I was there parties from the United States, with phonographs to record the old songs, and machines to take moving pictures of old weird dances. These retard progress and keep the people wedded to the old ways. There are some bright children that should be educated.

I have the honor to remain

Dear Mr. Ashbridge,

The Bishop of Victoria has asked me to write to you.

You know that His Excellency has been anxious to have a day school on the Kyuquot Reserve. At the beginning of this month, I wrote to Father Sorensen about the matter. I have just received a reply from him. In that letter he states that he has heard, apparently on good authority, that Dr. McLean of Ceepeecoo has been negotiating with Chief Emile Jules of Kyuquot with a view to opening a school....it would seem, on the Chief's land. Fr. Sorensen does not seem quite sure about the attitude of the Chief, but it would seem to have been favourable.

Practically all the Indians at Kyuquot are baptized Roman Catholics. Out of the list furnished me by Fr. Sorensen, I count only 7 non-Catholics...Protestants and Pagans.

It is hardly necessary for me to mention that His Excellency is very keen to do everything he possibly can to help the Indian people in every way. The work of the Missionaries cannot help but be very much hampered by the erection of a school under the auspices of Dr. McLean.

Last summer he was trying to get into Nootka, but the Cannery authorities are so appreciative of the work Fr. Sheahan is trying to do there, that they would not give the Doctor a 'pied a terre.' Now, it would seem, that having failed at Nootka Dr. McLean is going to see what can be done at Kyuquot.

Dr. McLean's main purpose is to counteract the work of the Catholic Missionaries; of that, personally, I have no doubt. When I was visiting the West Coast, as the Bishop's representative last spring, Henry Jack of Nootka, told me that at the beginning of the year, he had been seriously
ill and not expected to live, in Dr. McLean's Hospital at Cespecees. The good Doctor went out of his way and took no small trouble to tear the Catholic Faith from the sick man's heart.

I was astounded at the Doctor, but I was more astounded at the account an Indian was able to give of the Faith that was in him. The Doctor also tried his hand with Henry's wife. That this happened and that the boy answered in the way he did, was confirmed by what Fr. Sheahan told me, but I had the story from Henry's own lips.

Very much more might be said on the same line; anything might be expected from a man who would try to interfere with the Faith of someone supposed to be dying.

Please accept my best wishes for the new year. I hope that I may have the pleasure of seeing you again one of these days.

Very sincerely your,

J. L. Bradley,

(Supervisor of Indian Missions in the diocese of Victoria, B.C.)

The undersigned begs to submit herewith correspondence that has taken place between the Principals of the four Industrial Indian Schools in Ontario in respect to:

2. The curriculum to be followed in the instruction in the ordinary branches of education and in the training of pupils in the knowledge of industries;

Memorial

of the members of the Baptist Ministerial Association
of the City of Toronto,

To the Honorable Sir J. A. Abbott, K.C., M.P.,
Prime Minister of the Dominion of Canada:

Sir:

We, the undersigned members of a special commit-
tee, appointed by the Baptist Ministerial Association
of this City, respectfully ask, as Citizens of Canada,
your attentive consideration of the following state-
ments and protest:

Having learned from reports appearing in the
public press that, on a recent occasion, replying to his
representations of a deputation composed of the Methodist
members of the Senate and the House of Commons, who
waited upon you to ask an increase of the appropriations
from the Dominion Treasury, in aid of the Mission
schools under the care of the Methodist Church among
Among the Indians of the North West, you intimated that the Government had in contemplation a new and improved system in accordance with which appropriations in aid of denominational schools among the Indians of Canada would henceforth be made on a "per capita" basis, we beg leave, on behalf of the Association for which we operate, to say—

(1) We, as members of a body of Christians who have been among the most zealous in the establishment and carrying on of modern missions among the heathen in foreign lands, are in hearty sympathy with every properly directed effort for the civilizing and evangelizing of the Indian tribes of Canada.

(2) Though the Churches of the denomination with which we are connected, have not done so much as we could have wished in aid of this good work, which we recognize as a duty solemnly binding upon the Christian Churches of the Dominion, they have for a number of years been engaged in missionary work on
Brant Reserve, and have at present an ordained minister with several assistants, successfully employed on that Reserve. They have also, during the past year, been engaged in mission work on the Reserves around Lake Winnipeg in Manitoba, and are now organizing for more extensive work in that region. This will show that the Baptists are not indifferent to the religious welfare of the aborigines of the Dominion and that they are prepared to do what they can for their evangelization, in harmony with their cherished and time honored principles, viz.: absolute voluntaryism in religious institutions and operations.

(3) We, as Baptists, who have in days past suffered proscription and persecution for conscience' sake, in consequence of the union of Church and State in systems of Government, regard any and every appropriation of funds derived from taxation of the whole people for purposes of civil administration in aid of the denominational or sectarian schools or institutions of any kind under denominational...
denominational control, as not only demonstrating in principle and unjust, but as a violation of the fundamental principle of absolute separation of Church and State, which has been agreed upon, tacitly at least, as one of the cornerstones of our constitutional system.

The provisions of the British North America Act in the interest of Separate Schools in Ontario and Quebec will surely not be pleaded in support of practices adapted to weaken and contravene throughout the Dominion at large this most important feature of our Constitution.

(4) We, therefore, as Baptists, beg leave respectfully, but most earnestly to protest against the establishment of such a system of distribution of public funds in aid of denominational Indian Schools, as that said to be contemplated by your Government, and to submit that whatever changes are made in the matter should be in the direction of discontinuance of any such grants at the earliest practicable moment. In support of this protest and Memorial permit us to urge, in addition to the foregoing...
going, the following considerations:

(a) - The inherent absurdity, if you will pardon the expression, of such a method. We are well assured that in this matter the Government are sincerely anxious of promoting the moral and religious welfare of the Indians. But consider how ineffectual and even harmful such a system must be in relation to their very designs. The Methodists, for instance, in common with other denominations called "Evangelical," firmly believe that the doctrinal teachings of the Roman Catholic Church are based on deadly error and tend directly to foster ignorance, superstition, and moral and spiritual darkness in the minds of those who are brought under their influence. The Roman Catholics, in their turn, hold substantially the same views, and if possible even more strongly, with regard to the fruits and effects of Evangelicalism. And yet the Government hopes to christianize the Indians by having Methodists for the propagation of Roman Catholic teachings and Roman
Roman Catholics, for the propagation of Methodism,
and Baptists and many others who are neither Methodists
nor Roman Catholics for the propagation of the
views of both.

(b) - The mischievous and dangerous tendency
of such a system putting, as it does, a premium
upon mere numbers in the rival schools, instead,
if not to actual misrepresentations, at least to un-
desirable and vicious methods of competition; and
the holding out of wrong and demoralizing induc-
ments to Indian parents to permit their children to be
enrolled in the respective schools. We think that the
Government cannot be wholly unaware that already
missionaries representing rival schools sometimes
suspect and accuse each other of resorting to
unworthy tricks and other expedients in order to
enlarge their rolls. The moral effects of such rivalries
upon the minds of the Indians themselves may be readily
imagined.
The system lacks completeness and finality. All admit that it is in the highest degree desirable that such a system should be adopted as will effect the complete civilization and enlightenment of the Indians, not simply ultimately but within the briefest possible period. Now, though some very encouraging progress is reported from time to time in the industrial training of the North West Indians, the most sanguine friends of the present methods can hardly hope to see the 17,000 or 18,000 Indians in the North West, to say nothing of those in British Columbia and other Provinces, transformed into intelligent and industrious citizens within the next half Century. It is not to be hoped for, that under any system of state aided sectarian schools that can be devised, the work of educating the young Indians as a whole, will be carried on in a century, to say nothing of their moral and religious transformation. But if this be so, it follows that the establishment of the system proposed would really fail.
take on the characteristics of perpetuity, ineffec-
tiveness, and hopelessness so far as any complete
or satisfactory results are concerned.

If it be said that some progress is better than
none, and that the adoption of the view we advocate
would lead to a falling off in the amount of work
which is now being done for the uplifting of the
Indians, we make bold to reply:

That it would be a poor compliment to
the zeal and liberality of Canadian Christians to believe
that their efforts for the moral and spiritual welfare
of the aborigines in their own land are dependent
upon the aid derived from compulsory taxation
by the state. We have such faith in voluntarism
in religious work, a belief well founded upon what
is now being done in foreign lands, that we feel sure
that the withdrawal of the aid hitherto granted by the
government would lead to redoubled liberality and
zeal in the work of Indian missions.
As to the educational work which properly belongs to the State, we ask whether the time is not come when very much more should be done than has hitherto been done in this direction. May we not, without presumption, direct the attention of the Government and all friends of the Indian to the great work that is now being done in the United States?

After having for a century tried methods somewhat similar to those now employed in Canada, the United States government has at last, as is well known, adopted vigorous and hopeful measures for the final and complete solution of the whole Indian problem within a generation. MEMORIAL

OF THE

MEMBERS OF THE BAPTIST MINISTERIAL ASSOCIATION OF THE CITY OF TORONTO.

To the Honorable Sir J. J. C. Abbott, K.C.M.G., Prime Minister of the Dominion of Canada:

Sir,—We, the undersigned members of a special committee, appointed by the Baptist Ministerial Association of this city, respectfully ask, as citizens of Canada, your attentive consideration of the following statements and protest—

Having learned from reports appearing in the public press that, on a recent occasion, applying to the representations of a deputation composed of the Methodist members of the Senate and the House of Commons, who waited upon you for an increase of the appropriations from the Dominion Treasury in aid of the Mission schools under the care of the Methodist Church among the Indians of the North-West, you intimated that the Government had in contemplation a new or improved system in accordance with which appropriations in aid of denominational schools among the Indians of Canada would henceforth be made on a per capita basis, we beg leave, on behalf of the association for which we speak, to say:—

(1.) We, as members of a body of Christians who have been among the most zealous in the establishment and carrying on of modern missions among the heathen in foreign lands, are in hearty sympathy with every properly directed effort for the civilizing and evangelizing of the Indian tribes of Canada.

(2.) Though the churches of the denomination with which we are connected, have not done so much as we could have wished in aid of this good work, which we recognize as a duty solemnly binding upon the Christian churches of the Dominion, they have for a number of years been engaged in missionary work on the Brant Reserve, and have at present an ordained minister with several assistants successfully employed on that reserve. They have also, during the past year, been engaged in mission work on the reserves around Lake Winnipeg, in Manitoba, and are now organizing for more extensive work in that region. This will show that the Baptists are not indifferent to the religious welfare of the aborigines of the Dominion, and that they are prepared to do what they can for their evangelization, in harmony with their cherished and time-honored principle, viz., absolute voluntarism in religious institutions and operations.

(3.) We, as Baptists, who have in days past, suffered proscription and persecution for conscience sake, in consequence of the union of Church and State in systems of government, regard any and every appropriation of funds derived from taxation of the whole people for purposes of civil administration in aid of denominational or sectarian schools or institutions of any kind, under denominational control, as not only demonstrably wrong in principle and unjust, but as a violation of the fundamental principle of absolute separation of Church and State, which has been agreed on and acted on, at least, as one of the corner stones of our constitutional system. The provisions of the British North America Act in the interest of Separate Schools in Ontario and Quebec will surely not be pleaded in support of practices adapted to weaken and contravene throughout the Dominion at large this most important feature of our constitution.

(4.) We, therefore, as Baptists, beg leave respectfully, but most earnestly, to protest against the establishment of such a system of distribution of public funds in aid of denominational Indian schools, as that said to be contemplated by your Government, and to submit that whatever changes are made in the matter should be in the direction of discontinuance of all such grants at the earliest practicable moment. In support of this protest and memorial permit us to urge, in addition to the foregoing, the following considerations:—

(a.) The inherent absurdity, if you will pardon the expression, of such a method. We are well assured that in this matter the Government are sincerely desirous of promoting the moral and religious welfare of the Indians. But consider how ineffective and even harmful such a system must be in relation to these very designs. The Methodists, for instance, in common with other denominations called "Evangelical," firmly believe that the doctrinal teachings of the Roman Catholic Church are based on deadly error and tend directly to foster ignorance, superstition, and moral and spiritual darkness in the minds of those who are brought under their influence. The Roman Catholics, in their turn, hold substantially the same views, and if possible even more strongly, with regard to the tenets and effects of Evangelicalism. And yet the Government hopes to christianize the Indians by taxing Methodists for the propagation of Roman Catholic teachings and Roman Catholics for the propagation of Methodism, and Baptists and many others who are neither Methodists nor Roman Catholics for the propagation of the views of both.

(b.) The mischievous and dangerous tendency of such a system putting as it does, a premium upon mere numbers in the rival schools, to lead, if not to actual misrepresentations, at least to undesirable and vicious methods of competition, and the holding out of wrong and demoralizing inducements to Indian parents to permit their children to be enrolled in the respective schools. We think that the Government cannot be wholly unaware that already missionaries representing rival schools sometimes suspect and accuse each other of resorting to unworthy bribes and other expedients in order to enlarge their rolls. The moral effects of such rivalries upon the minds of the Indians themselves may readily be imagined.
(c) The system lacks completeness and finality. All admit that it is in the highest degree desirable that such a system should be adopted as will effect the complete civilization and enlightenment of the Indians, not simply ultimately but within the briefest possible period. Now, though some very encouraging progress is reported from time to time in the industrial training of the north west Indians, the most sanguine friend of the present methods can hardly hope to see the 17,000 or 18,000 Indians in the North-west, to say nothing of those in British Columbia and other provinces, transformed into intelligent and industrious citizens within the next half century. It is not to be hoped for, that under any system of State-aided sectarian schools that can be devised, the work of educating the young Indians as a whole, will be overtaken in a century, to say nothing of their moral and religious transformation. But if this be so, it follows that the establishment of the system proposed would really take on the characteristics of perpetuity, ineffectiveness and hopelessness so far as any complete or satisfactory results are concerned.

(b) If it be said that some progress is better than none, and that the adoption of the view we advocate would lead to a falling off in the amount of work which is now being done for the uplifting of the Indians, we make bold to reply:

(1.) That it would be a poor compliment to the zeal and liberality of Canadian Christians to believe that their efforts for the moral and spiritual welfare of the aborigines in their own land are dependent upon the aid derived from compulsory taxation by the State. We have such faith in voluntaryism in religious work, a belief well founded upon what is now being done in foreign lands, that we feel sure that the withdrawal of the aid hitherto granted by the Government would lead to a resembled liberality and zeal in the work of Indian missions.

(2.) As to the education work which properly belongs to the State, we ask whether the time is not come when very much more should be done than has hitherto been done in this direction? May we not, without presumption, direct the attention of the Government and all friends of the Indian to the great work that is now being done in the United States?

After having for a century tried methods somewhat similar to those now employed in Canada, the United States Government has at last, as is well known, adopted vigorous and hopeful measures for the final and complete solution of the whole Indian problem within a generation. Acting on the advice of the Lake Mohawk Conference, a society representing the statesmanship, philanthropy and religious intelligence and zeal of the friends of the Indian in the Republic, the Indian Department is now, with every prospect of success, following out a radically new departure in its treatment of the Indians.

The two great principles underlying this new policy are universal compulsory education of Indian children and youth, at the earliest practicable moment; and the breaking up of the Reservation, and with it, as a not remote consequence, of the tribal system, and the distribution of the land to the Indians in severalty. They are, in short, to be clothed with the duties and responsibilities, and with all the privileges too, of citizenship, under such conditions as may seem best adapted to make citizens of them, at the earliest possible moment. The work of Christianizing them will, of course, be left with the churches where it properly belongs. If the Provinces of Canada find it advisable and expedient, as a matter of self-interest, to provide for the compulsory elementary education of all the children who are to become their future citizens, ought not the Dominion itself, a fortiori, to do no less for the children of the Indians who are her wards? Let the Government thus settle the question of Indian education, and the churches may safely be trusted to do the work of Christianization. But the other day the Methodist Conference of the United States, assembled at Omaha, unanimously decided that the General Conference should hereafter "decline either to make a petition to or to receive from the National Government any moneys for educational work among the Indians." We are sure the Methodists of Canada will not be slow to emulate so good an example. In fact, some of them are already doing so.

While the members of the Ministerial Association whom this committee represents make no claim to speak for anybody but themselves, they are warranted by the whole history of Baptist principles, and by their general knowledge of the sentiments of their brethren all over the Dominion in their conviction that they voice the minds of the whole body of Canadian Baptists. Steps are being taken to have the question submitted to the various local associations shortly to meet; and also to the General Convention of the Baptists of Ontario and Quebec, which meets in October. We have no doubt that the protest will be heartily concurred in by all these representative bodies.

We deem it proper to forward printed copies of this memorial and protest to the members of the House of Commons and Senate.
