TORONTO, May 27th, 1892
MEMORANDUM FOR THE MINISTER.

A few remarks might not be out of place in regard to the "Memorial" forwarded to the Government by the Members of the Baptist Ministerial Association of the City of Toronto.

There are only two paragraphs that call for consideration, viz., "4" and Sub-section Two of "5".

Paragraph 4 says:—"We therefore as Baptists beg leave respectfully, but most earnestly, to protest against the establishment of such a system of distribution of public funds in aid of denominational Indian Schools as that said to be contemplated by your Government."

In regard to the above it may be stated that the Department in inaugurating the system of granting aid to Day Schools did not take the matter of religious education into consideration at all. It is true that when some of the Treaties were made the Indians on several occasions asked to be supplied with a Minister and School Teacher of whatever denomination we belong to." (Page 215 Morris' Book). The Lieut. Governor in reply, (Page 217) said:—"You ask for School Teachers and Ministers. With regard to Ministers I cannot interfere. There are large Societies formed for the purpose of sending the Gospel to the Indians. The Government does not provide Ministers anywhere in Canada. I had already promised you that when you settled down and there were enough children, schools would be maintained."

Let us look at the beginning of the granting of aid to Day Schools in the North West.

In Manitoba and the North West Territories the following
Treaties were made:

Manitoba.

Treaties Nos. 1 & 2 August 3rd, 1871.
Treaty 3 October 3rd, 1873.
Treaty 5 September 20th, 1875.

North West Territories.

Treaty No. 4 September 15th, 1874.
Treaty 6 August 23rd, 1876.
Treaty 7 September 22nd, 1877.

The clause in the Treaty referring to education reads thus:

"And further, Her Majesty agrees to maintain a school on each Reserve hereby made whenever the Indians of the Reserve should desire it."

And the Indian Act provides that the Chiefs in Council may regulate "as to what religious denomination the teacher of the school established on the Reserve shall belong to, provided always that he shall be of the same denomination as the majority of the Band, and that the Protestant or Catholic minority may likewise have a separate school, with the approval of and under regulation made by the Governor in Council".

It would appear that certain Christian Denominations had been carrying on work among the Indians some time prior to the Treaty being made with them. They had started some Day Schools, and doubtless finding that the Government was bound by Treaty to educate the Indians they applied for assistance in their Educational work.

The first vote made by the Dominion Parliament for Indian education in Manitoba and the North West Territories was in 1873-4, when between $2,000 and $3,000 were passed, and the first appli-

(2)
cation which the Government appears to have had for assistance toward Day Schools was from the late Rev. Enoch Wood, who was then General Secretary of the Wesleyan Missionary Society. This was in October 1873. The application was made to the Government through the Hon. J. C. Aikens, then Secretary of State, and was "for assistance to carry on Educational work among the Indians of the North West." The Methodist Church had then a Day School at Seron's River, one at Norway House, and one at Oxford House. They also had in operation in the Saskatchewan country a Day School at Victoria, one at White Fish Lake, and one at Edmonton House, and they proposed establishing in the Spring of 1874 one at Woodville and another at Morleyville, and also to do some work among the Blackfeet. The following are the words of the Rev. Mr. Wood's appeal:—"We cannot but be moved by the earnest and repeated requests made by the Indians on behalf of their children, the parents of whom are exceedingly anxious for them to be instructed.

x x x "Understanding that the Dominion Parliament has voted a certain amount of money to be expended for educational purposes among the Indians in this newly acquired Territory, we consider that these Day Schools are legitimately entitled to the favourable consideration of the Dominion Parliament."

Mr. Wood also mentioned in his letter the name of the Rev. J. B. Armstrong, who, he said, visited the Saskatchewan Territory, and, "became so impressed with the desire of the Indians in that Northern country to have their children educated that, of his own accord, he petitioned His Honour Governor Morris for financial assistance to establish Day Schools among them."

(3)
Upon these representations an Order in Council was passed, dated October 1873, authorizing the payment of $300 per annum towards the maintenance of Day Schools on Indian Reserves, both Protestant and Roman Catholic, provided sixty pupils were in attendance. A further Order in Council was passed in April 1874, on the recommendation of the Hon. David Laird, on substantially the same lines, the difference being that the attendance was reduced from 60 to 25 pupils.

The Department, in advising the Rev. Mr. Wood of the decision of the Government to aid Day Schools to the extent of $300 per annum, stated that "the Government was gratified to learn of the efforts which the Wesleyan Missionary Society were making for the education of the Indians in the North West, and of the success which was attending their efforts." The Department at the same time notified Bishop Grandin that similar aid would be granted to Day Schools in his Diocese.

It will thus be seen that the grants were made to aid in the work of secular education among the Indians, and that no reference whatever was made to Mission work.

The payments in many cases it is true were made to Teachers who had been sent in by Church Societies, but they were the only available Teachers in the country. They knew the Indians, and were likely to be much more successful in carrying on the schools than new comers. The Indians had a very strong aversion to sending their children to school, and it required a long acquaintance with them, and a great deal of tact to succeed in keeping up an attendance of children.
The experience of the Missionaries and their knowledge of the Indian character rendered them most useful Teachers and well qualified to do the work of opening new schools.

As the work of education among the Indians advanced it was considered to be in their interests that the methods of education should be somewhat changed. It was desirable to secure more regular attendance at the schools, and a higher class of education was becoming incumbent, as the mind of the child developed it was only right that it should be advanced in its studies, and in the case of pupils who had distinguished themselves by their intelligence and progress in the Day Schools that they should be drafted into schools of a higher order, such as—

Boarding Schools

where they could be trained more thoroughly in all kinds of knowledge. Then began the establishment of Boarding Schools. The cost of the system was fully considered. There was a legal obligation on the part of the Government to educate the Indian youth. There was also a strong moral obligation. It was contended that if the children were to be elevated from the paths in which their parents had walked a competent education would tend more largely than anything else to do it. It was looked upon as due to the rising generation to afford them an equal chance of success in life with their white brethren, by whom they were, it might be said, replaced; and even from an economic point of view the expenditure incurred in educating and training the children was regarded as a good investment, one that would repay to the country large interest, by the conversion of the descendants of a people a large number of whom were then a source of expense, into profit-

(5)
able citizens, who, instead of being supported from the revenue of the country, as their parents were, would contribute largely to it.

This developed into Industrial training, and in 1883 the first Industrial Schools in the North West were established, namely, one at Bathford, one at Qu'Appelle, and one at High River. These have increased largely since, and we have now some nine or ten under weigh now, seven or eight of which are in full operation.

The valuable work done in Industrial Schools in the United States was, to a great extent, an incentive to try similar work in Canada for the benefit of the Indians. In the United States the Industrial School system was inaugurated in 1869, during President Grant's term of office. About that time the policy of grouping the Indians and placing them on permanent Reservations, abolishing the "community" system, and allotting the land in severalty, was introduced. Those who had the interests of the Indians at heart thought that an effort should be made, and they considered it the duty of the Government to endeavour to make the Indian a citizen of the United States, and in order to accomplish that end education in Industry, and in the arts of Civilization, was necessary, consequently from 1869 forward a good system of education was pursued.

Industrial Boarding Schools were considered in the U.S. to be the best for educating the Indian youth. The Day Schools did good work as stepping-stones, but, as a writer on the subject put it, "Little can be done with the adult Indian. He can be taught to do a little at farming, and at stock raising, and to dress in a more civilized manner, but that is all. The child, again, who
"Go to a day school learns little, and what little he learns is soon forgotten, while his tastes are fashioned at home, and his inherited aversion to toil is in no way combatted."

Our experience is the same. The children must be entirely removed from their homes, and from the influence of their parents and surroundings, in order that the benefits of their school training may be lasting.

The United States has had in operation from that time up to the present a great many Industrial Schools under what they call the "contract" system. A contract was made with, for instance, the Church of England, the Roman Catholic Church, the Presbyterian, the Baptist, or the Methodist Churches, and they were paid a per capita sum towards the maintenance of the pupils. They have also non-denominational schools, managed by the Government, and schools conducted by Church Societies, the expenses of the latter being paid by the State.

The Industrial Schools in the North West are of two classes; one class being managed by the Church authorities, and aided on the per capita system; the other conducted under the auspices of a Denomination, the cost of which is paid by the Government. At these schools all kinds of trades are taught, and when a boy graduates employment at his trade or profession either on the Reserve or among white people is obtained for him. The female pupils are taught all sorts of domestic work, and other useful mechanical arts, and they, in turn, when their length of time is up at a school, are procured situations and gradually they become merged in the white population.

The system of Indian education has been a success in Manitoba.

In regard to Paragraph 5, Sub-section 2 of the Memorial,
which reads:—"The two great principles underlying this new
policy are universal compulsory education of Indian children and youth at the earliest practicable moment, and the breaking up of the Reservation, and with it, as a not remote consequence, of the Tribal system, and the distribution of the land of the Indians in severalty. They are, in short, to be clothed with the duties and responsibilities, and with all the privileges too, of citizenship, under such conditions as may seem best adapted to make citizens of them, at the earliest possible moment. The work of Christianizing them will, of course, be left with the Churches, where it properly belongs. If the Provinces of Canada find it advisable and expedient as a matter of self-interest to provide for the compulsory elementary education of all the children who are to become their future citizens, ought not the Dominion itself, a fortiori, to do no less for the children of the Indians who are her wards? Let the Government thus settle the question of Indian education, and the Churches may safely be trusted to do the work of Christianization; it may be stated that this condition of affairs refers to the United States, and the Memorial directs the attention of the Government and all friends of the Indians to it.

It has been found a very bad policy to attempt to force "Compulsory Education" upon the Indians. One of the great sources of trouble to the United States, and from which Canada has been free, is compulsion of the Indians. Those who recommend such a course do not understand the Indian character.

For years back the Department has been pursuing the policy of breaking up the community system, and endeavouring to induce the
Indians to take up their holdings in security.

Every effort is being made, and it may be safely said, with a very much greater degree of success than has attended the efforts of the United States, to clothe the Indians with the duties and responsibilities and all the privileges of citizenship.

The work of Christianizing them is entirely left with the Churches, where it properly belongs, and the Government is doing its duty in the direction of imparting to its Indian wards a liberal education.

MEMORIAL

OF THE

MEMBERS OF THE BAPTIST MINISTERIAL ASSOCIATION OF THE CITY OF TORONTO.

To the Honorable Sir J. J. C. Abbott, K.C.M.G., Prime Minister of the Dominion of Canada:

SIR,

We, the undersigned members of a special committee, appointed by the Baptist Ministerial Association of this city, respectfully ask, as citizens of Canada, your attention and consideration of the following statements and protest:

Having learned from reports appearing in the public press that, on a recent occasion, replying to the representations of a deputation composed of the Methodist members of the Senate and the House of Commons, who waited upon you to ask an increase of the appropriations from the Dominion Treasury in aid of the Mission schools under the care of the Methodist Church among the Indians of the North-West, you intimated that the Government had in contemplation a new or improved system in accordance with which appropriations in aid of denominational schools among the Indians of Canada would henceforth be made on a per capita basis, we beg leave, on behalf of the association for which we speak, to say:

(1.) We, as members of a body of Christians who have been among the most zealous in the establishment and carrying on of modern missions among the heathen in foreign lands, are in hearty sympathy with every properly directed effort for the civilizing and evangelizing of the Indian tribes of Canada.

(2.) Though the churches of the denomination with which we are connected, have not done so much as we could have wished in aid of this good work, which we recognize as a duty solemnly binding upon the Christian churches of the Dominion, they have for a number of years been engaged in missionary work on the Brant Reserve, and have at present an ordained minister with several assistants successfully employed on that reserve. They have also, during the past year, been engaged in mission work on the reserves around Lake Winnipeg, in Manitoba, and are now organizing for more extensive work in that region. This will show that the Baptists are not indifferent to the religious welfare of the aborigines of the Dominion, and that they are prepared to do what they can for their evangelization, in harmony with their cherished and time-honored principle, viz., absolute voluntarism in religious institutions and operations.

(3.) We, as Baptists, who have in days past, suffered persecution and prosecution for conscience sake, in consequence of the union of Church and State in systems of government, regard any and every appropriation of funds derived from taxation of the whole people for purposes of civil administration in aid of denominational or sectarian schools or institutions of any kind under denominational control, as not only demonstrably wrong in principle and unjust, but as a violation of the fundamental principle of absolute separation of Church and State, which has been agreed on, tacitly at least, as one of the corner stones of our constitutional system. The provisions of the British North America Act in the interest of Separate Schools in Ontario and Quebec will surely not be pleaded in support of practices adapted to weaken and contravene throughout the Dominion at large this most important feature of our constitution.

(4.) We, therefore, as Baptists, beg leave respectfully, but most earnestly, to protest against the establishment of such a system of distribution of public funds in aid of denominational Indian schools, as that said to be contemplated by your Government, and to submit that whatever changes are made in the matter should be in the direction of discontinuance of all such grants at the earliest practicable moment. In support of this protest and memorial permit us to urge, in addition to the foregoing, the following considerations:

(a.) The inherent absurdity, if you will pardon the expression, of such a method. We are well assured that in this matter the Government are sincerely desirous of promoting the moral and religious welfare of the Indians. But consider how ineffective and even harmful such a system must be in relation to these very designs. The Methodists, for instance, in common with other denominations called "Evangelical," firmly believe that the doctrinal teachings of the Roman Catholic Church are based on deadly error and tend directly to foster ignorance, superstition, and moral and spiritual darkness in the minds of those who are brought under their influence. The Roman Catholics, in their turn, hold substantially the same views, and if possible even more strongly, with regard to the tenets and effects of Evangelicalism. And yet the Government hopes to christianize the Indians by taxing Methodists for the propagation of Roman Catholic teachings and Roman Catholics for the propagation of Methodism, and Baptists and many others who are neither Methodists nor Roman Catholics for the propagation of the views of both.

(b.) The mischievous and dangerous tendency of such a system putting as it does, a premium upon mere numbers in the rival schools, to lead, if not to actual misrepresentations, at least to the most unfair and vicious methods of competition, and the holding out of wrong and demoralizing inducements to Indian parents to permit their children to be enrolled in the respective schools. We think that the Government cannot be wholly unaware that already missionaries representing rival schools sometimes suspect and accuse each other of resorting to unworthy bribes and other expedients in order to enlarge their rolls. The moral effects of such rivalries upon the minds of the Indians themselves may readily be imagined.
(c.) The system lacks completeness and finality. All admit that it is in the highest degree desirable that such a system should be adopted as will effect the complete civilization and enlightenment of the Indians, not simply ultimately but within the briefest possible period. Now, though some very encouraging progress is reported from time to time in the industrial training of the north west Indians, the most sanguine friend of the present methods can hardly hope to see the 17,000 or 18,000 Indians in the North-west, to say nothing of those in British Columbia and other provinces, transformed into intelligent and industrious citizens within the next half century. It is not to be hoped for, that under any system of State-aided sectarian schools that can be devised, the work of educating the young Indians as a whole, will be overtaken in a century, to say nothing of their moral and religious transformation. But if this be so, it follows that the establishment of the system proposed would really take on the characteristics of perpetuity, ineffectiveness and hopelessness so far as any complete or satisfactory results are concerned.

(d.) If it be said that some progress is better than none, and that the adoption of the view we advocate would lead to a falling off in the amount of work which is now being done for the uplifting of the Indians, we make bold to reply:

(1.) That it would be a poor compliment to the zeal and liberality of Canadian Christians to believe that their efforts for the moral and spiritual welfare of the aborigines in their own land are dependent upon the aid derived from compulsory taxation by the State. We have such faith in voluntaryism in religious work, a belief well founded upon what is now being done in foreign lands, that we feel sure that the withdrawal of the aid hitherto granted by the Government would lead to redoubled liberality and zeal in the work of Indian missions.

(2.) As to the educational work which properly belongs to the State, we ask whether the time is not come when very much more should be done than has hitherto been done in this direction? May we not, without presumption, direct the attention of the Government and all friends of the Indian to the great work that is now being done in the United States?

After having for a century tried methods somewhat similar to those now employed in Canada, the United States Government has at last, as is well known, adopted vigorous and hopeful measures for the final and complete solution of the whole Indian problem within a generation. Acting on the advice of the Lake Mohonk Conference, a society representing the statesmanship, philanthropy and religious intelligence and zeal of the friends of the Indian in the Republic, the Indian Department is now, with every prospect of success, following out a radically new departure in its treatment of the Indians.

The two great principles underlying this new policy are universal compulsory education of Indian children and youth, at the earliest practicable moment, and the breaking up of the Reservation, and with it, as a not remote consequence, of the tribal system, and the distribution of the land to the Indians in severalty. They are, in short, to be clothed with the duties and responsibilities, and with all the privileges too, of citizenship, under such conditions as may seem best adapted to make citizens of them at the earliest possible moment. The work of Christianizing them will, of course, be left with the churches where it properly belongs. If the Provinces of Canada find it advisable and expedient, as a matter of sentiment, to provide for the compulsory elementary education of all the children who are to become their future citizens, ought not the Dominion itself, a fortiori, to do no less for the children of the Indians who are here already? Let the Government thus settle the question of Indian education, and the churches may safely be trusted to do the work of Christianization. But the other day the Methodist Conference of the United States, assembled at Omaha, unanimously decided that the General Conference should hereafter "decline either to make a petition to or to receive from the National Government any moneys for educational work among the Indians." We are sure the Methodists of Canada will not be slow to emulate so good an example. In fact, some of them are already doing so.

While the members of the Ministerial Association whom this committee represents make no claim to speak for anybody but themselves, they are warranted by the whole history of Baptist principles, and by their general knowledge of the sentiments of their brethren all over the Dominion in their conviction that they voice the minds of the whole body of Canadian Baptists. Steps are being taken to have the question submitted to the various local associations shortly to meet, and also to the General Convention of the Baptists of Ontario and Quebec, which meets in October. We have no doubt that the protest will be heartily concurred in by all these representative bodies.

We deem it proper to forward printed copies of this memorial and protest to the members of the House of Commons and Senate.

We are, Sir, with great respect,

Your obedient servants,

THEODORE H. RAND,
Of McMaster University.

R. D. THOMAS,
Pastor of Jarvis St. Church.

O. C. S. WALLACE,
Pastor of Bloor St. Church.

MEMORANDUM:

The undersigned begs to submit the accompanying statement, which shows:

1. All the Day, Boarding and Industrial schools in the Dominion, grouped by Provinces according to the different religious denominations under whose charge such schools are conducted, as well as the undenominational schools:

2. The money spent on buildings and sites and for management and maintenance in each case, shown separately, and the total amount expended by the Government for each school from the 1st July 1877 to the 30th June 1896.

In treating of the relations which the different Churches bear to the Government in regard to Indian education, it is to be borne in mind that the present Indian school system is the offspring of the missionary efforts of the following
following religious denominations: the Roman Catholics, Church of England, Methodists, Presbyterians, Moravian Society, Society of Friends and the New England Company. Schools were first established at the principal Indian missions, supported partly by the missionaries and partly by the Indians themselves, and without any direct aid from the Government. The first Government grant was made to Indian schools established in Quebec out of Lower Canada Funds, and in 1864 there were only two schools drawing this grant.

In 1847 the Rev. Dr Egerton Ryerson submitted, at the request of the Government, a report (copy herewith) embodying suggestions as to the best method of establishing and conducting Industrial schools for the benefit of the aboriginal Indian tribes, and it was apparently as a result of Dr Ryerson's report that two Industrial schools were established: one at Alnwick, near Coburg, and the other at Muncey, called Mount Elgin, after Lord Elgin, its founder, and placed in charge of the Methodist Missionary Society. Both schools were mainly supported by voluntary contributions from the tribes in Ontario (Upper Canada) each of which devoted one-fourth of their Annuity to this object, with the exception of the Mohawks of the Bay of Quinte, whose village schools were then
then in a very flourishing condition; the Wyandottes of Anderdon, who received no annuity, and the Six Nations, whose educational wants were entirely provided for by the New England Company.

As far back as 1854, the Superintendent General, Mr Oliphant, called the attention of the Government to the advantages of a well defined educational system, and to how highly desirable it was that, if possible, the Department should exercise some authority in enforcing the attendance of children.

The Alnwick school was afterwards closed and merged into the Mount Elgin school, the policy of centralization of these two establishments having been suggested by Lord Bury in 1855, when Superintendent General.

The religious denominations, having in the first instance established schools among the Indians, they have continued to be recognized as exercising more or less control in their management, varying in degree in the case of the different denominations and schools, so that at present the recognized footing upon which they are conducted is as follows:

As regards Day schools: Roman Catholic. The full salary of the teacher, where salary is paid, is paid wholly, or in part, from the school vote or the funds of the Band for whose benefit the school is carried on. In most cases buildings are provided
provided by the Government or the Band, but repairs, fuel and school material are furnished by the Department or the Indians, and in the older Provinces the cost of inspection by the Separate or Public School Inspectors is paid for from the same source, and the Department has, until recently allowed the Church the privilege of nominating and appointing the teachers. This privilege has, however, lately been curtailed, the Department requiring that when practicable the nominees shall be possessed of teacher's certificates, recognized by the Provincial school system. The reason for not making this requirement obligatory is, that duly certificated teachers cannot always be had when a vacancy occurs, who are willing to accept the remuneration offered for the work required of them.

Besides the Day schools the Roman Catholics have established Mission Boarding schools on or in the vicinity of Indian Reserves in Ontario and the Western Provinces, which are directly in charge of members of the different religious orders of the Church. Such schools in Manitoba and the Territories are now paid a per capita grant of $72 per pupil up to the authorized number of pupils, such grant to cover the cost of tuition, management and maintenance, with the exception of school material. In Ontario and British Columbia the Government grant
grant is $60 per annum. The buildings have, in all cases, been provided by the Church with, or without the assistance of the Government. The statement shows to what extent the Department has made contributions for this purpose. These schools have in some instances superseded day schools on Reserves and receive day pupils, whose tuition is paid for at the rate of $12 per capita per annum. Such schools conform to the Regulations of the Department as to the course of study, dietary, clothing, admissions and discharges, and are subject to inspection by authorized officers of the Department. Special grants have, from time to time, been made for repairing, enlarging and equipping these schools.

The Roman Catholics are now in charge of 7 out of the 16 Industrial schools distributed as follows: one in Manitoba at St Boniface, two in the N.W.T. at Qu'Appelle and High River, and four in British Columbia, at Kootenay, Kamloops, Williams Lake and Kuper Island. These schools are all carried on under the per capita system, the grant varying according to the locality in which the school is situated. In connection with the above the undersigned begs respectfully to submit the following remarks in regard to Indian school matters:

The Census shows that the Indians are not decreasing in numbers. They are here to stay and the question naturally arises, what are we to do with them? and what obligations devolve upon the Government in regard to providing means for their advancement and civilization? Are they always to remain a charge on the country, or shall we, by educating the rising generation, endeavor to make them self-supporting and fitted for the duties and privileges of civilized life? The Department, recognizing its responsibility in regard to the future welfare of its Indian wards, has established and is now providing for and carrying on three classes of Indian schools.

Apart
Apart from what is being done in the United States for Indians, the undersigned finds that in all the British colonies, where a native population still remains, steps have been taken for the establishment of Industrial Training schools which are supported wholly, or in part, by the Government, and it is now universally conceded that such Institutions afford the best known means of training the aborigines in habits of industry and the formation of character.

The Indian population of the Dominion is stated as about 100,000, which would give, according to the Census, a school population of from 20,000 to 25,000 (It might be mentioned here that the number of Treaty Indians in the Dominion does not exceed 65,000).

There are close upon 10,000 Indian children now upon the school enrollment with an average daily attendance of over 5,000, or about 20% of the total number of school age, leaving about 75% to 80% who are deriving no benefit from the present school system.

To reach the greatest number, day schools have been established on nearly all Reserves where enough children of school age to attend could be found, but the indifference of Indian parents to education, their nomadic habits and poverty and want of proper clothing prevent much advance being made at present.

Irregular attendance is the greatest
greatest drawback, while the inefficiency and listlessness of teachers and lack of interest displayed by some of the Agents is another.

The Indians in some localities, while showing little interest in sending their children to school regularly are not averse to having them educated, and the correspondence on file in the Department will bear me out in saying that they are now awakening to the necessity for having schools in their midst.

The Regulations for Compulsory Education, lately passed, will when enforced as needed, have a most salutary effect in increasing the attendance and making it more regular and will the undersigned be convinced, dispel the idea that has hitherto been prevalent amongst them that it mattered little whether they took advantage of the educational facilities offered them by the Government or not.

Our Agents should evince a livelier interest in education,—many of them look upon the work now required of them in connection with school matters as an extra duty which is performed in a very perfunctory manner,—especially in the cases of schools conducted by religious bodies. They should be informed that it is useless for the Department to expend large sums of money for the maintenance of schools unless its local officers bestir themselves in the matter of Indian education and render the Department every assistance.
assistance in their power, as without their hearty co-operation, good and lasting results cannot be obtained. A word in seasons from our Agents should have great weight with teachers, parents and children alike. They should not content themselves with making merely a hurried visit to the schools periodically, but when on the Reserves they should visit the homes of parents and explain what the Department is doing and requires them to do in the matter of education.

The Missionaries too, might do much to improve the present state of affairs. At one of the day schools visited by the undersigned, he saw an example of what could be done by a zealous missionary for the cause of education; he refers to Roman Catholic school on the Garden River Reserve, where there were 42 children present on the day of his inspection, while only three pupils were at the Church of England school on the same Reserve, they having no resident missionary. About an equal number of children of school age belong to both denominations.

It has been suggested that the granting of a small prize for regular attendance of pupils would have a good effect. This suggestion is worthy of consideration and should, if possible, be arranged for. The money prizes given by the Mississaugas
Mississaugas of the Credit are a great incentive to the pupils, both in regard to regularity and proficiency.

Our schools are chiefly denominational and receive assistance from various religious bodies, while others have been established and are carried on wholly by the Government under Section 76 sub-sec: ", which reads as follows:

"76: The Chief or Chiefs of any Band in Council may frame, subject to confirmation by the Governor in Council, rules and regulations in respect of the subjects following that is to say:

"(A) As to what religious denomination the teachers of the school established on the Reserve shall belong to: Provided that he shall be of the same denomination as the majority of the Band; and that the Protestant minority may likewise have a separate school, with the approval of and under the regulations made by the Governor in Council".

The Church authorities have up to the present, with few exceptions, exercised full control in the appointment of teachers and they fixed the course of study also. The teachers appointed by the various religious bodies engaged in the work of Indian education, are not as a rule
rule well fitted for the work of teaching, not so much from want of scholarship as from the lack of ability to adapt their instruction to the children's needs, owing to their not having received the proper training. Many of these teachers are no doubt earnest workers, who have at heart the spiritual welfare of those under their charge and would, if qualified, render efficient service to the Department. In addition to their lack of professional training and experience, many of the present teachers have their missionary duties to perform, which take up their time and attention.

As a remedy the undersigned would suggest that communication be had with Normal School Principals, and the insertion of an advertisement in the educational journals published in the different provinces, describing the kind of teachers desired for Indian work, giving localities of Reserves, salaries to be paid and such other information as would enable the intending applicant to decide whether he or she would care to enter upon the work and requesting such Principals to endeavor to induce suitable persons to apply for positions in the school service. Applications for positions should be submitted to the Department, with testimonials and certificates of qualifications and no unqualified teacher should be employed. No changes should be made in teachers without consulting the Department.
Department and receiving its sanction.

Many of the Indians on the outlying Reserves in Ontario and the Lower Provinces are necessarily away from the vicinity of their schools for long periods at certain seasons of the year, taking their families with them. These absences which cannot well be avoided, seriously interfere with the progress of the pupils, as by the time they return to school, they have lost nearly, if not all, they had previously acquired. Teachers are not to blame for this, and the undersigned does not well see how it can be remedied so long as these periodical migrations continue.

Schools are established on some Reserves where the number of children of school age is small and the average attendance is not such as to justify the continuance of a school, but the closing of a school so situated would cause dissatisfaction, and the only remedy that suggests itself to the undersigned would be to provide for an increased number of pupils at some of the existing Boarding schools then and the closing of such schools. The undersigned would suggest that the lowest average attendance that should entitle a school to be continued should be placed at 6 or 7 pupils, as that number could be provided for at a boarding school for about what it costs to maintain a day school.

Most
Most of the Indians so situated are Roman Catholic and there is only one Industrial school conducted by that denomination east Winnipeg at Wikwemikong, at which accommodation could be found for 150 to 200 pupils, 90 pupils being provided for at present. The Fort William school also has room for more pupils than are now provided for.

The Indians of Quebec and the Lower Provinces have no facilities provided for their industrial training. The attendance and progress at most of the schools in these Provinces is very discouraging. The Indians are poorly off and could contribute nothing towards the establishment of a suitable training school, but the necessity for such a school is felt by the intelligent members of the different Bands, and if, in the future, anything could be done in the direction of securing the advantages of an Industrial school, it would be a step in the right direction. A large amount of money is contributed annually for the purchase of supplies for destitute Indians and for seed grain for the Indians of these provinces, most of which could be spent much more advantageously in obtaining industrial training for the rising generation.

Returning to the question of day
day schools and the teachers engaged at such schools the undersigned begs to remark that the salaries paid are not sufficient to induce the right kind of persons to look for such employment, and most of these who seek such situations are generally unfitted for the work, being either lacking in energy or qualifications. This does not, however, in many instances apply to the female teachers, who are as a rule contented to receive even the small salaries offered by the Department. The question of salaries is hard to arrange and is not now in a satisfactory condition. Teachers having large, well conducted schools receive no more than those in charge of schools where the average attendance is so small as to scarcely justify the school being kept open and where little if any good results from their teaching. The undersigned thinks that steps should be taken to remedy this evil, and would suggest that teachers of schools where the average attendance is over a certain number, say 25 as in the North West and Manitoba, they should be paid an additional fee of $12 per annum for each pupil over that number and up to a maximum of 42; and that teachers of such schools, where the average for the year has been below 12 should be paid a smaller salary than many of them are now receiving, viz $300. At present, however
the money available for school purposes does not admit of any such changes being made.

In some cases the small average attendance is beyond the control of the teacher, but such instances are the exception, and the low average is generally attributable to their lack of interest or inability as well as to the indifference of parents. Energetic, painstaking teachers are nearly always successful in securing the attendance of a large percentage of the children of school age who live within a reasonable distance of the school.

Poverty is another great drawback which some of our schools have to contend with. The Indians on some Reserves are so badly off that the children are only half clothed and fed. They often have to go a considerable distance to school, arriving there wet and hungry, and when school is dismissed in the morning they have to return home, having brought nothing with them for lunch, and do not come back in the afternoon and perhaps not for some days. If a certain sum could be set apart to purchase a small quantity of biscuits or pork, peas and flour for making soup, so that each child that went hungry to school in the morning might have a bowl of hot, nourishing soup at noon, regular attendance would be sure to follow. The undersigned has seen this experiment successfully tried at a school he visited on the North Shore.
Shore of Lake Superior, and at the Garden River Roman Catholic school. Biscuits are supplied in Manitoba and the North West, to school children, and at many of the poor schools in Great Britain and on the continent, a warm meal is provided, and in such schools in Paris, breakfast is also given. Education has no charms for the hungry.

Accommodation should, if possible, be provided for teachers of Indian schools on Reserves which are isolated, as no suitable lodging can be had in such localities. Two rooms at least should be added to the school building and small plot of ground should be fenced off and set apart for a garden. This would be an object lesson for the pupils who could attend to it. There is no reason why some industrial training might not be given even at the day schools, as is done at some of the schools in the North West.

Some of the Bands whose schools now receive a grant have sufficient capital to pay liberally for the education of their children. If this were done, funds would then be available when required for the establishment of new schools if necessary, or for increasing the salaries of deserving teachers, or procuring additional assistance.

Of the religious bodies which are engaged in educational work, among the Indians, the Methodists as a class contribute most liberally towards that
that object, paying one-half the salaries of the schools conducted under their auspices. The Church of England in most cases does the same, while the Department has no official knowledge of what the Roman Catholics do in such cases. A few schools are carried on wholly by religious sects without any aid from the Department, save occasionally a moderate supply of school material or a small outlay for repairs and furniture.

When denominational schools were first established too much power and control was placed in the hands of the Church authorities, and it will require the exercise of considerable tact to curtail these powers and withdraw some of the concessions made to them. Under the old system, all that the Department required was that quarterly returns showing the attendance should be sent in, and the grants were frequently paid even without compliance with this rule. They are all now complying with the regulations of the Department as regards the various returns which are called for, but the question of the appointment of teachers remains to be settled. Teachers until lately were removed and replaced without consulting the Department, and complaints of incompetency were made without action being taken by them. This is being remedied, but it has led to very unsatisfactory results and seriously interfered with the educational policy of the Department.
The system of inspection, as now carried on by the Public School Inspectors is, compared with its cost, of little if any practical value to the schools visited or to the Department. The annual expenditure for this service is close upon $1000.

The undersigned expressed his views already in regard to this matter and he begs to call your attention to it again and to state that although certain contingencies might arise when it would be well to call upon a Public School Inspector for a report upon a particular school, he considers that the semi-annual visits of the Provincial officers who only take a cursory glance at the school, could with advantage be discontinued on the score of economy, reserving the privilege of calling upon an inspector to make such special visit as above referred to. In connection with the Memorandum of the 25th ultimo herewith relative to the present system of inspection of Indian schools in Ontario, Quebec and the Maritime Provinces by the Public School Inspectors of those Provinces, the undersigned would respectfully recommend that for the reasons set forth in the Memorandum above referred to, the semi-annual inspections by the Public School Inspectors be discontinued and that they should visit our schools only when called upon to do so by the Department.

After a further experience of three years, the undersigned is still of the same opinion in regard to the system of Inspection followed by the Public school inspectors.

In Manitoba and the North West many of the schools are visited by the Inspectors of Agencies and Reserves, and Mr Betourmay; while some schools cannot possible be visited by these officers, owing to the distance they would have to travel and the other work they have to perform. All the schools on Reserves are however
however, visited periodically, once a month being the rule, by our Agents. The undersigned is, however, inclined to think that Agents as a rule are opposed to make an adverse report on a school if there is any way of avoiding it, it being more than likely that such action would bring them into collision with the Missionaries and interfere with their authority among the Indians. The undersigned knows of instances where unfavorable reports have led to charges being made against the officers making them, and for this reason he considers it would be better if the principle schools, boarding and industrial, could be visited more frequently by Departmental inspectors, or some other officer detailed specially for that service.

The undersigned considers that when our inspectors do visit a school they devote too much time and attention to minute details, such as inventories, statements, returns, accounts &c and pass lightly over such high matters as the general progress, management and results obtained. An Inspector should be able to tell at a glance if proper order and discipline obtains and whether the school is well managed or not. The undersigned is convinced that the success or failure of a school depends entirely upon the executive head and not upon subordinates or surroundings. A thoroughly competent Principal will make a success of a school while
while a man lacking the ability to direct and manage, no matter how well educated, will fail or be content to work on and trust to luck. When an Inspector finds an unsuccessful man in charge he should say so plainly and not leave it to the Department to try and discover where the defects exist.

There are no Inspectors for British Columbia, although the Superintendent visits as many of the Reserves as his time will allow. The schools in that Province are also visited by our Agents who no doubt have the same hesitancy as its Agents elsewhere in making too critical reports.

The undersigned cannot help expressing the opinion that he considers it at least unfortunate for the school and the Department, that Boarding and Industrial schools are not inspected at least once a year by some other officer than the Agent.

There is no one in the Department who has ever seen more than a few of our principal schools or knows how they are carrying on the work best suited to the wants of the Indians, or whether the training given is required for any particular locality. The different conditions of the Indians scattered over the Dominion call for different methods of Industrial training. In Central Ontario, attention is only given
given to farming. On the Georgian Bay and North Shore of Lake Superior, farming alone would not support the Indians on most of the Reserves. In Manitoba and the North-West stock raising and fishing will be the chief means of support according to the location of the Reserves, while in British Columbia there can be little or no farming for Indians, small garden plots being about all the land they can have, but at fishing and labor, either mechanical or common, there is plenty of employment to be found. These considerations should be taken more largely into account in fixing on the industrial training to which a school is to devote more particular attention.

As previously stated the difference between boarding and industrial schools is more a matter of money than anything else, boarding schools receiving in most cases a much lower rate of Government assistance than is allowed for Industrial schools, viz: $60 to $72 per capita per annum. There is no reason why the results aimed at by Industrial schools could not be achieved by boarding schools. In some cases equally good work is done in the way of teaching and industrial training.

Boarding schools were established as an advance on Reservation Day schools, where children could be removed from home influences and have the benefit of civilized surroundings without being taken...
taken away from their parents sight, to which many Indians made strong objections at first. A well conducted boarding school on a Reserve should have a powerful influence for good.

The policy of the American Government in regard to education is apparently to encourage Reservation Boarding schools, while our efforts have been, in the past, chiefly directed towards the establishment of Industrial schools, as it was thought much better results would be obtained from the latter class of school, which in all cases are situated off Reserves. It has been found from experience in some cases, that the progress made at Reservation schools is more or less interrupted by the proximity and influence of the Indians on the Reserve, who for very trivial reasons frequently wish to remove their children, and even, if unsuccessful in their efforts the children become unsettled.

Many, if not all of the Boarding schools are in receipt of outside aid, the exact amount of which the Department has, at present, no means of knowing, as the Principals are decidedly averse to furnishing such information. The Department has, however, lately called upon them for a return of all amounts received in money and in kind by such schools, as it is very necessary that it should have reliable information on this point so that it may be able
able to judge of the ability of the Church authorities to successfully carry on any particular school. It may be here stated that some of the religious bodies heretofore refused to furnish this information or even to state for publication the salaries paid by them to employees at the schools.

The Reservation Boarding school should be used as a feeder for the Industrial schools, where young children should be sent and trained until they arrive at a suitable age for the Industrial school. At present children are admitted to Industrial schools at ages varying from 4 to 18 or 20 years. The admission of very young children to Industrial schools should, the undersigned thinks be discontinued for very many reasons. First the cost of maintaining a child at a boarding school is from $60 to $75 only, while at an Industrial school the cost to the Government is all the way from $110 to $145 a year, and a child of 4 years would have to remain about 15 years in the latter Institution before its discharge, costing the country all the way from $1650 to $2175, making Indian education a very costly experiment. There are pupils at present in some of the Industrial schools who have cost the country this amount, if not more.

An age limit should be fixed for the admission of pupils to Industrial schools and they should not be allowed to remain beyond
beyond a certain time. If pupils were in the first instance drafted into Industrial schools from boarding or day schools at a suitable age and after having reached a certain standard of proficiency in their studies, such schools could be more easily managed and at less expense than at present; besides which the mingling of very young children with grown up boys and girls is not the best training they can receive, and the Department is aware of many instances where this practice has produced many pernicious results, while the admission of boys nearly or over 16 is equally disastrous to the morals and discipline of the school. A case in point is that of a boy over 16 admitted to Calgary school, who is now under arrest for criminal assault on one of the female employees of that Institution.

If young children were excluded from Industrial schools more time and attention could be given to Industrial training and pursuits. A stronger and healthier class of pupils could be obtained, as evidences of hereditary complaints would have become apparent before their transfer and the cost of maintenance of sickly pupils would be avoided.

The undersigned considers that if the above plan of recruiting for Industrial schools were followed, that 14 years would be about the proper age for receiving pupils who should be ready for their discharge when they arrive at 16 years.
years, this being the limited age to which they can be retained at such schools under the Regulations relating to the Compulsory education of Indian children, and any pupils taken under the prescribed age should be paid for at only at Boarding School rates. Four years residence at an Industrial school, after a previous training at a day or boarding school should be long enough to furnish them education and manual training. It is longer than most white children receive. When the Industrial and Boarding schools were first opened, it was difficult, owing to the aversion that parents had to parting with their children, to obtain pupils who were in every instance physically sound, and in consequence of the hereditary ailments of many of these children, the death-rate has been higher than otherwise; but it is a source of pleasure to say that the Indians are recognizing the benefits which their children receive at these Institutions and applications for admission are constantly coming in, which are (for some of the schools greatly in excess of the accommodation provided, and out of which the Department is enabled to select a much more healthy class of pupils, and instructions have already been given to admit none but those who are able to pass a medical examination.

The establishment of an Industrial school near a thriving town is thought to be a step in the right direction, as pupils at such schools are brought
brought into closer contact with the white population, and from their association and environment more readily acquire civilized habits. There is also this additional advantage—pupils can be taught trades and have freer scope for the exercise of any particular aptitude they may exhibit for one or other of the trades taught at the school, as they can be and often are apprenticed to local tradesmen who are always glad to secure their services, but generally without remuneration, and by whom they are well cared for and instructed. Printing, tinsmithing and harness making are thus acquired by pupils, while some are clerks, who if placed in a school on a Reserve, would not have similar opportunities and advantages.

The Industrial school system which is intended for the higher education and manual training of Indian youth, has to a large extent been adopted from the older established Industrial schools in the United States, principally the Carlisle Institute in Pennsylvania, which is the largest and most successful school of the kind on this continent. The policy followed by Captain Pratt, who has had charge of the school since its inception, is to so civilize and educate his pupils, that they cease, for all practical purposes to be Indians, being absorbed by the white population, as none of his pupils are returned to their Reserves. This policy has its adherents.
adherents among the Principals of our Industrial schools. While this scattering of the clans may be possible in the thickly populated portions of the United States it is impracticable for our Western Indians as great difficulty is found in obtaining steady work at living wages for pupils who have learned trades at any of our schools.

The question therefore presents itself,-what is ultimately to become of pupils who have finished the prescribed course at our Industrial schools, and what is to be their civil status? Are they still to remain Indians in the eye of the law, or is their graduation from an Industrial school to be recognized as a preliminary step towards their ultimate enfranchisement? Are they to be returned to their Reserves, or to have Crown lands assigned to them, either in block so as to form an advanced Indian settlement, or are they to be allowed to take up lands like white settlers? All these schemes have their advocates, some suggesting that allotments on Reserves, laid out on the cart-wheel system, should be given them; while others would prefer the formation of separate colonies on Government lands near the Industrial schools. A definite policy of dealing with ex-pupils still remains to be settled upon. There are at present a number of youths of both sexes who should, on account of age and length of time spent in such schools, at once be discharged, but
this cannot be done until suitable arrangements have been made for their final disposition.

Another question which presents itself is, have our schools been a success in the past? Judging from reports received on the status of discharged pupils, they cannot be said to have been a success. Who or what has caused this apparent failure? Such failure is partly due to their selection in the first instance, to the superficial work done at the school, from which they returned and to the want of proper arrangements for their return.

Agents although requested to have a special care for discharged pupils, cannot fairly be held responsible for their having failed to reach such a state of civilization as would assure success in their future career. The English Government, which has about 190 Reformatory and Industrial schools throughout Great Britain for youthful criminals and waifs and strays, adopts this plan of dealing with schools that fall below the prescribed standard of excellence.

It may be said that nearly all these schools are carried on under contract with religious bodies, like our per capita grant system. If the Inspector of these schools reports unfavourably of any particular school it is warned and if in his subsequent report the management is still unsatisfactory a certain reduction in the grant follows. This is said to have the desired effect.
and does away with a great deal of unnecessary correspondence. This plan is worthy of consideration.

The American Reports do not show how they deal with such cases, but judging by the frequent change of Principals at many of the schools, they have similar difficulties to contend with. Such changes do not follow changes of Government, as Indian school employees come under the Civil Service rules.

Judging by the difficulty experienced and time expended in the preparation of the Financial Statement accompanying this report, the undersigned is of opinion that a change in the method of dealing with Indian school accounts is most desirable.
