Sir,

In addition to the Statement and report asked for showing the cost and condition of Indian schools, I beg to make the following remarks:

The chief desirability in selecting a site for an Industrial or Boarding school should be good land, suitable for mixed farming. Where have such schools in Manitoba and the North West been placed? In most cases they have not enough good farming land attached to them to be of any real benefit. A well selected site would materially lessen the cost of maintenance.

What do we find? Hay and grazing land some miles away from the school, water supply altogether inadequate, no timber or wood land. These mistakes were made when the schools were built, but the Department is the looser by the want of proper foresight in the selection of sites. Expensive appliances have had to be furnished to provide water, extra expenditure has had to be incurred for fuel, and loss of time incurred in the cutting and hauling of hay for stock.
stock. No private individual could carry on farming operations under similar circumstances.

In connection with the unsuitable sites, the location of the buildings has, in many instances, evinced a greater want of judgment; buildings have been put up where drainage is well nigh impossible and without any attention or consideration being had for ordinary sanitary laws, and in the most exposed situations. The buildings have been put up without due consideration of the purposes for which they would be required, hurriedly constructed of poor material, badly laid out, without due provision for lighting, heating or ventilation.

In all modern school architecture, great stress is laid on lighting, heating and ventilation, as it is recognized that the health of the pupils is to a great extent dependent upon good light, equable temperature and pure air, the last of which is of the greatest importance.

What do we find in our schools? Ventilation wholly disregarded, or in the few instances where any attempt has been made to provide for it, that an entire disregard of all scientific principles has been shown. Outlets for the escape of foul air are provided in some rooms at a few schools but without adequate provision for the ad-
mission of fresh air, and it is scarcely any wonder that our Indian pupils who have an hereditary tendency to phthisis, should develop alarming symptoms of this disease after a short residence in some of our schools, brought on by exposure to draughts in school rooms and sleeping in overcrowded, over-heated and unventilated dormitories.

This subject of ventilation or the want of ventilation was brought home so forcibly to the Department that it has been making close enquiry into the subject, and I regret to say that in almost every instance I find that it has been totally overlooked in the past, and that to improve it will entail heavy expense on the Department. I have consulted several prominent architects and visited all the public institutions here in Ottawa and in Toronto and I find that the proper ventilation of overcrowded sleeping rooms is absolutely essential to the health of the inmates. I have seen several devices for the improvement of the ventilation of old buildings and I consider the one placed in the St Patrick's Orphans Asylum here the cheapest and best.

On the subject of dormitories I have no hesitation in saying that large dormitories are unsuited to our schools. The best equipped institutions I have read of or seen, provide for smaller numbers and more isolation. At the Alexandra
Industrial school for girls in Toronto, each girl has a separate apartment. At the Mohawk Institute, Brantford, four girls are in each compartment, while in the United States Indian schools, they recommend separate rooms to accommodate three pupils. I know that it would not be possible to make such arrangements in our schools, but I see no reason why smaller rooms, with partitions could not be had. It would ensure a proper classification of pupils as to age and provide a certain amount of privacy which is now entirely lacking.

Intimately connected with the subject of ventilation, is the question of closets. In all our larger Institutions these are placed in the main building, which I maintain is entirely wrong, no matter what system is adopted. The Smead Dowd system is exclusively used and has proved, from different causes to be a failure and a menace to the health of the pupils. The Principal of the Mimico Industrial school, where the system is placed in some of the cottage homes, told me that he had more sickness in the cottages where it was used than in the others and he disapproved of it and was doing his best to have it removed. We have been obliged to do away with it at Rupert's Land. The Principal of the Brandon school is constantly complaining of foul air arising from these closets. Experts have examined the construction and working of these
closets and have pronounced against them. The flush closet is also, in my opinion, open to objection as there is always a likelihood of something getting out of order, clogging of drains, traps, etc. Cess Pools have, in nearly all cases, to be provided in connection with flush closets, and these at the best are most unsavory places and entail a lot of disagreeable work in connection with keeping them fairly clean.

The system most highly spoken of and which gives the best satisfaction is the dry earth closet. This is recommended by the New York Board of Health and School Board. It is in use at the Mohawk Institute and gives perfect satisfaction. Even in a cold climate like the North West there is no absolute necessity why the closets should be inside the main building. A covered way leading to dry earth closets at a distance would be far preferable, and a dry earth commode could be placed near the dormitories for night use in case of necessity.

The dry earth closet is the most simple and easily managed closet known while the Smead-Dowd system requires a skilled mechanic to look after it, and only work fairly well at certain seasons and stages of the wind.

The water supply is a constant source of trouble and expense.
Windmills do not answer. Hot-air pumping engines are apparently hard to manage, while a steam pumping plant is very costly and intricate.

The ages of pupils vary all the way from four to twenty years and over and little if any distinction is made among pupils of the same sex as regards food, clothing, study, work, recreation, moral and religious training, rest and sleep. The time table for the day generally covers 15 hours or more, for study work and play, and the balance of the time for sleep. A days routine at a school is a wearisome grind for teacher and pupil and should in most cases be shortened considerably. There is time allowed for rest, unless change of occupation is considered to be rest. The half day system, although in use generally in schools of the kind, is very trying for any but the grown up pupils. Say a boy works all the morning on the farm, at his trade or about the house and barns, he is pretty well used up by noon, and then after dinner he has to put in four or five hours in class and study. I am inclined to think that the half-day system should occasionally be changed and that work and study should be taken up alternately, monthly or oftener.

The dietary scale provides for an ample supply of plain food, but variety and skill in its preparation is not
insisted on. The bill of fare is decidedly monotonous and makes no allowance for peculiarities of taste or constitution. What is one man's meat is said to be another man's poison, but at our schools it is die dog or eat the hatchet. In almost every instance when meals are mentioned by inspectors they are said to be well cooked.

I doubt very much whether they ever took a full regulation school meal of bread and dripping, or boiled beef and potatoes. Cooking is one of the civilized arts and should be practised and taught at our schools.

As nearly all our schools are now on the per capita system the supply of clothing rests with the schools. Better foot wear should be provided for winter, especially for boys working about the barns. Discharged pupils should receive a new outfit and not be obliged, as is at present the case, at some schools, to return their clothes and take any old worn out garments that come to hand.

Children should be classified according to ages, the very young children in a separate room. Double beds should in all cases be done away with and not allowed in any school. Straw ticks, even when charged frequently, are not suitable for crowded rooms, or for young children. The dormitories are well over-heated in most
cases, so they are not required for warmth, and on the score of cleanliness they should be dispensed with. Nearly all the schools have been supplied with modern spring mattresses and if they had a thick felt or rag mat spread over them, they would be quite warm and comfortable and could be easily aired and cleaned. They are manufacturing felt at Qu'Appelle and could no doubt supply such mats at a reasonable price. They are made at Central Prison, Toronto and are used by the Ontario Government schools.

The question of overcrowding should be particularly looked into. In many of the schools ablutions are performed in the dormitories. This causes a good deal of work and makes a great mess and confusion. A well arranged lavatory with plenty of basins and separate towels for each pupil should be provided for both boys and girls. The bath tub in a large Institution is of very little use and wastes a lot of water, which is slopped about the floor. In all modern institutions and gymnasiums a large concrete space with a raised run of 10 inches to a foot is made and supplied with a hot and cold shower; bathing can be done quickly by this means with clean water. I have seen eight or ten boys run through the same water in an ordinary bath tub, water being scarce but very dirty at the last. A teacher should occupy a room looking into
and having communication with each dormitory.

The heating is nearly all done by stoves and hot air furnaces, and the consumption of fuel is enormous even for the coldest climate. There are no thermometers in most of the schools and a well regulated temperature cannot be maintained. When Lord Aberdeen visited Brandon in the fall of '95, he complained of the excessive heat of the rooms and recommended that thermometers be supplied, six of which were sent that school. Have seen no mention of any appliances being used to moisten the atmosphere, which must be hot dry and stifling.

In connection with the internal economy and management of a well-organized school, I would refer you to my report on the Mohawk Institute, which gives full details regarding that well conducted school.

I will now refer to the organization of our schools. All the denominational schools are in charge of the clergy, but it is a question whether priest or parson is best fitted by education, training or profession to assume the direct control and management of such institutions. Frequent changes in the staff of some of the Boarding schools handicap their work while the constant bickering and petty jealousies at other
schools have had an equally bad effect on some of the larger Institutions. I have already pointed out what I consider the only remedy for this state of things.

The education and civilization of the Western Indians is still in its infancy and we should be content to let them creep for a time before they attempt to walk. It is only a few years since they were wild untamed savages, living by the chase, hunting in small bands or families. Now that game is not to be had, they must, of necessity, turn to the soil for their subsistence. Necessity will be their best civilizer. The Government is assisting in every way to make them farmers, farmers first, then citizens. Then they can do what they like with their children. If the Government succeeds in making farmers and settlers of the rising generation, it will have carried out its obligations. I do not see that it is called upon to make them all mechanics, merchants, teachers or clerks. The first thing to do is to teach them how to get their living from the soil, give them locations and assistance at the start. When they have learned this all the rest will be easy. We should go steadily to work with this end in view, instead of trying to over-run the country with a lot of half-trained and half-educated so-called Industrial pupils. The needs of the country do not call for all the different trades pupils even if they
were turned out as finished workmen. The use of ordinary carpenter's tools and some knowledge of blacksmithing should be acquired by all the boys as these would be useful to them—but what opening is there for printers, shoemakers, tailors and several other trades that are now taught at a loss of time, wages and material at some of the schools.

The chief ambition of an Industrial school is to possess a Brass Band and a printing press. Music has charms, but enough money has been expended upon brass bands to place a musical instrument, such as a piano or organ in nearly every school in the country. The Brass Band and newspaper are outward show and help to advertise the school. More solid comfort and enjoyment could be had with the other kind of music in which all could join.

There are ten Industrial schools in Manitoba and the North West with accommodation for about 1400 pupils, more than one-half of whom are boys, not more than one-half of whom, under the system lately pursued, would know anything of farming, while the other half would be supposed to be taught trades. Where could the Government expect to find employment for 200 apprentices annually—for they would still have to serve an apprenticeship before they could join the Union. The religious denominations do not bestir themselves, so far as I am aware, to secure
employment for ex-pupils of their schools.

If all these boys could be placed in civilized countries, what is to become of the educated Indian maiden, "tempestiva virō" is she to be provided with a civilized husband by a fostering Government, or is she to return to the Reserve and become the bride of some untutored savage. I think that for some time at least, it would be better not to be ambitious but to restrict our energies to the only field that at present presents a prospect of success.

Contrasting the suggestions contained in Dr Ryerson's report of 50 years ago with the elaborate scheme adopted by our schools and copied from the Carlyle, on the strength of Mr Davin's report made in 1879, it must be admitted that Dr Ryerson's idea of industrial training is the one best suited to the present generation of Indians. In the hereafter, probably 40 years hence, the more elaborate training might be successful, but by that time I trust the Indians will be able to support such high class Institutions themselves.

The prescribed Programme of Studies for Indian schools is very similar to that used in the Public schools, with more stress laid on the teaching of English. The Superintendent of Indian schools Washington D.C. has issued a Syllabus of Language work and suggestions to teachers.
containing lessons in speaking, reading, writing, spelling and grammar for use in Indian schools. Our teachers have no similar aids provided, and as in most instances they are not skilled in teaching methods, the acquisition of the English language by Indian pupils is an exceedingly slow process. What we most require is a better qualified class of teachers and a more improved primary system. Teachers should possess the true missionary spirit and be the best all round men and women. Ignoramus, idlers, time-killers and salary grabbers should not be employed.

The Kindergarten is now recognized to be the means for interesting and instructing children and in the few schools where it has been introduced, its beneficial influence is shown in many ways and especially in the easy acquirement of English. It should certainly be introduced where there are young children, as well as object lesson cards, maps and the more general use of the blackboard. A visit to a Kindergarten class will convince the most sceptical of the benefits conferred by this system. Willing and efficient teachers will make a success of any school and be an acquisition to any Indian settlement.

I think the number of Industrial schools is greater than at present called for. The Churches carrying them on look after them as part of their missionary work, while the Government pays the shot. If the designation of some of the
so-called Industrial schools were changed to Manual Training or Sloyd, it would be nearer the mark. We have few, if any, Industrial or technical training schools properly so-called. Four or five of the latter class of school would more than supply all the technical training required. There is always likely to be a certain percentage of Indian boys who will show some special fitness for technical work and these might have the benefit of proper training, but I consider it a waste of time and money to force a trade on a boy who is not likely to make a success of the opportunities afforded him.

In British Columbia the Industrial schools are the rule, there being no less than seven of these institutions, each allowed an annual grant of $130 per pupil, which is higher in proportion, considering climate and cost of living, than the grant to any other schools.

The distinction between Industrial schools in British Columbia is even less noticeable than in Manitoba and the Territories. There is a Roman Catholic school at the Mission on the Lower Fraser which has been in existence for a number of years and draws $60 per cap per annum, while the Methodist school at Coqualeetza, a few miles further down the River receives $130 per pupil. The amount
of the grant is the only distinction between the two schools.

Openings for Indian boys in British Columbia are, if anything, harder to find than in Manitoba and the Territories. The condition of the B.C. Indians is very different from those of the North West. They mix more with whites and have always been able to support themselves and need not be to any great extent a charge upon the Government. Education of the right kind will of great use and assistance, but high class industrial training will do them very little good and be of very little practical value.

The B.C. Indians are all experts in the industries and pursuits they are engaged in, and the time spent in these schools will not help to fit them for their after work. These remarks apply to the Coast Indians who are all engaged in fishing for their livelihood. The Indians of the interior will have to work in the mines or on the railroad, raise stock or become farmers, and manual training will be a great help to them, but technical or industrial training is not needed to any extent. One school of the latter class would more than supply the requirements of British Columbia.

I have referred to the difficulty of obtaining employment for graduates from our Industrial schools and when
work is found, to keep them at it. As an instance I will mention the case of Gilbert Bear, ex-pupil of the Battleford Industrial school, a printer by trade. Gilbert was a "star pupil", spent three months at the World's Fair, returned to the school, was foreman of the school paper and a good specimen of the Industrial school pupil. When the time for discharging Gilbert arrived, it was difficult to know what to do with him. Happy thought, bring him to Ottawa. He arrived here nearly two years ago and has had steady employment at night work in the Citizen office. His wages for the first year and a half were $3.50, lately raised to $4 a week, not enough to pay for his board and clothes. Although he is admitted to be a good printer, he cannot get more wages. He does not belong to the Union and is merely a printer's devil. Now Gilbert had some difficulty with the foreman about working over-time and was discharged on Saturday last. He says he is not fairly treated, while the foreman contends that he would not obey orders. I have had to see the proprietor of the Citizen twice and hunt up Gilbert, take him to the office to try and settle the dispute and get him taken back. Since the close of the Session printers are plentiful and Gilbert is back as a favor. Trouble is likely to occur again as Gilbert is dissatisfied, hates the night work, and if the truth were told, would rather be back home on the Reserve and end his brilliant career of letters. This is my experience of
Industrial school training and I cannot say that I consider it very encouraging.

We have another class of school which has not cut much of a figure in the past. This is the Reservation day school.

It must be confessed that the ordinary Indian day school on outlying Reserves does no appreciable good as a civilizer or educator. It would seem to have been instituted to afford a resting place for some lazy, incompetent individual with just sufficient energy to draw a small salary. I think that a well conducted day school, in charge of a practical man or woman, who knows a good deal outside the text-books, and who would be ready and willing to do anything useful and right, and who was eager to find something to do for the real good of the people, would be the greatest blessing that could fall to the lot of the Indians. I am confident that there are such people and that they could be found if properly sought for and appreciated when discovered.

Mr William Duncan, who founded the Indian Colony at Metlakahtla in British Columbia, was such a man. He first settled as a lay missionary among the Indians at Fort Simpson. These Indians are described as then being all pagans and the most debauched and demoralized Indians on the Coast. After a few years the settlement at Metlakahtla, to which he and the
Indians had removed, was admitted to be a model of Christianity, civilization and good government. All this was achieved through the unaided efforts of one earnest Christian worker.

In conclusion I think I may fairly say that during the four years I have been connected with the school work of the Department, I have given the subject of Indian education most careful attention and study and have endeavored in every way possible to fit myself for the responsibilities this work entails, and my only regret is that I have not had an opportunity of becoming more intimately acquainted with our schools as they are and of meeting more people engaged in this work.

Memorandum:

With reference to the Minister's memo. of the 24th February last addressed to the late Deputy Superintendent General requiring a statement showing fully, clearly and exhaustively the relations which the different churches bear to the Government in the matter of Indian education, which statement was to include,—

1. All day, boarding and industrial schools in the different parts of Canada, grouped according to the churches which have them in charge.

2. All moneys spent on buildings and sites in each case.

3. By whom such moneys were spent; that is, whether by the church or the Government, and if partially by one and partially by the other, the amount spent by each to be separately shown.

4. The exact terms upon which each school is conducted, and the instances in which the same have been departed from, and the nature of and reasons for such departures.

5. The yearly expenditure by the Government on Indian education, showing in brief the yearly amount paid to schools, grouped under the names of the churches.
churches controlling them,—the undersigned begs to submit herewith a statement prepared by the clerk in charge of schools, giving the information asked for, in the form of four statistical statements, marked "a", "b", "c", & "d",— "a" showing the expenditure for the last twenty years ending the 30th June, 1896, of all schools in the Dominion, grouped according to the churches which have them in charge;

"b" showing the total cost of the different Industrial Institutions in Man., the N.W.T., and B.C.;

"c" showing the total cost of the different boarding schools in the N.W.T., Man., and B.C., with summary of the entire expenditure of all classes of schools in these three Provinces named.

"d" showing the number of industrial, boarding and day schools in operation during the year ended 30th June, 1896, with enrollment, attendance, appropriation, &c., grouped under the different churches which have them in charge.

Also a memo. from Mr. Benson showing the relationship the Department sustains to the schools in question;

And a semi-official report addressed to the undersigned, in which Mr. Benson expresses his views in detail.

In connection with the foregoing, the undersigned would state that in 1879 Mr. Nicholas Flood Davin made a report on the working of industrial schools for the education of Indians and mixed bloods in the United States and as to the advisability of establishing similar institutions in the North West Territories of Canada—a copy of which report the Minister
Minister already has before him.

The result of Mr. Davin's report was, that in 1884 the Industrial Schools at Battleford, High River and Qu'Appelle were established in the North West Territories. Since the date of Mr. Davin's report there has been no other printed report dealing with the school question, except a confidential report made by Mr. Vankoughnet to Sir John Macdonald in 1887—a copy of which report the Minister has likewise before him,—and which provided for a large increase of expenditure, by raising the salaries of the teachers, providing houses for a number of them, and a midday meal for the pupils. The additional cost to be incurred in the first place if Mr. Vankoughnet's report had been adopted would have been $892,620.63 and a further yearly cost of $545,206.60, as contrasted with the present expenditure, which is in the neighborhood of $400,000. Mr. Vankoughnet's report, however, was not adopted in toto, but the Department has provided for the Indian attendants of schools in Manitoba and the North West a mid-day meal; but no such provision is made for the pupils attending schools in the other Provinces. The salaries paid the teachers have not been increased. The Department pays in the North West and British Columbia at the rate of $300, with a possible increase up to $504; that is, for any school that has an average attendance of over 25 and up to 42, $12 per capita per annum is paid.

It will be seen on reference to Mr. Benson's memo., page 5, et seq., that by an Order in Council of the
the 23rd October, 1892, a basis was arrived at by the Department for carrying on Industrial Schools in Manitoba and the North West Territories under the per capita system; and on page 10 of his report the Minister will see the concessions that have been made by the department in dealing with such schools. In view, therefore, of the Order in Council of the 23rd October, 1892, and the Departmental concessions as stated in Mr. Benson's memo., the undersigned considers that the basis of dealing with these Industrial Schools is almost as definite as if the Department had a special agreement with each institution. In the case of the Brandon School, recently handed over, the arrangement come to was virtually in accordance with the conditions already indicated. According to Statement "D" it will be seen that there are 15 Industrial Schools in the Dominion. This statement deals with the schools to the 30th June, 1892. Since then the Coqualeetza School, in British Columbia, has been recognized as an Industrial School, which makes the number sixteen instead of fifteen, as given in Statement D. The same statement shows that there are 84 Boarding Schools and 230 Day Schools. As pointed out in Mr. Benson's memo., there is not a great deal of difference between the present Boarding and Industrial school as regards what is taught in each, the chief difference being in the grant made by the Department, only $78 being paid per pupil in the case of Boarding Schools, and from $110 to $145 in the case of Industrial. In each the girls get the same instruction; but more trades are taught the boys in some of the Industrial Schools. The boarding school takes the place of what the Americans call the "Reserva-
"Reservation Boarding School," they being on reserves and the Industrial Schools being off reserves.

It would appear necessary that the Department should have the three grades of schools; but the undersigned considers that it would be well to lay down the rule that pupils should not enter the Boarding Schools unless under exceptional circumstances, under the age of 8 years and not remain in these schools longer than six years, which would bring them to the age of 14, making the age from 8 to 14 for Boarding Schools. And from the Boarding School they could be drafted into the Industrial Schools, where they might remain from 14 to 18. The undersigned considers that in the case of pupils entering Boarding and Industrial Schools, they should be required to pass a medical examination, and none but the healthiest children should be educated thereat.

As regards the intellectual training at such schools, the object should be to give a plain English education, adapted to the needs of the working farmer and mechanic.

As indicated in Dr. Ryerson's report of 1847—a copy of which is sent herewith—the undersigned does not consider it advisable that extra efforts should be made to train the Indian youths as carpenters, cabinet makers, shoemakers, tailors, &c., as there is not much likelihood, for many years to come, of Indians so trained being capable of earning a livelihood at such trades in competition with others. The chief aim should be to train the Indian youths how to earn a livelihood when they return to the reserves, and it seems altogether out of the question for the Department to undertake to educate
educate a large number of Indians with the idea of making them equal to white men by the process of education. The result of such course is, that the Indian pupils have still to be provided for by the Department after they leave school; and thus a double responsibility is undertaken, namely, that of educating them and then of providing them the means afterwards of obtaining a livelihood: Whereas if the Indians were educated simply with the idea of obtaining their livelihood as Indians and assuming the status of white men as soon as they might have the means to do so, they would be better prepared to go back to their reserves and set an example to other members of the band. It might be advisable, however, in the case of graduates of Industrial Schools to provide for their ipso facto enfranchisement, and give them locations on their reserves as enfranchised Indians.

With regard to the question of inspection of Indian Schools, the Minister will see from Mr. Benson's memo, that the Department has its schools inspected in the older Provinces by the Public School Inspectors of the Province; but this is not done in the North West and British Columbia, where the inspection is made by the Department's own officials. The Minister might consider it necessary to do away with this inspection by the School Inspectors in the older Provinces, as so far it must be confessed such inspection has not resulted in much good and has entailed considerable expense.

With regard to the concluding part of Mr. Benson's
Benson's report, in which he suggests some change in the manner of dealing with Indian School accounts, the undersigned would state that he has looked into this matter, and he considers that there is no particular need for any change in the present system. He finds that a separate account is kept with each Industrial School in Manitoba and the North West Territories and British Columbia, and the expenditure of each can be ascertained from the Ledger without any difficulty whatever. Moreover, an account is kept with each Agency in these Provinces of expenditure for Day Schools in the Agency, from which can always be taken the total expenditure under that head and with very little trouble. There is also a general account, in which appears the total expenditure on account of schools in these Provinces.

As regards the schools in Ontario, Quebec and the Maritime Provinces, one account is kept, but there is no difficulty whatever in ascertaining the expenditure on each, as the Ledger is divided into sub-heads, by which can be told at a glance the expenditure on each. The undersigned is satisfied that if the Minister were to see the books he would not be disposed to suggest any change.

The undersigned would add that although the expenditure upon Indian Schools for the past 30 years has been large and the appropriation for such purpose is still large, it is questionable after all whether the expenditure has not been justified considering the advance the Indians of the North West have made during that time; and it is difficult, of course, to tell to what
what extent this expenditure has been a factor in helping the Indians forward. The true policy would, however, seem to be to keep this expenditure as much within bounds as possible and not to extend our Industrial School system, unless such extension becomes an absolute necessity. It might even be possible to change some of the present Industrial Schools into Non-Reservation Boarding Schools and give a smaller grant than they are now receiving.

The undersigned considers that more responsibility should be thrown on the denominations which have charge of Indian Schools to provide employment for the Indian pupils. As it is now, the onus appears to be altogether on the Department, and it seems only fair that, as co-workers with the Department, the denominations should be made to realize their responsibility in this direction. They have constituencies in which, no doubt, a large number of the Indian pupils who graduate could obtain employment if the denominations exerted themselves to provide such for the Indian pupils.

Respectfully submitted,

Acting Secretary.

Department of Indian Affairs—
OTTAWA, 30th January, 1902:

Statement "A" herewith shows the different classes of Indian Schools by denominations with the enrollment at each, average attendance, total cost and cost per capita on enrollment and average attendance as taken from the Annual Report of 1900.

Statement "B" herewith shows the number of boarding and industrial schools conducted by the different denominations by provinces with the number of pupils provided for and the amount of the grant for maintenance for the current year, 1901-2.
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, 30th January, 1902:

The Secretary:

With reference to the comparative statement of amounts granted by the Government of the Dominion of Canada for educational purposes among the Indians, to the Roman Catholic, the Anglican, the Methodist and the Presbyterian denominations respectively, which you handed me on the 17th instant for report, I beg to say that while the numbers of Indians belonging to each denomination is correctly stated according to the Census as shown in the Annual Report for 1900, it is hardly fair to calculate the per capita cost on this basis. The only reliable way to arrive at the cost of Indian education is to take the actual enrollment and the expenditure for each class of school.

There were 287 schools in operation that year:-226 day, 39 boarding and 22 industrial with a total enrollment of 9634 pupils and an average attendance of 6193. The total cost of all schools was $365,933.27.

I have prepared a statement showing the cost calculated in the above manner which you will find herewith marked Statement "A".

Of the 38,651 Indians claimed by the Roman Catholics as belonging to their faith, 11,456 are included in the census of Quebec and the Lower Provinces, for which only day school accommodation is provided,-there being 34 such schools to meet this demand, 28 of which are conducted under the auspices
of the Roman Catholic church, two are undenomination-
al and paid for by the Indians, three are carried on
by the Methodists, who pay half the salaries and one
is Church of England.

There are also 4,607 Roman Catholic Indi-
ans shown in the census above referred to as being
outside of Treaty Limits.

Of the 11,838 Roman Catholic Indians in
British Columbia, it may be said that most of them
are so migratory in their habits and their reserves
are so small and scattered that it is next to im-
possible to provide them with day schools, while it
has been considered that it would be a useless out-
lay to increase the number of boarding and indus-
trial schools in that province to any large extent
as residence in such institutions would tend to un-
fit pupils from earning their livelihood in the
occupations they will have to follow in later life.

I have also prepared a statement marked "B"
taken from the current year's estimates, showing the
number of boarding and industrial schools conducted
by the different denominations by provinces, with the
number of pupils provided for and the amount of the
grant for maintenance, from which you will see that
the Roman Catholics are receiving as much as the
Protestant denominations all put together, both in
money and numbers.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 7th instant regarding cheque No. 346 charged against the Ontario and Quebec Indian vote for the year 1903-04, being a payment of $700.00 to the Shingwauk Home on account of the deficit incurred by that Institution, I beg to inform you that the total amount of the deficit of that Institute on the 30th September 1903 as shown by its books which were audited by Mr. Dalton of this Department in November of that year was $1,552.98. The accounts making up this sum are enclosed herewith. The reason for assisting this Institution was owing to the fact that the deficit had not occurred through extravagant management and that the per capita grant was not sufficient to maintain excessively pupils and at the same time to keep the buildings in repair; and to refuse to assist the Institution at that juncture would have meant to close the school. It was ascertained also that a considerable portion of the grant for maintenance of pupils had been expended in repairs to buildings and for furniture &c., which was not originally intended should be paid from the per capita grant.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Let me ask your attention to my letter of Nov. 7th last with reference to the payment of a part of the deficit incurred by the Shingwauk Home, and to your reply thereto (file No. 152067-1).

On account of the various deficits which the Government has, from time to time, been called to pay, I am of opinion that it would be advisable to slightly modify the system of paying the per-capita grants to the various Industrial and Boarding Schools.

In the first place an Order-in-Council should be obtained fixing the amounts of the grants to the various schools; this Order-in-Council should also specify clearly what expenses are supposed to be covered by the grant and what expenditure the Government is prepared to pay in addition to the grant, which should be of the same nature for all the schools, and under what conditions this extra expenditure will be recognised.

In the second place, the grants being fixed at a fair figure, based on the requirements of each individual school, the different denominations, controlling the various schools, should be given to clearly understand that in the future no claims for deficits will be entertained by the Government.

The Deputy Superintendent General,
Indian Affairs.
In the third place, a uniform and adequate system of bookkeeping should be imposed on every school receiving a Government grant, which books should at all times be open for examination by a duly authorized Government inspector. A rigid inspection of the financial affairs of each school should be made on behalf of the Government at least once a year; the report of such inspection to be made in a form, uniform for every school, such as to show clearly the financial state of the school at the time of inspection. Should however the inspector find anything out of the ordinary or requiring special comment, this should be included in a special report.

I should like to have your opinion on the above suggestions.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Auditor General.

The Deputy Superintendent General,
Indian Affairs.
Department of Indian Affairs.
OTTAWA, 16th Decr., 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General:-

A further communication has been received from the Auditor General with reference to the payment of a part of the deficit incurred by the Shingwauk Home in which he expresses his opinion that it would be advisable to modify the system of paying the per capita grants to the various Industrial and boarding schools. This letter of the Auditor's was written in acknowledgment of a letter from the Department of the 9th ultimo, giving him certain information for which he asked regarding this payment.

It is a question for the Department to decide how far it is to be guided by the Auditor's opinion in the management of its schools.

The Order-in-Council of the 22nd Oct. 1892 on file No. 91,883 herewith outlines the system adopted for the maintenance and management of industrial schools on the per capita basis.

The question of not recognizing deficits is correct in theory but difficult of practice, as there are many unforeseen circumstances that may prevent a school from drawing the full grant allowed, in which case deficits are bound to occur.

The system of book-keeping is, I understand, supposed to be uniform and instructions have already been issued to the Indian Commissioner to have inspections made of these schools every six months.
The Department is in receipt of detailed reports of such inspections, upon which any necessary action is taken.

I understand that it is the intention of the Minister to go thoroughly into the organization of our schools at an early date, and until this is done, I do not see that the Auditor's suggestions can be dealt with.

[Signature]

Martin Benson
MEMORANDUM:

For the Deputy Sup't. General of I.A.

I have read the Auditor's letter of Sept. 7th, making certain suggestions in the way of regulations to govern Industrial School expenditure. The subject is too difficult to be satisfactorily dealt with in the way that the Auditor suggests. As a matter of fact there is nothing essentially new in what he suggests. The point is that he wants us to be bound by an Order-in-Council to which he can refer as authority if we happen to pay any deficits after it became operative.

I think we ought to be wise enough to avoid being placed in that position and it would be just as well, as a matter of policy, to refrain from giving any opinion upon his suggestions, at least for the present, as we might be involved in a correspondence in which general principles would have to be stated which might not in the future conform to particular occasions.

Accountant.

MEMO OF RESOLUTIONS.

Agreed upon by a Joint Committee representing the Methodist Presbyterian and Anglican Churches, and presented to the Government by a Joint Delegation in the month of April 1907.

1. That the Government be requested to create an Advisory Board of Indian Education to which all churches and organizations engaged in Indian work shall have the privilege of nominating two representatives each.

2. That in addition to the elements of an English education the Indian boys shall be trained in agricultural or such other pursuits in their different branches as may be possible where the School is situated, and also in such manual pursuits as may be useful to them in an outdoor life in the district to which they belong. Similarly with the girls that they be trained for domestic life and elementary nursing.

3. That all the schools, resident and non-resident, shall be so constituted, equipped and conducted that the policy briefly outlined in the above clause may be most perfectly realized, and that the Government shall provide suitable buildings and equipments therefor.

4. That pupils, as a rule, shall be discharged at the age of eighteen, but it should be arranged that in exceptional cases, pupils may be retained longer on the recommendation of the Church in charge of the school, and with the consent of the Indian Commissioner. Also it should be made possible for especially promising pupils to receive extra training for any special vocation at the expense of the Government, such pupils meantime to be under the supervision of the school.
5. — While realizing the difficulties of administering a policy of compulsory education, we are convinced that such a principle is in the best interests of all concerned—of the parents, of the children, and of the State, and should be enforced so far as can be wisely and rightly done. If this becomes the accepted policy of the Government, is it too much to expect that the influence of Government employees be brought to bear in the kind but firm enforcement of the law?

The policy of funding the treaty money for children attending Boarding or Industrial Schools, having been found to operate against securing pupils for these schools, should be discontinued, and all Government donations in excess of Treaty obligations should be withheld from such parents as refuse to send their children to school.

6. — That whereas the Indians are wards of the Government, and their education, at least in part, secured by treaty, it is only reasonable that the Government should bear all expenses involved in such training as is contemplated, which would include a larger per capita grant. The Churches anxious and willing to continue to co-operate with the Government in the civilization and Christianization of the Indians are convinced that the moral and spiritual side of education cannot be hoped for except by the appointment of teachers in every way qualified for a work so peculiar and important. The request is therefore made that the appointment of teachers be entrusted to the Churches on terms to be mutually agreed upon.

7. — That sanitarium and medical equipment and nurses, and medical attendance, be provided in central or suitable locations for the treatment of tubercular and other contagious diseases.
At a further interview on the 25th October, the following additional recommendations were submitted:

8. - The salary for a day school teacher to be $500. The Church to appoint teachers who have Provincial certificates.

We agree to manage residential schools in Ontario at a per capita grant of One Hundred Dollars, and One Hundred and Thirty Dollars per pupil in all such schools West of the Great Lakes.

This grant not to include the cost of material for the plant, nor anything that may be regarded as a fixture in the building, such as any plumbing or heating apparatus, etc.

Any deficits in the cost of management to be met by the Church managing the school. The Department to make the buildings of residential schools thoroughly sanitary and with sufficient ventilation, supplying medical men and nurses wherever necessary.

As the suggested changes may involve larger financial outlay, attention is called to the fact that at present there are more residential schools than are necessary to supply the needs of the territory occupied, and that it might be a wise policy to reduce the number or to transfer some of them to more needy localities.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

Reverend and dear Sirs,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of the Memorandum of resolutions agreed upon by a Joint Committee representing the Methodist, Presbyterian and Anglican Churches in the month of April 1907 with additions made on the 29th of October; comprising altogether eight sub-heads.

These resolutions embody certain recommendations which you have thought proper to submit to the Department on the subject of Indian education, and since their receipt they have been the subject of careful consideration. Before dealing with the present position occupied by the question of Indian education it seems desirable to give a short review of the whole subject in order that it may be seen how the existing establishment has arisen, and why it is maintained.

It is self evident that the prime purpose of Indian education is to assist in solving what may be called the Indian problem, to elevate the Indian from his condition of savagery, to make him a self-supporting member of the state, and eventually a citizen in good standing. The work of Indian education from the earliest times has always been experimental, having this object in view, and if these methods have been open to criticism in some important particulars, yet it can safely be said that the general effect of the policy has made for the betterment of Indian conditions throughout the country.

The first efforts to educate the Indians were undertaken by the early missionaries to this country. Probably the first regular school established was at the Grand River, after the Six Nations had been settled there by Governor Haldimand. The imperial authorities under whose direction Indian affairs were administered up to the year 1860 did not make any special grant for education. The first funds set apart for these purposes arose from the commutation made by certain
tribes of their annual distribution of ammunition. This formed the nucleus of what was called the Indian school fund, an account which was held as part of the Indian Trust Fund. This contribution began in 1848 and ended on the 30th June 1862. This Indian School Fund maintained Industrial schools at Mount Elgin and Alderville which were conducted by the Methodist Church upon a per capita grant. Thus, at the inception of the Indian School question, we find two main characteristics which have ever since continued, i.e., the principle of the per capita grant and the denominational interest. The Indian School Fund remained the sole financial aid to Indian education until 1875-6 when a grant to assist it was made by the Parliament of Canada. This financial aid enabled the Department to open day schools on various reserves in the Maritime Provinces and the Provinces of Ontario and Quebec. The Trust funds of the Indian bands also began to be made use of to a certain extent as the interest of the Indians themselves in education increased. The early Treaties or Surrenders by which the Indians ceded territory to the Crown did not stipulate for education as one of the considerations for this cession. The first mention of education as an obligation to be met by the Government appears in the Indian Treaty known as Treaty No. I, which was signed in the year 1871. This provision for education was included in the subsequent treaties and it is in part owing to the endeavor of the Department to carry out these Treaty stipulations that the large expenditure has arisen. But these Treaty stipulations have been more than fulfilled. As a rule the educational clauses of the Treaties simply state that teachers shall be provided when the Indians desire them. The inception of an educational policy was thus left to the Indians but has been initiated solely by the Government with a view to advance their general interests.

The first grant by the Dominion Government towards Indian schools was made as an assistance to be given in a lump sum to the
Indian School Fund. The first vote was taken in 1875-6 and amounted to $2000.00. It was not until the year 1879-80 that any appropriation was made for Indian education in Manitoba and the North West Territories and in that year the sum of $11,000.00 was granted. The Indians of British Columbia received no educational benefits from Dominion expenditure until the year 1874-5 when $2474.47 was spent from the general appropriations. In 1878-9 the question of establishing Indian Industrial Schools in the West was first taken up.

The first industrial school was established at Battleford in 1883. The Department adopted the principles which had long governed Indian education in the older Provinces and this school was conducted by the Church of England. In the following year industrial schools were established at Qu'Appelle and High River under the guidance of the Roman Catholic Church. The principle of the per capita grant was extended to the schools in the new district in the year 1891 as a step in the direction of economy. It may, therefore, be said that the Department in establishing these schools merely extended the system already in vogue in the Eastern Provinces. In the year 1887 the Department inaugurated the policy of expansion which resulted gradually in a very large increase in expenditure. New principles of action were however adopted and the schools were conducted practically under the same rules and regulations and systems of payment. In the year 1878-79 the whole school appropriation for Canada was $16,000.00; in 1888-89 the expenditure was $178,980.98; for the year 1908-9 the appropriations will be $445,837.00. In addition to this expenditure from Consolidated Revenue the Indians themselves contributed an annual amount of over $10,000 from their own funds for the maintenance of day schools on their reserves, making a grand total of $456,000.00.

In the interval between 1862 and 1898 the Department had also completely wiped out the Indian School Fund, capital $39,142.85, and
interest, and the account was accordingly closed on the 1st July 1896.

This large expansion in expenditure has been accompanied by increased educational facilities. In 1888 there were about 30 schools in operation; at the present time there are 236 day schools, 55 boarding schools, and 22 industrial schools distributed as follows:

In addition to this large expenditure from Consolidated Revenue and Indian Trust Funds the religious denominations interested in the welfare of the Indians and the development of educational facilities have provided large sums of money to assist in the work. The exact amount so spent is not available, but is doubtless known to the financial agents of the Churches interested. From statements furnished during the eight years ending the 30th June 1906, published in the Report of the Department, it is gathered that the denominations contributed during that time at least $435,000.00 toward this end; and from this amount some idea may be formed of the aggregate of the expenditure during the whole term. This outlay has principally taken place in connection with Boarding Schools which were for the most part established by the Churches, erected by them, and supported to a large extent from Church funds; the Department contributing relatively small amounts for buildings and equipment, and an even per capita grant of $60.00 and $75.00 per annum.

The growing inability of the religious denominations to finance the claims made by the Institutions which they have been largely responsible in establishing has led to the demands for increased grants and for a re-consideration of the educational methods referred to in your memorandum.

The financial aspect of the question is important as without
a very large increase in appropriations the present establishment could not be maintained; the number of pupils at present on the roll could not be provided for, nor the buildings at present occupied could not be rebuilt, enlarged or improved. If the policy outlined in the joint memorandum were to be adopted without any effort at rearrangement or retrenchment a moderate estimate of the necessary appropriation would be $381,979.00.

If there had been no doubt that the educational system heretofore maintained was best calculated to further the civilization of the Indians, the increased appropriations might be justified and probably an extension of educational work along the same lines, but it is clear that the present system with its large expenditure has not operated as was expected towards the civilization of the aborigines. The high death rate in the schools and the adverse influence of the reserve environment on discharged pupils has tended with other causes to minimize the effect of educational advantages. These influences have always been known to the Department and have been accepted as one of the inherent difficulties of the problem.

The Department has by regulations, enforced by medical officers, endeavored to prevent the admission to the schools of pupils tainted with tubercular diseases or children unhealthy in any other respect; and considering the extent to which disease is rife amongst the Indians, it may be stated that a fair measure of success has followed the efforts to select only healthy pupils for residence in the schools.

The Department has endeavored also to maintain an interest in pupils discharged from the schools, as it was early recognized that one of the great difficulties to be overcome was to prevent whatever degree of improvement had been received during the school life from being lost the moment it came in contact with the relatively savage life of the reserve. To this end the Department has assisted the most promising graduates with gifts of agricultural implements, cattle, seed
grain and material to build houses, and has endeavored to separate as far as possible promising young Indians from the influences of the ordinary Indian life; and these efforts have been reasonably successful. But despite all this official care and the interest manifested by the religious denominations it is open to question whether the very large expenditure from all sources has been justified by the result; whether as regards the Indians of the plains and British Columbia the system was not in advance of the needs of the case, and whether a better plan would not have been to proceed on a less extensive scale and to postpone the more elaborate system of residential schools until such a time as the Indian has become more or less civilized by the pressure of influences from without, and had shown the improving effect of the instruction and supervision in agricultural pursuits freely given by the Government.

It would seem to be good policy at this juncture to attempt to devise a better system of Indian education, applying to each locality methods which would best achieve the desired result and at the same time while not increasing the financial obligations of the Government would remove from the Churches a burden which they do not now find themselves able to bear. With these preliminary remarks the sections of your memorandum may be considered seriatim.

(I) That the Government be requested to create an Advisory Board of Indian Education to which all churches and organizations engaged in Indian work shall have the privilege of nominating two representatives each.

(I) - There would appear to be no objection to the Churches creating an Advisory Board, having two representatives from each Church, for the purpose of consulting with the Department on educational questions in which the Churches are interested.

The Department has at all times been willing to give full
consideration to the representations of the churches, but it has been found confusing to deal with a large number of persons in authority who are interested in the Indian work.

(2) That in addition to the elements of an English education the Indian boys shall be trained in agricultural or such other pursuits in their different branches as may be possible where the School is situated, and also in such manual pursuits as may be useful to them in an outdoor life in the district to which they belong. Similarly with the girls that they be trained for domestic life and elementary nursing.

(2) -- This has always been the policy of the Department with reference to Indian education in residential schools. Often from the difficulty of collecting pupils from districts where the curriculum of the school can be of direct benefit to them it has not been carried out, but as the future policy of the Department and the contemplated rearrangement of residential schools would have in view a closer relation to the policy, it is hoped that it may be carried out with greater strictness with better results.

(3) That all the schools, resident and non-resident, shall be so constituted, equipped and conducted that the policy briefly outlined in the above clause may be most perfectly realized, and that the Government shall provide suitable buildings and equipments therefor.

(3) -- This clause is germane to No. 2, and it follows wherever day schools or residential schools are established suitable buildings and equipment should be provided. The general management of the school should reflect as closely as possible the policy to be adopted.

(4) That pupils, as a rule, shall be discharged at the age of eighteen, but it should be arranged that in exceptional cases, pupils may be retained longer on the recommendation of the Church
in charge of the school and with the consent of the Indian Commissioner. Also it should be made possible for especially promising pupils to receive extra training for any special vocation at the expense of the Government, such pupils meantime to be under the supervision of the school.

(4) - The existing rule is that pupils should be discharged at the age of 18, and, until it is clear that some other age limit could be established with advantage, that age may be allowed to stand. Exceptional cases should be considered on their merits, and the recommendation of the advisory board would be considered when the question for the further education of promising pupils comes up for consideration.

(5) While realizing the difficulties of administering a policy of compulsory education, we are convinced that such a principle is in the best interests of all concerned - of the parents, of the children, and of the State, and should be enforced so far as can be wisely and rightly done. If this becomes the accepted policy of the Government, is it too much to expect that the influence of Government employees be brought to bear in the kind but firm enforcement of the law?

The policy of funding the treaty money for children attending Boarding or Industrial Schools, having been found to operate against securing pupils for these schools, should be discontinued, and all Government donations in excess of Treaty obligations should be withheld from such parents as refuse to send their children to school.

(5) - The question of compulsory education will receive at once full consideration. Sections 9, 10 and II of the Indian Act, Chap. 61 of the Revised Statutes, empower the Governor in Council to make regulations to secure the compulsory attendance of children at school, and under a previous enactment, Chap. 32, 57, 58 Vict., regulations governing the education of Indian children were passed by His Excellency in Council on November 10, 1894. These regulations are still in force and go as far as was deemed advisable, as it was not considered that attendance at boarding and industrial schools could be made compulsory, and that no rule should be adopted which would provide for the arbitrary separation of parents and children. It has always been the wish of the Department that
officials and employees should give their active influence in furthering the educational policy, and the attention of Agents generally will be again directed to this very important phase of their general administrative duties.

The funding of treaty money for children who attend boarding and industrial schools (which were undertaken in order that, on leaving school, they might have a small amount of cash to expend in the purchase of some necessary articles to begin life on the reserve) might be discontinued. It has often been questioned whether the trouble which the administration of these small accounts entails was compensated by any genuine benefit to the mass of depositors, and if the withholding of annuity money from parents operates against the securing of pupils it may be thought well to reconsider this question.

The suggested step of withholding Government aid in excess of treaty obligations could hardly be adopted as part of a general educational policy. In very few agencies are donations given beyond treaty obligations and these are principally extended to destitute Indians, and it is necessary not to permit any harshness to Indians who cannot well provide for themselves.

That whereas the Indians are wards of the Government, and their education, at least in part, secured by treaty, it is only reasonable that the Government should bear all expenses involved in such training as is contemplated, which would include a larger per capita grant. The Churches anxious and willing to continue to co-operate with the Government in the civilization and Christianization of the Indians are convinced that the moral and spiritual side of education cannot be hoped for except by the appointment of teachers in every way qualified for a work so peculiar and important. The request is therefore made that the appointment of teachers be entrusted to the Churches on terms to be mutually agreed upon.

The increased per capita grant suggested in Clause 8, if adopted, will virtually place the Government in the position of bearing all expenses involved in Indian education. The present establishment includes schools which while recognized by the Govern-
ment were established in the first instance by the Churches, and it is thought that a rearrangement of these schools and the adoption of a new type of school would further the interests of Indian education and at the same time render it unnecessary to apply to Parliament for an increase in the gross appropriation. The expression of willingness on the part of the Churches to co-operate with the Government is noted with pleasure; and it is most important that teachers well qualified for the work should be appointed.

(7) That sanitarium and medical equipment and nurses and medical attendance be provided in central or suitable locations for the treatment of tubercular and other contagious diseases.

(7) As you are no doubt aware the Department has a system of medical attendance which is intended generally to provide for this branch of the Indian work throughout the country. At a very early date it was recognized that this class of relief was one which would largely devolve on the Dominion Government and Parliamentary appropriations have since Confederation been obtained for this purpose. Of late years hospitals have also been established and in the older Provinces the hospitals for white communities have been made use of by the Indians. For the approaching fiscal year the Department has asked Parliament to vote the following sums for medical attendance, medicines and hospitals:
