Within the last few years the experiment has been made of establishing tent hospitals for the treatment of tubercular diseases; one at Saddle Lake, one at Touchwood Hills, and one at Birtle, also a well equipped small hospital at Morley for the same purpose for the use of the Story Indians and the pupils of the McDougall Orphanage. In British Columbia the Department has assisted in the establishment of five hospitals where Indian patients may be treated. It will be understood from these facts that it will be necessary simply to extend the present provisions of the Department if thought advisable; no initiative is needed as would seem to be implied in this clause of the joint memorandum.

It might be wise however to test the results of the hospitals already established before increasing their number. Wherever well equipped hospitals are provided by municipalities which could be used by Indians it would seem a good policy to use these for treatment instead of multiplying the number of small hospitals intended solely for Indians; and this system the Department is following wherever the conditions warrant.

In addition to this professional attendance and supply of medical accessories the Department makes as large a use as possible of professional knowledge with reference to contagious diseases, tuberculosis, and sanitary measures generally. It issues to its Agents positive instructions in all matters of sanitation on the reserves and places them in possession of the
simple and obvious methods of preventing the spread of tuberculosis; and they are made clearly to understand that a principal part of their duty is to enforce these regulations, and to keep constantly before the Indians the desirability of practising such preventive measures.

The question of nurses will be dealt with in remarks to be made on clause No. 8.

(8) The salary for a day school teacher to be $500. The Church to appoint teachers who have Provincial certificates.

We agree to manage residential schools in Ontario at a per capita grant of One Hundred Dollars, and One Hundred and Thirty Dollars per pupil in all such schools west of the Great Lakes.

This grant not to include the cost of material for the plant, nor anything that may be regarded as a fixture in the building, such as any plumbing or heating apparatus, etc.

Any deficits in the cost of management to be met by the Church managing the school. The Department to make the buildings of residential schools thoroughly sanitary and with sufficient ventilation supplying medical men and nurses wherever necessary.

As the suggested changes may involve larger financial outlay, attention is called to the fact that at present there are more residential schools than are necessary to supply the needs of the territory occupied, and that it might be a wise policy to reduce the number or to transfer some of them to more needy localities.

(8) This clause deals with the financial side of the question.

As stated in my preliminary remarks, if the present educational system could be shown to have justified the expenditure upon it, it might not be difficult to ask for increased appropriations; but as the consensus of opinion seems to be that such is not the case, I would find it difficult at present to justify the increase which would be necessary if the augmented scale of per capita allowances and teachers' salaries was to be adopted for the present enrollment; and if any change were to be made it would involve an increase as before shown of about $186,142.00 and a capital expenditure of about $350,000.00.

At the outset it might be remarked that the question is complicated by the fact that the Roman Catholic Church while equally
interested with the Protestant denominations in the evangelization and education of the Indians has not asked for any generally increased grants, and do not seek more favorable terms. You will recognize the impossibility of dealing with the question at all and overlooking the rights of a Church so largely interested in the work to treatment equally favorable.

The educational needs of the Indians vary in different Provinces and it would seem to be advisable to divide the subject into several classes geographically, and to deal with each separately:

NOVA SCOTIA, NEW BRUNSWICK, PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND,
QUEBEC, ONTARIO.

The day schools throughout Indian reserves in these Provinces are usually more or less in touch with surrounding civilization and as the Indians themselves are more or less civilized the conduct of the schools should approximate as nearly as possible to conditions which appertain amongst white people. It might be laid down as a rule that the teachers of Indian schools who are well qualified for the special work should be paid a salary of from $300.00 to $500.00, and the principle of annual increases should be resorted to in order to give an incentive for diligence and application; and that the interest of teachers and pupils should be stimulated in every possible way in order to increase the average attendance.

The residential schools in Ontario situated in settled districts and drawing their pupils from Indians that are already well advanced in civilization should be useful factors in improving the standard of Indian life. The increase in the grant from $60. to $100. per capita does not seem to be excessive, and I would feel inclined to recommend the Government to increase the grant at
these schools to that rate; if it were found possible to carry out the changes which will be mentioned later on and if the increase does not involve a general increase in the appropriations.

It may be remarked, however, that these schools within the next few years should prove their usefulness as it might be better to allow the day schools on the reserves to furnish whatever would be required in the way of literary education and to give more attention to the improvement of general agricultural conditions throughout the older Provinces, as they are by no means in as forward a condition as they should be. After the increased grant has been paid for a year or two an inspection of the school accounts will show whether it was larger than required.

MANITOBA, SASKATCHEWAN, ALBERTA AND NORTH WEST TERRITORIES.

It is probably the fact that the educational system adopted for use in the unorganized territories in the year 1883 was in advance of the real needs of the case; that a more permanent influence for good would have been exerted by Industrial education carried on upon the reserves, and made up not only of tuition at day schools but of the generally civilizing influence of instruction given to adults in agricultural, ranching and domestic pursuits. It must not be lost sight of that in several districts of the Provinces of Saskatchewan and Alberta the Indians are practically self-supporting, and as a basis of material progress is always necessary before education can have any lasting value, it may be said that the best interests of the Indians have been served by instruction carried out upon the reserves and not by the elaborate system of education. It would seem to be advisable to get back to these first principles and to expend whatever appropriations are placed at the disposal of the Department largely in improving conditions on reserves.

In line with the foregoing remarks it would seem to be admirable
to close certain residential schools which have been for some time in operation. The Industrial School at Calgary has been abolished, the St. Paul's Industrial School at Middlechurch was not rebuilt after the late fire, and in considering a further reduction in the number of Industrial Schools it occurs that either the Brandon or Elkhorn School might be done away with, as well as the School at Regina. The Brandon School, while well conducted, has not served the purpose for which it was established, as the pupils are drawn from districts where agriculture cannot extensively be carried on. The Elkhorn School while it is also well conducted is an expensive institution. The School at Regina while it draws its pupils from an agricultural district has been a source of considerable unforeseen expense to the Department and of late years has not been very successful.

The closing at the end of the present fiscal year of the following Boarding Schools might also be carried out:

Crowstand, Emmanuel College,
File Hills, Gordon's,
Round Lake, Onion Lake,
Peigan, Morley,
Old Suns, Bloods,
Sarcee,

On the reserves which have heretofore been served by these Schools an improved type of day school might be established. The staff would consist of a married teacher, and, on the large reserves, of a nurse also; and a nutritious and simple noonday meal might be served to the pupils at the school. The nurse might be occupied in house and tent visitation, directing sanitary measures, and the wife of the teacher should have domestic qualifications which would make her useful in instructing the Indian women in the ordinary domestic employments. Such a system might
be given a trial for four or five years. Children of whose strong constitutions and general health there could be no reasonable doubt could be drafted into the existing Industrial Schools which would be placed in a thoroughly sanitary condition and the tuition at which would be specially designed for the localities where they are situated. The experience of the Department with the best Day Schools under its control has shown conclusively that most efficient work may be done through this medium. The best Day Schools in the older Provinces are doing an excellent work. Those at Lorette, St. Francois, Caughnawaga and the Six Nation Reserve may be specially cited; and in dealing with the school on Mistawasis Reserve, in the Province of Saskatchewan, the Indian Commissioner felt called upon to remark that the report shows the school to be in a highly creditable condition. If we had Day Schools like this, our Boarding Schools might be dispensed with.

The experience of the United States Indian Department also shows that the Day Schools as conducted in that country, which include gardens and substantial hot lunches for the children, are considered the strongest civilizing influence that can be brought to bear upon the Indian. If it is to be considered any disadvantage that the children should remain with parents living a semi-civilized life, against this disadvantage must be weighed the positive gain which would result from the children being brought up surrounded by the conditions under which they must gain their livelihood.

As the sanitation of Indian dwellings is gradually improved, the Indian children who are tainted with tuberculosis will have a better chance to overcome the disease than if they were closely housed in Boarding Schools or sanitariums, and the danger to other pupils would be minimized. If this change was carried out with
reference to the Protestant schools just mentioned and certain Roman Catholic schools as well it would enable the Department to pay the increased grant to the industrial and boarding schools to be maintained in the future without asking Parliament for largely increased appropriations.

Schools in unorganized districts which draw their pupils from the reserves where the Indians maintain themselves by hunting might be allowed for the present to continue, but it is thought that the number of pupils in residence should not be increased beyond the present provisions. As the Indians settle upon their reserves and as new conditions arise these schools might also be abolished and the new type of school substituted.

It will be observed that the new departure consists of maintaining Residential Schools in the unorganized districts, where Indians spend their winter on their hunting grounds and are not settled on the reserves, and the provision of an improved type of Day School, with a few large residential schools for Indians who have already settled on the reserves and are supporting themselves to a greater or less extent by agricultural pursuits and ranching.

BRITISH COLUMBIA.

The situation in British Columbia requires special attention and it would not seem to be advisable to authorize the large capital expenditure which would be necessary if the establishment is to be maintained as at present, until the needs of each locality are carefully enquired into and the necessity of each existing school demonstrated. In some localities where the question of entirely rebuilding or enlarging and improving certain school buildings would have to be immediately considered it might be found advantageous to establish Day Schools. The location of several of the Boarding Schools was not considered with sufficient
care when the buildings were erected, and it would seem hardly advisable to spend any considerable amount on their improvement.

The closing of the Metlakatla Industrial School and the maintenance of an efficient Day School at that point will be necessary to spend in the neighborhood of $30,000.00 to put the present buildings in a satisfactory condition. There are only 18 boys in attendance and the school accounts show a deficit. As all the pupils are drafted from Metlakatla it would not seem to be necessary to continue the large expenditure for this institution. It should be remembered that the British Columbia Indians are practically self-supporting, and the policy of removing the children from their parents and separating them from the ordinary vocations by which in their future lives they must obtain a living is questionable. From these general causes it seems advisable in this province to proceed with a good deal of circumspection before large expenditures are incurred which would tend to perpetuate the present system. It is therefore not at present proposed to extend the increased per capita grant to the Schools in this Province, or to provide for augmented capital expenditure.

If these changes were carried out the residential schools to be maintained would be thoroughly overhauled and increased ventilation and improved sanitation would be provided for. As the Department now provides medical attendance and medicines for the schools, no change is necessary in that regard, and the question of the possibility of engaging nurses as instructors would be considered. The increased grant to be paid to the Schools would carry with it the obligation on their part to meet all deficits, and to provide whatever labor for repairs etc is necessary; as at present.

MEMORANDUM OF A CONFERENCE
HELD IN THE OFFICE OF THE HONOURABLE S. H. BLAKE
ON TUESDAY, WEDNESDAY, THURSDAY AND FRIDAY, THE
24th, 25th, 26th and 27th days of March, 1908.

The members duly appointed by the Anglican, Presbyterian, and Methodist Churches to represent them in conference with the Superintendent of Indian affairs on the subject of Indian education beg to acknowledge the receipt of two letters from the Superintendent dated the 14th and 28th of last January and a communication from the Deputy Superintendent of date the 21st of this present month, all of which have been carefully considered by the Committee appointed as above mentioned.

The Committee begs to acknowledge the satisfaction with which it has perused these three documents, prepared with evident care, setting forth the salient facts connected with this most important question, dealing in detail with the resolutions presented to the Department dated April and October 1907, and making suggestions as to all the matters laid before the Superintendent by the Committee, which will now be dealt with seriatim in as few words as possible.

1. The Committee agrees with the statement of the Department that "the work of Indian education from the earliest times has always been experimental", and recognizes that the time is now ripe, acting upon the experience of the many years
past, to take a forward movement all along the lines and
to introduce such modifications and improvements as are clearly
called for.

2. The Committee recognizes the importance of the fol-
lowing conclusions of the Department:

(a) "The financial aspect of the question is important
as without a very large increase in appropriations the present
establishment could not be maintained. If the policy outlined
in the joint memorandum were to be adopted without any effort
at re-arrangement or retrenchment a moderate estimate of the
necessary appropriation would be $81,979.00;

(b) If there had been no doubt that the educational sys-
tem heretofore maintained was best calculated to further the
civilisation of the Indians, the increased appropriations
might be justified and probably an extension of educational
work along the same lines, but it is clear that the present
system with its large expenditure has not operated as was ex-
pected towards the civilisation of the aborigines. The high
death-rate in the schools and the adverse influence of the
reserve environment on discharged pupils has tended with other
causes to minimise the effect of educational advantages.
These influences have always been known to the Department and
have been accepted as one of the inherent difficulties of the
problem;

(c) The Department has by regulations enforced by medical
officers endeavored to prevent the admission to the schools
of pupils tainted, &c.,

(d) The Department has endeavored also to maintain an
interest in pupils discharged from the schools;

(e) It is open to question whether the very large
expenditure from all sources has been justified by the results."

The Committee while recognizing the wisdom of the
regulations made by the Department and its sincere desire
through its agents to better the pupils, would ask that by a
more complete system of supervision the Department would in-
sist that its agents more thoroughly carry out the instructions
given to them.
3. The Committee concur heartily in the following general statement which precedes the dealing with the matters in detail by the Department: "It would seem to be good policy at this juncture to attempt to devise a better system of Indian education, applying to each locality methods which would best achieve the desired result and at the same time while not increasing the financial obligations of the Government would remove from the Churches a burden which they do not now find themselves able to bear".

4. We note the concurrence in the proposal made by the Committee for the formation of "an Advisory Board" on Indian education of two members from each of the three above named Churches, which has been already acted upon. This Board will be ready at all times to co-operate with the Department.

5. It is satisfactory to find how completely the Department assents to the following proposal:

(a) "That in addition to the elements of an English education the Indian boys shall be trained in agricultural or such other pursuits in their different branches as may be possible where the school is situated, and also in such manual pursuits as may be useful to them in an outdoor life in the district to which they belong. Similarly with the girls so that they may be trained for domestic life and elementary nursing;

(b) That all the schools, resident and non-resident shall be so situated, equipped and conducted that the policy briefly outlined in the above clause may be most perfectly realized and that the Government shall provide suitable buildings and equipments therefor".

As to which the Department replies:

(a) "As the future policy of the Department and the contemplated re-arrangement of residential schools would have in view a closer relation to the policy, it is hoped that it may
be carried out with greater strictness and with better results;

(b) It follows wherever day schools or residential schools are established suitable buildings and equipment should be provided. The general management of the school should reflect as closely as possible the policy to be adopted."

6. The Department concurs in the view of the Committee that while eighteen as the age limit may be allowed to stand, exceptional cases should be considered on their merits and dealt with as to further education when they arise.

7. On the request made by the Committee to introduce more largely the principle of "compulsory education", it is glad to receive the answer that "the question of compulsory education will receive at once full consideration". The reasons why a different rule should apply as to compulsory attendance in the case of industrial and boarding schools and the case of day schools is obvious, and the reasonableness of the conclusion "that no rule shall be adopted which would provide for the arbitrary separation of parents and children". The Committee learns with pleasure that "it has always been the wish of the Department that officials and employees should give their active influence in furthering the educational policy, and the attention of agents generally will be again directed to this very important phase of their general administrative duties." From such action of the Department the Committee looks forward to good results.

The Committee is pleased to know that the Department concurs with it in the view expressed in its memorandum that
the policy of funding the treaty money for children should be discontinued and that the question of withholding treaty money from parents will be reconsidered.

8. The Committee notes that in answer to the clause of its memorandum which asks that as the Indians are the wards of the Government it should bear all the expenses of the contemplated training, which would include a larger per capita grant, and that in order to obtain qualified teachers the same should be appointed by the Churches on terms to be mutually agreed upon, the Department calls attention to the fact that "the increased per capita grant suggested in Clause 8 of the Committee's memorandum which is above referred to is as follows:

"The salary for a day school teacher to be $500.00. The Church to appoint teachers who have Provincial Certificates. We agree to manage residential schools in Ontario at a per capita grant of $100.00 and $150.00 per pupil in all such schools west of the Great Lakes. This grant not to include the cost of material for the plant nor anything that may be regarded as a fixture in the building, such as any plumbing or heating apparatus, &c. Any deficit in the cost of management to be met by the Church managing the school. The Department to make the buildings of residential schools thoroughly sanitary and with sufficient ventilation, supplying medical men and nurses wherever necessary. As the suggested changes may involve larger financial outlay, attention is called to the fact that at present there are more residential schools than are necessary to supply the needs of the territory occupied, and that it might be a wise policy to reduce the number or to transfer some of them to more needy localities."

As to this statement of the Committee the Department remarks:
This clause deals with the financial side of the question. As stated in my preliminary remarks, if the present educational system could be shown to have justified the expenditure upon it, it might not be difficult to ask for increased appropriations; but as the consensus of opinion seems to be that such is not the case I would find it difficult at present to justify the increase which would be necessary if the augmented scale of per capita allowances and teachers' salaries was to be adopted for the present enrollment; and if any change was to be made it would involve an increase as before shown of about $186,142 and a capital expenditure of about $350,000.

At the outset it might be remarked that the question is complicated by the fact that the Roman Catholic Church while equally interested with the Protestant denominations in the evangelization and education of the Indians has not asked for any generally increased grants and do not seek more favorable terms. You will recognize the impossibility of dealing with the question at all and overlooking the rights of a Church so largely interested in the work to treatment equally favorable.

On this the Committee desires to make but two remarks. If the policy of judiciously reducing the number of residential schools be introduced the saving thus caused will enable the Department to carry out the improvements and modifications suggested with but little if any increase in the cost to the Department of the schools generally.

That in dealing with the question of any complications arising because of the Roman Catholic Church to which the Department calls attention, it will no doubt be present to the mind of the Superintendent that at his request, well nigh a year was spent in endeavouring to procure the presence of representatives of the Roman Catholics at our conferences, but all the efforts failed, and a refusal to co-operate in working out a scheme was finally the answer received. It is
therefore submitted that the position of the three Churches now approaching the Department should not be in any manner prejudiced because of the refusal of this Church to co-operate but that whatever is considered in the best interests of the Indians should be carried out. Wherever it is thought wise to close or change the class of school this should be done, and wherever the school is not found to answer the best interests of the Indian the grants of the Department should cease no matter what religious body might be controlling the school.

9. The Committee has received with pleasure the statement of the work that has been done by the Department throughout the Dominion in the way of medical attendance, hospitals, nurses, sanitary arrangements and the like, and that it is the intention of the Department to extend this work until the demands of the country are answered. The Department may count upon the assistance of the Churches represented by the Committee.

The Committee emphasizes the weight it attaches to the following statement:

"The Department 'issues to its agents positive instructions in all matters of sanitation on the reserves, and places them in possession of the simple and obvious methods of preventing the spread of tuberculosis; and they are made clearly to understand that a principal part of their duty is to enforce these regulations, and to keep constantly before the Indians the desirability of practising such preventive measures.'"
10. In the general remarks made in the communication of the Department the Committee is well pleased to find the following:

"It might be laid down as a general rule that the teachers of Indian schools who are well qualified for the special work should be paid a salary of from $500.00 to $600.00 and the principle of annual increases should be resorted to in order to give an incentive for diligence and application; and that the interest of teachers and pupils should be stimulated in every possible way in order to increase the average attendance."

The Committee heartily approves the wisdom and necessity of this determination but suggests from the experience of its members that, looking at the increased cost of living and the arduous nature of the work demanded of the teachers, it will be necessary to increase the maximum figures so that $650.00 shall be generally the ultimate figure and in case of married men $750.00. It is feared that unless this incentive be given it will be difficult to command a good class of teachers and therefore the problem of the day school will fail to be satisfactorily solved.

11. The Department proceeds to deal specifically with certain of the residential schools, and considers it advisable that they should be closed. This is a matter with which the Department, having a large and general knowledge of the locations of the schools, the needs of the various reserves, the advisability of the class of school whether residential or day, can better deal than can the Committee.
In some cases one day school will not take the place of a boarding school because of the large extent of some of the reserves and of the impossibility of the attendance of the pupil daily at a school far removed. In such cases it may be necessary either to increase the number of the day schools in that locality or to erect or to continue where erected a boarding school to answer the requirements of the extensive reserve.

If the system of compulsory education be enforced it will be necessary to increase considerably the school accommodation in order to provide for the larger attendance, as now only about fifty per cent of the children of school age attend the present schools.

It will be necessary for the Department to take, as no doubt it will, a wide view of the whole situation, and with the full information that can be obtained by its agents and officials in all quarters, to determine what in the general interest of the whole work is best to be done.

It must not be forgotten that the Department supplies such a very large portion of the funds necessary to carry on this work — in not a few cases covering the whole of the expenditure — that it should ultimately control in dealing with the question of location and class of school. It is responsible for the proper carrying on of the work of educating the Indian.
At the same time the Committee humbly submits that it will be in the interest of the Department in dealing with this phase of the case before any present existing school is closed and before any new school is opened, that a statement of the intention of the Department and the reasons for such action should be presented to this Committee in order that the proposal of the Government may be presented to the Church to be affected by the change in order that if it pleases reasons may be assigned either against or for a modification of the proposed action of the Government. This it is conceived would go far to prevent friction between the Department and the Churches.

At the same time it should be mentioned that the Committee does not desire to shirk any responsibility that may reasonably be cast upon it and that it will be at all times prepared to consider any proposal that may be made by the Department to obtain whatever information it is within its power to procure and to confer with the officers of the Department in their efforts to solve for the best the important questions which are now being dealt with between the Department and the Committee.

The Committee notices the conclusion of the Department that British Columbia requires special attention; in which it entirely concurs. The conditions of settlement on the Coast are in a state of transition. There is but little
of the vast amount of coast line suitable for agricultural purposes or perhaps even habitable. It may be that in the near future, looking at the demands of railways and commercial undertakings, the rights of the Indians may be largely purchased out by those promoting these works, which would necessitate the removal of the Indians and would render schools erected to answer the merely present demand useless for the purpose of their education.

The Committee very earnestly presses upon the Department the very great desire on the part of all the Churches it represents, embracing probably one-half of the Indians in the Dominion, to have the proposed improvements carried out at as early a date as possible. Even although all that is contemplated may not be accomplished within a year or two, yet still the making of a beginning will be grateful to our constituents and be an earnest of the fuller work which is being undertaken.

The Committee begs to present its grateful thanks to the Superintendent and the Deputy-Superintendent for the courtesy extended by them to its members and for the careful investigation of all the matters presented to them for their consideration.

[Date: 27 March 1905]
MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Oliver,

A reply has been received to the letter of 21st March addressed to the members of the Joint Committee on Indian educational matters, and I beg to set forth the action which it seems to me necessary to take in consequence of the Committee's reply.

As a preliminary I may say that an Advisory Board has been formed consisting of two members from each of the three protestant Churches concerned, and the Hon. S. H. Blake has been appointed Chairman and the Rev. R. P. MacKey Secretary. I take it for granted that in forming the Board the members have the authority of their respective denominations, and that the Department may communicate from time to time with the new Advisory Board on matters of importance involving the general question of Indian education. It may be said that the opinions of the Committee coincide with those of the Department on all general matters and that the detail alone requires to be worked out.

Action under these headings might be taken at once:—

Consideration of the regulations for compulsory attendance at Day Schools throughout the Dominion, and a revision of the existing regulations in this regard.

Preparation of a circular to all Indian Agents instructing
them to give their active influence in furthering the educational policy of the Department.

The adoption of the principle that the annuity money shall not be arbitrarily withheld from the parents of Indian children and that only where they request that a child's annuity be funded for its benefit shall this be done.

The Committee desires before action is finally taken to close any residential schools that the matter be laid before the Committee in order that the proposal of the Government may be presented to the Church affected.

This is at present really the heart of the matter and as the initiative must come from the Department it seems to the undersigned that it would be advisable to take up the question of closing such Schools as we are in a position to say should be closed, and then proceed to consider the desirability of closing all the Boarding Schools mentioned in our letter of the 21st March. At present the following schools could be closed without any detriment to the work.

MORLEY: There is no doubt that the pupils of this School could be accommodated at Red Deer. They are both Methodist institutions.

REGINA: There should only be one school for the district covered by Regina, Elkhorn and Brandon, and that school should in my opinion be located at Brandon. The present institution should be considered in the light of a model Indian institution, and we should expect the best methods and results from its management. Situated near
the city and being constantly visited by the people, it would serve as an object lesson of what the Department was doing for the Indians in these Industrial Schools. It should draw its pupils from the agricultural reserves, and not from the northern fishing districts. It should furnish a non-denominational education and any pupils that belong to the Anglican or Presbyterian persuasion should be taken to their respective Churches each Sunday by an officer of the School, and Ministers of the denominations should at all times have access to them.

If this School is built up and encouraged there will be no necessity for a School at Regina or at Elkhorn. If the Department allows the Boarding Schools at Birtle, Round Lake, Crowfoot, and File Hills to remain until we can decide where it is best to place a few model Day Schools, it should go far to remove the dislike of the section of the Presbyterian Church to the closing of the Regina School. While we would not consider these Boarding Schools as permanent, we might well allow them to remain until we see our way clear to their abolishment.

As the Elkhorn School is conducted by the Department there should be no insurmountable difficulty in closing it. I would suggest that the pupils be transferred to Brandon; that the staff, with the exception of any that might need to be transferred to Brandon on account of the increased pupilage, be given three months' notice with pay from the 1st of May; that the Principal and the Matron, Mr. and Mrs. A. E. Wilson, be retained in the service of the Department at their present salary, with a free house at Elkhorn and two rations, to be employed in an inspectorial capacity in connection with the remaining Schools. I think
some consideration is due Mr. and Mrs. Wilson after their long connection with Indian work.

I have for some time been considering the necessity of the appointment of another Inspector in the North West Territories to devote his time exclusively to the Inspection of Residential Schools. The work of the Agency Inspectors is too heavy to permit them to spend much of their time at Schools, and I think both sides of the work have suffered in consequence. I would not propose to appoint Mr. Wilson as Inspector at once until he had proved his capacity; and I think Mrs. Wilson's services could be well utilized by the Department in superintending whatever system of nurses or field matrons we may adopt in connection with the new type of Day School. It is thought that retaining Mr. and Mrs. Wilson in the service would lessen somewhat the difficulty of closing the Elkhorn Industrial School.

EMMANUEL COLLEGE: The present position of Emmanuel College is this. The Principal has been informed that the School must be closed unless the Church pays the deficit but if the deficit is paid the Department will continue the School. It is hardly probable that the Church authorities will pay the deficit, and it may be foreshadowed that the School will be closed at an early date. If so, I would propose to establish one or two of the improved Day Schools in the Carlton and Duck Lake Agencies at favorable points, one I think should be located in Mistawasis Reserve.

If this action is carried out, I would suggest paying the remaining
Boarding and Industrial Schools at the rate of $130.00 per capita for the Protestant Schools in Manitoba and the North West Territories, and increasing the grant of the Ontario Schools to $100.00 per capita. The Mohawk Institute would not at present be included in this arrangement which is conducted by the New England Company. I think the grant to this School should be somewhat increased, but not to the extent of $100.00. This might form the subject of correspondence with the Principal of the School. This would involve taking a vote of, say, $50,000.00 for Indian Schools generally.

I would suggest that the Roman Catholic Bishops who are interested in the Indian work should be requested to appoint two representatives to confer with the Department with reference to Indian educational matters in the Western Provinces. When they agree upon representatives the scheme for the increase in the per capita grant, and the reduction in the number of Schools, etc., could be brought before them.

With reference to Clause 10 of the Memorandum from the Joint Committee I would say that evidently the purpose of the Department in proposing an increase to $500.00 for Day Schools has been somewhat misunderstood. This rate would not apply to the improved type of Day School but to the ordinary school as at present conducted. We are looking forward to the provision of a salary for a teacher and his wife at an improved Day School, which would be equal to at least $750.00 per annum, as two rations and free quarters would be included in the emolument.

Ottawa, April 24th., 1908.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of the Memorandum of the Conference held by your Board from the 24th to the 27th of March, 1908. It is gratifying to find that such an unanimity of opinion exists in the important matters dealt with in the previous correspondence. Concurrence in all the main features of the question seem to be so general that it is only required to work out the details involved with care and proper consideration for the many interests concerned. It was never designed to be the policy of the Department to immediately abolish the residential schools without substituting some efficient means for caring for the pupils who had previously been accommodated therein. It would seem to be well therefore to place before your Committee very fully what the Department has hoped would be an improved Day School, which might in very many localities be a useful factor in Indian education and remove to a large extent the ground for criticism which exists even as regards the best residential schools.

I therefore submit herewith plans of an improved building which it is proposed to erect on one or two reserves where the Indians are favourably situated for such an experiment. As you will see, the School is designed to accommodate a teacher and his wife and a nurse. The nurse's sleeping apartment is connected with an infirmary where a few sick children might be cared for and a dispensary where a supply of drugs could be kept on hand. The quarters for the teacher and his family are, it is thought, sufficiently commodious; comprising Dining Room, living room and bed-rooms, with proper kitchen accommodation.

The school building is separated from the residence of the staff and will form a commodious class-room for tuition at certain hours of the day.

You will observe the buildings are designed to provide for the
serving of a sum mid-day meal for the pupils in attendance, and to be
the headquarters of civilising influences on the reserve. Accommodation
is afforded for a few sick children, and it would be the duty of the
nurse by house-to-house visitation to inoculate sanitary principles,
dispense simple medicines, instruct the Indian women in the simplest
methods of nursing, and to care for a few cases which might require
hospital treatment. This feature of the plan might be further extended
where the Department has already established a hospital on the Reserve,
and the physician in charge of the Indians would be expected to co-operate
with the nurse.

The duties of the teacher and his wife would be of course
limited to educational work; but it is thought to make the woman's
influence a large factor in the scheme. She will be expected in the
character of field matron to take an interest in the women of the
reserve and to endeavor by precept and example to instruct them in the
simplest domestic arts - the making of good bread, the preparation of
ordinary articles of diet, the cleanliness of houses &c. &c. It is ex-
pected that she would have the assistance of the larger girls in pre-
paring the mid-day meal which is to be a feature of the scheme and
which it is hoped will largely influence a more regular and interested
attendance. The duties of the teacher would be instruction in the
simpler branches of scholastic training, and a small garden should be
established in which the pupils could assist in raising vegetables for
use at the mid-day meal.

The rate of pay, which might be stated tentatively, would be
as follows:

| School teacher and wife, in cash | $ 800.00 |
|---------------------------------|----------|
| Two rations                     | 120.00   |
| Free House                      | 300.00   |
| Nurse, in cash                  | 400.00   |
| One ration                      | 60.00    |
| Free quarters                   | 100.00   |
As such a type of Day School would be more or less experimental it should only be established under the most favorable conditions and at one or two reserves specially selected for the purpose. Generally speaking such a school could be located on reserves where the Indians are settled. It could hardly be applicable to districts where the Indians are nomadic. It should be most important that the personnel of the staff should be the best obtainable for the special work, and great care should be exercised in the selection of persons to take up this important duty. In fact, the success of the new type of school would largely depend upon the character of those who would be the pioneers in the effort. The forecast might safely be made that such an institution would be a real centre of civilization on the reserve from which good influences might radiate in every direction.

Having laid before you what in the opinion of the Department would be a useful type of new school, combining some features of both the Day and residential schools, I might now pass to the question of closing certain residential schools. It is needless to say that action in this direction should not be taken without very serious consideration. As before stated, the Department has closed the St. Paul's Industrial School, the Calgary Industrial School, and the Matilaiitla Industrial School, and, it is thought, without prejudicing in any way the interests of pupils who had been accommodated therein. Taking up only those institutions which it would seem possible to close without detriment to the interests involved, the group of Industrial Schools, namely, Regina, Eldon and Brandon which were designed to meet the needs of the Indians of Manitoba and southern Saskatchewan, might be considered. It might be emphasized that one well equipped residential school could effectively provide for all perfectly healthy Indian children, who might benefit by the agricultural instruction therein accorded. As the Regina School has for many years been in an unsatisfactory state and is now in serious financial difficulties, it is thought that it and the
Elkorn School should be merged in the Brandon School and that we should have at that point a model institution. While this school is administered by the Methodist Church it is thought that pupils of the three denominations could be accommodated there, and that religious instruction and church attendance would be readily and satisfactorily arranged.

Emmanuel College is now in great financial embarrassment and it is thought that it should be closed, and the Battleford Industrial School allowed to accommodate the healthiest and most promising of its pupils. Probably as good a point as any at which to start one of the improved Day Schools would be in the Carlton Agency, probably on Mistassini Reserve where already the Department has had some encouragement in the conduct of a day School.

The Holcomb Orphanage at Morley being by its geographical position an accessory to the Red Deer Industrial School, and under the same denomination, might be closed and the pupils from the Stony Reserve drafted to Red Deer. It is open to discussion whether the Stony Reserve would not be a good place to start an improved day school, as the Department already has a hospital on that reserve.

The School at Old Siksika Camp on the Blackfoot Reserve should be closed at once as the building is unsanitary and has been condemned by the Medical Officer.

For the present it is thought that the measure of closing the schools should not be pushed any further than these instances and that a reasonable time might be allowed to intervene before either the improved Day School is extended to other reserves or further residential schools closed in the West.

When these matters are amicably arranged and carried out with your Committee, the Department would feel disposed to adopt the increased scale of per capita grant at the remaining residential schools in Ontario and the West. The new arrangement would be carried out under a contract showing explicitly and in detail the various items of
expenditure for which the Department and the Churches would be responsible. It is understood that the Province of British Columbia must receive special consideration before any increases are made or schools abolished.

The Department intends at an early date to approach those interested in the education of Roman Catholic children along the same lines, but it is submitted that as the best interests of all Protestant children are not being lost sight of but furthered by the present scheme it should not be wrapped up with the acceptance by the Roman Catholic Church of the same conditions. In other words this scheme for the Protestant schools should stand upon its merits.

In due course a circular of instructions will be prepared for all employees of this Department pointing out their duties and responsibilities as regards Indian education; a copy of which will be sent for your information, and as before stated, the regulations for compulsory attendance will be revised where necessary.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Oliver.

Now that the Advisory Board of the Protestant denominations has accepted the suggestions of the Department with reference to Indian education it becomes necessary to make an additional appropriation for the financial needs of the scheme. We have come to an agreement only with the Protestant denominations, and if we are to alone provide for increased per capita grants to Protestant Schools, we will require in the Supplementary Estimates an additional vote of $35,765.00, (say $36,000.00).

If we are this year to provide sufficient to enable us to pay an increased grant to all Roman Catholic schools as well, without reduction, we will require $108,361.00, (say $108,000.00).

In one of the early memoranda on the subject certain Roman Catholic schools were scheduled to be closed, but Roman Catholics not having been dealt with and not having approached the Department in the same way as the Protestant bodies, asking for a general re-consideration and expressing their inability to carry on the work unless some increased financial assistance were given, no agreement has been arrived at as to closing the said schools. However, supposing that they are to
be closed, the Department to provide for the remaining Roman Catholic schools and for the Protestant schools on the basis of the new arrangement, we would require to provide $80,111.00, (say $80,000.00).

I would submit these alternative estimates for your immediate consideration, as it will be necessary to decide within the next few days, in order to add the amount to the Supplementary Estimates of the Department, now before the Finance Minister.

The Protestant schools which are to be closed according to agreement are: Regina, Elkhorn, Morley, Emmanuel College and Old Suns.

The question of closing the following Roman Catholic schools might be brought before the proper authorities:— Cowessess, Keesekoose, Muscowequan, Onion Lake, Thunderchild's, Blood, Peigan, Ermineskin, and Crowfoot. These schools are all situated in the Provinces of Alberta and Saskatchewan. A new type of day school will be established experimentally at certain points to be decided upon, and the Boarding Schools at Ermineskins and Bluequills and the large Industrial Schools at Duck Lake and Bumbow would remain; together with all the Boarding Schools in the outlying districts where the Indians make their living by hunting.

Rev. and dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your communication of the 4th instant, pointing out the desirability of at once carrying out the proposals contained in letter from the Department of Indian Affairs, dated the 24th April, 1908.

It is clear that greater financial assistance was an essential feature of the proposed re-arrangement and the letter above quoted stated that the Department would feel disposed to increase the scale of per capita grants. As the school work is divided pretty equally between the Protestant churches and the Roman Catholic church any new arrangement to be made must be the same for both the interested parties. After a certain necessary interval the Protestant churches agreed to the propositions which were advanced by the Department but up to the present the Catholics have not accepted any proposition looking toward the reduction of the number of schools under their jurisdiction. Moreover there is not absolute unanimity amongst the Protestants themselves as there is considerable opposition from some influential quarters, notably from the Bishop of Calgary.

In view of these facts and considerations it was felt to be useless to present an estimate to Parliament for an increased appropriation, and that such a step should not be taken pending the acceptance by the Roman Catholic Church of the main features of the proposition and more complete harmony amongst the various local interests of the Protestant churches.

My Dear Mr Oliver:-

Yours of July 18 to hand and the contents carefully noted. In replying it appears necessary to quote a little from former communications of the Department to the Advisory Board of Indian Education, and if you can reconcile what appears to be strange contradictions it may suggest some plan of future action.

The Advisory Board discussed very fully the three points covered by your letter, viz:- 1st The Financial side of the proposition advanced by the Department; 2nd The attitude of the Roman Catholic Church; 3rd The necessity of unity on the part of the three churches in our acceptance or rejection of the Government proposition.

First As to the Financial side of the proposition. You say it is clear that greater financial assistance was an essential feature of the proposed re-arrangement. This is exactly what the Advisory Board understood. The statements, facts and figures presented in the documents of January 24th and March 21st are clear on this phase of the question. In these documents we have the following:- January 24th "This prominent phase of the subject has therefore received immediate consideration."
"It is thought that a re-arrangement of these schools and the adoption of a new type of school would further the interests of Indian Education and at the same time render it unnecessary to apply to Parliament for an increase in the gross appropriation." March 21st. "The increased grant could be made without asking Parliament for additional appropriations."

From such statements and the facts and figures so carefully compiled in these documents the committee concluded that in the closing of these schools proposed, a saving of about $50000 would be made and from this $50000 the increased grants could be given, and the request from Parliament would remain about the same. It now appears that there are some new facts and new considerations to be taken into account. You say,—

"In view of these facts and considerations it was felt to be useless to present an estimate to Parliament for an increased appropriation." Since these statements appear to contradict each other answers to a few questions may throw light on the subject.

Did the Advisory Board arrive at a wrong conclusion when they assumed that a saving of about $50000 would be made by the closing of the schools mentioned, and that this would be sufficient to meet the advanced grant of the remaining schools? If not sufficient what additional amount would be required from Parliament?

Second Re the attitude of the Roman Catholic Church On March 27th the Advisory Board said,—"It is therefore submitted that the position of the three Churches now approaching the Department should not be in any manner prejudiced because of the
refusal of this Church to co-operate but whatever is considered in the best interests of these schools should be carried out."

The reply of your Department to this dated April 24th was,—

"The Department intended at an early date to approach those interested in the Education of Roman Catholic children along the same lines but it is submitted that as the best interests of all Protestant children are not being lost sight of but furthered by the present scheme it should not be wrapped up with the acceptance of the Roman Catholic Church of the same conditions. In other words this scheme seems—for the Protestant schools should stand on its own merits.

As the school work is pretty evenly divided between the Protestant Churches and the Roman Catholic Church any new arrangement to be made must be the same for both interested parties. After a certain necessary interval the Protestant Churches agreed to the propositions which were advanced by the Department but up to the present the Catholics have not accepted any proposition looking toward the reduction of the number of schools under their jurisdiction.

Is this proposition of April 24th to the Advisory Board to stand on its own merits or have we to wait for the Roman Catholic Church to accept of a similar reduction of their schools?

Third The question of unity on the part of the three Churches

The document of March 21st says,—

"The Department has at all times been willing to give full consideration to the representations of the Churches but it has been found confusing to deal with a large number of persons in authority who are interested in the Indian Work." In the document of April 24th "It is gratifying to find that such an unanimity of opinion exists in the important matter dealt with in the previous correspondence." When these matters are amicably arranged and carried out with your committee the Department would feel disposed to adopt the increased scale of per capita at the remaining residential schools in Ontario and the West.

Realizing the great need of unity the proposition of April 24th was considered by the Board of Management of the Missionary Society of the Church of England.
in Canada, by the Foreign Missionary Committee of the Presbyterian Church, and the Executive of the Missionary Board of the Methodist Church and the Advisory Board was able to inform the Superintendent General that all these bodies were prepared to co-operate with the Department in carrying out this proposition.

Now you inform us that there is not absolute unanimity amongst the Protestants themselves as there is considerable opposition from some influential quarters, notably from the Bishop of Calgary.

From this twofold position it is very plain that the Department must choose between doing business on the old plan, which may be with every Bishop of a Diocese, Moderator of a Synod, Chairman of a District, President of a Conference or any preacher, merchant or politician who may be interested directly or indirectly with the Indian Work, or on the other new plan with the Advisory Board which is clothed with absolute power to speak on behalf of the Anglican, Presbyterian and Methodist Churches.

The Advisory Board is well aware of the fact that opposition will be forthcoming from those engaged in the work who will not see the question beyond their own little sphere, and from merchants and others who have the trade of these schools to be closed, also from some small politicians who will be afraid of losing a few votes. At the same time we never expect to have a more unanimous and influential b
backing to any proposal that may be presented by the Department than we have to the proposition of April 24th and the Board have assured the Superintendent General that in every way, in their power they will most gladly co-operate with him and with the Department in endeavoring to make effectual the plan which the Superintendent has outlined. There are matters in connection with the schools which require immediate action, arrangements which cannot be delayed must be made in respect of teachers and principals, all of which require a knowledge of the policy the Department intends to pursue. We are writing not under the authority of the Advisory Board, but on behalf of the Methodist Church which body we have the honor to represent on that Board and we assure you that we are willing to take our full share of the difficulties and responsibilities involved in putting this new policy into operation.

Yours most respectfully,

The members duly appointed by the Anglican, Presbyterian and Methodist Churches to represent them in conference with the Superintendent of Indian Affairs on the subject of Indian education beg to state that they have perused and carefully considered the communications which have taken place between the Superintendent and the Chairman of the Committee dated the 17th and 25th of June, the 16th of July, and the 4th, 13th and 19th of August, 1908.

(1) While the Committee learns with the deepest regret that no provision has been made to enable the Superintendent to carry out the plan set out in the letters of the 14th and 26th of last January and of the Deputy Superintendent of the 27th of March and the 24th of April, it cannot but express its pleasure at the last paragraph of the communication of the Superintendent of the 18th August in which this statement is
"I hope in the interval between now and the coming session to be able to reach a conclusion that will be at any rate measurably satisfactory, but in order to do this it appears to me that I will have to take a more personal part than has been possible during the past year."

(2) The Committee is convinced that nothing will tend more largely to the success of the plan proposed, than that the Superintendent of Indian Affairs shall personally take the matter up and bring to bear his large knowledge and experience on the subject. There must be some person whose conclusion, after conference, must be final on the question of the closing, opening, location and character of the schools, and the spheres of action of the various religious bodies engaged in the work.

Without the careful superintendence of one skilled in these matters, and who is bound to act impartially as between the various interests that from time to time arise, there will be hopeless confusion and such friction as will interfere most materially with the due carrying out of the formulated plan. The questions which have been raised between the Department and the representatives of the Churches in various portions of the Northwest and British Columbia show how absolutely correct is this statement.
(3) On the receipt of the communications referred to from the Superintendent and the Deputy the Committee informed the Churches interested of the conclusion of the Department. It was generally accepted, and, when better understood, by those who did not in the first instance agree to the scheme, the objections raised by them seemed to have been removed, and arrangements were made based on the proposals going into operation at once. It is impossible to exaggerate the disappointment caused by the action of the Superintendent at present contemplated. Promises had been made based on the earlier statements, which must be broken as, apart from the aid of the Government, it is simply impossible to fulfill them.

(4) It is very earnestly hoped that even yet the Superintendent may see his way out of the money saved by a concentration of the work and closing some of the schools, as suggested in his proposals, and the cutting down of expenses in the Department, to make a reasonable beginning in the way of the improved schools and some increase in the per capita grants although not up to the full standard suggested.

(5) The Committee has read with regret the following statement in the letter of the Superintendent of July 18th:-
"After a certain necessary interval the Protestant Church agreed to the propositions which were advanced by the Department but up to the present the Catholics have not accepted any proposition looking towards the reduction of the number of schools under their jurisdiction."

And also the following in reference to the presentation of an estimate to Parliament for an increased appropriation:

"Such a step should not be taken pending the acceptance by the Roman Catholic Church of the main features of the propositions".

It will not be forgotten by the Superintendent that over two years ago at his suggestion more than twelve months was spent in endeavouring to procure representatives of the Roman Catholics at our conferences, but all the efforts failed, and a refusal to co-operate in working out a scheme was finally the answer received. It was then submitted by this Committee to the Superintendent "that the position of the three Churches now approaching the Department should not be in any manner prejudiced because of the refusal of this Church to co-operate, but that whatever is considered in the best interest of the Indians should be carried out". Wherever it is thought wise to close or change the class of school this should be done, and wherever the school is not found to answer the best interest of the Indians the grants of the Department should
cease, no matter what religious body might be controlling the school. This statement was presented in writing last March, and the Committee was gratified to find by a communication from the Department of the 24th of last April that—

"The Department intends at an early date to approach those interested in the education of Roman Catholic children along the same lines; but it is submitted that as the best interests of all Protestant children are not being lost sight of but furthered by the present scheme, it should not be wrapped up with the acceptance by the Roman Catholic Church of the same conditions. In other words, this scheme for the Protestant schools should stand upon its merits."

The Committee gladly accepted this conclusion and have since acted upon it.

(6) It still seems to the Committee to be a mere act of justice, that if those representing one-half of the Indian population accept an offer which the Superintendent makes, and which he considers to be in the best interests of his wards, whereby under a system of concentration inefficient and useless schools are cut off and thereby better schools, better equipment, and a larger per capita grant are given, it is monstrous that this should be interfered with because there are some interested in the work who will not consent to these terms.
The price to be paid for the increased grant and better schools is the diminution of schools which the Superintendent finds are not doing their duty. There is no interference with those who do not accept these terms, but they continue to do in the future as they have done in the past. What right have those who reject the terms of the Superintendent and desire to continue in the old path and who are not interfered with, to complain of the Superintendent because he has procured the assent of one-half of those interested in the work to his plan for a great improvement in the welfare of those for whom he is responsible? The Committee cannot but dissent very strongly from this apparently retrograde step, and regrets the unfortunate position in which the Department now suggests that it shall be placed.

(7) In the communication of this Committee to the Department of date March last there is this statement:

"The Committee learns with pleasure that 'it has always been the wish of the Department that officials and employees should give their active influence in furthering the educational policy, and the attention of agents generally will be again directed to this very important phase of their general administrative duties' from such action of the Department, and the Committee looks forward to good results."

And in answer to the Committee's Memorandum of March
last, in the communication of 24th April, there was the following undertaking:

"In due course a circular of instructions will be prepared for all employees of this Department and pointing out their duties and responsibilities as regards Indian education; a copy of which will be sent for your information, and as before stated, the regulations for compulsory education will be revised where necessary".

The Committee is unable to find that any such circular has been issued.

Some complaints that have been very recently made show the necessity for such instructions and for such superintendence as will compel their observance.

(8) The Committee feels that the following matter is of such very great importance that it cannot help referring to it and emphasizing it:

In the portion of territory more immediately dealt with in the negotiations with the Department — that is, Manitoba, the Northwest, and British Columbia — the total number of Roman Catholic schools is, according to the last report of the Department, 52; Church of England 76; Methodist 32; Presbyterian 16. Therefore you are dealing with 52 Roman
Catholic schools and 128 Protestant. While the majority should not and does not desire that ought that is unfair should be done to the minority, yet the majority cannot but feel that it has its rights, and that it is eminently unfair that the plan which you propose in the interest of your wards, and which the bodies, representing 128 of the schools, desire to have carried out, is to be thwarted because 52 schools which are not being interfered with choose to say No.

The Committee still trusts that before the close of this year the Superintendent will see his way so to order matters in his Department that the members of the Churches interested will see a fair commencement made along the lines suggested by him, and approved heartily by the Advisory Committee.
