IMPRESSIONS REGARDING MISSIONARY EFFORT AMONGST THE INDIANS, BEING AN ADDRESS GIVEN AT THE FIRST CONVENTION OF INDIAN WORKERS IN THE PROVINCE OF ALBERTA, AT EDMONTON, JAN. 6TH, 1909

BY ARCHBISHOP TILB

---

Mr. Chairman & Friends:

I am glad to have the privilege of being permitted to take part in this the first Convention of workers amongst the Indians in the Province of Alberta. The moment I heard of it, it appealed to me as something that might be of immense profit to Missionaries, Teachers, officials of the Indian Department, the Churches and the Government, and through them to the Indians themselves. I fully hope that this may be but the first of many such gatherings, and I feel sure that to bring together representatives of the Churches and the Government for a straightforward discussion and interchange of opinions on the subject, for which we are all working - the betterment and the elevation of the Indian in our midst - can only be fraught with blessing. I have always maintained, and see no reason to change my opinion, that the christianization and civilization of the Indian should go hand in hand. It is difficult, it is almost impossible, for the minister of the Gospel to do anything with a lazy man in any part of the world. The most successful work has been always amongst peoples and communities that are industrious. We have illustrations of this in Holy Scripture. Thus Gideon was threshing wheat when called to lead his people to victory; Eliash was following the plough when called to take up the mantle of Elijah;
David was keeping sheep when called to be king over Israel, and Matthew was sitting at the receipt of customs when called to be an Apostle and Evangelist. The success of Mission work has been greater amongst the working populations in England and heathen nations than amongst the Indians, whether rich or poor. It is therefore of importance to our success in Missionary work amongst the Indians that the people should be taught to work. In days past all the Natives had to work and, at certain seasons of the year, work hard for their livelihood whether in the chase, or as trappers and fishermen. They have become creatures of circumstances, and those with whom it has been my lot to be cast, have perforce been obliged to give up the chase for lack of the buffalo. The latter had gone for good when I first arrived in the country a quarter of a century ago, and a more pitiable condition could hardly be conceived than was that of the Indians in Southern Alberta at that time. The buffalo had disappeared, and they were just settling down to 'reserve' life. They did nothing except dance and attend the ration house. They were poor in the extreme, except for the few remaining skin garments, and most of the people were wearing cotton stuffs in exchange for skin shirts and dresses, and Hudson Bay blankets in place of the buffalo robe. Whilst a few skin tents remained the majority of the people were already reduced to duck or cotton tepees. Several had erected log huts with the best cottonwood trees at their disposal, but they had mud roofs and floors, no windows, and in some cases, a skin hung over the entrance to serve as a door. No attempt had been made at agriculture, what was done was done by employees of the Government who ploughed, sowed, harvested for the chiefs in whose names the fields were held, and also cut hay.
The Tobacco Dance and Sun Dance with their accompanying smaller rites occupied the tribe from April to the end of July when they all went berry picking. Tea and other dances occupied them through the winter season. Their knowledge of the Almighty and His love to them i. Christ Jesus was almost nil. Still they were religious to a degree even if their religion consisted solely in the desire to propitiate the many spirits of evil which they seemed to think constantly surrounded them.

Their code of morality was peculiar. It was not wrong to steal but it was terribly so to be found out. Unfaithfulness in the women was punished by the excision of the nose, and there were some women thus disfigured in the camp. But what can be said for the elevating influences of the white race when every white man in the district had his women, and some two or three!

After recalling some of the past as I have done, I can well quote the words of Mr. Smart, then Deputy Supt. General for Indian Affairs, in 1901.

"Although there is much to be deplored by those who are earnestly striving for the elevation of the race, there would not appear to be any cause for discouragement if the mind be fixed upon what has been accomplished rather than allowed to dwell exclusively upon what remains to be done." And from a missionary point of view one is glad to be able to quote the words of Mr. Selley in his report for 1903. Various influences conspicuously those of the Missionaries of the various denominations who labour among them, are surely, if slowly, bringing about a better condition of things."
I am sure I voice the feelings of every Missionary present when I say that Mr. edley on the part of the Department appears to be modesty itself in thus writing. The wise changes which the Department has made in the past few years in the personnel of its staff agents and other officers, has done much towards bringing about a better condition of things.

There have certainly been great strides made towards civilization by the Indians in Southern Alberta. I remember in 1894 writing to the then Indian Commissioner and suggesting the necessity of letting the Sun's rays into the dark huts of the Blackfeet. At that time only one house in the reserve had a window and the Commissioner sent me up two dozen windows on my undertaking to assist the Indians in putting them in. How many of the natives have houses equal to and better than many of the white settlers and they take a pride in them. They have good floors and good roofs overhead, whilst their walls are covered with pictures and ornaments; clocks stand on shelves; cupboards hold crockery; and tables, chairs, and cooking ranges are found in nearly all. Iron bedsteads and spring mattresses are not uncommon and tend towards cleanliness, whilst I have seen leather bottomed chairs as well as washstands and bureaus amongst the furniture. It is some time since I attended an Indian feast until this last New Year's day, and then I found wonderful progress had been made, for instead of a great crowd huddled on the floor with food held between the fingers and so transmitted to the mouth, tables and chairs were provided, and the people sat down in batches of twenty. Cups, plates and spoons were provided for all and a woman stood in the background washing up the utensils ready for the next batch of people. The delicacies were carried round on a large tray, and tea was poured out in the old fashioned tea meeting style of our young days; a large toilet jug highly filled being used for the purpose.
But not only in their surroundings is this advance towards civilization seen. In most cases the men were dressed in tweed suits, and the women in gowns of their own make after a civilized pattern, whilst the younger women wore blouses made with their own hands if their skirts had been purchased in one of the city stores.

And whilst one sees great progress towards civilization in the past twenty-five years, one also is struck with the great strides being made towards self-support. To me their progress in industry is very marked. As I remember, in those days, the only vehicle used on the reserves, besides the travoy, was the Red River cart, a few of which were supplied by the Indian Department just after my arrival. They served a purpose. The chiefs seemed to appropriate them and broke some of their ponies into driving. But ponies wouldn't break in, broke or tried to break the carts. Now, what could the Indians do without a wagon? I looked up the last Blue Book available, that for 1907, and I found that the four tribes, Blackfoot, Blood, Peigan, and Sarcees now have 683 wagons, besides 43 draught sleighs (the figures in number only testifying to the salubriosity of the climate), 67 democrats, and 121 buggies and road carts, most of which I believe were purchased out of their own earnings.

The Indians late in the 90's were desirous of putting up hay for sale to the few settlers then in the country. I remember how they were encouraged in their laudable desires by the Departmental issuing to them a quantity of scythes and wooden rakes. Anxious to get some hay myself, I purchased a mowing machine and leased it for the season to the Chief, White Leg, who provided me with five loads for the use of the machine, and then made £200 for himself. Up to that time the Indians had no mowing machines except what were owned by the Department and solely for the farmer's use. Now I see by the Blue Book the
Indians of these four tribes own no less than 283 mowers and
27 horse-drawn, and in the season 1906 put up 6582 tons of
wild hay besides other food stuffs. The cultivation of the land
has not perhaps been their strong point, but who that saw the
crops of years ago, when most of the work was done by their
instructor, could blame the Indians for not taking a deep interest
in the tillage of the soil! This perhaps accounts for the small
number of ploughs, 95, owned by them. But this source of wealth,
as it now is, will not be long let go by the Indians. Already
I understand that a large amount of winter wheat has been harvested
by some of the Indians in the vicinity of MacLeod.

It is possible that the attempt to make the Indians
tillers of the soil was premature. In biblical days, the tending
of flocks and herds was the more primitive industry of Abraham
and his immediate successors, and it looks as if our Southern
Indians may soon find a real means of self-support in the herds
of cattle that are increasing year by year on their reserves.
In 1906-1907 they are credited with having 5817 cows and 5757
head of young stock or altogether 11,554 head.

Whilst all this is making for progress, it strikes me
as somewhat strange that the total income of 555 families,
reckoning the 2779 souls as five per family, from all sources
including beef eaten and sold, should be only $167.10 per family
or $31.42 per head per annum. It means of course that there are
a great many old people and a great many children who cannot
work, and perhaps it is not so bad a showing as it appears at
first sight. At any rate it shows great progress from 25 years
ago when their income was about nil, whilst today it aggregates
$92,893.64, or rather did so in 1906. This year it probably
reaches the $100,000 mark. I make no apology for dealing so
far with matters connected with the civilization and industrial
progress of the Indians. As I said at the commencement of this
paper, I believe that civilization and christianity must go hand
I come now to that work generally accepted as more nearly connected with its literary effort—the progress of the Indians in Christianity, and of this it may be said that since 1863 it has been all progress. I can hardly describe the feelings that came over me when first I made the acquaintance of the Blackfoot speaking race. I arrived in the month of July when that great heathen festival—the Sun Dance—was in full swing—when every Indian on the reserve almost was willing or unwilling, obliged to attend that gruesome spectacle, the torturing of the body and tearing of the flesh, on the victims doomed before the Medicine Pole to the beating of the tom-tom and weird singing of a thousand voices. The fantastic costumes of the people, the paint and feathers, the then to me foreign tongue, made my heart sink within me, and if ever I felt the hopelessness of a task set me to do it was then.

But the Christian Missionary is not thrown altogether on his own resources. "Not by might nor by power, but by My Spirit," saith the Lord; and "When we are weak, then are we strong," saith the Apostle. Upheld, as I believed in prayer, by numerous friends from whom I had but a few weeks before parted in the Home Land, I endeavoured to settle down to the work as hundreds had done before me, looking to the Master for strength and help. The Agencies employed by our Church in its work amongst the Indians have been various. Naturally after building one's house, the next and most important thing is the learning of the language. In my case it had to be done from the people themselves; for there were no books except a small hand book for traders which the ethnologists at Washington told me was "useless." So far as I know all literary work in the Blackfoot language has been produced by our Church. A grammar and dictionary in 1869 and the Gospel of Matthew in the same year were the first published in book form, but a small Manual of Instruction including the Lord's Prayer, Ten Commandments, and Apostles Creed, with other
matter were earlier produced and printed at the Blackfoot Mission on a small hand press. Then portions of the other Gospels appeared in 1890. In 1906 a part of the Prayer Book and some hymns were translated and printed. The hope of reaching the older people by the Syllabic System led to a study of the Cree Syllabics and their adaptation, and we believe simplification, for the Blackfoot people. In this character we produced in 1906, Morning & Evening Prayer, Litany, a Hymn Book, and a portion of St John's Gospel. The introduction of the Syllabic System has been a success; some adult Indians who have never been to school can read and write fluently by its means.

Evangelistic Work, by which I mean the effort to get hold of the heathen and teach them Christianity, which embraces the sinfulness of sin and the need of a Saviour, was at first very difficult. It was something altogether alien to the Indian's way of thinking. Listen to him as he begins his prayer. "Pity me, I am a righteous man, I do not lie, I do not steal, I am not immoral," and so on. Tell him that the Creator has given us a Book and in the Book it is written, "All men have sinned," and he replies, "Yes, I know, all men are sinners, but so far as I am concerned, "I am a righteous man, I do not lie," etc. Thank God, His Spirit has taught many of this self-righteous nation to see themselves in the light of God's Holy Word and to acknowledge or bend the knee that they are sinners indeed in His sight and to plead with Him for pardon and for the Grace of His Holy Spirit to lead new lives or become New Creatures in Christ Jesus.

Our Evangelistic methods in the old days were to get a few people together in the house, or in the tepee by producing a little tea, and then one could talk to them as long as the tea lasted. This could be done and was done at all hours.
of the day, but the same method would hardly serve now
as most of them are generally busy with their work, which
they had not got in those days. We used sometimes to try
Evangelistic meetings amongst them after the pattern still in
vogue amongst white people. We did not find them a success.
The Indian needs, first, instruction in the rudiments of Christian-
ity. The more successful work, we find, is that done with indivi-
duals - "line upon line, precept upon precept," here a little
and there a little," a quiet talk and instruction in the home
or in the study, combined with the changed lives of some of the
Christians, is a surer method for obtaining good results.

The first adult baptism took place in 1890. A
few children, whose parents had promised to send them to school
for instruction when old enough, were baptized before that date.
The number of church members on the four reserves is now about
570, and the Blue Book quoted above gives the same number to the
Roman Catholics. In 1906 and 07 the Baptisms numbered 68.
Of these 26 were adults and 63 children. The number confirmed
during the same period was 31, making a total of 163 admitted
into full membership in our Church.

We have church buildings at three of the Reserves,
and at the fourth, the Blood Reserve, a school chapel serves
the purpose. Our adherents are not all of them what we could
wish, but comparing them with the average white congregation,
I think their attendance at Divine Service and on the means of
grace generally is good. They are learning to give of their
substance to God's work, and I have more than once noted that
when an Indian has failed to have the offering ready when the
plate was taken round, he or she invariably brings it up at
the close of the service instead of doing as many a white person
would do - carry it home again.
MEDICAL WORK has always had a place in our Missions.

In the early days the Mission House always had a supply of simple medicines, and the missionary was often called upon to alleviate suffering. A hospital was built at the Blackfoot Reserve in 1894 by the help of the Government, and it has ever since been in use. It has been a useful agency in our work, and not a few Indians have found healing for both body and soul whilst residing there.

One of the most valuable agencies employed by us, I think, is that of the schools. This in the first instance took the form of day schools, and when the Indians were accustomed to dwell together in large camps there was no difficulty in getting a large attendance at certain seasons of the year. Such, however, when the people were induced to separate and scatter over the Reserves in small villages, the attendance dwindled, and as the people generally left their villages in the Spring and migrated with their tepees to another part of the Reserve until Fall, day schools became impracticable. We gave them up in the end, feeling that even though a few children could be got to attend regularly, the influence in their homes more than counterbalanced the best teaching they obtained in the schools. Boarding Schools were then started by the Church, first with the child's ration of beef and flour as the only assistance from Government. Then the Indian Department came to our aid and offered a per capita grant of $72.00 per annum, making at the same time certain regulations to which we were bound to adhere. As buildings were needed a small grant was made towards the cost of each by the Government, the rest being obtained by appeals from the individual missionaries to Eastern Canada and England. I feel bound to say that this work has done a great deal towards educating the younger generation in the doctrines of Christianity as well as prepar-
ing them for the changed conditions of life that have come over the people in the past few years. The number of pupils in the four schools is about 125.

The question of the school is, shall I say, a burning one at the present time. For three years past the Churches and the Government have been trying to solve the school question and it is not solved yet. The type of school most suited to the needs of the Indian, whether Industrial, Boarding, or Day; the share of financial responsibility that should be borne by the church and by the government respectively in the upkeep of the institutions; and the nature of the instruction that should be given to the pupils are all matters of great importance to the Government, the Churches, and the Indians alike. We had an Industrial School at Calgary for a few years and whilst it lived it did some good work. But it is dead, and I do not see how it could have been kept alive. It was away from the Reserves and no boy or girl can be legally taken from the Reserve except as a lawbreaker. For the next generation or so it is my firm conviction that the reserve boarding school will best serve the needs of the Indians in Alberta—at any rate in the North and South. I do not know what your needs is in this central portion of the province. I am fully convinced that it would be a retrograde movement to return to day schools, even of an improved type, where boarding schools are in existence for the simple reasons that the Indians are too widely scattered for a school in any one position on a reserve to get a sufficient number of pupils, and that the irregular attendance and the baneful influence of camp life would more than counterbalance the good done in the school.

The bad influence of home life is recognized by Mr. Bealey who in his report in 1913 said: "As a civilizing factor the
advantages of the removal of the pupils from the retrogressive influence of home life is shared pretty equally by the Industrial and Boarding Schools." I am strongly in favor of Boarding Schools of an improved type—improved buildings, improved sanitary conditions, improved equipment, and improved grants.

The United States Commissioner, in his last report, extracts of which I have been permitted to see, says: "Though the day school system is the ideal mechanism for the uplifting of the Indians, we cannot yet wholly dispense with Boarding Schools because so many tribes still continue the nomadic and semi-nomadic habits which would require the continual moving of the day schools from place to place in order to keep near a sufficient number of families for their support." Now it seems to me that this puts into a nutshell as it were our position in this province and I should like to see a resolution passed by this Convention favouring the well equipped and up to date Boarding School in preference to a larger number of well equipped day schools. My own view is that so much of the Industrial School should be embodied in the Reserve Boarding School as would, besides giving the pupils fair instruction in the three "R's," enable them to get sufficient knowledge of the use of tools to build their own barns and dwellings, and become thoroughly acquainted with the management of stock and all that goes to make a good farmer. So far as the girls are concerned, the present type of Boarding School already provides them with a capital education in domestic affairs. There are other matters that interest us from a Missionary point of view that I should like to touch upon but I fear my paper has already overreached its proper length, so I will confine myself to two
very important matters, the observance of the Lord's Day, and
the sanctity of marriage. It seems to me that our Indians are
not only getting the habit of working, but of working on the
Lord's Day to a greater extent than formerly. So far as I am
personally aware it is from no bad example on the reserve although
I have heard of machinery being fixed up and set in motion,
and lumber being hauled by, and with the sanction of those in
authority, on the Lord's Day. The law of the country calls for
abstinence from all labour except work of necessity on the day
of Rest, and it would be well if the attention of the Indian
Dept. at Ottawa could be called to this tendency with a suggestion
that steps should be taken to secure a better observance of the
day on all reserves.

The other matter concerning marriage was brought
specially before me at the last treaty payments when a young
Indian, who had been baptized and had afterwards contracted a
marriage according to tribal custom with an unbaptized girl came
to me and said: "The agent has sent us to get married by you and
won't pay us our treaty money until we have been married by the
Church," - or some such words. I have on two or three occasions
felt obliged to conduct similar marriages where one party has been
baptized, but only after first getting an assurance that the
unbaptized believes in God. It seems to me that for marriages
of this kind and for all marriages that are contracted, as in the
past according to tribal customs, the Indian Agent should be given
the powers of a Registrar for solemnizing marriages, and that the
parties should all pledge their troth before him, and such marriages
should have the force of civil marriages, and the subsequent non-
observance of the laws of marriage should be subject to the same
penalties as in other cases.
And now in conclusion let me express the pleasure I feel at being here face to face with officials of the Government and my brethren of other Churches in conference for the welfare of the Indians. It is a good work to be engaged in and only good can come of it if we work with good motives. The convening circular bore the motto, "Our work is one," and that one work must be the upbuilding of the Red Man in Civilization, in Christianity, and in Character, whilst we look forward to a fourth "C," in Citizenship.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Oliver,

I beg to draw your attention to the present position of the Indian School problem and to make certain suggestions which will tend to carry out as nearly as may be practicable the plan outlined in the Department's letter of the 24th. of April last, which plan was accepted by the Advisory Board. As you are aware, this plan contemplated the payment of per capita grants at the rate of $100.00 to the pupils in residential schools east of the Great Lakes and $130.00 to pupils in residential schools west of the Great Lakes, excluding the Province of British Columbia. The payment at the increased per capita rate was in effect made conditional upon the closing of the Regina and Elkhorn Schools, Emmanuel College and McDougall Orphanage, and the Old Sun's Church of England School on the Blackfoot Reserve. It was hoped both by the Department and the Churches interested that this new scheme could go into effect from the 1st. of April 1908, but lack of funds in the existing appropriations and the inability of the Department to obtain larger grants rendered this impossible. The Estimates for the fiscal year 1909-10 have been made out without any increases owing to the urgent request that our Estimates should conform as nearly as possible to those of 1907-08; but it seems obligatory that the Department should take some steps either to obtain increased grants or to make some use of money already voted in the direction of the proposed change of plan and increase in grant to the Schools. I have, therefore, to make the following suggestions, dealing with the Provinces separately,-

ONTARIO: As the Shingwauk Home, situated at Sault Ste. Marie, is in constant financial difficulties and as the Department has declined
to be responsible for any further deficits, it is thought advisable to withdraw from the support of this School and to use the grant for other purposes. The institution is badly situated for agricultural operations and the pupilage is drawn not only from the Diocese of Algoma but from remote parts of Ontario. It is proposed with a portion of the money saved by this closure to improve certain Church of England Day Schools on Reserves in the Province of Ontario, to secure if possible a better class of Teacher at a higher rate of pay, and to modernize the buildings and equipment where necessary, and to increase the grant for pupils at Mt. Elgin (Maths.), Chapleau and Moose Factory (O. of E.) to $85.00 per capita. This is an increase of $25.00. The proposed rate for the Province of Ontario was to be $100.00 per capita, but the Department has not the funds at present to provide that rate.

The only other Schools that should be provided for are the Roman Catholic Schools at Wikwemikong and Albany and the Mohawk Institute at Brantford. As the latter School is supported by the New England Company, I do not think the Department should increase the grant. Sufficient funds can be found for increasing the per capita grant to the Roman Catholic Schools mentioned. This Church has not joined as yet in the new movement and it might not be thought advisable at present to increase any particular school without reference to a general understanding between that Church and the Department.

Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta &c.: If the Regina and Elkhorn Schools were closed before the end of the year the Department would have available $28,250.00 from this source with which to increase the per capita grant and to establish a certain number of Day Schools of the new type. It would be impossible, however, to increase the grant to Boarding Schools to $130.00 per capita, and after re-considering that rate I think it is probably higher than is necessary and might be reduced to $100.00 until the experience of a couple of years has proved that rate to be insufficient. There are 600 pupils estimated in Protestant Boarding Schools which at an increase to $100.00 would requi-
$14860.00 additional to pay the grant. I would recommend that the Institutions at Regina and Elkhorn be closed and that the per capita grant be increased to $100.00 for Protestant Boarding Schools in these Provinces.

Dealing with the Roman Catholic Schools in the same Provinces it will be necessary to provide $26,650.00 to place the grants to pupils on the same basis. I think that in advance of any expression of willingness to consider a reduction in the number of Boarding Schools it would be premature to offer this increase, but at the same time I think the authorities of the Church should be approached more directly on this question with a view to arriving if possible at a harmonious conclusion.

The Protestant denominations have suffered great diminution of their teaching force without embarrassing the Department in any way, and I think that with reference to the savings effected or to be effected in the money voted or in any additional demands which may hereafter be made upon Parliament this fact should not be lost sight of. The following items have disappeared from the Estimates owing to Schools being closed, and the expenditure has been correspondingly reduced:

- St. Paul's: $15,000.00
- Emmanuel College: $4,304.00
- Calgary: $4,550.00
- Morley: $3,940.00
- Metlakatla: $7,200.00

Total reduction: $34,294.00

If the Shingwauk Home be closed $6000.00 may be added to this; Regina $14,700.00, and Elkhorn $14,550.00, making a total diminution in our Estimates on account of the closing of Protestant Boarding Schools aggregating $88,544.00. This is a prominent and outstanding fact that will not be lost sight of by the Protestant denominations and should be kept in mind by the Department.

BRITISH COLUMBIA. Owing to the saving which has accrued on account of closing the Metlakatla School the Department was
enabled to take preliminary steps toward establishing Day Schools of
the new type at Massett on the Queen Charlotte Islands and at Aiyansh:
and possibly at Hazelton. These three Schools are under Church of
England auspices, as was the Metlakatla School. It seems only fair to
divert any portion of the appropriation which may be thus saved to the
purposes of that denomination. In Boarding Schools in British Columbia
there are 165 Protestant pupils and 160 Roman Catholic pupils. In
this Province the grant is only $60.00 per capita so that $40.00 would
have to be provided to raise it to $100.00, and this would necessitate
granting $8,600.00 in the Supplementary Estimates.

YUKON: Affairs in the Yukon are on the same standing as
they were before the Supplementary appropriation which last Session
provided $10,000.00 for the erection of a new Boarding School building.
I am inclined to think that whatever may be the urgency of the Church
of England for further expenditures for Indian purposes in the Yukon,
the Indians themselves will not suffer seriously if the Department takes
time to consider slowly and carefully the needs of the Territory along
this line. We have had some correspondence with the Rev. Mr. O'Meara
and later on I will bring various matters to your attention.

REGATULATION: I am of the opinion that if the action
above outlined is taken; that is, if the Shingwauk Home, and the Regina
and Elkhorn Schools were closed; if the Brandon School was given a
constituency from which pupils could be drawn who would benefit by
agricultural training; if the per capita rate was advanced to $100.00
for the Mt. Elgin Institute in Ontario and to $85.00 in Manitoba and
the North West Territories; and if a sufficient amount was provided in
the Supplementary Estimates to give British Columbia the same treatment
from the Ist. of July prox., the Advisory Board would probably be
satisfied. In this connection I may say that in a memorandum dated
the 4th. of Sept. 1908 the Board stated that "It is very earnestly
hoped that even yet the Superintendent may see his way out of the money
saved by a concentration of the work and closing some of the schools, an
suggested in his proposals, and the cutting down of expenses in the Department, to make a reasonable beginning in the way of the improved schools and some increase in the per capita grants although not up to the full standard suggested." I think it will also be possible from the general avail of the appropriation to begin three or four Day Schools of the new type in various localities; probably two in the Prince Albert district and one or two at points to be suggested by the Presbyterian Church, whose educational opportunities should be strengthened on account of the closing of the Regina School. If these suggestions meet with favor, I think that we may safely anticipate that the Advisory Board will be gratified that a start has been made.

Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs.
MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Superintendent General.

Since presenting the memorandum of 27th of January to the Minister affairs have been somewhat furthered by a Meeting of the Advisory Board on February 8th at which I was present. We would also be able to pay an increased salary rate to Day
School teachers who are worthy of increases, and we could establish three improved Day Schools, one each for the Presbyterian, Methodist and Church of England denominations, at points to be decided upon after most careful consideration.

GENERAL MEMORANDUM:

I attach herewith a detailed plan of expenditure on Indian education in lieu of certain Industrial Schools to be closed.

With reference to the increase in per capita grant, this would only be given on the distinct understanding that no salary increases were to be made or additional obligations undertaken without the consent of the Department. The instruction in Boarding schools must be considered in the light of the special needs of the Indians who attend, and the general policy of the Department is to simplify the tuition and to make it directly applicable to the afterlife of the pupil. Investigation may lead to the conclusion that in Boarding Schools in agricultural districts the term of residence should be from 12 or 18 to 16 years and in fishing and hunting districts from 10 to 15 or 16 years. The Methodist Mission work is centred in three localities in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta; First; in the Norway House District; Second; the Saddle Lake District; Third; The Stony Reserve. The educational equipment in these districts at present consists of the Brandon Industrial School School, a Boarding School at Norway House, nine Day Schools in the Lake Winnipeg District and four in the Saddle Lake district.

After the Brandon Industrial School is closed it is proposed to provide for the educational work conducted by the Methodist Church in these districts as follows:

Re-build and enlarge the Boarding School at Norway House to accommodate a pupilage of 100, at a per capita grant of $700, and provide two Day Schools of the new type at Fisher River and Berens River.

It is difficult at present to determine what is the best course to pursue on the Stony Reserve. The Boarding School was not a success, and an experiment is now being made with a Day School which since its opening has had a very good attendance. The Indians seem interested and it may possibly develop into a permanent Day School of the improved type.

It seems clear that the Red Deer Industrial School is not favorably located for the work to be done by the Methodist Church in the northern part of Alberta. It is submitted for consideration that it might be better at some not far distant date to close this School and to open a Boarding School at a point to be decided upon in the Saddle Lake District, nearer the source of pupils, and to gradually build up the Day School work with this institution as a centre.

It will be seen from the above outline that the Department wishes to take a conservative stand on the question of Boarding Schools and not to close any of the existing institutions until it
has been proved that day schools will as well provide for the pupils as do the residential schools; or until the Department is convinced that a school is not properly managed and should be abolished. At the same time it must not be understood that any Boarding School is to be considered permanent on account of the increase in the per capita grant or in the number of pupils in attendance. The Boarding Schools are to come under criticism and are to prove their effectiveness while the attempt is being made to develop the day schools. The increased per capita grant is only given on the distinct understanding that no salary increases are to be made or additional obligations undertaken for maintenance without the consent of the Department.

The instruction to be given in Boarding Schools and the terms of attendance must be considered in the light of the special needs of the pupils and the general policy of the Department is to simplify the tuition and to introduce a larger element of outdoor work for the boys and more practical instruction in domestic employments for the girls; in a word, to make the tuition directly applicable to the afterlife of the pupil. Investigation may lead to the conclusion that in agricultural districts pupils should enter the school at 12 or 13 years of age and remain till 16, and in fishing and hunting districts they would enter at 10 and leave at 14 or 16. In no event should the course at a Boarding School be longer than six years. The tendency has been to admit pupils who were hardly more than infants, and to keep them until they were 18 or over. It may be open to question whether girl pupils should not be kept a year or two longer, but boys who are to earn their living by farming will receive the most valuable tuition between 15 and 16 and pupils of the same sex who are to become fishermen and hunters or voyageurs should begin their life of active employment at 15 or 16.

The Advisory Board has received and carefully perused the communication of the Deputy Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs from Ottawa, of date March 26th, 1909, giving, amongst other information, a list of the Industrial Schools which the Department proposes to close, and showing the dealing generally with the Residential Schools and Day Schools in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, and how the funds saved by this proposed action are to be expended.

2. The Board suggests that before the Department determines finally upon the action to be taken opportunity should be given to those in the locality immediately affected by the proposed changes for consultation, so far as possible, approval or modification, according to the result of the stated conference.

The Board reiterates the conclusion arrived at after full consideration that the regulation as to compulsory attendance should be strictly enforced. The Board concurs in the conclusion that "where Day Schools have now a very small attendance" and the number can not be increased, arrangements should be made at as early a date as possible for the closing of these schools and for the adoption of what may be determined upon for giving education to the children of the locality.

It would be well to name a minimum attendance; if this is not reached, then on due notice, such schools should be closed.

There is a careful in-
spection of schools, yet, in order to aid the Department in its conclusions in this matter there should be more careful and constant supervision and medical inspection of all the schools, and that the officers responsible for this branch of the work should from time to time make such reports as will give the Department a complete statement of the facts so as to enable it to act.

6. The Board concurs in the shortening of the period for attendance of the children at the Residential Schools according to the schedule suggested in the communication referred to, and that it should not generally be longer than six years.

While Residential Schools may be necessary in some localities and may serve a good purpose for the time being, the Board concurs in the policy of the Department in establishing wherever possible an improved type of School. In a recent communication the Bishop of Galesdonia, who has devoted much time to the consideration of the Indian, states:

"Viewed in the light of relative expenditure, I have no hesitation in saying that there has been far greater return from the Day School than from the so-called Industrial School which on the per capita grant system, cannot afford to keep first-class trade instructors". Again: "It is not the policy for the Government to relieve the parents from the duty of providing for their children". "In some cases only a few of the people can carry at one time. If we had a man and his wife in charge a tent that could hold a dozen children, with blankets, etc., might meet the need. I think the parents would be willing to provide food for their children during their absence".

This equipment would be an adjunct to the Day School and is well worth

4 suggests that it would be in the interest of the Indians to adopt a plan whereby the older children, in all cases where they demand it should be drafted into the White Schools.

The Board also notes with satisfaction that "the Boarding Schools are not subject to criticism and are to prove their effectiveness while the effort is being made to develop the day schools". And, also, "the per capita grant is only given on the distinct understanding that..."
salary increases are to be made or additional obligations undertaken for maintenance without the consent of the Department, and that no Boarding School is to be considered permanent on account of the increase of the per capita grant. The Board would, however, add that the increased per capita grant only covers part of the expenditure and cherishes the hope that by and by it may be considerably increased.

The Board in dealing with the proposal to close Regina, Elkhorn and Brandon Industrial Schools is of the opinion that there is not room for all three; there is room for one; the proposition of the Department would leave only one small residential school at Portage la Prairie and another at Birtle for the Protestant children in all that section of country East of Elkhorn.

Taking up these three schools in the order in which the Department has placed them, we suggest the following:

First Elkhorn - By closing this school the constituency East of the School can be supplied by the schools at Pilot Mille, Gordon, Round Lake and Crossland, while that to the North will be served by the new type of Day School at Mistassini, and those who need a residential school can be drafted to Battleford, and the Gordon and Round Lake agencies given as a constituency to the Battleford School.

Second Elkhorn - The pupils in this school are drafted almost entirely from territory East and North of the school. About one-half of the pupils now in attendance belong to that District of country starting with Little Saskatchewan on the South East and travelling by way of Swan Lake to Cumberland House and North of this line. This portion of the Elkhorn constituency has an Indian population of about 2400. The proposal of the Department to build a school at the Pne, or wherever it may be most suitable, to accommodate about a hundred children might conserve the interest of this entire section, which at present has not one residential school. The fact that so many have been sent to Elkhorn from this District, and the people being of nomadic habits, it is more than probable that such a residential school would serve their educational interests better than any other system that might be devised, and we strenuously
commend the building of a Residential School for the Pas district.

The Archbishop of Rupert's Land makes the following strong representations on behalf of the Church of England: For many years it was the only Protestant body working among the Indians of the North West; his Diocese was the scene of the labours of the first missionaries and the establishment of the first churches and Mission Schools early in the 19th century and in consequence a large number of the Indians are members of the Church of England; when St. Paul's School was burned down, three or four years ago, an assurance was given to him that if he did not press for its immediate rebuilding an equivalent would be given him there or in some other more suitable locality; the present proposals of the Department do not contemplate even the establishment of an improved Day School in his Diocese; and the closing of the Elkhorn School would blot out the last vestige of Church of England influence in the education of the Indians of Manitoba.

The Advisory Board feels that there is great force in the Archbishop's contention and would recommend to the Department the establishment of an improved Day School and a Residential School at X point to be hereafter indicated to the Department.

Third Brandon - The territory East of Elkhorn might be made a constituency from which those who need a Residential School might be drafted into the Brandon School if that be retained and into such other Residential Schools as may hereafter be determined upon.

The unsanitary condition of the Residential School at Norway House has been before the Department for some time, and the Board approves the intention of the Government to build a new school at that point.

The wisdom of closing the Red Deer School and erecting a Residential School in a more suitable locality to the North commands itself to the Board worthy of the serious consideration of the Department.
As to all matters of detail mentioned by the Department regarding the improvement of Day Schools and Residential Schools and the establishment of the new type of Day School at Hintonburg and White Bear, together with the increased per capita grant to all the Residential Schools, this Board is in entire agreement with the proposals of the Department.

The Board heartily concurs in the last clause of the communication, —
(a) the special needs of the pupils; (b) the simplification of the tuition;
(c) the introduction of a larger element of outdoor work for the boys and more practical instruction in domestic employment for the girls should be the aim of education so as to make it directly applicable to the after life of the pupils; and strongly urges the importance of having a parcel of land in connection with all schools, Day or Residential, so that facilities may exist everywhere to teach farming to the children.

It will be the duty of the Churches to aid in every way in their power in devising some plan whereby —
(a) Improved teachers can be fitted for work in the North West.
(b) Nurses can also be prepared for this particular class of work.
(c) Matrons or deaconesses can be procured to aid and help generally in uplifting the Indian women in the locality.
(d) The evils of tuberculosis and other infectious diseases can be combated.
(e) The Indians can be protected from the evils of intemperance and immorality, especially in his contact with the white man.

We urge upon the Department the necessity of making the proposed changes, as far as they may be finally agreed on at the earliest possible date so as to bring the appropriations within the present fiscal year, and we assure the Department of our hearty co-operation to bring the whole to a successful issue.

Sir:

Referring to your letter No 289032 of Febry. 23rd, I have the honor to submit the following:

At the outset I wish to state (what is already well known to the Department) that in the Indian work, the kind and quality of the workers is more important than the methods or systems they are required to carry out.

1 Education.

A. Industrial Schools:

(1) While the conception of this class of school is a good one, and good work has been done; as good results might be reached in smaller schools with less equipment. At present the great barrier to the success of this class of school seems to be in the lack of a sufficient number of pupils, mentally and physically fit for the course of instruction provided, who really wish for such training, or for any higher education.

(2) It does not seem advisable to teach trades to the young Indians, with the view to their earning a livelihood in that way. Outdoor work, such as farming and care of stock, is evidently the most suitable life for the majority.

(3) If any wish to take a higher education or special training; the way should be open for them; but let them take this in existing schools and colleges along with white students. It is desirable that race distinctions eventually disappear; co-education might hasten that end.
(4) The present system of congregating pupils in large schools at a distance from their reserves, is not a good one. While it is true that pupils make greater progress when taken to non-reserve schools away from parents, the most of them have to return to the reserves; and that at an age when they are still easily influenced by reserve life. Any scheme for the improvement of the race must include old as well as young.

The old people may to a certain extent constitute a hindrance to the work of a school located in their immediate vicinity; a school should be a great moral force in the uplift of the life of the reserve.

Also, as an object lesson in farming, gardening, housekeeping, care of the sick and in maintaining sanitary conditions about their homes the reserve school is a great benefit to the older Indians.
Day Schools:

This class of school is unsatisfactory except in the most advanced Indian communities.

Difficulties to contend with are:

(a) Indifference of parents.

(b) Nomadic habits of parents.

(c) Difficult to discipline: if necessary to punish, pupils absent themselves from school for a long period; parents sympathy usually with children in such cases.

B. Day Schools that have proved most successful have combined some of the Boarding school features:-i.e.-the children remaining at the school; in some cases for the noon meal; in others from Monday morning until Friday night.

C. On reserves where the nomadic habit has been given up, especially where a large percentage of the parents are themselves graduates of schools, the day school could be used to good advantage. However where such communities do exist, it would be well; where possible, to erect these into ordinary school districts, along with adjacent white families; under the provincial educational system.
3 Boarding Schools.

(A) For the majority of the western reserves this seems to be for the present, the most satisfactory kind of school. There are improvements that might be made in present system of Boarding Schools.

(a) Many of the schools are too large; becoming institutional rather than homelike.

(b) That a school be as homelike as possible; that there be less danger in case of disease of a contagious nature appearing in the school; that pupils get better individual attention: No school should have more than twenty pupils in attendance.

B. (1) One Principal could take charge of more than one school of this kind, where reserves are near each other.

There would be a great advantage if the Principal of the school were also Agent for the reserve or reserves.

(2) Such a Principal-Agent would be in a position to know his pupils from infancy to manhood and womanhood:

To supervise the after-leaving-school period; and would be in a greater measure than now, responsible for the ultimate success or failure of each individual.
(3) A weakness in the present system lies in the period immediately after leaving school. It is then that a boy (the restraint of the school suddenly thrown off) spends much time moving from place to place; visiting etc., but in fact rapidly drifting back to the nomadic habits of his ancestors.

(4) Instead of giving a boy his discharge at a stated age, it should be given when he has proven himself capable of carrying out satisfactorily, the purpose for which he has been educated. The discipline and restraint of the school should not be suddenly thrown off; but continued and relaxed as the conduct of the ex-pupil might warrant.

(5) A year or more before a boy is to leave the school the Principal could allot him his land and arrange that he do some work on it, from time to time, while he was still a pupil at the school. Land could be broken and prepared for seeding, a small and stable built etc., so that a boy would have a place of his own, independent of the old people; who invariably hinder the progress of an ex-pupil if he is allowed to go back and reside with them.
D.(6) All the girl pupils should be under the guardianship of the school until they are married.

(7) Domestic service among white people is a most unsatisfactory occupation for Indian girls.

E.(1) The principal part of the industrial training should be to fit the pupils for farm life.

(2) Something should be done to retain and develop the native trades such as bead-work, tanning of skins, and basket making.

General Remarks.

At the risk of seeming disloyal to my own school; I wish to say that it is my belief that it would be better to close all Indian Industrial schools; but before this is done, provision should be made for continuing the education of the pupils now in attendance and for the reserves served by these schools. For instance, the Regina school is the only Protestant school serving the Piapot, Muscowpetung and Pasqua group of reserves also the Assiniboine reserve near Sintaluta. A small boarding school would serve the first three reserves named. A school with quarters suitable for housing and boarding the children from Monday to Friday should be provided for the other. The nearest Protestant schools to these reserves are the File Hills and Round Lake Boarding schools. These have already, all the pupils the buildings will accommodate; and for reasons stated in par. A. under Boarding schools the attendance at these schools should not be increased.

Better schools should be provided for the Mistawasis and Ahtahkakoop reserves, from which many of
General Remarks (continued)

the pupils in this school are recruited.

No school should be so large that the elements of a home are in danger of being lost in institutional routine.

Where a school is located on or near a reserve, all children of school age should be compelled to attend; unless unable to do so by reason of illness or other reasonable cause.

Where there is no school on or near a reserve; it seems a real hardship to compel an Indian to send his children to a distant school. A distant school might be termed, one to which the parent could not easily drive and return home in the one day.

Indian homes should have more air space per occupant; better ventilation and the sanitary conditions generally improved. A regular inspection and also on diseases etc., illustrated lectures of a popular nature, would do much good in this line.

Provision should be made for the isolating of consumptives and all suffering with running, scrofulous sores. These might well be classed with such diseases as smallpox and the same precautions taken.

The establishing of small reserve hospitals is of utmost importance. These could undertake the care of the sick and also be a source of instruction to the people of the reserve in:

(a) Improving the sanitary condition of the homes,

(b) Informing the Indian women as to best methods of feeding and caring for infants; among whom the death rate is altogether too high,

(c) Informing women as to diet and general care of the sick.
General Remarks (concluded)

Temperance laws now in force might well be amended by forbidding the sale of intoxicants in any town located on or in the immediate neighborhood of an Indian reserve.

Indians should be required to register their marriages, either with the Agent or some other officer, and whether married by pagan or Christian form, to more strictly observe the marriage vow.

Some provision should be made for Indian divorce in exceptional cases.

MEMORANDUM

Re Indian Education.

The three Protestant denominations interested in Indian education having found themselves straitened for funds by reason of the large amounts which have to be provided owing to the rapid settlement of the new Provinces approached the Department with a view to obtaining additional appropriations for the maintenance of schools which had been in the past supported to a large extent from denominational funds. In addition to this financial interest consideration was given to the whole question of Indian education with a view to improving the educational facilities and the speedy civilisation of the Indian.

Upon receipt of a joint memorandum in the autumn of 1907 from the representatives of the three Churches, Anglican, Presbyterian and Methodist, the Department replied on the 21st. of March 1908 and endeavored to lay down certain principles upon which the question might be considered in the future. In the latter part of the same month the Department received from the representatives of the Churches (who had in the meantime formed themselves into a Committee or Advisory Board upon the subject of Indian education) agreeing in the main with the principles laid down by the Department in this communication of the 21st. of March, whereupon, on the 24th. of April following, certain proposition were made to the Protestant denominations that certain Industrial Schools should be closed; that improvements should be made in the existing type of Day Schools and better salaries paid to the teachers; and that when these matters were amicably arranged the Department would feel disposed to adopt an improved
scale of per capita grant to the remaining residential schools.

These suggestions were accepted by the Advisory Board but it was found impossible for the Department to obtain a supplementary vote for the additional expenditure contemplated. The Advisory Board, being anxious that the changes and improvements should not be indefinitely postponed, urged that wherever it was possible to close schools without detriment to the work that they should be closed and the funds so saved diverted to the purposes of each denomination, and the plan outlined in the communication of the 24th of April carried out as far as possible. In accordance with this wish the Department made certain suggestions involving the closing of three Industrial Schools, Brandon, Elkhorn and Regina and a redistribution of the funds to be thus saved. The Advisory Board accepted the suggestions with reference to Regina and Elkhorn, subject to the consideration of views to be expressed by persons interested in those localities, but suggested that the School at Brandon should be retained.

The Department has received certain representations from the Anglican Archbishop of Rupert's Land and from the Bishop of Keewatin, and the matter now stands in this position:—the Department is prepared to close Regina and Elkhorn if it is found advisable to do so and to continue Brandon under the present Methodist management with non-denominational features.

I may say that the Roman Catholics, although the matter was brought to their attention in the first place for the purpose of having their co-operation in re-adjusting the school question, have not seen their way clear to join with the Protestant denominations.

(Sd) Frank Pedley
BISHOP LEGAL ON INDIAN EDUCATION

May 13th, 1897

To the Editor of the Free Press:

Sir—I beg, with your kind permission, to call attention to certain statements made in his official report by Mr. James McKenna, and dealing with the education of Indians, especially children in industrial schools and boarding-schools.

I quote his words: "There are people who say that the best way to think about the question is to belittle the work of the missionaries and the government in the Indian question seriously, and at first sight there seems some force in this description of the civilizing influences of their efforts. But let us consider what these influences far in advance of the present stage of development may bear witness to their great benefit to the child."

These are words of common sense spoken by a man of experience. It should be high time now to stop saying that the missionaries are the failure of Indian education. After years of experience in the field, I have no hesitation in saying that the missionaries are doing an education in our industrial schools and among our Indians which is far in advance of what could have been reasonably expected.

Imagine what the result of those splendid results could have been.

It is perfect nonsense to expect that such a thing could have been accomplished in the short space of, perhaps, six years, or even ten years, in making a child a creature absolutely immune against the influence of an Indian child, that would do away with all the bad habits of the race.

If, after leaving school, some of these children fall into the hands of the mission to which they find themselves returned, they will be treated as youths of good and respectable families, and will be educated and act in an honest and upright manner, even though they be placed in the same surroundings.

Much mischief might have been avoided had the government seen fit to send these youths, having graduated in these schools, back to their own homes under special control, so that they might receive some special guidance and encouragement, and thus avoid the chances, just the reverse of which has been the case.

As I am trying again the system of day schools in the industrial schools, or residential schools, as it is purposed to call them (for the sake of calling them), it is for anyone who is even slightly familiar with the condition of our Indian reserves, at least in the west, to see how impossible it is. This system has been tried and found wanting. The reason why it is the scattered condition of the Indians that makes it impossible is the low of more than half a dozen of children to a teacher, and the distance, on account of the distance; but even worse is the fact that many of them are in the immediate vicinity of schools, yet the number of truant officers to bring the attendance to any approximate standard is nil.

No, there is only one way to get the desired and lasting effect on the Indians, and that is to send them to residential schools, if you like, young boy or girl, after leaving the industrial school, where they could have been wished for, where education has not been wasted, not a particle of it, and where the effects will show again and be lasting.

The amount of money spent (not more than $500 per child) for the betterment of these children is not worth the expenditure. It is really unnecessary that we should spend another thousand dollars spent on Indian education, when we have vast immensities of fertile lands, once the proper methods are employed, and an inexhaustible supply of wealth promptly available for such descriptions.

EMILE J. LEGAL, O.M.I.

Bishop's House, St. Albert, Alta.

There are a large number of school graduates on this reserve, and I regret to say the advancement made by them has not been anything like it should have been. They seem to have no desire to branch out, but keep dwelling in a small way. They clothe themselves and provide some food, it is true, but this is usually done by taking a small load of wood to town from time to time.

The Indians of this band are capable of doing a great deal more than they are doing, and most of the farming is done by Indians who have never been at school. Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your printed circular dated the 2nd ultimo regarding the desired attitude of all officials towards pupils of Boarding and Industrial Schools who are about receiving their discharge from such schools and to say that while I am in full sympathy with the expressed desires of the Department to continue the leading of the Indian youths into higher spheres of man and woman-hood I foresee many discouragements, if not complete failures, in trying to carry your expressed wishes to a successful issue. When we read of ex-missionaries encouraging the Indians to cling to the customs of their forefathers, such as the giving of war and other ancient dances, to appear in public in nude attire and with little on them except paint and feathers, we must confess that we fail to see wherein this either tends to civilize or christianise our pelican wards. I also read in a Calgary newspaper that the late exhibitions were honoured by a flying visit of about 50 of the International Council of Women and that these women were fortunate in arriving at the show ground just when the squaw race was starting "and down to the ring the delegates went and saw their less intellectual but perhaps more athletic and unconventionally dressed sisters doing the bareback act". These delegates did not see the moving pictures or they would, doubtless, have been more highly pleased with their western trip and known more of what is being done to please and edify the public. I saw the pictures referred to and one picture which appeared to please the public most was: a teepee in the background and an entirely naked Indian youth in the foreground and another whose only attire was a very short shirt. The chief attraction now at most exhibitions appears to be a great number of Indians and the more uncivilized they appear at these exhibitions the more they please the public and more is the honour bestowed upon the missionaries who enticed the Indians from their homes and their work to take prominent parts in such entertainments. The Blackfeet Indians took a prominent part in the parades, etc., at the late Calgary exhibition and while I do not know personally of
the aftermath of this recent tramp to the Calgary exhibition I am persuaded, however, that when the Blackfeet returned to their homes, if they have all yet returned, that they came much poorer, financially and morally, and in short, debauched, less tractable and several degrees lower in man and woman-hood than when they went. CRITICISM OF NEW SCHEME

R. V. Sinclair Opposes Archbishop's Views.

Public Interest in Education not Academic.

Indian School Question Discussed at Length.

Editor Journal—Archbishop Matheson's late statement to the Synod of Rupert's Land that in his opinion the time has arrived when the churches should be relieved of the financial burdens they have voluntarily assumed in their attempt to educate Indians, and that the Dominion should assume those burdens, directs attention to the subject.

His Grace's view might, or might not, be agreed with, if it were proper to consider the question of the schools. Doubtless however, even in that case, it might be said that the subject of much difference, denominational embarking upon all sorts of unstandardized religious education, was best left to the public to take over and to pay for an educational hotch-potch, rather than to provide schools for the denominations to keep their schools and make the public pay for them.

Public interest in Indian affairs is not academic. It goes far beyond the question of the schools. Government figures as published at present summarily show anything but a gain. It seems that the public pays some $420,000 a year to educate Indians in Separate schools, while the same amount is paid for white children, and a further large sum for officials to look after the schools and $2000 superintendence down. This staff may consist of well trained educators who believe in modern methods and practice but even so it is very doubtful indeed whether any attempt to educate Indian children apart from the children it is designed to make them resemble will be wise or successful.

It is impossible to reconcile the proper intention to convert Indians into citizens at the earliest moment possible with the justification for spending many millions of public money in the hope of achieving it with the long cherished ideals of Imperial, Canadian, and American citizenship. It is the teaching of that common sense which is begotten of experience. It is the chief weapon against the tyranny of an Indian Department.

Local control and criticism have been the keynote of success in common school education, and common schools the best means of common citizenship. It may be unfortunately true that there are localities in which discriminatively "In the best interests of the whites" there are no common schools at which Indian children can be comfortably educated without mixing with white children. But it cannot really be best for Indian children to be educated together when it can be avoided, nor to have schools under the control of a distant centre of administration. For this is to train Indian children as units of a separate population, to incite them to a spirit of competition which directly conflict with the only sound idea of assimilation, to make them feel distinctly inferior, trying to extirpate difference and to perpetuate the very things which it is our privilege and duty to try to completely put an end to, and to do this under distant direction is worse than to have local directions. It is to set back indefinitely the day when common citizenship will be attained by Indians.

It has been said in defence of this illusory founding or continuation of denominational "Indian schools" that some treaty agreements make it obligatory to maintain such schools, not missions or boarding schools, but day schools. The true sense of such agreements is that they are not binding but supposing for the moment such an obligation exists, it is to be noticed that the Indian schools of today could possibly be subject to it, and that in other cases, least of all matters where the agreements have not been considered beneficent by officials, politicians or philanthropists they have been entirely overlooked or openly swept away.

Grouping Indians together was said enough to such grouping seemed to be the only, or easiest way out of some difficulty. The difficulties appear when the necessity for grouping passes, as preventing the play of the forces of civilization. It is therefore certainly the height of folly and bad policy is reached in the development of a system of education for the Indian child as a person distinct from ordinary persons within the administration of which the aim is to make an ordinary person out of it. If that mistake could be rectified, it would be done by placing each system under the control of dominating influence in the management of various religious denominations whose views may be that separate education is best to keep the Indian "child apart from the other children," a marked character, whilst the country whose interest is certainly and merely that this should not be done, looks at the bills.

R. V. SINCLAIR.
Indian Boarding Schools Passing

Anna A. Hawley, Teacher and Nurse on James Smith Reserve Discusses Education.

The Indians are not a dying race, but a living, increasing and progressive people, in the opinion of Miss Anna A. Hawley, teacher and nurse of St. Joseph's Mission. For a little over a week she has been spending her time in the city. Miss Hawley, who has spent five years among the Indians in the district north of town, and nurse, believes that the change from boarding schools to day schools for the children, which is being made by the government, at this particular time, is a move in the right direction.

The boarding schools, like the whites' factory system, for several years of school life the children returned to the reserve to live the life of the white man or the Indian. They had no opportunity to make a living when they returned they were at sea, ignorant of the ways of the world, different from those of other people, but the parents and the children had grown fat upon the profits of the Indians' interests.

With the day school it was known there would be difficulties. One would be the difficulty of getting the Indians to attend school regularly; and the other the difficulty of raising the ideals of the Indians so that during the hours they would be subject to the influence of the school.

But in many reserves the experiment of the day school has been tried instead of sending out inexperienced teachers, fully qualified teachers are sent out; the Indians are driven to and from school during the winter months, and also during the summer months the year round.

Miss Hawley tells of this experiment on James Smith's reserve, where Miss Hawley teaches. The average attendance during the past year has been one-third higher than the average attendance last year.

In the reserve there is a church building, a neat mission hall, and a schoolhouse. The present accommodation of more than fifty children, who are attending the school, is inadequate. Next year better accommodations will be necessary.

On Sunday morning Miss Hawley spoke at a large gathering. The object being, "Life Among the Crees." In the address she pointed out that the government, of the Dominion, has during the past ten years spent more than one thousand per year. In the district north of town there are several hundred Indians living on the reserve. During the past decade, and this in spite of the fact that the Indians are passing through a transition state. They have not yet become completely changed in their mode of life. From a free life, living in peace with nature, with fresh air and fresh meat, they have gone to live on reserves, where they have taken up farming, where they have met new shocks, and where they must live on an artificial diet. It is impossible for the Indians to pass through such a change, and yet the Indians, as a race, as Miss Hawley has, cannot be dying out. They have now passed the turning point, and steadily increasing.

The James Smith Reserve is situated about thirty miles north of Kintail, which, lest anyone should forget, is situated some six hundred miles northwest of Winnipeg. The reserve is large, and surely there is enough of it, 32,000 acres, in which the Red man may live in peace and contentment as he wishes. The Indians live by hunting, trapping, gathering berries and picking berries. Some of the younger men are employed in the mines, when the spring is calling the white man to sow the seed, it is calling the Red man to sow the seed, and the Red man goes away he goes and there is no harvest for him.

Miss Hawley is known as "The Medicine Woman" and while there is some rivalry between her and the Indian Medicine Man, she does not give up, and slowly gaining ground, the Indians are slowly giving up with all the superstitions and conceptions on which they have depended for years. The Indians are in time of illness and are depending more and more on the white man's doctor. However, the Indian Medicine Man does treat a patient who recovers and then refuses to pay. The name of the old faith is restored although in some cases the payment of the doctor is very relentless. In one instance he was known to take the sick man's horse as payment. One day an Indian suddenly appeared at the mission house and asked for Miss Hawley. She related his tale of woe, repeatedly dwelt on the fact that he had never paid, and pleaded with her to help him.

Miss Hawley told many interesting incidents of life on an Indian Mission and so earnest was her plea for the Indians that when the Indians were present, at once signified their willingness to assist in the work.

Miss Hawley intends to visit Yorkton after which she will resume her duties at the mission.

Sir:

I am frequently asked why the Indian Boarding Schools conducted under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church are allowed $100.00 per pupil per annum while the Catholic Boarding Schools are only paid $75.00.

I have no official information in the matter. A rumor that there was a difference in the rates paid reached me long ago, but I did not believe there was any foundation for it. Its truth, however, has recently been forced upon me.

I have been told that because the Presbyterian Church authorities agreed to the closing of the Industrial School at Regina, the Department rewarded them by devoting the money that went to that school to the increasing of the per capita grant of their boarding schools and undertaking in addition, to erect a costly boarding school for them at File Hills.

As I represented the Department some years ago in the examination of the financial condition of the former Industrial school at Regina, I am well aware that its continuance was impossible without a considerable increase in the grant or a constant increase in the debt. I cannot therefore understand how its closing could be regarded as a reason for giving an increased grant to Presbyterian schools, while other schools are kept at the old rate.
Take the case of the former Industrial School at St. Boniface. Its situation came to be considered as undesirable for an Indian school. The Church offered to take the building and the land (which the late Archbishop Tache has transferred for a nominal consideration to the Government for school purposes) in exchange for three school buildings to be erected at the expense of the Church at Sandy Bay, Fort Alexander and Fort Frances. These three boarding schools are the best equipped of the kind under the control of the Department. In the agreement of exchange the cost was put at a less figure than the actual outlay which was found necessary to incur in order to complete and modernly equip them. The per capita grant of the St. Boniface school was simply divided among the Boarding Schools at the rate of $72.00 per capita.

Nor it seems to me that if the closing of the Regina Industrial School is the reason for the increased grant, for Presbyterian Boarding Schools, the closing of St. Boniface Industrial School affords a stronger reason for an increased grant to Catholic Boarding Schools. In the former case, the buildings are left on the hands of the Government, whereas in the latter case, three fine buildings have been transferred to the Government in exchange for the St. Boniface building, while, if I am correctly informed, a costly school building is to be erected at the public expense for an Indian Boarding School to be conducted under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church.
May I ask why, if I am correctly informed, there is this difference in the treatment of the schools of the two denominations? I ask the question because I am unable to give a satisfactory reply to enquiries made by conductors of Catholic Schools in respect to what they regard as a discrimination against them.

I may say that I regard $78.00 per capita as quite inadequate for boarding schools. My experience teaches me that all properly conducted boarding schools should be paid $100.00 per annum per capita.

St. Michael's School at Duck Lake is paid $100.00 per capita. This school however, does a higher class of work than is done by the regular boarding schools. In fact, it might fairly be classed as an Industrial. The grant of $100.00 was allowed it on that account, and, therefore in advancing rates paid boarding schools its grant should be proportionately increased.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
