The Minister laid before the delegates his views on the subject of the present position of Indian Boarding Schools, their usefulness as a factor in Indian education and the present uncertainty...
condition of their relations with the Government. He stated that while in his opinion the boarding schools situated on or near reserves were the more valued factor in educating the Indians, the relations of these schools with the Government had always been indeterminate. He found that while in some few cases the buildings had been erected by the Department, in the large majority of cases these had been erected by the Churches as missionary enterprises in the early days of the country's settlement and the Government had been called upon from time to time, as the needs of the case demanded, to improve these properties to render the schools more efficient.

His present desire was to make an arrangement with the Church authorities whereby the whole conduct and management of these schools would be covered by a contract between the Government and the Churches whereby the responsibilities of each to the other would be definitely fixed, and that the financial straits in which the churches found themselves owing to the general increased cost of living and the extraordinary demands made upon their finances on account of the expansion of evangelical work in the western country owing to its rapid settlement would in a measure be relieved by the Government.

A most interesting discussion ensued in which the Minister's proposals were carefully considered by the Church Dignitaries present, from the various points of view, denominational and otherwise, and after full consideration and some slight amendment it was unanimously decided to adopt Mr. Oliver's suggestions as meeting all reasonable demands for the purposes of these schools for several years to come.

The schools are to be classed geographically in three divisions, Eastern, Western and Northern, and again into three classes representing the ownership and general character of the buildings in which the schools are carried on. The grants for the Eastern Division are to be from $60.00 to $100.00 per capita per annum; in the Western Division from $100.00 to $125.00 and in the Northern Division they will
will be one rate, viz:- $125.00. The grants are, therefore, increased from $60.00 to $75.00 to the new scale of payment.

Before qualifying for payment under the new system the school authorities are required to sign a contract with the Government. The contract is to limit the number of pupils in residence so as to prevent overcrowding, to provide for medical examination of the children to be admitted, give the Government control over the staff and other conditions which provide for general improvement. The contract also provides for improvements in existing buildings which will bring them up to a particular standard.

Archbishop Matheson moved a vote of thanks to Mr. Oliver for the opportunity he had given them for such a free discussion of the whole subject of Indian education and the liberal treatment which had been accorded the different churches with such an open acknowledgment of their efforts to educate and uplift the aborigines in the country. Archbishop Matheson's remarks were concurred in by all and the meeting closed with a general expression of approval.
MORE GOVERNMENT AID.

INCREASED GRANTS TO INDIAN BOARDING-SCHOOLS.

School Authorities Will be Required to Sign a Contract With the Government — Hon. Frank Oliver's Proposal Meets With Approval.

(Special Dispatch to The Globe.)

OTTAWA, Nov. 3.—An important conference was held today in the office of Hon. Frank Oliver, Superintendent-General of Indian Affairs, on the subject of Indian boarding schools receiving Government aid. Mr. Oliver had called together the school authorities who have the more immediate control and direction of Indian boarding schools, and the conference, which was an invitation met with a ready response.

There were present the conference representatives of the Anglican, Roman Catholic, Methodist and Presbyterian Churches.

The question laid before the delegates was his views on the subject of the present position of Indian boarding schools, the future needs of Indian education, and the present unsatisfactory financial conditions of their relations with the Government. He stated that while, in his opinion, the boarding schools had been a great service, they had not been the more valued factor in education. The question was raised whether these schools with the Government had been a success or failure. He found that, while the schools had been built by the government, the buildings had been erected by the government, and the schools had been built by the Church. The schools had been built at the early days of the country's settlement, and the government had been asked to meet the first cost. The needs of the case demanded, to improve the efficiency of the Indian schools more efficient.

His proposal was to make an arrangement with the Church authorities whereby the whole conduct and management of these schools would be covered by a contract between the government and the Churches, with the responsibility of such a contract being placed upon the financial straits in which the Churches found themselves owing to the general increase costs. It was suggested that extraordinary demands made upon their finances should be met by the Church of evangelical work in the western countries, where the rapid settlement would, in a measure, be relieved by the Government.

The proposals were carefully considered by the Church representatives from all points of view, denominational and otherwise, and after full consideration and some slight modification, it was unanimously decided to adopt Mr. Oliver's proposal, and to make reasonable demands for the purposes of the schools for several years to come.

The schools are to be classified geographically in three divisions—eastern, central, and northern—and again into three classes, representing the ownership and general character of the institutions in which the schools are carried on. The grants for the eastern division are to be from $100 to $150; capital from $100 to $125; and the grants for the division there will be one rate—namely, $115. The grants for the central division will be $460 to $72 in the new scale of payment.

Before qualifying for payment under the new system, the school authorities must enter into a contract with the Government. The contract provides for the number of pupils in residence so as to prevent overcrowding, provide for medical examination, provide for the school building (if needed), and give the Government control over the school. The contract also provides for general improvements, and the contract also provides for improvements in educational equipment which will bring them up to a par with other schools.

The conference closed with a general expression of thanks to Mr. Oliver for the opportunity he had given for a free discussion of the question of Indian education, and for the liberal treatment extended to those interested in the different churches.
INDIAN SCHOOLS ARE RE-CLASSED

Increased Government Aid and Control.

Result of Conference With Church Bodies.

Medical Examination and no Overcrowding.

On Tuesday a conference took place in the office of the Honorable Frank Oliver, superintendent general of Indian affairs, on the subject of Indian boarding schools and increasing government aid. Mr. Oliver had requested the attendance of those who have more immediate control or supervision of Indian boarding schools throughout Canada and his invitation met with ready response, representatives of the Anglican, Roman Catholic, Methodist and Presbyterian churches being present.

After an interesting discussion an arrangement was made whereby the future the schools are to be classified geographically in three divisions, eastern, western and northern, and again into three classes representing the ownership and general character of the institutions which the schools are carried on. The grants for the eastern division are to be from $85 to $100 per capita, the amounts in the western division from $100 to $125, and in the northern division there will be one rate, viz., $125. The grants are, therefore, increased from $60 to $75 to $90 per capita payment.

Before qualifying for payment under the new system the school authorities must sign a contract with the government. The contract is to limit the number of pupils in residence, prevent overcrowding, to provide for medical examination of the children to be admitted, give the government control over the staff and other conditions which promise for general improvement. The contract also provides for improvements in existing buildings which will bring them up to a particular standard.

The circumstances which led to the conference may be briefly outlined.

When Indian education was taken up seriously in Western Canada in the eighties the policy of the Government was to establish Industrial schools, erected at the cost of the Government, to be conducted under the auspices of the several religious bodies interested, the Government contributing to the maintenance of the schools a fixed sum per head. In pursuance of what was then believed to be sound policy these schools were, generally speaking, located at points distant from the Indian reserves, and for this reason there was frequently considerable difficulty in securing a sufficient attendance of Indian pupils to earn the grant adequate for their upkeep.

To meet the educational needs of the Indian children who could not for one reason or another be provided for in the Industrial schools already mentioned, from time to time boarding schools were established on a number of reserves at the charge of the various religious bodies. It was a foundation principle in the case of the Industrial schools that the Government erected the building at Government
Government cost, while in the case of the boarding schools the church erected the buildings at the cost of the church. In recognition of the efforts towards Indian education by the erection of these boarding schools, and to substantially assist the churches in their work, a grant per head was made by the Government towards their support.

As time went on it became more and more apparent that the boarding schools were filling a want that the Industrial schools had not filled, and for this reason instead of the number of industrial schools having been increased the number of boarding schools has been increased. With this increase in the number of boarding schools the burden for their support upon the various churches has correspondingly increased; and as the buildings which were erected in the first place by the churches have required repair or enlargement the Government has, from time to time, and in many cases, been called upon to provide these enlargements, improvements and repairs. Besides, there have been occasions when the difference between the contribution of the Government and the actual cost of the school was greater than the church interested in the school felt
felt itself able to provide, and the Government was called upon to meet the deficit. This was not a desirable condition from the point of view either of the church or of the Government. If there had been a prospect of these conditions being grown out of there might not have been a need of change, but all reports tended to show that so far from the probability being that this condition would be grown out of it seemed to be grown into more and more deeply year by year. Realizing the importance of the educational work being done by the boarding schools and the serious burden that the support of these schools is upon the various churches interested in them the Government concluded and the conference agreed that it would be wise to substantially increase the grant per head to boarding schools conducted under church auspices, but in doing this it was necessary that the unbusinesslike lack of arrangement whereby the Government repaired and added to mission buildings and met deficits in mission management should cease.

The draft of the contract embodies the conditions upon which the increased grant will be paid. These conditions require that the school buildings
buildings shall be sanitary and that the school management shall be such as will conduce to the physical, moral and mental well-being of the children. Differences in the amount of the grant are made by reason of differences in conditions which bear upon the cost and up-keep. It is assumed that in the eastern division the cost of up-keep is less than in the western division, and that in the northern division the cost is still higher, and that there is no possibility of supplying the modern construction and appliances. The difference between the minimum and maximum grants in the eastern and western divisions is to give the church the benefit by an increased grant of the capital expenditure which it makes in the erection of a first class building. It is recognized that the standard of comfort and sanitation is much higher today than it was twenty years ago, and that the condition of the Indian children with them should have the benefit of the most improved sanitary conditions. Therefore the maximum grant is given where the church erects a building at its own cost that will meet the most modern conditions. MEMORANDUM

For the purpose of deciding upon a proper geographical division of the Boarding Schools to receive the maximum and minimum of the new scale of payment, i.e., $80.00 and $100.00, and $125.00, they shall be divided into Eastern, Northern and Western divisions. The Eastern division ($80.00 and $100.00) to include all the schools in Ontario except Albany, Moose Factory, Fort Frances, Rat Portage and Cecilia Jeffrey. The Northern division ($125.00) to include the following schools which are located 200 miles or more from a railway, i.e., Albany, Moose Factory, Lac la Plonge, Lac la Ronge, Whitefish Lake, Lesser Slave Lake, Sturgeon Lake, Ft. Chipewyan, Lake Wabaseew, N.C., Lake Wabaseew, C.of R., Ft Resolution, Ft. Vermilion, Hay River, and Fort Providence. The Western division ($100.00 and $125.00) to include all the other boarding schools in Manitoba, North West Territories, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia and including the three Ontario boarding schools mentioned above, i.e., Fort Frances, Rat Portage and Cecilia Jeffrey.

The number of children to be accommodated in each school to be limited by the contract. The limit is to be fixed by consideration of air space and ventilating systems, and floor space in class rooms. In the dormitories the air space must be at least 500 cubic feet for each child. In the class rooms the limit is to be fixed by the floor space for seats and the air space for pupils, the latter to be not less than 250 cubic feet for each pupil, and the former sixteen square feet for each pupil.

Ottawa, November 23rd., 1910.

Sir,

I have to enclose herewith memorandum of information relating to Indian Boarding Schools with a classification of such schools on increased scale of per capita grant, and copy of a contract which must be entered into with the Government for the conduct of such schools. As you will observe by a perusal of these papers the payment of an increased per capita grant is contingent upon the condition of the buildings in which the schools are operated. I have, therefore, to request that you will, with as little delay as possible, inspect the buildings of the Boarding Schools within your district and report whether they conform to the specifications laid down. The specifications of school buildings in Class "A" are given with sufficient definiteness in the eight clauses in the memorandum. School buildings owned by the Government should, of course, conform to these specifications. Buildings owned by the Churches which will entitle the management to a grant of $100 should be sanitary, in a good state of repair, and conform to clauses 5, 6 and 8 of the specifications, that is—

5. Hospital accommodation for the isolation of pupils "ill with infectious disease or tuberculosis."

6. Modern system of ventilation in dormitories and "class rooms and sufficient air space in dormitories and class rooms for the number of pupils accommodated."

8. Sufficient area of land for farms and gardens and "practical industrial work."

You will readily understand what is required for Hospital accommodation. Two or three rooms in the main building or in a separate building should be available for this service, and they
should be so situated as to provide isolation for special cases of illness. They should have if possible a southern exposure and should be well lighted and properly ventilated.

The dormitories and class rooms should be measured to ascertain the air and floor space for pupils. You will see by the memorandum that at least 500 cubic feet for each child should be available in the dormitories and 350 cubic feet for each pupil in the class rooms.

A modern system of ventilation is called for, that is, the foul air must be taken from the floor of the rooms through a heated chimney stack or in some other effective way and arrangements must be made for the entrance of fresh air.

The provision of sufficient areas for farms and gardens only applies where agricultural work can be conducted; on reserves where the Indians can support themselves by farming, both farming and gardening should be taught at the school.

After carefully considering the needs of each building you should report what changes it will be necessary for the Churches interested, or the Department, to carry out in order to improve the buildings, make them uniform and equal to the standard specifications.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The circumstances which led to the conference may be briefly outlined.

When Indian education was taken up seriously in Western Canada in the eighties the policy of the Government was to establish Industrial Schools, erected at the cost of the Government, to be conducted under the auspices of the several religious bodies interested; the Government contributing to the maintenance of the schools a fixed sum per head. In pursuance of what was then believed to be sound policy these schools were generally speaking, located at points distant from reserves and...
and for this reason there was frequently considerable difficulty in securing a sufficient attendance of Indian pupils to earn the grant adequate for their upkeep.

To meet the educational needs of the Indian children who could not for one reason or another be provided for in the Industrial schools already mentioned, from time to time boarding schools were established on a number of reserves at the charge of the various religious bodies. It was a foundation principle in the case of the Industrial schools that the Government erected the buildings at Government cost, while in the case of the boarding schools the Church erected the buildings at the cost of the Church. In recognition of the efforts towards Indian education by the erection of these boarding schools, and to substantially assist the Churches in their work, a grant per head was made by the Government towards their support.

As time went on it became more and more apparent that the Boarding schools were filling a want that the Industrial schools had not filled, and for this reason instead of the number of Industrial schools having been increased the number of boarding schools has been increased. With this increase in the number of boarding schools the burden of their support upon the various Churches has correspondingly increased, and as the buildings which were erected in the first place by the Churches have required repair or enlargement the Government has from time to time, and in many cases, been called upon to provide these enlargements, improvements and repairs. Besides, there have been occasions when the difference between the contribution of the Government and the actual cost of maintaining the school was greater than the Church interested in the school felt itself able to provide, and the Government was called upon to meet the deficit.

This was not a desirable condition from the point of view either of the Church or of the Government. If there had been a prospect of these conditions being improved there might not have been need of change, but all reports tended to show that far from the probability that this condition would improve it was
was likely to become aggravated year by year. Realizing the importance of the educational work being done by the boarding schools and the serious burden that the support of these schools is upon the various Churches interested in them the Government concluded and the conference agreed that it would be wise to substantially increase the grant per head to boarding schools conducted under Church auspices, but in doing this it was necessary that the unbusinesslike lack of arrangement whereby the Government repaired and added to mission buildings and met deficiencies in mission management should cease.

The draft of the contract embodies the conditions upon which the increased grant will be paid. These conditions require that the school buildings shall be sanitary and that the school management shall be such as will conduce to the physical, moral and mental well-being of the children. Differences in the amount of the grant to different schools are caused by reason of differences in conditions which bear upon the cost and upkeep. It is assumed that in the Eastern division the cost of upkeep is less than in the Western division, and that in the Northern division, the cost is still higher, and that there is no practical possibility of supplying modern construction and appliances in the Northern Division. The difference between the minimum and maximum grants in Eastern and Western divisions is made to give the Church the benefit by an increased grant of the capital expenditure which it makes in the erection of a first class building. It is recognized that the standard of comfort and sanitation is much higher today than it was twenty years ago, and that the condition of the Indian children is such that they should have the benefit of the best sanitary improvements. Therefore the maximum grant is given where the Church erects a building at its own cost that will meet specified modern conditions. The minimum grant is given where the buildings erected by the Church do not provide modern improvements. In case the Government erects a building it is intended that it shall conform in all respects to modern ideas, but in that case the capital charge having been borne by the Government the
the Church can only receive the minimum grant.

The Government is willing to a moderate amount from year to year in establishing new and modern buildings, but it does not undertake to furnish modern buildings in all cases where they are required within a short space of time. The Churches interested have the option of erecting a first class building and thereby securing a maximum grant, or of erecting or continuing a second class building and receiving the minimum grant, or as a third choice, awaiting the time when it will be possible for the Government to erect the building, in which case they will also receive the minimum grant.

In the case of buildings now in existence and the property of any Church it is to be understood that they must be made to conform to the minimum requirement as set out in the accompanying memorandum, and in accordance with the terms of the draft contract at the cost of the Church or they cannot receive any grant. In case of buildings owned by the Government improvements will not be paid for unless they are made by the Government; that is unless the contract is signed and lived up to no grant will be paid.

For the present after signing the contract, grants will be paid to schools according to the schedule herewith beginning on the 1st. of April, 1911, until it has been shown that these schools are entitled by reason of improvements to be placed in a different class. If after due notice any school does not conform to the terms of the contract and of the memorandum of classification it will not be entitled to receive any grant.

In case it is desired to establish new schools it is to be thoroughly understood by all concerned that unless the Department is consulted in regard to the proposed establishment of any school and until a decision favourable to such establishment has been given, the Church establishing such a school has no claim under the arrangement made. The funds available to meet the obligations of the Government under the arrangement are
provided by Parliament from year to year, and provision cannot be made for the support of any school until the amount necessary has been voted by Parliament.

As it is contemplated under the arrangements that the Government shall pay a much larger proportion of the total cost of Indian education than before it is thereby compelled to assume a proportionately larger measure of responsibility as to the conduct of those schools, especially in the matter of the accommodation which they give and the bearing which their conditions have upon the health of the pupils.

The Inspectors of the Department are being instructed to immediately examine the school buildings in their districts with a view to ascertain whether the classification of the schools shown in the schedule is correct. When their report shows that the school buildings entitle the management to payment of the new grant a form of contract will be forwarded for signature. When the Inspector finds that certain improvements have to be made the management will be notified and upon the completion of the improvements and after they are approved by the Inspector, a contract will be forwarded for signature.

Each Contract is to be signed by the Bishop of the Diocese in which the school is situated or when the Church has not Episcopal organization, by the officer empowered by the Church to sign the contract.

It is hoped that the arrangement arrived at amicably and unanimously will result in improved relations between the Department and the religious bodies interested in Indian education, and, as well, will result in benefit to the physical condition and the intellectual and industrial advancement of the Indian children.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

In connection with the re-organization of schools, I beg to bring the following matter to the attention of the Department.

I notice in Clause 15 of the Contract, it is expressly stated that there is to be one month's holidays taken between the first of July and the first of October, unless some other course is expressly sanctioned by the Department. I beg to point out that at the Industrial school, the Qu'Appelle File Hills Boarding school and in fact, almost all the schools in this district, it has been the custom to let all the children go home for ten days or two weeks at Christmas time. If this practice is to be discontinued, I think Principals should be specially notified, as the parents should be informed of the Department's ruling on the matter.

If, on the other hand, it is your intention to allow the practice to be continued, I think it would be wise to have these additional holidays stipulated in the contract. I would point out that it would have a bad effect to allow one school to let the children

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
children go home at Christmas, and to insist on others keeping them at school. Personally I think the children should be allowed to go home at this time, and it will be a great disappointment to the parents if this permission is not granted.

There is another very important matter upon which I should like your ruling. In the past there have been cases where children have been taken into Boarding and Industrial schools, and kept there for weeks and some times for months, before being brought before the Doctor for Medical examination. The reason for this is that sometimes the children are unhealthy, and it is felt they would not pass the examination at the time, or the children are under school age. It seems to me, and I know this is the Department's desire also, that none but perfectly healthy children should be admitted to schools, but I am sorry to say this intention is not always carried out, and as a result the supposedly healthy children, already in school, are exposed to disease. There is a tendency on the part of some Principals to take children into school, no matter how unhealthy, in the hope that good food and warm clothing will effect a cure, and I am afraid these Principals to not also realize the danger to which they are exposing the children already admitted to the institution, when they allow these new comers to mingle.
mingle and sleep with them. For as you know, Indian children are very susceptible to Tuberculosis. I think the Department should issue strict instructions to all Principals that they are not to take children into schools for a longer period than two days before having them examined by a Doctor.

I think it would be a good idea if doctors were specially instructed that they must be most particular in the examination of children applying for admission to schools, and on no account to admit those with tubercular tendencies. I am perfectly aware that doctors are supposed to know all this, but sometimes certain influences are brought to bear on them, and they are perhaps more lenient than they otherwise would be, and I think if they were specially warned of the Department's desire on this point, there would be fewer unhealthy children admitted. I think also it would be an excellent idea if doctors were called upon to make a personal examination of all pupils in the schools under their charge at least once a quarter, for as I said before Indians are very susceptible to pulmonary troubles, and cannot be too closely watched, and the effect of letting two or three cases get into advanced stages would be very serious. Indian children are not like Whites and in a school of some two hundred and fifty pupils
pupils, it is necessary to be on the watch all the time. We have paid Medical Officers and I think we should expect efficient service, and I am sure if they knew what was expected of them by the Department they would gladly do it.

I think that in order to get good results and in the interests of discipline, the Department should have more control of the Staff, especially Principals of schools. I do not think it right for the Principal to go away from the school for any length of time without first getting permission from the Department, and such permission should come through the Agent. Of course I do not mean that Principals should not go out recruiting when they see fit, but I refer to cases where they go away to attend to matters that have nothing whatever to do with their schools. It was formerly the practice for Principals, when leaving for a holiday to first obtain the permission of the Department, but of late this practice has been discontinued. During the last few years I think there has been far too much time spent by Principals away from their schools.

INCREASED GRANT TO INDIAN SCHOOLS

System of Giving Assistance to Church Schools More Businesslike

An agreement regarding the maintenance of Indian boarding schools has been unanimously arrived at between the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa and the four churches engaged in educational work among the Indians of Canada.

According to the estimates submitted under the new arrangement the government appropriates $25,000 towards the maintenance of the boarding schools conducted under the auspices of the Methodist, Presbyterian, Anglican, and Roman Catholic churches in Canada, including the provinces of Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta, and British Columbia.

"Realising the importance of the educational work being done by the churches in connection with the missions, and the fact that the support of these schools is upon the various churches," reads the statement.

The government concluded, and the conference agreed, that it would be wise to substantially increase the grant per head to boarding schools conducted under church auspices, but not doing so would result in the undesirable lack of arrangement whereby the government repaired and added to dilapidated buildings and desirable schools should cease."

The draft of the contract embodies the conditions upon which the increased grant will be paid. These conditions are that the school buildings shall be sanitary and that the school management shall be such as will contribute to the welfare and well-being of the children. It is recognised that the standard of education is much higher today than it was twenty years ago, and that the children attending the schools should have the benefit of the best sanitary improvements. Therefore, the church undertakes to erect a building at its own cost that will meet specific requirements.

The increased grant is given where the buildings erected by the church do not meet the new requirements. It means the government erects a building it is intended that it shall be used for the purpose to which it is put; but in that case the capital charge having been borne by the government, the church will receive the minimum grant.

The purpose of deciding upon a proper ecological division of the boarding schools to receive the maximum and minimum of the new scale of pay.

By the terms of the contract the churches undertake: "To provide at the said school premises and thereon facilities to give the pupils religious instruction at proper times; to instruct them in the duties of the farm and care of stock, or such other industries as are suitable to their local requirements; to instruct the female pupils in cooking, laundry work, needlework, sewing, knitting, etc., and any other work where such dairy work can be carried on; to teach all the pupils in reading, writing, arithmetic, and other education; to teach calisthenics, physical drill and fire drill; to teach the effects of alcohol and tobacco, the advantages of the healthy system, and how to live in a healthy manner; to instruct the pupils in the duties and privileges of British citizenship, especially the principles of the government of Canada, and to train them in such knowledge of the laws of Canada as will inspire them with respect and affection for our country and its laws."

By the application, the Roman Catholic church will receive $163,960, the Anglican church $148,760, the Presbyterian church $54,290, and the Methodist $23,560.

(The Indian Department's appropriation for Indian schools this year will be stated above, or $25,000. This is an increase of $100,000, the greater portion of which is the result of the new arrangement.)

In the Eastern Division the grant to Class A schools was formerly $75 and $80 per pupil. Now it is $100 per capita. In Class B schools the grant was formerly $60 and $70 per capita.

In the Western Division Class A schools, which formerly drew $60 and $70 per capita under the new arrangement, Class B which also formerly drew $75 and $100 per capita, now draw $100 and $110 per capita. Now the grant is $100 per capita.

In the Northern Division the new arrangement provides a grant of $75 per capita, which was the old rate, or $100 per capita.

The grants which it is stated each church will receive are really estimates as the final allotment will secure his share according to the number of pupils in attendance and the manner in which the conditions are carried out.—(See Times.)

AGREEMENT IN REGARD TO THE MANAGEMENT OF INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOLS AND CORRESPONDENCE RELATING THERETO

Extract from letter, dated Ottawa, November 25, 1910, sent to the representatives of the several religious bodies in Canada interested in Indian education.

Sir,—Herewith I beg to inclose a memorandum of information relating to Indian boarding schools, and draft of contract which it is proposed that the authorities responsible for the maintenance and conduct of Indian boarding schools shall become a party to, and be entitled such schools to government aid.

The memorandum and draft contract in question are the result of a conference held in Ottawa on November 8.

The circumstances which led to the conference may be briefly outlined.

When Indian education was taken up seriously in western Canada in the eighties, the policy of the government was to establish industrial schools, erected at the cost of the government, to be conducted under the auspices of the several religious bodies interested; the government contributing to the maintenance of each school a fixed sum per head. In pursuance of what was then believed to be sound policy, these schools were, generally speaking, located far distant from Indian reserves, and for this reason there was frequently considerable difficulty in securing a sufficient attendance of Indians who could earn the grant adequate for their upkeep.

To meet the educational needs of the Indian children who could not for one reason or another be provided for in the industrial schools already mentioned, from time to time boarding schools were established on a number of reserves at the charge of the various religious bodies. It was a foundation principle in the case of the industrial schools that the government erected the buildings at government cost, while in the case of the boarding schools the church erected the buildings at its own cost, and the church. In recognition of the efforts towards Indian education by the erection of these boarding schools, and to substantially assist the churches in their work, a grant per head was made by the government towards their support.

As time went on, it became more and more apparent that the boarding schools were facing a want that the industrial schools had not filled, and for this reason instead of the number of industrial schools having been increased, the number of boarding schools has been increased. With this increase in the number of boarding schools, the burden of their support upon the various churches has correspondingly increased, and the buildings which were erected in the first place by the churches have required repair or enlargement the government has from time to time, and in many cases, been called upon to provide these enlargements, improvements and repairs. Besides, there have been occasions when the difference between the contribution of the government and the actual cost of maintaining the school was greater than the church interested in the school felt itself able to provide, and the government was called upon to meet the deficit.

This was not a desirable condition from the point of view either of the church or of the government. If there had been prospect of these conditions being improved, there might not have been need of change, but all reports tended to show that, far from the probability that this condition would improve, it was likely to become aggravated year by year. Realizing the importance of the educational work being done by

SCHOOL BUILDINGS, CLASS "A."

The buildings owned by the church, which would entitle the school to a per capita grant of $800 in the Eastern division and $850 in the Western division should conform to the following general specifications:

1. Substantial building, either of brick, stone, cement or wood, in good state of repair.

4. A proper system of sanitary water-closets, drainage and disposal of sewage.

5. Hospital accommodation for the isolation of pupils ill with infectious disease or tuberculosis.

As it is contemplated under the arrangement that the government shall pay a number of representatives a larger amount of responsibility as to the conduct of these schools, especially in the matter of the accommodation which they give it is hoped that the arrangements have been made in a manner which will result in improved relations between the department and the religious bodies interested in Indian education, and will result in an improvement in the physical condition and the intellectual and industrial attainments of the pupils.

In the matter of Schools on the Indian Reserve,

I beg to submit my opinion as follows:

"I think the sooner the School system on the Western Reserves is systemized on the plan of the Provincial Schools among the whites, the better it will be for the Department and for the Indians. I think that those denominational Schools on the Reserves are more of a curse to the Department and the Indians than a benefit, and that the Department should take upon itself the whole responsibility of the education of our Indians.

In order to do that it will be necessary to conform to the Provincial methods forming Day Schools wherever there are sufficient number of scholars and running them exactly on the same principle as they are run outside the borders of the Indian Reservations. I find the desire among the Indians is for the same treatment with regard to education as the whites receive. I realize before this can be done that it will be necessary to make a specific Treaty or agreement with the Indians of the various Reservations for compulsory attendance of the children at the School, and I believe that this can be done quite easily; in fact believe that in six months I can have every Reservation agree to terms of that kind. These Boarding Schools while they superficially educate our Indians do not teach them self reliance in any way. The Indian youth
is taken there and is cared for for a term of years like children in a nursery and are practically helpless in a business way when they leave School to take up the battle of life. For that reason I believe our Schools are not doing the service that we should expect from the expenditure. Were the boys and girls taken and apprenticed to trades when they leave the School till such a time as they could get self reliance and get the knowledge of the value of money and their value as a factor in obtaining money, it would be a move in the proper direction. The expenditure with regard to those denominational Boarding Schools is very much greater than is necessary. Take for instance the Old Sun School at Blackfoot run by the English Church, an expenditure is incurred by the Government of what will be at least $50,000.00 under a guarantee from the Church that a certain number of pupils will attend. After the School has been opened several months with a staff of five or six, there are only some eight or ten pupils enrolled with an attendance when I was there of seven. This is absolutely ridiculous and more so when one realizes that other churches will ask for the same consideration as the English Church on the same Reserve. The policy should be changed and as I have already said the whole control of the School system on the Indian Reservation should be centred in the Indian Department and its Officials. I realize the desire of the various Churches to do what they think is a good work, but I think that expenditures such as I have instanced are a heinous waste of public money. The same policy in my mind applies to Hospitals. When the Government has to practically assume the cost, it should also take the responsibility and keep the Schools and hospitals entirely in its own hands. I had an interview with the Indians at Morley, Wood Mountain, Kamsack, Muscowpetung, Pasquah, Piapot's, and other Reserves, and they brought to my attention in all cases their desire to be put on the same plane as the whites outside of the Reserve.
in the matter of education. After the children go through a Day School Course up to the age of fourteen or sixteen if the churches desire then to give them a higher education that is a matter for the consideration of the churches.

Honorable Sir:

Referring to the memorial addressed to you on
the 24th ultimo, resulting from the consideration by the Bishops
at Regina of the contract for the conduct and management and
maintenance of Indian Boarding Schools, the undersigned finds
that the following was omitted therefrom:

Clause 2 (a) provides "That no child shall be admitt-
ed to the school who is under seven years of age."

Regulations respecting the education of Indian
children were made by Order in Council of the 10th November,
1894, and, in amending those Regulations by Order in Council of
the 6th August, 1908, the age of admission of children to school
was left at seven years.

There is nothing to show that any Order in Council has
since been made changing the age; and, if none were made fixing
the age at seven years, then, it is submitted, the parties to the
contract have no power to go beyond the Regulations established
by Order in Council and fix the age of admission at seven years.

Such a change is undesirable. The Indians have become
used to the requirement that the education of their children
should begin at six years of age, and it is of the utmost import-
ance that there should be continuity in our educational policy.
The change will tend to make the Indians sceptical of the
wisdom of the department; for they will reason that, if six years
Of age was found to be too young in November, 1910, in another year or so seven years may be found to be too young, and that gradually the view of the authorities of the department as to education may come into accord with their own.

The undersigned cannot conceive that any experience gained since August, 1908, has led to the change. The undersigned are not aware that any educational authority of wide repute has recently expressed an opinion that would justify the change. The general tendency is not to advance the years of age at which schooling should begin. And what may be urged in favor of the early schooling of white children has ten-fold force in the case of Indian children, for they must "be caught young" to be saved from what is on the whole the degenerating influences of their home environment.

The change in the age is a serious drawback to the schools, whose managers have, in accordance with the policy in vogue up to the time of the contract, arranged for the admission of, and now have in the schools, children under seven years of age, for whom, under the contract, payment will be refused.

The undersigned would, therefore, respectfully ask that Clause 2 (a) be amended by substituting "six" for "seven".

2. It is essential to the success of the contract system of Indian schools that the Department should pursue, at least, a policy which will not run counter to them. Recent happenings, however, give the impression that, instead of a supporting policy, the Department has entered upon and is pressing a policy which is bound, in the measure of its extension, to make against the success of the contract schools.

Under your immediate predecessor in office a very
marked departure was made in Canada's Indian educational policy. Up to then day schools had not been regarded as sufficient, or, indeed, wholly efficient, agencies of Indian education. It was the proved inadequacy of the day school system that led the Government, under Sir John Macdonald, to provide for the establishment and maintenance of Indian residential schools. As early as 1880 that great statesman wrote:

"The greatest obstacle to the successful education of Indian children at day schools consists in the irregularity of their attendance, caused in part by the neglect of their parents to oblige them to attend, and by the frequent absence of many families from the reserves while fishing, hunting and berry picking."

And anyone with more than a perfunctory knowledge of Indian conditions, as they generally obtain today in Western Canada, is aware that the hope of the permanent advancement of the aborigines lies in the education of the children in residential schools, where the ordinary work of day schools can be supplemented by domestic, manual, agricultural, and such like training, and the lack of proper home environment supplied by an atmosphere favorable to moral culture and character building.

In his report of the 1st January, 1889, the Hon. Edgar Dewdney, then Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and a man who had long, practical experience as Indian commissioner in the west, wrote:

"The superiority of the boarding over that of the day school system as a means for the enlightenment and elevation, both morally and intellectually, of Indian youth, is, I think, unquestionable. The extension of the same to several of the..."
reserves should, in my opinion, be regarded with satisfaction by all who really take an interest in the advancement of the Indian race".

In his report of the 13th January, 1891, the same gentleman wrote:

"It would be highly desirable, if it were practicable, to obtain entire possession of all Indian children after they attain to the age of seven or eight years, and keep them at schools of the industrial type until they had a thorough course of instruction, not only in the ordinary subjects taught at public schools, but in some useful and profitable trade, or in agriculture, as the aptitude of the pupil might indicate he was best fitted for. Were such a course adopted the solution of that problem, designated the Indian question, would probably be effected sooner than it is likely to be under the present system"...........................................

"The system of absorption of Indian children by boarding and industrial training schools should be widely extended, and efforts to make the residence therein of Indian children of the proper age to be admitted the rule, and not, as it is at present, the exception, should be unremitting. Apart from other, and obviously more important, advantages of which an extended policy of the kind, if it were systematically pursued, would doubtless be the result, it would certainly be the most economical in the end, as the Indian children trained at such institutions would acquire practical knowledge which would fit them to become useful members of society".

In his report of the 31st December, 1894, as Deputy
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Mr. Hayter Reed wrote:

"The extension of educational work is being chiefly carried out in the direction of industrial and semi-industrial institutions, in which the children not only get the positive advantages of instruction superior to what could be given them on the reserves, but are removed from the retarding influences of contact with them".

Viewed in the light of conditions, the results produced by residential schools have been gratifying, no such results could have been produced by day schools. And it may in fairness be said that, if the unremitting efforts recommended by Mr. Dewdney had been persisted in, the results would have been still more gratifying. But it is a regrettable fact that very many officials of the department make no real effort to secure the attendance of Indian children at institutions maintained out of the public revenues for the advancement of the Indians. With the active co-operation of Indian Agents and the members of agency staffs the sphere of usefulness of residential schools could be easily extended.

Not only has such co-operation in recent years been sadly lacking, but a policy has been inaugurated of establishing day schools that seem designed to make more difficult the securing of pupils for the residential schools. It is an inexplicable policy that with one hand builds up, at considerable public expense, a system, well considered, matured, and of proved efficiency, and with the other hand sets to work, also at the public cost, to elaborate and put in extensive operation a discredited scheme of Indian education, which, if successful in drawing pupils, must, in the measure of its success, be destructive..."
of a system created at great expense and well tried.

To a considerable extent the Indians, particularly of the west, are still nomadic. The number that has regularly settled down to farm life is still relatively small. Many who farm to some extent still move about at seasons. It is mainly the graduates of residential schools who have really settled down as tillers of the soil, and too many of these yet seek subsistence otherwise. And very many who have taken, in greater or less degree, to the cultivation of land are yet without such homes as furnish the environment essential to completing the educational work that can be done in day schools.

In the summer, tepee life is common amongst the great majority of the Indians of the West. In the winter, they are, with rare exceptions, housed in ill ventilated shacks, composed most generally of an undivided ground floor and a loft. The sleeping arrangements are of the crudest, and the ground floor is often used as a sleeping place by numerous dogs, as well as by the men, women and children. The air is foul, the place dirty. Its circumstances make against wholesome cleanliness of body, and are not favorable to mental or moral development. How can improvement be looked for in the race if the children, when out of school, are subjected to such degenerating environment?

It was just to save the children from it, and to supply, with the ordinary school training, a physically healthy and morally wholesome environment that the residential schools were established and are maintained at much expense by the Government of Canada.

It seems strange that synchronously with an extra effort to strengthen and develop the boarding schools, the Department should have taken measures to extend the day school system into the very territories which the boarding schools depend upon.
as feeders, and at the same time enter upon a costly experiment to render the day schools more effective competitors of the boarding schools. It seems to make of the Department's educational policy a process of building up and tearing down.

In his report, dated 1st June, 1910, the Superintendent of Indian Education states:

"In many places these (day) schools are quite sufficient to meet the educational needs of the Indians".

But a little farther on he has to acknowledge "the severe deterrent of poverty is often present; some children have no proper clothing to wear during the winter, and the provision of any food for a luncheon at the noon hour is neglected of sheer necessity".

In his last report he repeats the statement as to the sufficiency of these schools, and then goes on to say:

"Aid has to be given to poor children in the supply of footgear and clothing, and the plan of furnishing a warm mid-day meal has been also continued with gratifying results. In several districts the transportation of the children to and from school has assisted in maintaining a regular attendance".

But Mr. Inspector Jackson, in his report of the 31st March, 1911, on Okanase Day School, states:

"Really no progress is seen since last year, owing to irregular attendance. The average attendance for the quarter ended March 31st, 1910, was three. The average attendance for the quarter ending June 30th will be seven, and this increase, the teacher reports is due to the warm mid-day meal .......... With the exception of one pupil, all are in the ABC class".

In reporting on Upper Fair-ford Day school, Mr.
Jackson states:

"At this inspection there were eight present.......

I can see a reason for the irregular attendance. The roads are so bad it is almost impossible for the smaller children to get through and they have not the clothing and footwear for the bad roads and severe weather..."

As to the Roseau River Day School, which is classed "undenominational", he reports:

"Miss Godon appears capable of imparting knowledge if the pupils could be furnished her. She says it is impossible to get the children to attend regularly, on account of their parents' moving away on their hunting trips and taking their children with them. When they do come back on the reserve, there is always the difficulty of getting the children started back to school again, lack of clothes, &c., being the excuse......................

There is always a mid-day meal, and, when the parents go away, the children between six and twelve are kept by the teacher." Mr. Jackson thinks that "this is one of the places where a little boarding school might be established".

Of the Oak River Day School Mr. Jackson writes:

Mr. McGraw was the last teacher here, and he tells me that the Indians would not, or could not, send their children to school, by could not, I mean lack of clothes and footwear. This is one of the points at which a small boarding school would do well".

Rev. John Semmens, on his tour of inspection, found ten children at Brokenhead River Day School, and remarks:

"During portions of the year there was a lack of wood for carrying on school work, and some irregularity resulted".

Of the South St. Peter's Day School he states:
"Number of children enrolled 35, but the average attendance for three months was only 7.1. This was very unsatisfactory."

But he found only five at the North St. Peter's Day School.

Mr. Inspector Graham does not give specific information as to actual attendance at time of inspection and average attendance. He gives prominence to the new features that are to make day schools supply the place of boarding schools. To the Moose Mountain Day School an addition has been made, containing a kitchen and pantry. There is also a garden. But provision has had to be made for boarding some of the children, for he says: "Some seven or eight children, whose homes are at a distance, live in a log house near the school and are looked after and fed by an Indian man and his wife".

That is the newest improvement on residential schools for Indians as conceived by Sir John Macdonald and the practical men whose opinions have been quoted earlier in this communication. For the ordinary mortal it is difficult to conceive how children, seven or eight of them, can be better cared for in a log house by an Indian man and his wife than they would be at a regular boarding school.

Mr. Graham tells us that at the Assiniboine Day School "the attendance was at one time as high as twenty-four, but during the severe weather it has fallen off considerably", but this time he "found twelve children in attendance", and was "greatly pleased to note the progress that has been made during the short time the school has been opened".

Mr. Inspector Chisholm reports:
"On Mistawasis reserve a comfortable teacher's dwelling has been provided, with pupils' dining-room attached; and by conveying the children from the more distant parts to and from school a very fair attendance has been maintained."

He gives no details as to attendance, so it is impossible to ascertain exactly what is meant by "a very fair attendance."

He goes on: "The school on the wig river reserve is a suitable building and properly equipped; and at intervals very satisfactory work has been done. However,....................it has not been found possible to secure a full or uniform attendance. The value of the work has been very much impaired in consequence."

"The average attendance at the school at Ahatakakoo's reserve is less than one-third of the school population."

On the wahapton reserve the farmer, Inspector Chisholm tells us, acts also as teacher, but that he has "little capacity for school work, and the attendance at best is poor." But we are assured that there has been "latterly a slight improvement... through the assistance of the farmers wife "in preparing the noon meal for the children (there are but eight of them all told) and in training them in sewing and knitting."

It is upon such "slight improvements" that the Superintendent of Indian Education erects the opinion paraded in his public report as to the sufficiency of day schools for Indians; and it is from such evidence that he draws his conclusion as to the "practical beneficial result" that have followed from the taking up of "instruction in plain sewing, knitting, and mending."

Mr. Inspector Markle reports that the average attendance at Godfish Lake School for the year 1910 was 5.2; that "there were no children present when" he visited Saddle Lake Day school on
February 17th last, that the Whitefish Day school "has not been in operation during the past years"; that he has heard that Old Sun's Day school on the Blackfoot reserve is "a failure", and he adds this striking remark, which apparently has escaped the eye of the Superintendent of Education,—"it is not convenient for the children to attend any school other than a residential one".

The reports from which the foregoing quotations have been made appear as appendices to the recently published Report of the Superintendent of Indian Education, in which Mr. Scott speaks favorably from the work of day schools.

It has in the last few years become sadly and increasingly apparent that Indian policy has not always been shaped by teachings of experience.

In March 1911, His Grace the Archbishop of Saint Boniface was compelled by a sense of duty to submit to your predecessor a protest against the then proposed erection of an undenominational day school on the File Hills reserve. Despite that protest, a building under the guise of an hospital, has been erected by the Department of Indian Affairs. It contains two small rooms, 12 x 12, which are designated hospital wards; but the Superintendent of Education in his report calls it "a day school". Not far away from where this day school, which may even now be about to start operation, stands, the Dominion Government recently completed and opened a large boarding school, conducted Presbyterian auspices, in the place of the Regina School which was closed some time ago. Within some twenty miles is the large St'Appelle School, rebuilt at the public expense.
and in need of recruiting ground to ensure its effective continuance, and thereby a return in results for the public expenditure.

Surely it is rather strange, for the Department to spend public money in building that elaborate day school between these two residential schools, and in specially equipping it with kitchen, dining-room, sick-rooms, teacher's and nurse's quarters so that it may more effectively interfere with the success of the two residential schools.

It cannot be denied that it is deliberately intended to interfere with the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, for a prohibition against the recruiting for pupils within the territory it is planned to serve was formally issued by the Department, and was withdrawn at the emphatic protest of the said Archbishop.

And then as to denominational control of that and other day schools under the new policy: It has been expressly stated by the Department that the day school at File Hills was to be a secular school.

It is observed that the Superintendent of Indian Education gives, in only a comparatively few instances, the denominational auspices under which day schools are conducted. Inspectors Graham and Chisholm do not give the denominational auspices of any of the day schools mentioned in their reports. It certainly looks as if a concerted effort has been made to secularize our Indian day schools. But the law provides that Indian day schools are to be denominational. Have certain officials Department decided to evoke another strike creating school question?

On behalf of himself and his venerable colleagues who signed the memorial, first referred to, respecting Indian boarding schools,
the undersigned would respectfully ask your consideration of what
is set forth herein, believing that you will readily see the neces-
sity, in the public interest, as well as in the interest of the In-
dian wards of the Government, of corrective action being taken in
respect to the Indian educational policy that has come into sway.

Accept, Honorable and Dear Sir, the assurance of
our regard and best wishes, and believe us,
