Honorable Sir:

The undersigned, at a meeting held on the occasion of the induction into his see of the recently appointed bishop of Regina, have had under consideration the contract for the conduct and management and maintenance of Indian Boarding Schools entered into between your predecessor in office and the Principals of such said schools as are under the auspices of the Catholic Church.

The draft of the contract was submitted by the then Superintendent General at a conference held at Ottawa on the 6th November, last, between him and certain officials of the headquarters staff of the Department of Indian Affairs, on the one part, and representatives of Churches conducting Indian schools, on the other part.

The representatives of the Churches had not been previously advised of the terms or tenor of the contract; and the careful consideration which the undersigned has given it compels them to the conclusion that the said representatives had not that opportunity of deliberating it which the importance of the contract demanded.

The undersigned find that the contract, hurriedly entered into, is lacking in certain essentials and in several
respects faulty.

They, therefore, beg to be permitted to recite the defects they find in the contract, and to set forth in some detail the reasons of their finding:

1. The contract lacks statutory authority. In the Sections of the Indian Act treating particularly of schools, being Sections 9, 10 and 11, of Chapter 81, Revised Statutes, 1906, there is no mention of contract schools; nor is any authority conferred, by those or any other Sections of that Act, or by any Statute of the Parliament of Canada, upon the Governor in Council, or upon the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, to enter into contracts for the conduct and management of Indian schools.

A contract by which the party of the second part, i.e., the representative of the Church under whose auspices the school named therein is conducted, assumes large responsibilities and is obligated to incur outlays on works of a permanent nature, in addition to the continuous burden of expenditure incident to maintenance and management, should have the sanction necessary to afford the amplest security to the party aforesaid. As it is, the party of the first part, i.e., the Superintendent General, can not, and does not, bind himself to perform his essential part of the bargain, that is to meet the payments to be made in consideration of the due performance of the work contracted to be done by the party of the second part. The clause marked "V" stipulates that there shall be no liability to make any payment to the school under the contract "should the amount voted by Parliament and applicable towards payment........be at any time expended during the continuance..."
of this contract".

Up to the adoption of the contract system a policy had been in operation which in its working was somewhat elastic. Under it the Department undertook to contribute to the maintenance of denominationally controlled residential schools for Indians through the payment of a per capita grant. But the policy was not bound in rigid bands; and contributions to the schools were made by the department in more ways than through the per capita grant. Contributions were made to help in the erection of certain school buildings, the ownership of which was recognized to be in the Church under whose auspices these institutions were to be conducted. And when considerable expenditure had been, or was to be, undertaken for additions, improvements or repairs, the department not infrequently came to the assistance of the Church by meeting in whole or in part the expenditure. The per capita grants paid under that policy can not, therefore, be taken as the full measure of the liability which the Department in practice assumed in respect of those schools.

Now that policy has passed from the easy elastic state to the rigid contract form, under which aid can neither be claimed for nor given to those schools beyond the fixed per capita grant. And the party of the first part is tightly bound to the performance of onerous obligations to the State, while the State appears to be bound not at all to make the compensatory payments.

It is true that the agreement, in the beginning, sets forth that the Superintendent General represents His Majesty the King; but, as there is no Parliamentary authority for thus assuming monetary obligations, nor apparently any sanction by
The Governor in Council of the contract, the undersigned doubt whether the Superintendent could constitutionally bind the Crown to the terms of the contract. Yet it is obvious that there should be equally binding obligations upon both parties to the contract. And, when a public policy of import assumes contractual form, it seems but the part of wisdom to have it sanctioned by the highest authority.

The undersigned, therefore, respectfully submit for your consideration the advisability of the Indian Act being so amended at the present session of the Dominion Parliament as to duly authorize the system of contract schools adopted by the Department of Indian Affairs. And to bring the proposal before you in concrete form, they beg leave to suggest the following amendment:

"That Section 10 of the said Act be hereby amended by adding the following Sub-Section thereto:

"The Superintendent General may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, enter into contracts with any church or religious denomination carrying on missionary work among the Indians for the conduct and maintenance of such industrial or boarding schools, or of any industrial or boarding schools established for Indians, with the approval, consent or concurrence of the Superintendent General, by any such church or religious denomination, whether the buildings in connection therewith be or be not the property of the Crown, and may assume under such contracts the payment of per capita grants to any or all of such schools for the education, keep and proper care of children, in whole or in part of Indian blood, admitted under rules or regulations made by the Superintendent General."
from time to time, or with his approval or consent, and in accordance with the terms of the contracts.

Such an amendment would give the desired sanction and security. It would give to the contract system that element of permanency which is essential to its success. Without adequate guarantee of stability and reasonable surety of compensatory payment for work done, there is no sufficient warrant for the party of the second part incurring capital expenditure and assuming costly and onerous obligations under the contract. That is so obvious that the undersigned can not conceive of objection being taken to such an amendment, except on factious grounds. But if objection were taken, it seems to the undersigned that this would be a ready and ample answer:

The contract system was adopted by the late administration; the late Minister entered into contracts with representatives of different churches for the conduct and maintenance of Indian schools; the contracts have gone into operation; they lack proper sanction; they were entered into without requisite authority; all that is now sought is to make them regular, and to afford reasonable security for the expenditure which has already been and is being incurred under them.

2. And, now, the undersigned, apologizing for having to continue to trespass, and to such great extent, upon your very valuable and so much occupied time, venture to deal, seriatim, with the faults in the contract itself.

Sub-Clause "b" of Clause 4 provides -

"That no Half-breed child shall be admitted....unless Indian children can not be obtained to complete the number..."
authorized by Article I., Section 1., and Section 4. (a) of this agreement, in which event the Superintendent General may in his discretion permit the admission of any Half-breed child; but the Superintendent General will not pay any grant for any such Half-breed pupil provided under Article II., Section 1., of this agreement, nor any part of the cost of its maintenance or education whatever."

That, the undersigned submit, is a very drastic provision and pregnant of much evil. It is contrary to the policy which long obtained, and against which no reasonable objection has been or can be urged. And in a measure, it is obviously ultra vires.

Half-breeds may be grouped into three fairly well defined classes.

1. Those who live, in varying degrees of conditions, the ordinary settled life of the country.

2. Those who live, in varying degrees, the Indian mode of life.

3. Those who - and they form the most unfortunate class in the community - are the illegitimate offspring of Indian women, and of whom white men are mainly the begetters.

Those of the first class make no claim upon the Government of the Dominion for the education of their children; nor has any such claim, as far as the knowledge of the undersigned goes, been made on their behalf.

The third class are entitled to participate in the benefits of Indian Schools; and, in so far as the afore-quoted provision of the contract is designed to exclude them from such participation
such participation, it is ultra vires of the parties to the contract, or of any authority save that of the Dominion Parliament itself.

Section 12, the very first of the sections of the Indian Act dealing with "Membership of Indian Bands", enacts as follows:

"Any illegitimate child may, unless he has, with the consent of the band whereof the father or mother of such child is a member, shared in the distribution moneys of such band for a period exceeding two years, be, at any time, excluded from the membership thereof by the Superintendent General".

It follows from that that the illegitimate child of an Indian woman having membership in a band is ipso facto a member of the band to which the mother belongs, and can only be removed from membership in such band by the Superintendent General, if he sees fit to exercise the power conferred upon him by the law; and that, if the child has participated for over two years in the moneys of the band, with the consent of the band (and acquiescence constitutes consent within the meaning of the provision), then there is no authority under the law for the removal of such child from membership. Such child is legally entitled to recognition as having full membership in the mother's band, unless the Superintendent General exercises his right of exclusion within the period aforesaid, which exclusion can not be by way of general order or act, but must be by specific order or act in each case; and every child not so excluded is entitled to all the benefits of band membership, including Indian educational privileges; and no such child can be contracted out of such privileges.
When Indian treaties are made the illegitimate children are taken into and given all the benefits of treaty irrespective of the blood of the fathers. In years after the existing treaties were made, subsequently born illegitimate children of Indian treaty women were excluded and payment of annuity money for them or on their behalf was refused. That policy appears to have been adopted to discourage illegitimate breeding. How far it has operated in that direction those who have been for years in close contact with Indians know best.

The undersigned are not aware of the form of the order or act by which such policy was put in operation, but they know that its operation has varied in times and places. Such children have been by one Indian Agent recognized as having band membership, by another they have been excluded; one year they are admitted, another year they are debarred.

But whatever be the object of the policy of exclusion, whatever be the variations in its application, or whatever be its results, such of those children as are being excluded under it are being excluded illegally, unless each such child has been specifically excluded from band membership by the Superintendent General as aforesaid.

The undersigned would, therefore, respectfully ask that, if the view of the case of those children as herein stated appears to you to be correct, you would have the goodness to issue an order which will promptly bring the policy and practice of the Department with respect to them into full accord with the law.

As to the second class of Half-breeds, the undersigned at once admit that they present a difficult educational problem. But the very difficulty affords a strong reason against drawing a hard and fast line such as is drawn in the agreement.
This second class of Half-breeds may be divided into three groups:

(1) Those who generally live apart from Indians, but follow somewhat the Indian mode of life, fishing, hunting and trapping, and to some extent engage in freighting, a business which narrows as railways extend. To this group may be added those who hang about towns, doing odd jobs when necessity compels them to work, and eking out a precarious existence, oftentimes, unfortunately, after a fashion which makes not for their own or the community's good.

(2) Those who live in the vicinity of Indian reserves, mingle more or less freely with Indians, and follow the Indian mode of life.

(3) Those who live on Indian reserves, with tacit or expressed consent, and live the life of Indians.

When, and for years after, Indian residential schools were established, Half-breeds of the three groups of this second class, as well as those of the third class already dealt with herein, were admitted. In the early years of these schools, when all existing were classed as industrial, the whole expense of the cost and management was met out of the public revenues, and there was then no possibility of dividing, as is now done, pupils into grant-earning and non-grant-earning classes. And after the Departmental system of contributing by per capita grant to the support of residential schools was adopted, which during the incumbancy of the Indian Commissionership by Mr. Hayter Reed, Half-breeds of the second, as well as of the third class, continued to be admitted as grant earners, now and then, perhaps, there being a refusal in the case of a child whose parents would come within the first group of the
Second class, while quite close to the fringe of the first class. But, indeed, the practice of the Department was very liberal.

Soon after 1896, certain officials of the administrative branch of the Department at headquarters, whose animus in the matter was evidently begotten of theory formed in the closet rather than of contact with conditions, succeeded in having a rule made excluding all Half-breed children from Indian schools. When, however, reasoned objection was taken to that rule before the then Superintendent General, the Honorable Clifford Sifton, he set it aside and directed that the children of Half-breeds living on or in the vicinity of Indian reserves, and following the Indian mode of life, should be admitted as grant-earners to Indian residential schools. The rule then made by him, when fairly followed, covered pretty fully the classes of Half-breeds whose education can only be properly provided for in such schools. Shortly after Mr. Oliver took office Mr. Sifton's safe rule, if not formally rescinded, was allowed to lapse into desuetude, and the rule which had, on good grounds, been set aside was revived, put into operation, and finally crystallized in Sub-Clause "b" of Clause 4 of the contract.

The Half-breed children now excluded from Indian schools are in a most unfortunate position. Their "homes" are not homes in our sense of the word. They dwell in tepees or are hearded in shacks. Their environment militates against moral and physical development, and breaks down instead of building up character. What is so readily and so often charged against a people of mixed blood is the result, not of blood, but of environment.

Up to the adoption of the contract system a policy had been in operation which in its working was somewhat elastic. Under it the Department undertook to contribute to the maintenance of denominationally controlled residential schools for Indians through the payment of a per capita grant. But the policy was not bound in rigid bands; and contributions to the schools were made by the Department in more ways than through the per capita grant. Contributions were made to help in the erection of certain school buildings, the ownership of which was recognized to be in the Church under whose auspices these institutions were to be conducted. And when considerable expenditure had been, or was to be, undertaken for additions, improvements or repairs, the department not infrequently came to the assistance of the Church by meeting in whole or in part the expenditure. The per capita grants paid under that policy can not, therefore, be taken as the full measure of the liability which the Department in practice assumed in respect of those schools.

Now that policy has passed from the easy elastic state to the rigid contract form, under which aid can neither be claimed for nor given to those schools beyond the fixed per capita grant. And the party of the first part is tightly bound to the performance of onerous obligations to the State, while the State appears to be bound not at all to make the compensatory payments.

It is true that the agreement, in the beginning, sets forth that the Superintendent General represents His Majesty the King; but, as there is no Parliamentary authority for thus assuming monetary obligations, nor apparently any sanction by
the Governor in Council of the contract, the undersigned doubt whether the Superintendent could constitutionally bind the Crown to the terms of the contract. Yet it is obvious that there should be equally binding obligations upon both parties to the contract. And, when a public policy of import assumes contractual form, it seems but the part of wisdom to have it sanctioned by the highest authority.

The undersigned, therefore, respectfully submit for your consideration the advisability of the Indian Act being so amended at the present session of the Dominion Parliament as to duly authorize the system of contract schools adopted by the Department of Indian Affairs. And to bring the proposal before you in concrete form, they beg leave to suggest the following amendment:

"That Section 10 of the said Act be hereby amended by adding the following Sub-Section thereto:

"The Superintendent General may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, enter into contracts with any church or religious denomination carrying on missionary work among the Indians for the conduct and maintenance of such industrial or boarding schools, or of any industrial or boarding schools established for Indians, with the approval, consent or concurrence of the Superintendent General, by any such church or religious denomination, whether the buildings in connection therewith be or be not the property of the Crown, and may assume under such contracts the payment of per capita grants to any or all of such schools for the education, keep and proper care of children, in whole or in part of Indian blood, admitted under rules or regulations made by the Superintendent general..."
from time to time, or with his approval or consent, and in accordance with the terms of the contracts".

Such an amendment would give the desired sanction and security. It would give to the contract system that element of permanency which is essential to its success. Without adequate guarantee of stability and reasonable surety of compensatory payment for work done, there is no sufficient warrant for the party of the second part incurring capital expenditure and assuming costly and onerous obligations under the contract. That is so obvious that the undersigned can not conceive of objection being taken to such an amendment, except on factious grounds. But if objection were taken, it seems to the undersigned that this would be a ready and ample answer:

The contract system was adopted by the late administration; the late Minister entered into contracts with representatives of different churches for the conduct and maintenance of Indian schools; the contracts have gone into operation; they lack proper sanction; they were entered into without requisite authority; all that is now sought is to make them regular, and to afford reasonable security for the expenditure which has already been and is being incurred under them.

2. And, now, the undersigned, apologizing for having to continue to trespass, and to such great extent, upon your very valuable and so much occupied time, venture to deal, seriatim, with the faults in the contract itself.

Sub-Clause "b" of Clause 4 provides -

"That no Half-breed child shall be admitted..., unless Indian children can not be obtained to complete the number..."
authorized by Article I., Section I., and Section 4. (a) of this agreement, in which event the Superintendent General may in his discretion permit the admission of any Half-breed child; but the Superintendent General will not pay any grant for any such Half-breed pupil provided under Article II., Section I., of this agreement, nor any part of the cost of its maintenance or education whatever."

That, the undersigned submit, is a very drastic provision and pregnant of much evil. It is contrary to the policy which long obtained, and against which no reasonable objection has been or can be urged. And in a measure, it is obviously ultra vires.

Half-breeds may be grouped into three fairly well defined classes.

1. Those who live, in varying degrees of conditions, the ordinary settled life of the country.

2. Those who live, in varying degrees, the Indian mode of life.

3. Those who - and they form the most unfortunate class in the community - are the illegitimate offspring of Indian women, and of whom white men are mainly the begetters.

Those of the first class make no claim upon the Government of the Dominion for the education of their children; nor has any such claim, as far as the knowledge of the undersigned goes, been made on their behalf.

The third class are entitled to participate in the benefits of Indian Schools; and, in so far as the afore-quoted provision of the contract is designed to exclude them from such participation
such participation, it is ultra vires of the parties to the contract, or of any authority save that of the Dominion Parliament itself.

Section 12, the very first of the sections of the Indian Act dealing with "Membership of Indian Bands", enacts as follows:

"Any illegitimate child may, unless he has, with the consent of the band whereof the father or mother of such child is a member, shared in the distribution moneys of such band for a period exceeding two years, be, at any time, excluded from the membership thereof by the Superintendent General".

It follows from that that the illegitimate child of an Indian woman having membership in a band is ipso facto a member of the band to which the mother belongs, and can only be removed from membership in such band by the Superintendent General, if he sees fit to exercise the power conferred upon him by the law; and that, if the child has participated for over two years in the moneys of the band, with the consent of the band (and acquiescence constitutes consent within the meaning of the provision), then there is no authority under the law for the removal of such child from membership. Such child is legally entitled to recognition as having full membership in the mother's band, unless the Superintendent General exercises his right of exclusion within the period aforesaid, which exclusion can not be by way of general order or act, but must be by specific order or act in each case; and every child not so excluded is entitled to all the benefits of band membership, including Indian educational privileges; and no such child can be contracted out of such privileges.
When Indian treaties are made the illegitimate children are taken into and given all the benefits of treaty irrespective of the blood of the fathers. In years after the existing treaties were made, subsequently born illegitimate children of Indian treaty women were excluded and payment of annuity money for them or on their behalf was refused. That policy appears to have been adopted to discourage illegitimate breeding. How far it has operated in that direction those who have been for years in close contact with Indians know best.

The undersigned are not aware of the form of the order or act by which such policy was put in operation, but they know that its operation has varied in times and places. Such children have been by one Indian Agent recognized as having band membership; by another they have been excluded; one year they are admitted, another year they are debarred.

But whatever be the object of the policy of exclusion, whatever be the variations in its application, or whatever be its results, such of those children as are being excluded under it are being excluded illegally, unless each such child has been specifically excluded from band membership by the Superintendent General as aforesaid.

The undersigned would, therefore, respectfully ask that, if the view of the case of those children as herein stated appears to you to be correct, you would have the goodness to issue an order which will promptly bring the policy and practice of the Department with respect to them into full accord with the law.

As to the second class of Half-breeds, the undersigned at once admit that they present a difficult educational problem. But the very difficulty affords a strong reason against drawing a hard and fast line such as is drawn in the agreement.
This second class of Half-breeds may be divided into three groups:

(1) Those who generally live apart from Indians, but follow somewhat the Indian mode of life, fishing, hunting and trapping, and to some extent engage in freighting, a business which narrows as railways extend. To this group may be added those who hang about towns, doing odd jobs when necessity compels them to work, and eking out a precarious existence, oftentimes, unfortunately, after a fashion which makes not for their own or the community's good.

(2) Those who live in the vicinity of Indian reserves, mingle more or less freely with Indians, and follow the Indian mode of life.

(3) Those who live on Indian reserves, with tacit or expressed consent, and live the life of Indians.

When, and for years after, Indian residential schools were established, Half-breeds of the three groups of this second class, as well as those of the third class already dealt with herein, were admitted. In the early years of these schools, when all existing were classed as industrial, the whole expense of the cost and management was met out of the public revenues, and there was then no possibility of dividing, as is now done, pupils into grant-earning and non-grant-earning classes. And after the Departmental system of contributing by per capita grant to the support of residential schools was adopted, which during the incumbancy of the Indian Commissionership by Mr. Hayter Reed, Half-breeds of the second, as well as of the third class, continued to be admitted as grant earners, now and then, perhaps, there being a refusal in the case of a child whose parents would come within the first group of the
Second class, while quite close to the fringe of the first class. But, indeed, the practice of the Department was very liberal.

Soon after 1896, certain officials of the administrative branch of the Department at headquarters, whose animus in the matter was evidently begotten of theory formed in the closet rather than of contact with conditions, succeeded in having a rule made excluding all Half-breed children from Indian schools. When, however, reasoned objection was taken to that rule before the then Superintendent General, the Honorable Clifford Sifton, he set it aside and directed that the children of Half-breeds living on or in the vicinity of Indian reserves, and following the Indian mode of life, should be admitted as grant-earners to Indian residential schools. The rule then made by him, when fairly followed, covered pretty fully the classes of Half-breeds whose education can only be properly provided for in such schools. Shortly after Mr. Oliver took office Mr. Sifton's safe rule, if not formally rescinded, was allowed to lapse into desuetude, and the rule which had, on good grounds, been set aside was revived, put into operation, and finally crystallized in Sub-Clause "b" of Clause 4 of the contract.

The Half-breed children now excluded from Indian schools are in a most unfortunate position. Their "homes" are not homes in our sense of the word. They dwell in tepees or are housed in shacks. Their environment militates against moral and physical development, and breaks down instead of building up character. What is so readily and so often charged against a people of mixed blood is the result, not of blood, but of environment.

It is begging the question for the Department to
take the position, as it has, that it is the duty of the Provincial Governments to provide education for Half-breeds.

As you very well know, and as anyone at all familiar with conditions knows, there are no Provincial institutions in which the required kind of education can be provided for Half-breeds of the second and third classes herein described. Even if the white rate-payers of school districts were willing to admit such children to their day schools, not as Pariahs, but on a footing of equality with their own sons and daughters, the sad condition of these Half-breed children would not, in any effective degree, be ameliorated. As educational agencies day schools presuppose a home environment that makes, at least, not against mental and moral development. And anyone that is cognizant of the conditions that obtain must know that our Indian residential schools are the only existing agencies for the proper upbringing of those unfortunate children. If they are excluded from those schools, what can they be expected to become but outcasts and menaces to society?

The Department seems to have acted upon the supposition that the Government of Canada assumed the burden of providing for the education of Indian children in residential schools solely to meet obligations imposed by treaties with Indians; and from that hypothesis to have reached the conclusion that the Dominion Government is not justified in increasing the burden by extending the benefits of the system to Half-breeds who are not recognized by it as having membership in Indian bands. But the man who laid the foundation of the system, Sir John Macdonald, had no such narrow view. Under his administration the policy was adopted and followed of admitting Half-breeds of the aforesaid second and third classes into those schools.
And that policy was in accord with the basic purpose of the system; for such schools were established not merely to meet treaty obligations towards Indians, but as a means of preventing, in the public interest, a race of wild men growing up whose hands would be against all men and all men's hands against them.

The Government of Canada never took the position in the past that it had no obligations at all as to Half-breeds. It recognized them as possessing, in a degree, an aboriginal title to the land of this country, and took measures to compensate for its extinguishment. In other ways and at different times it helped these people. It gave to the children of certain of them the right of entry as regular pupils of Indian schools, and in doing so created a right in the nature of a vested right, the destruction of which is an injustice, and against the interest of the commonwealth.

The undersigned, therefore, respectfully submit that the afore-quoted excluding clause of the contract should be expunged; and that the old and wise policy, or, at the very least, Mr. Sifton's rule, be reverted to and made permanent by incorporation in the contract.

3. Clause 6 of the contract baldly provides that the "school shall be conducted under such regulations as may from time to time be approved by His Excellency the Governor General in Council".

Those regulations, which would be framed in the Department, and might, in the pressure of Governmental business, or in the ordinary course of routine matters, be approved of, could easily be so framed as to practically exclude, or unduly
Interfere with the teaching of religion.

It is true that under Clause 9 the managers of the school are required "to provide... teachers and officers pupils qualified to give religious instruction at the proper times." But that provision inferentially makes the Superintendent General the sole and final judge of the qualification of "teachers and officers" to impart "religious instruction," and of what are "the proper times" at which such "religious instruction" should be given. It occurs to the undersigned that so theological a function as that would not be pleasurably assumed by a Minister of State in Canada. Ethical training being wisely recognized as essential in Indian education by the Government of Canada from the very beginning of its relations with Indians, Indian schools were put under the auspices of different religious denominations carrying on missionary work among them to make impossible the clash which might occur between the views of a Minister of the Crown as to the nature and scope of the ethical training that should be imparted and the tenets of the church to which the particular Indians to be so trained belonged. Indeed this provision of Clause 9 seems to the undersigned to have been intended rather for undenominational than for denominational schools, and to have been drafted by one holding the view that religious instruction can be adequately imparted irrespective of ecclesiastical dogma. From that view the undersigned must, of course, most unhesitatingly and most emphatically dissent.

The undersigned are convinced that you will readily agree that it is the part of wisdom to obviate all possibility of conflict as to religious teaching in the administration
Of the contract system of Indian schools; and that to that end it would be advisable to have an explicit provision in the contract securing the teaching of religion in the school in accordance with the tenets of the church under whose auspices the school is conducted.

They would, therefore, suggest that the said Clause 6 be amended by adding thereto the following proviso:

"Provided that no such regulation shall prohibit, or interfere with, the teaching of religion in the said school in accordance with the tenets of the church under the auspices of which the said school is conducted."

4. By Clause 8 of the contract it is covenanted

"Not to employ, except on probation for a period not exceeding six months, at said school any teacher or instructor until evidence satisfactory to the Superintendent General has been submitted to him that such teacher or instructor is able to converse with the pupils under his charge in English, and is able to speak and write the English language fluently and correctly, and possesses such other qualifications as, in the opinion of the Superintendent General, may be necessary".

That is a hard and fast provision, compliance with which is practically impossible; yet its violation in any respect would vitiate the contract.

It is not only required that every "teacher" and "instructor" shall be able to speak and to write the English language "fluently and correctly", but the party responsible for the conduct of the school under the contract must furnish the Superintendent General with "evidence satisfactory", and within "six months", of the date of the employment of every teacher and instructor, that every such "teacher or instructor.....is
able to speak and write the English language fluently and correctly.

It is required by Clause 9 of the contract that "gardening, farming, and care of stock..., cooking, laundry-work, needle-work, general housewifery and dairy-work" shall be taught.

Therefore, the farmers, gardeners and stockmen, the cooks, laundresses, and seamstresses, the house-keepers and the dairy-women must be able to speak and write the English language fluently and correctly; for each of them is an instructor under the contract, and the party of the second part convenants that each shall "instruct" the pupils of the school in his or her line of work.

Now, everybody knows that there are cooks and dairy-men and house-wifery experts, laundresses and seamstresses, gardeners and farmers and stockmen, competent in their various callings, and good, practical instructors in the work thereof, who, while they speak English well enough for properly training others along their own vocational lines, cannot "speak and write English fluently and correctly". They are exceptions who do.
We understand that something has already been done by the Department to mitigate the rigor of the clause we object to. Therefore our considerations in the first edition of this memo are no more relevant, and we suppressed them. Still we believe that something more should be done to make things less stringent.

For instance, we suggest the elimination of the word instructor.
If it be necessary to convenant to secure the teaching of English in schools where the force of necessity compels its being learned, let the following be substituted:
6. To duly provide for the pupils of the said school being taught to speak, read and write the English language to the same extent that pupils are so taught in the ordinary schools of the country.

Such a provision would secure, if special security in that respect be required, adequate English teaching to Indian pupils. If, in addition, they hear and become in some measure familiar with French, no danger to the commonwealth will result therefrom, nor will they be thereby the less well equipped for the battle of life.

5. The conditions intended to be imposed by Clauses 12, 13 and the first part of 18 should have been more aptly, clearly and comprehensively expressed. They are as follows:

"12. To keep and maintain the school buildings and premises, to supply proper sanitation and sanitary appliances, and to keep the buildings free from flies, insects and vermin."

"13. To maintain the buildings at the said school and the school premises when they are the property of the (blank) in good condition and repair, the whole to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General"

"18. To make any change or alteration in the school building or premises . . . . . ."

In considering those provisions reference must be made to the "Memorandum" which appears immediately before the draft contract in the blue booklet entitled "Correspondence and Agreement relating to the Maintenance and Management of Indian Boarding Schools".

The following are excerpts therefrom:
SCHOOL BUILDINGS, CLASS 'A.'

The buildings owned by the church which would entitle the school to a per capita grant of $100 in the eastern division and $125 in the western division should conform to the following general specifications.

1. Substantial building either of brick, stone, cement or wood in good state of repair.
2. To be built on a stone or cement foundation with a light airy basement of full size of main building with cement floor.
3. Pure and plentiful water-supply distributed throughout the building.
4. A proper system of sanitary water-closets, drainage and disposal of sewage.
5. Hospital accommodation for the isolation of pupils ill with infectious disease or tuberculosis.
6. Modern system of ventilation in dormitories and class-room and sufficient air space in dormitories and class-rooms for the number of pupils accommodated.
7. Modern heating apparatus, hot water, steam or hot air.
8. Sufficient area of land for farms and gardens and practical industrial work, where such work can be carried on.

SCHOOL BUILDINGS, CLASS 'B.'

The buildings owned by the government which would entitle the management to $80 per capita in the eastern division and $100 per capita in the western division class must conform to the requirements of clauses 5, 6, and 8 of class 'A.'

SCHOOL BUILDINGS, CLASS 'C.'

Buildings owned by the churches which do not in all particulars conform to the specifications in classes 'A' and 'B,' and which are nevertheless sanitary and kept in a good state of repair, and which would entitle the school to $80 per capita in the eastern division and $100 per capita in the western division. The buildings in this class must conform to the requirements of clauses 5, 6, and 8 of class 'A.'

The specific re-statement in the paragraph dealing with schools in Class C, of the requirements of Class A which have to be met by them makes it clear that the general statement in that paragraph that the schools coming within Class C are to be "nevertheless sanitary and kept in a good state of repair" can not fairly be interpreted to mean that these schools are to be called upon to meet in regard to sanitariness the specific and costly requirements of Class A, the schools of which class, in consideration of the more costly and extensive improvements required, are paid $25.00 per capita more than the schools in Class C. The buildings to be scheduled in Class C are described as "buildings owned by the churches which do not in all particulars conform to the specifications..."
specific requirements of that class are to be provided in their case being the things described in sections 5, 6 and 8 of the paragraph describing the requirements of Class A, namely, isolated hospital accommodation, modern system of ventilation, sufficient air space, and adequate land for farms and gardens, where farming and gardening can be carried on. As to sanitariness, all that can be insisted upon is that such school buildings shall be made and kept sanitary as similar buildings are ordinarily made and kept sanitary, without "light airy basements", "water supply distributed", "system of sanitary water-closets, drainage and disposal of sewage; all of which requirements are specifically set forth as necessary for Class A, but are not so set forth as required for Class C. And the reason for their not being set forth as requisite for the latter classification is quite obvious; for, if these costly things had to be provided for entry into Class C and to secure the per capita grant of $100.00 payable to schools in that class, it would be the veriest improvidence not to meet the other requirements of Class A and secure the per capita grant of $125.00, especially as, in a climate marked by severe cold in winter, "modern heating apparatus", a requirement of Class A which as are the other things mentioned for Class C, is strangely not insisted upon, would be essential to a system of water distribution, water-flushing closets and pipe drainage throughout buildings, which are insisted upon, on the reports made on certain schools by a saidasant expert employed by the Department last summer to examine the buildings, after they had been, under special instructions from the Department, examined, not by the School Inspector, but by the regular Inspectors of Agencies, and on their reports classified for the purposes of the contract by the Department.
The changes and improvements ordered are, in almost every case in which the undersigned have been advised of the said expert's specifications, so vastly out of proportion to the building itself as to be quite absurd. Take, for instance, the school at Delmas—it has had, since its establishment, never more than an authorized attendance of twenty. It is classed C.

Yet it is required that the building shall be done over and entirely remodelled. Stone foundations are to be changed, ceiling made higher, windows enlarged, and hard wood floors laid and oiled and finished in shellac. Each dormitory is to be provided with "one water closet... automatic low tank combination operated with push button" and "one cast iron enamelled bath". Galvanized iron tanks are to be put on the second floor, from which water is to be distributed throughout the building by gravitation; and the floors and walls are to be strengthened to sustain the tanks. A sewage system, with septic tanks, is to be installed.

And all those things are in addition to the specific requirements of Class C as to isolated hospital et cetera.

The undersigned know of only one school classed C in the territory toured by the said expert that would warrant the assuming of such burdens. That school is Ermineskin's at Hobbema. And because certain of the improvements called for have been made and the others are to be gone with, its classification should be changed to A.

Over and above the objections herein made to the extensive and costly improvements demanded, on an unwarranted interpretation of the official description of the requirements of Class C, the undersigned regard the requirement of isolated hospital accommodation as excessive.
An isolated hospital, a building standing alone and devoted to the treatment of virulently contagious diseases, necessitates special provision for heating, special culinary arrangements, special provision for laundering, and an addition to the staff of the school to which it appertains.

Now a school with twenty or thirty, or even forty or so pupils, can not in reason be expected to bear the burden of building, equipping and maintaining such an hospital.

Where outside of the Indian Department is such a requirement dreamed of? How many hamlets, villages, and even towns in the west have isolated hospitals? And where there are such hospitals, the health regulations permit persons struck with certain infectious diseases being kept at their own homes if proper isolation can be effected. And for proper isolation, even in cases of scarlet fever and diphtheria, it is not necessary that the stricken ones should be put under a different roof, and those suffering from one disease separated by a doorless wall from those taken down with another, as Dr. Lafferty insisted should be done at Crowfoot's School on the Blackfoot Reserve.

The isolated hospitals demanded are to have accommodation, it is stipulated, for "infectious disease or tuberculosis." It would be an unprecedented, and a dangerous and cruel proceeding, to put tubercular cases with cases of scarlet fever, diphtheria or small-pox. Phthisis is not virulently contagious. The best medical opinion, the undersigned are given to understand, is that it can be safely treated without isolation, if simple precautions are taken; and, indeed, it is well known that very many suffering from that dread disease are, under medical direction, so treated in homes that, to say the least, have not better accommodation than is afforded by the infirmaries.
already provided at the schools.

The Department itself did not provide in connection with the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, which it built and owns, and in which there are in residence some two hundred and twenty-five pupils, an isolated hospital. The only hospital provided is on the top flat of the main building, and has not even a balcony, though the open air treatment is the approved one for tuberculosis, and most desirable as a means of affording a sunning to all convalescents.

Why, then, should the same department insist that church schools with an attendance of one or two score, and paid only $100.00 per capita, shall have such isolated hospitals as have been demanded?

All that should reasonably be called for is a special infirmary in the building, safeguarded to prevent contagion, and in area proportionate to the capacity of the school building, the same to be kept in readiness for the isolation of pupils who might contract infectious diseases. If such a disease spread, the school would have, as residential schools have had, to take on the circumstances of an isolated hospital.

It is important to have a clear description of what is required in the way of hospital accommodation. Schools have been submitted to vexatious requirements by physicians, whose interest therein appears to have been in large measure confined to making unnecessary demands. For sometime, indeed, it has been painfully evident that the Department's medical policy has been inspired by faddism.

The undersigned would be quite satisfied if the schools schedule in Class C were only called upon to meet requirements.
proper to that class; for the increase from $72.00 to $100.00 per capita would warrant the necessary expenditure; and the improvements, with the increased yearly income, would enable those schools to better serve the purpose for which they are intended.

The description of the classes of schools, the undersigned respectfully submit, should have been incorporated in the contract. As they stand, it would not appear that they can be held to be part of it; and Clauses 12, 13 and 18 are so loosely framed and capable of so broad and variant interpretations that almost anything in the way of alterations and improvements can be demanded. It seems to the undersigned to be quite obviously in the interest of both parties thereto that the contract entered into for each and every school should definitely and clearly set forth what improvements are to be made and maintained in order to entitle the school to receive a per capita grant of $100.00 or $125.00, as the case may be. And to that end the undersigned would ask that the contract be amended.

6. By Clause 18 of the contract the party of the second part is required -

(1) "To make any change or alteration in the school building or premises, or (2) in the management or control of the said school rendered necessary to comply with the intent and spirit of the agreement, and (3) to remove for cause from the said school any teacher, officer, employee, or pupil when required to do so by the Superintendent General".

To be properly canvassed this clause must be taken apart and divided, as marked by the undersigned in the above quotation of it.
Its first section should have been embodied in a clause covering the matter of Clauses 12 and 13.

But, apart from that, which is after all only a fault in drafting, the first section is objectionable in that it destroys finality in the matter of improvement, and enables the party of the first part to demand, at any time after the changes and improvements first required have been acceptably made, further alterations, which may be extensive and costly and destructive of expensive improvements made by order of the Department at the time of entering into the contract. Under this provision, managers of schools may find themselves embarrassed by Departmental approval of the recommendations of Inspectors or Agents with fads; and school managers, unfortunately, are not without experience of such faddists.

The undersigned, therefore, respectfully submit that, in recasting the contract, it should be made clear that, when the changes and improvements called for by the requirements of the class in which the school is placed have been acceptably made and such improvements are being duly maintained, there shall be no obligation to make any further changes, alterations or improvements during the continuance of the contract.

7. The second section of Clause 18 is particularly objectionable and dangerous. It empowers the party of the first part "to make any change or alteration,...in the management or control of the school rendered necessary to comply with the intent and spirit of the agreement", of which necessity the said party is to be the sole and final judge.

The word "management" means and is intended for "managers", the word used by the undersigned in their review of the contract to prevent confusion with the word management.
as used in the title and generally throughout the contract. But, if there were room for doubt as to the sense in which the word "management" is used in the clause now under consideration, it is entirely removed by the addition of the word "control", which is sufficiently comprehensive to be inclusive of the meaning of "auspices" as that word is used when it is stated that a certain school is conducted under the auspices of a certain church. The provision is certainly very wide and far reaching.

The undersigned can find no provision in the contract for the school being conducted under the auspices of a particular church. If such a provision be not within the four corners of the contract, then it would not be contrary to its "intent and spirit", and, indeed, might be found necessary thereto, to change the auspices.

That may be regarded as quite unlikely to happen, and too far fetched a contingency to guard against. However that may be, this might happen:

A school might come to be regarded by an Inspector or Agent as being too religiously conducted, and, on his report, the ecclesiastical "management or control" thereof might be changed to lay management and control.

Or it might come to be considered that the "management" was not sufficiently Anglicized or too Frenchified, and that it was, therefore, necessary to due compliance with the "intent and spirit of the agreement" to change or alter the management and control.

The undersigned respectfully submit that each contract should set forth the designation of the church or religious denomination under whose auspices the school is conducted; that, in the case of each school conducted under the auspices
of the Catholic Church, the designation of the order or community of priests or nuns the school is managed or controlled by at the time of the entering into the contract should be set forth therein; and it should be provided that no change shall be made in such management or control without the consent or concurrence of the Ordinary of the diocese or vicariate in which the school is situated.

8. The third section of Clause 18 empowers the party of the first part to have removed, "for cause", from the school any teacher, officer, employee, or pupil.

The term "for cause" is dangerously indefinite. It is not difficult to allege a cause. The question always is as to its sufficiency. Under the section a teacher, officer or employee might be removed because he or she used, even in English, French idiomatic forms of expression, or spoke with too French an accent, or conversed or prayed with pupils in other than the English tongue. A teacher might be removed because he or she did not hold a certificate from one of a certain number of Normal Schools. A child might be removed and placed in a school conducted under other religious auspices.

The undersigned respectfully submit that the clause should be so amended as to set forth the causes for which removal may be made. In the cases of teachers, officers and employees the grounds for removal should be confined to incompetency, unbecoming conduct, and violation of the terms of the contract or of Departmental regulations not inconsistent therewith. Pupils should only be removed, before the full period for which they entered, for serious offences in the nature of crimes under the law, or on account of incurable disease or of
disease inimical to the health of the other pupils, or because of utter intractability; and it should be provided that a pupil so removed shall not be placed in a school conducted under religious auspices different from that under which the school from which the removal is made is conducted.

9. In the part of the agreement which sets forth the obligations of the Superintendent General under the contract, he covenants, under Clause 2 thereof, "to provide the pupils of... the... school with medicines, school-books, stationery, and school appliances".

It is the practice to also furnish medical attendance; and the undersigned respectfully submit that the clause should be so amended as to include it.

10. Under Clause III the party of the first part takes power to "cancel and rescind" the contract on his sole judgment that "any of the covenants and stipulations" therein have not been complied with, on giving six months notice.

The undersigned regard that as rather an extensive power to take without the right of appeal on the part of the other party to the contract, who, in virtue of it, incurs large outlay and assumes serious responsibilities; and they would, therefore, suggest that the clause be amended so as to give the party of the second part the right to appeal against an order of cancellation to the Governor in Council within six months of the date of such order, it being provided that such order shall set forth the grounds of cancellation, so that the same may be attacked if an appeal be made.

11. By Clause V it is provided that there shall be no liability to make any payment to the school under the contract.
"should the amount voted by Parliament and applicable towards payment,......be at any time expended during the continuance of this contract".

The Indian educational appropriation, the undersigned understand, is voted in bulk, and not for particular schools or classes of schools. Through over expenditure in one direction there might be lack of funds to meet payments due in another. Or there might be neglect to estimate for moneys payable under the contract. There is no expressed obligation under the contract to estimate for payments to the school the maintenance of which by its managers is contracted for, or to ask Parliament for the necessary money for the per capita grant stipulated.

It seems to the undersigned that those obligations should be expressed in the contract. Indeed, they venture to think that it would not be going too far to ask that it be agreed that the name of the school and the amount provided for it be set forth in the Supply Bill. That would give Parliamentary sanction to each contract, would ensure that no money voted for the school could be diverted, and would estop any demands for additional payments to the school.

If you, Honorable Sir, should find the contract sufficiently faulty to warrant its recasting, it would, the undersigned respectfully suggest, be well to have it so recast that no room for doubt might remain as to covenants and conditions, its spirit and intent. In the recasting, it should, the undersigned venture to suggest, be borne in mind that the Indian educational system has now proceeded "from status to contract". In the former condition there was nothing hard or fast. Variant conditions and unforeseen contingencies could at any time be taken into consideration, and an unpropitious
financial situation might at any time be ameliorated by aid other than the per capita grant. Claims could be made for the meeting by the Department of certain expenditures; and such claims were often made and often met. No such aid can be looked for, no such claims are entertainable under the contract system. It is rigid. It crystallizes a policy. There is no room for give or take. It is, therefore, of the utmost importance that the conditions should be clearly expressed, and that no room be left for misunderstanding. It is of the very essence of a contract to aptly describe the things contracted for. And, when a public policy of import assumes contractual form, it is, as already observed, the part of wisdom to have it sanctioned by the highest authority in the State.

We beg you, Honorable Sir, to accept the assurance of our high esteem, and to believe us

Your faithful servants,

MEMORANDUM -

The main points in connection with Roman Catholic Contract Indian Boarding Schools which are raised by the Right Rev. Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church who signed the letters addressed to the Honourable Robert Rogers on the 16th and 24th November, 1912, are as follows:

1st. That the contract was hurriedly entered into.

2nd. That the contract was ultra vires of the Superintendent General; an amendment to the Indian Act is proposed to overcome the alleged illegality.

3rd. Detailed objections are made to certain clauses of the contract.

4th. That the Department has entered upon a policy of establishing day schools which conflicts with the interests of the Boarding Schools and that an attempt is being made to secularize the schools.

I will take up the points in their order.

1st. That the contract was hurriedly entered into,

On the 8th November, 1910, the Honourable Mr. Oliver held a conference with Bishops, Clergymen and Laymen representing the churches interested in Indian Education to discuss the question of the future conduct and maintenance of Indian
Indian Boarding Schools throughout the Dominion. The churches had for some time urged the necessity of better financial terms and the then Superintendent General desired to find some satisfactory basis upon which increased grants could be made. He had found that there was what he characterized as an "unbusiness-like lack of arrangement," whereby the Government was called upon to spend money on buildings owned by the churches and to meet deficiencies in the management of Mission Schools. The payment of augmented Per Capita Grants was, therefore, made upon the basis of ownership in the building. The Government was no longer to be held liable for any improvements to Church property and all the school buildings whether owned by the Church or Government were to be improved and brought up to a certain standard. The draft contract was read by the Superintendent General at this conference and it was approved by the delegates. On the 26th November a copy was sent to everyone who had been present and to others who were interested. These copies were sent to the Right Rev. Bishops who signed the letters at present under discussion, with the exception of the lately appointed Bishop of Regina. The contracts themselves were not signed until March of the following year. Most of them are dated in that month and the months of April and May following. It will be seen, therefore, that a draft of this contract was in possession of the Right Rev. Bishops for at least four months, during which interval no objection was raised by them and the contract was signed without amendment. The contract has been in operation since the 1st of April, 1911, and two years of the contract will have been completed on the 31st March, proximo. During this period the authorities of the Roman Catholic Church and the Department have worked amicably.
amicably together. Every stipulation of the contract has been met by the Church and the Government, and the buildings have been improved or are in course of improvement by both parties.

Before proceeding to deal with the objections raised by the Right Rev. Bishops to the contract itself, I would state that the contracts terminate on the 31st March, 1916. That is they have still four years to run after the end of the present fiscal year. I would recommend that if the contract be found to be legal that the agreement be allowed to run its course. Experience will show where changes ought to be made. If the Superintendent General has no power to enter into such a contract it is inoperative and the whole matter can be reconsidered pending the provision of statutory authority to make a contract.

2nd. That the contract was ultra vires of the Superintendent General; an amendment to the Indian Act is proposed to overcome the alleged illegality.

This is a matter which should be presented to the Department of Justice for opinion, as well as the question as to the illegitimates raised in connection with Section 12 of the Indian Act.

3rd. Detailed objections are made to certain clauses of the contract.

The admission of Half-breed children. This is a question to which much attention has been paid of late. A Half-breed, being legally "a person" within the meaning of the Act, that is not an Indian, he is an ordinary citizen of the country and the problem of his education belongs to the Provinces not to the Dominion. It must be remembered that during the early days in the West there was a good deal of carelessness as regards
as regards the admission of Half-breeds to Indian bands and educational institutions intended for Indians. The Government of the Northwest Territories was then under the Dominion, the Provinces had not been erected, the school lands had not been set apart for the support of schools. There is now no more reason for the Dominion Government to intervene to provide for the education of Half-breeds than there would be for intervening action in connection with any other progressive policy with reference to this special class. It will be observed that we do not absolutely exclude these children from our schools; they may be taken in if Indian children cannot be obtained, but, the cost of their maintenance should not fall upon the Dominion Treasury but upon the Provinces.

Has an effort ever been made by the school authorities to get the Provincial Governments to recognize their duties and responsibilities in this matter? The Half-breeds are one class of their citizens and a certain portion of them can better be provided in resident schools than in any other class of institution. The Dominion Government has generously said, "We will give accommodation for this class, let the Provinces provide the maintenance." It would be a serious matter of expense to open our doors unreservedly to Half-breeds and the appropriation being intended for Indian Education only; it would not be proper to divert any portion of it to the education of Half-breeds. The Government of Canada certainly recognized some obligations to the Half-breeds but these were cancelled by the issue of Half-breed scrip, just as the Indian obligations were cancelled by the making of Treaties to the Indians. It is purely a question of policy for the Govern-
Government to decide whether they will assume the responsibility of the education of Half-breeds. Parliament can provide funds for the education of Half-breeds or any foreign element in the population. At present there is no Parliamentary authority and the late Superintendent General decided that he would not educate citizens of the Provinces. I think that this question should be taken up with the Provincial Ministers of Education, and the policy of the Department should be made clear to them, and I think it highly probable that they will be willing to contribute to the maintenance of Half-breeds in Industrial and Boarding Schools.

With regard to Half-breeds, the position of the Church is not made clear in any of these documents. They are I think chiefly concerned as to the maintenance of Industrial Schools. It is exceedingly difficult to recruit Indian children for both Industrial and Boarding Schools, but particularly difficult for the former class, because the Indians object to sending their children far away from home. Most of the Boarding Schools are on the Reserves and they have less objection to allow their children to attend this class of school. Up to the present time every Industrial School has had in residence a number of Half-breeds, for whom the Government paid nothing, but who were supported by the general revenues of the schools. So long as the Indian attendance could be kept up, the Church could derive revenue from the Department and thus support a large number of Half-breeds.

While dealing coldly with the legal aspect, I do not think we should altogether lose sight of humane considerations and I would be inclined to go back to the Hon. Mr. Sifton's ruling and at the same time endeavour to get the Provincial
Provincial Authorities to contribute something, any one moiety of the Per Capita Grant for this class of children as specified in Mr. Sifton's ruling and admit to Industrial Schools "children, either those of mixed blood whether legitimate or not, who live upon an Indian Reserve and whose parents on either side live as Indians upon a Reserve, even if they are not annuitants." The Department is not a mere machine. Compassion should be active where it is properly due, and certainly there is no class of children the State should more compassionate than the unfortunate class above referred to.

Clause 6 of the Contract.

The contract provides that the school shall be conducted under such regulations as may from time to time be approved by His Excellency the Governor General in Council. The school regulations now operative were approved by His Excellency in Council on the 6th August, 1908. Both the Indian Act and the regulations provide for Denominational Schools and I think it a most remote contingency that the Governor in Council would impose oppressive regulations as to religious teaching in the schools. Since the establishment of the schools, the Churches have been allowed great freedom in imparting religious training.

Clause 8 of the Contract.

With reference to the inability of teachers and instructors to speak English fluently. We are quite well aware that the Roman Catholic Schools employ a number of teachers and instructors whose native language is not English, and while it has been thought advisable that the English language should be taught in localities where it is the language of the people the Department has not objected to the employment of instructors or teachers whose native language is not English. It will be observed that the Right Rev. Bishops withhold in part
in part their objection to this clause, and I think it might be allowed to stand. It is not the intention to be unreasonable in the application of this provision or any other of the contracts.

Clauses 12-13, first part of 18,

Practically all the necessary changes and improvements have already been made at the request of the Department by the Roman Catholic Boarding Schools. It should be remembered that the new arrangement placed the Roman Catholic Authorities in a much better financial position. During the first year from the 1st April, 1911, to the 31st March, 1912, the Roman Catholic Schools received $70,186.00 more than they would have received under the old arrangement.

Clause 18 of the Contract.

This clause is characterized as "particularly objectionable and dangerous"; it is not intended to be either, and it is no wise harmful to the interests of the school. In these cases the contract is made with a Bishop of the Roman Catholic Church to conduct the school for five years. It would be contrary to the spirit of the contract to convert the school into a Protestant Institution or to alter the form of religious instruction to be given.

"Cause", of course, means good and sufficient cause. We cannot remove a teacher or instructor for any frivolous reason.

4th. That the Department has entered upon a policy of establishing day schools which conflicts with the interests of the Boarding Schools and that an attempt is being made to secularize the schools.

Quotations are made from general remarks in my report for 1910-11. In generalizing I state that in many places
places Indian day schools are quite sufficient to meet the educational needs of the Indians. I do not refer to schools in the Western Provinces nor to Roman Catholic Schools, I simply state what is a fact, that in many places day schools are quite sufficient to meet the educational needs of the Indians.
