Honorable Sir,

Referring to the memorial addressed to you on the 24th ultimo, resulting from the consideration by the Bishops at Regina of the contract for the conduct and management and maintenance of Indian Boarding Schools, the undersigned find that the following was omitted therefrom:

Clause 3 (a) provides "That no child shall be admitted to the school who is under seven years of age."

Regulations respecting the education of Indian children were made by Order in Council of the 10th November, 1894, and, in amending those Regulations by Order in Council of the 16th August, 1908, the age of admission of children to school was left at seven years.

There is nothing to show that any Order in Council has since been made changing the age; and, if none were made fixing the age at seven years, then, it is submitted, the parties to the contract have no power to go beyond the Regulations established by Order in Council and fix the age of admission at seven years.

Such a change is undesirable. The Indians have become used to the requirement that the education of their children should begin at six years of age, and it is of the utmost importance that there should be continuity in our educational policy.

The change will tend to make the Indians sceptical of the wisdom of the Department, for they will reason that, if six years...
of age was found to be too young in November 1910, in another year or so seven years may be found to be too young, and that gradually the view of the authorities of the Department as to education may come into accord with their own.

The undersigned cannot conceive that any experience gained since August 1908, has led to the change. The undersigned are not aware that any educational authority of wide repute has recently expressed an opinion that would justify the change. The general tendency is not to advance the years of age at which schooling should begin. And what may be urged in favor of the early schooling of white children has ten-fold force in the case of Indian children, for they must "be caught young" to be saved from what is on the whole the degenerating influences of their home environment.

The change in the age is a serious drawback to the schools whose managers have, in accordance with the policy in vogue up to the time of the contract, arranged for the admission of, and now have in the schools, children under seven years of age, for whom, under the contract, payment will be refused.

The undersigned would, therefore, respectfully ask that Clause (a) be amended by substituting "six" for "seven".

2 It is essential to the success of the contract system of Indian schools that the Department should pursue, at least, a policy which will not run counter to them. Recent happenings, however, give the impression that, instead of a supporting policy, the Department has entered upon and is pressing a policy which is bound, in the measure of its extension, to make against the success of the contract schools.

Under your immediate predecessor in office a very
marked departure was made in Canada's Indian educational policy.

Up to then day schools had not been regarded as sufficient, or, indeed, wholly efficient, agencies of Indian education. It was the proved inadequacy of the day school system that led the Government under Sir John MacDonald, to provide for the establishment and maintenance of Indian residential schools. As early as 1890 that great statesman wrote:

"The greatest obstacle to the successful education of Indian children at day school consists in the irregularity of their attendance, caused in part by the neglect of their parents to oblige them to attend, and by frequent absence of many families from the reserves while fishing, hunting and berry picking."

And anyone with more than a perfunctory knowledge of Indian conditions, as they generally obtain today in Western Canada, is aware that the hope of the permanent advancement of the aborigines lies in the education of the children in residential schools, where the ordinary work of day schools can be supplemented by domestic, manual, agricultural, and suchlike training, and the lack of proper home environment supplied by an atmosphere favorable to moral culture and character building.

In his report of the 1st January 1889, the Hon. Edgar Dewdney, then Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and a man who had long practical experience as Indian Commissioner in the West, wrote:

"The superiority of the boarding over that of the day school system as a means for the enlightenment and elevation, both morally and intellectually, of Indian youth, is I think, unquestionable. The extension of the same to several of the..."
reserves should, in my opinion, be regarded with satisfaction by all who really take an interest in the advancement of the Indian race.

In his report of the 15th January 1891, the same gentleman wrote:

"It would be highly desirable, if it were practicable, to obtain entire possession of all Indian children after they attain to the age of seven or eight years, and keep them at schools of the industrial type until they had a thorough course of instruction, not only in the ordinary subjects taught at public schools, but in some useful and profitable trade, or in agriculture, as the aptitude of the pupil might indicate he was best fitted for. Were such a course adopted the solution of that problem, designated the Indian question, would probably be effected sooner than it is likely to be under the present system" ..........................

"The system of absorption of Indian children by boarding and industrial training schools should be widely extended, and every effort to make the residence therein of Indian children of the proper age to be admitted the rule, and not, as it is present, the exception, should be unremitting. Apart from other, and obviously more important advantages of which an extended policy of the kind, if it were systematically pursued, would doubtless be the result, it would certainly be the most economical in the end, as the Indian children trained at such institutions would acquire practical knowledge which would fit them to become useful members of society".

In his report of the 31st December 1894, as Deputy
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Mr. Hayter Reed wrote:

"The extension of educational work is being chiefly carried out in the direction of industrial and semi-industrial institutions, in which the children not only get the positive advantages of instruction superior to what could be given them on the reserves, but are removed from the regarding influences of contact with them."

Viewed in the light of conditions, the results produced by residential schools have been gratifying. No such results could have been produced by day schools. And it may in fairness be said that, if the unremitting efforts recommended by Mr. Dewdney had been persisted in, the result would have been still more gratifying. But it is a regrettable fact that very many officials of the Department make no real effort to secure the attendance of Indian children at institution maintained out of the public revenues for the advancement of the Indians. With the active co-operation of Indian Agents and the members of agency staffs the sphere of usefulness of residential schools could be easily extended.

Not only has such co-operation in recent years been sadly lacking, but a policy has been inaugurated of establishing day schools that seem designed to make more difficult the securing of pupils for the residential schools. It is an inexplicable policy that with one hand builds up, at considerable public expense, a system, well considered, matured, and of proved efficiency, and with the other hand gets to work, also at the public cost, to elaborate and put in extensive operation a discredited scheme of Indian education, which, if successful in drawing pupils, must, in the measure of its success, be destructive.
Of a system created at great expense and well tried.

To a considerable extent the Indians, particularly of the West, are still nomadic. The number that has regularly settled down to farm life is still relatively small. Many who farm to some extent still move about at seasons. It is mainly the graduates of residential schools who have settled down as tillers of the soil, and too many—of them yet such subsistence farmers, and very many who have taken, in greater or less degree, to the cultivation of land are yet without such homes as furnish the environment essential to completing the educational work that can be done in day schools.

In the summer, tepee life is common amongst the great majority of the Indians of the West. In the winter, they are, with rare exceptions, housed in still ventilated shacks, composed most generally of an undivided ground floor and a loft. The sleeping arrangements are the crudest, and the ground floor is often used as a sleeping place by numerous dogs, as well as by the men, women and children. The air is foul, the place is dirty. Its circumstances make against wholesome cleanliness of body, and are not favorable to mental or moral development. How can improvement be looked for in the race if children, when out of school, are subject to such degenerating environments?

It was just to save the children from it, and to supply, with the ordinary school training, a physically healthy and morally wholesome environment that the residential schools were established and are maintained at much expense by the Government of Canada.

It seems strange that synchronously with an extra effort to strengthen and develop the boarding schools, the Department should have taken measures to extend the day school system into the very territories which the boarding schools depend upon—-
as feeders, and at the same time enter upon a costly experiment
to render the day schools more effective competitors of the
boarding schools. It seems to make the Department's educational
policy a process of building up and tearing down.

In his report, dated 1st June 1910, the Superintendent
of Indian Education states:

"In many places these (day) schools are quite sufficient
to meet the educational needs of the Indians".

But a little farther on he has to acknowledge "the
severe deterrent of poverty is often present; some children have
no proper clothing to wear during winter, and the provision of any
food for a luncheon at the noon hour is neglected of sheer necessity".

In his last report he repeats the statement as to the suf-
ficiency of these schools, and then goes on to say:

"Aid has to be given to poor children in the supply of footwear and
clothing, and the plan of furnishing a warm mid-day meal has been
also continued with the gratifying results. In several districts the
transportation of the children to and from school has assisted in
maintaining a regular attendance".

But Mr. Inspector Jackson, in his report of the 31st
March 1911, on Okanase Day School, states:

"Really no progress is seen since last year, owing to irreg-
ular attendance. The average attendance for the quarter ended March
31st 1910, was three. The average attendance for the quarter ending June
30th will be seven, and this increase, the teacher reports is due to
the warm mid-day meal.........................With the exception of
one pupil, all are in ABC class".

In reporting on Upper Fairfield Day School, Mr.
Jackson states:

"At this inspection there were eight present........

I can see a reason for the irregular attendance. The roads are so bad, it is almost impossible for the smaller children to get through and they have not clothing and footwear for the bad roads and severe weather...."

As to the Roseau River Day School, which is classed "undenominational", he reports:

"Miss Gordon appears capable of imparting knowledge if the pupils could be furnished her. She says, it is impossible to get the children to attend regularly, on account of their parents moving away on their hunting trips and taking their children with them. Then they do come back on the reserve, there is always the difficulty of getting the children started back to school again, lack of clothes, &c., being the excuse..........................

There is always a mid-day meal, and when the parents go away, the children between six and twelve are kept by the teacher". Mr. Jackson thinks that "this is one of the places where a little boarding school might be established."

Of the Oak River Day School Mr. Jackson writes:

"Mr. McGraw was the last teacher here, and he tells me that the Indians would not, or could not, send their children to school, by could not, I mean lack of clothes and footwear. This is one of the points at which a small boarding school would do well."

Rev. John Semmens, on his tour of inspection, found ten children at Brokenhead River Day School, and remarks:

"During portions of the years there was a lack of wood for carrying on school work, and some irregularity resulted".

On the South St. Peter's Day School he states:
Number of children enrolled 35, but the average attendance for the three months was only 7.1. This was very unsatisfactory.

But he found only five at the North St. Peter's Day School.

Mr. Inspector Graham does not give specific information as to actual attendance at time of inspection and average attendance. He gives prominence to the new features that are to make day schools supply the place of boarding schools. To the Goose Mountain Day School an addition has been made containing a kitchen and pantry. There is also a garden. But the provision has had to be made for boarding some of the children, for he says: "Some seven or eight children, whose homes are at a distance, live in a log house near the school and are looked after and fed by an Indian man and his wife."

That is the newest improvement on residential schools for Indians as conceived by Sir John Macdonald and the practical men whose opinions have been quoted earlier in this communication. For the ordinary mortal it is difficult to conceive how children, seven or eight of them, can be better cared for in a log house by an Indian man and his wife than they would be at a regular boarding school.

Mr. Graham tells us that at the Assiniboine Day School "the attendance was at one time as high as twenty four, but during the severe weather it has fallen off considerably", but this time he found twelve children in attendance" and was greatly pleased to note the progress that has been made during the short time the school has been opened".

Mr. Inspector Chisholm reports:
"On Mistawasis reserve a comfortable teacher's dwelling has been provided, with pupils' dining-room attached; and by conveying the children from the more distant parts to and from school a very fair attendance has been maintained."

He gives no details as to attendance, so it is impossible to ascertain exactly what is meant by "a very fair attendance".

He goes on: "The school on the Big River reserve is a suitable building and properly equipped; and at the interval very satisfactory work has been done. However, ..............it has not been found possible to secure a full or uniform attendance. The value of the work has been very much impaired in consequence."

"The average attendance at the school at Allatakakop's reserve is less than one-third of the school population".

On the Wahapaton reserve the farmer, Inspector Chisholm tells us, acts also as teacher, but that he has "little capacity for school work, and the attendance at best is poor". But we are assured that there has been "latterly a slight improvement... through the assistance of the farmer's wife" in preparing the noon meal for the children (there are but eight of them all told) and in training them in sewing and knitting.

It is upon such "slight improvements" that the Superintendent of Indian Education erects the opinion paraded in his public report as to the sufficiency of day schools for Indians; and it is from such evidence that he draws his conclusion as to the "practical beneficial result" that has followed from the taking up of "instruction in plain sewing, knitting and mending."

Mr Inspector Markle reports that the average attendance at Godfish Lake School for the year 1910 was 8.3; that "there were no children present when he visited Saddle Lake Day School on..."
February 17th last: that the "Whitefish Day School" has not been in operation during the past years; that he has heard that old Mr.'s Day School on the Blackfoot reserve is a "failure", and he adds this striking remark, which apparently has escaped the eye of the Superintendent of Education,—"It is not convenient for the children to attend any school other than a residential one."

The reports from which the foregoing quotations have been made appear as appendices to the recently published Report of the Superintendent of Indian Education, in which Mr. Scott speaks favorably upon the work of day school.

It has in the last few years become sadly and increasingly apparent that Indian policy has not always been shaped by teachings of experience.

In March 1911, His Grace the Archbishop of Saint Boniface was compelled by a sense of duty to submit to your predecessor a protest against the then proposed erection of an undenominational day school on the File Hills reserve. Despite that protest, a building under the guise of an hospital, has been erected by the Department of Indian Affairs. It contains two small rooms, 12 x 12, which are designated hospital wards, but the Superintendent of Education in his report calls it "a day school". Not far away from where this school, which may even now be about to start operation, stands, the Dominion Government recently completed and opened a large boarding school, conducted under Presbyterian auspices, in the place of the Regina School which was closed some time ago. Within some twenty miles is the large Qu'Appelle school, rebuilt at the public expense.
And in need of a recruiting ground to ensure its effective continuance, and thereby a return in results for the public expenditure.

Surely it is rather strange for the Department to spend public money in building that elaborate day school between these two residential schools, and in specially equipping it with kitchen, dining-room, sick-rooms, teacher's and nurse's quarters so that it may more effectively interfere with the success of the two residential schools.

It cannot be denied that it is deliberately intended to interfere with the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, for a prohibition against the recruiting for the pupils within the territory it is planned to serve was formally issued by the Department, and withdrawn at the emphatic protest of the said Archbishop.

And then as to denominational control of that and other day schools under the new policy: It has been expressly stated by the Department that the day school at Pine Hills was to be a secular school.

It is observed that the Superintendent of Indian Education gives, in only a comparatively few instances, the denominational auspices under which day schools are conducted. Inspectors Graham and Chisholm do not give the denominational auspices of any of the day schools mentioned in their reports. It certainly looks as if a concerted effort has been made to secularize our Indian day schools. But the law provides that Indian day schools are to be denominational. Have certain officials Department decided to evoke another strife creating school question.

On behalf of himself and his venerable colleagues who signed the memorial, first referred to, respecting Indian boarding schools
the undersigned would respectfully ask your consideration of what is set forth herein, believing that you will readily see the necessity, in the public interest, as well as in the interest of the Indian wards of the Government, of corrective action being taken in respect to the Indian educational party that has come into sway.

Honorable Sir,

The undersigned, at a meeting held on the occasion of the induction into his see of the recently appointed bishop of Regina, have had under consideration the contract for the conduct and management and maintenance of Indian Boarding Schools entered into between your predecessors in office and the Principals of such said schools as are under the auspices of the Catholic Church.

The draft of the contract was submitted by the then Superintendent General at a conference held at Ottawa on the 8th November, last, between him and certain officials of the headquarters staff of the Department of Indian Affairs, on the one part, and representatives of Churches Conducting Indian schools, on the other part.

The representatives of the Churches had not been previously advised of the terms or tenor of the contract; and the careful consideration which the undersigned have given it compels them to the conclusion that the said representatives had not that opportunity of deliberating it which the importance of the contract demanded.

The undersigned find that the contract, hurriedly entered into, is lacking in certain essentials and in several
respects faulty.

They, therefore, beg to be permitted to recite the defects they find in the contract, and to set forth in some detail the reasons of their finding:

1. The contract lacks statutory authority. In the sections of the Indian Act treating particularly of schools, being Sections 9, 10 and 11, of Chapter 81, Revised Statutes, 1906, there is no mention of contract schools; nor is any authority conferred, by those or any other sections of that Act, or by any statute of the Parliament of Canada, upon the Governor in Council, or upon the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, to enter into contracts for the conduct and management of Indian schools.

A contract by which the party of the second part, i.e., the representative of the Church under whose auspices the school named therein is conducted, assumes large responsibilities and is obligated to incur outlays on works of a permanent nature, in addition to the continuous burden of expenditure incident to maintenance and management, should have the sanction necessary to afford the amplest security to the party aforesaid. As it is, the party of the part, i.e., the Superintendent General, can not, and does not, bind himself to perform his essential part of the bargain, that is to meet the payments to be made in consideration of the due performance of the work contracted to be done by the party of the second part. The clause marked "V" stipulates that there shall be no liability to make any payment to the school under the contract "should the amount voted by Parliament and applicable towards payment .......be at any time expended during the continuance..."
Up to the adoption of the contract system a policy had been in operation which in its working was somewhat elastic. Under it the Department undertook to contribute to the maintenance of denominationally controlled residential schools for Indians through the payment of a per capita grant. But the policy was not bound in rigid bands; and contributions to the schools were made by the Department in more ways than through the per capita grant. Contributions were made to help in the erection of certain school buildings, the ownership of which was recognized to be in the Church under whose auspices these institutions were to be conducted. And when considerable expenditure had been, or was to be, undertaken for additions, improvements or repairs, the Department not infrequently came to the assistance of the Church by meeting in whole or in part the expenditure. The per capita grants paid under that policy cannot, therefore, be taken as the full measure of the liability which the Department in practice assumed in respect of those schools.

Now that policy has passed from the easy elastic state to the rigid contract form, under which aid can neither be obtained for nor given to those schools beyond the fixed per capita grant. And the party of the first part is tightly bound to the performance of onerous obligations to the State, while the State appears to be bound not at all to make the compensatory payments.

It is true that the agreement, in the beginning, sets forth that the Superintendent General represents His Majesty the King; but, as there is no Parliamentary authority for thus assuming monetary obligations, nor apparently any sanction by
the Governor in Council of the contract, the undersigned doubt whether the Superintendent could constitutionally bind the Crown to the terms of the contract. Yet it is obvious that there should be equally binding obligations upon both parties to the contract. And when a public policy of import assumes contractual form, it seems but the part of wisdom to have it sanctioned by the highest authority.

The undersigned, therefore, respectfully submit for your consideration the advisability of the Indian Act being so amended at the present session of the Dominion Parliament as to duly authorize the system of contract schools adopted by the Department of Indian Affairs. And to bring the proposal before you in concrete form, they beg leave to suggest the following amendment:—

"That Section 10 of the said Act be hereby amended by adding the following Sub-Section thereto:—

"The Superintendent General may, with the approval of the Governor in Council, enter into contracts with any church or religious denomination carrying on missionary work among the Indians for the conduct and maintenance of such industrial or boarding schools, or of any industrial or boarding schools established for Indians, with the approval, consent or concurrence of the Superintendent General, by any such church or religious denomination, whether the buildings in connection therewith be or be not the property of the Crown, and may assume under such contracts the payment of per capita grants to any or all of such schools for the education, keep and proper care of children, in whole or in part of Indian blood, admitted under rules or regulations made by the Superintendent General."
from time to time, or with his approval or consent, and in accordance with the terms of the contracts."

Such an amendment would give the desired sanction and security. It would give to the contract system that element of permanency which is essential to its success. Without adequate guarantee of stability and reasonable surety of compensatory payment for work done, there is no sufficient warrant for the party of the second part incurring capital expenditure and assuming costly and onerous obligations under the contract. That is so obvious that the undersigned can not conceive of objection being taken to such an amendment, except on factious grounds. But if objection were taken, it seems to the undersigned that this would be a ready and ample answer:

The contract system was adopted by the late administration; the late minister entered into contracts with representatives of different churches for the conduct and maintenance of Indian schools; the contracts have gone into operation; they lack proper sanction; they were entered into without requisite authority; all that is now sought is to make them regular, and to afford reasonable security for the expenditure which has already been and is being incurred under them.

2. And, now, the undersigned, apologizing for having to continue to trespass, and to such great extent, upon your very valuable and so much occupied time, venture to deal, serially, with the fault in the contract itself.

Sub-Clause "b" of Clause 4 provides—

"That no Half-breed child shall be admitted...unless Indian children can not be obtained to complete the number..."
authorized by Article I., Section I., and Section 4. (a) of this agreement, in which event the Superintendent General may in his discretion permit the admission of any Half-breed child; but the Superintendent General will not pay any grant for any such Half-breed pupil provided under Article II., Section I., of this agreement, nor any part of the cost of its maintenance or education whatever.

That, the undersigned submit, is a very drastic provision and pregnant of such evil. It is contrary to the policy which long obtained, and against which no reasonable objection has been or can be urged. And in a measure, it is obviously ultra vires.

Half-breeds may be grouped into three fairly well defined classes.

1. Those who live, in varying degrees of conditions, the ordinary settled life of the country.

2. Those who live, in varying degrees, the Indian mode of life.

3. Those who - and they form the most unfortunate class in the community - are the illegitimate offspring of Indian women, and of whom white men are the begetters.

Those of the first class make no claim upon the Government of the Dominion for the education of their children; nor has any such claim, as far as the knowledge of the undersigned goes, been made in their behalf.

The third class are entitled to participate in the benefits of the Indian schools; and in so far as the afore quoted provision of the contract is designed to exclude them from such participation
it is ultra vires of the parties to the contract, or of any authority save that of the Dominion Parliament itself.

Section 12, the very first of the Sections of the Indian Act dealing with "Membership of Indian Bands," enacts as follows:

"Any illegitimate child may, unless he has, with the consent of the band whereof the father or mother of such child is a member, shared in the distribution moneys of such band for a period exceeding two years, be, at any time, excluded from the membership thereof by the Superintendent General."

It follows from that, that the illegitimate child of an Indian woman having membership in a band is ipso facto a member of the band to which the mother belongs, and can only be removed from membership in such band by the Superintendent General, if he sees fit to exercise the power conferred upon him by the law; and that, if the child has participated for over two years in the moneys of the band, with the consent of the band (and acquiescence constitutes consent within the meaning of the provision), then there is no authority under the law for the removal of such child from membership. Such child is legally entitled to recognition as having full membership in the mother's band, unless the Superintendent General exercises his right of exclusion within the period aforesaid, which exclusion can not be by way of general order or act, but must be by specific order or act in each case; and every such child not so excluded is entitled to all the benefits of band membership, including Indian educational privileges; and no such child can be contracted out of such privileges.
When Indian treaties are made the illegitimate children are taken into and given all the benefits of treaty irrespective of the blood of the fathers. In years after the existing treaties were made, subsequently born illegitimate children of Indian treaty women were excluded and payment of annuity money for them or on their behalf was refused. That policy appears to have been adopted to discourage illegitimate breeding. How far it has operated in that direction those who have been for years in close contact with Indians know best. The undersigned are not aware of the form or the order or act by which such policy was put in operation, but they know that its operation has varied in times and places. Such children have been by one Indian Agent recognized as having band membership, by another they have been excluded; one year they are admitted, another year they are debarred.

But whatever be the object of the policy of exclusion, whatever be the variations in its application, or whatever be its results, such of those children as are being excluded under it are being excluded illegally, unless each such child has been specifically excluded from band membership by the Superintendent General as aforesaid.

The undersigned would, therefore, respectfully ask that, if the view of the case of those children as herein stated appears to you to be correct, you would have the goodness to issue an order which will promptly bring the policy and practice of the Department with respect to them into full accord with the law.

As to the second class of Half-breeds, the undersigned at once admit that they present a difficult educational problem. But the very difficulty affords a strong reason against drawing a hard and fast line such as is drawn in the agreement.
This second class of half-breeds may be divided into three groups:

(1) Those who generally live apart from Indians, but follow somewhat the Indian mode of life, fishing, hunting and trapping, and to some extent engage in freighting, a business which narrows as railways extend. To this group may be added those who hang about towns, doing odd jobs when necessity compels them to work, and eking out a precarious existence, oftentimes, unfortunately, after a fashion which makes not for their own or the community's good.

(2) Those who live in the vicinity of Indian Reserves, mingle more or less freely with Indians, and follow the Indian mode of life.

(3) Those who live on Indian Reserves, with tacit or expressed consent, and live the life of Indians.

When, and for years after, Indian residential schools were established, half-breeds of the three groups of this second class, as well as those of the third class already dealt with herein, were admitted. In the early years of these schools, when all existing were classed as industrial, the whole expense of the cost and management was met out of the public revenue, and there was then no possibility of dividing, as is now done, pupils into grant-earning and non-grant-earning classes. And after the Departmental system of contributing by per capita grant to the support of residential schools was adopted, which was during the incumbency of the Indian Commissionership by Mr. Hayter Reed, half-breeds of the second, as well as of the third class, continued to be admitted as grant earners.
now and then, perhaps, there being a refusal in the case of a child whose parents would come within the first group of the second class, while quite close to the fringe of the first class. But, indeed, the practice of the Department was very liberal.

Soon after 1896, certain officials of the administrative branch of the Department at headquarters, whose animus in the matter was evidently begotten of theory formed in the closet rather than of contact with conditions, succeeded in having a rule made excluding all half-breed children from Indian schools. When, however, reasoned objection was taken to that rule before the then Superintendent General, the Honorable Clifford Sifton, he set it aside and directed that the children of Half-breeds living on or in the vicinity of Indian Reserves, and following the Indian mode of life, should be admitted as grant-earners to Indian residential schools. The rule then made by him, when fairly followed, covered pretty fully the classes of Half-breeds whose education can only be properly provided for in such schools. Shortly after Mr. Oliver took office, Mr. Sifton's sane rule, if not formally rescinded, was allowed to lapse into desuetude, and the rule which had, on good grounds, been set aside, was revived, put into operation, and finally crystallized in Sub-Clause "b" of Clause 4. of the contract.

The Half-breed children now excluded from Indian schools are in a most unfortunate position. Their "homes" are not homes in our sense of the word. They dwell in tepees or huts in shacks. Their environment militates against moral and physical development, and breaks down instead of building up character. What is so readily and so often charged against a people of mixed blood is the result, not of blood, but of environment.

It is begging the question for the Department to take
the position, as it has, that it is duty of the Provincial Governments to provide education for half-breeds. As you very well know, and as anyone at all familiar with conditions knows, there are no Provincial institutions in which the required kind of education can be provided for half-breeds of the second and third classes herein described. Even if the white rate-payers of school districts were willing to admit such children to their day schools, not as Pariahs, but on a footing of equality with their own sons and daughters, the sad condition of these half-breed children would not, in any effective degree, be ameliorated. As educational agencies day schools presuppose a home environment that makes, at least, not against mental and moral development. And anyone that is cognizant of the conditions that obtain must know that our Indian residential schools are the only existing agencies for the proper up-bringing of those unfortunate children. If they are excluded from these schools, what can they be expected to become but outcasts and menaces to society?

The Department seems to have acted upon the supposition that the Government of Canada assumed the burden of providing for the education of Indian children in residential schools solely to meet obligations imposed by treaties with Indians; and from that hypothesis to have reached the conclusion that the Dominion Government is not justified in increasing the burden by extending the benefits of the system to half-breeds who are not recognized by it as having membership in Indian bands. But the man who laid the foundation of the system, Sir John MacDonald, had no such narrow view.
Under his administration the policy was adopted and followed of admitting Half-breeds of the aforesaid second and third classes into those schools. And that policy was in accord with the basic purpose of the system; for such schools were established not merely to meet treaty obligations towards Indians, but as a means of preventing, in the public interest, a race of wild men growing up whose hands would be against all men and all men's hands against them.

The Government of Canada never took the position in the past that it had no obligations at all as to Half-breeds. It recognized them as possessing, in a degree, an aboriginal title to the land of this country, and took measures to compensate for its extinguishment. In other ways and at different times it helped these people. It gave to the children of certain of them the right of entry as regular pupils of Indian schools, and in doing so created a right in the nature of a vested right, and destruction of which is an injustice, and against the interest of the commonwealth.

The undersigned, therefore, respectfully submit that the afore-quoted excluding clause of the contract should be expunged; and that the old and wise policy, or, at the very least, Mr. Sifton's rule, be reverted to and made permanent by incorporation in the contract.

3. Clause 6 of the contract badly provides that the "school shall be conducted under such regulations as may from time to time be approved by His Excellency the Governor General in Council."
Those regulations, which would be framed in the Department, and might, in the pressure of Governmental business, or in the ordinary course of routine matters, to be approved of, could easily be so framed as to practically exclude, or unduly interfere with, the teaching of religion.

It is true that under clause 9 the managers of the school are required "to provide... teachers and officers qualified to give the pupils religious instruction at the proper times." But that provision inferentially makes the Superintendent General the sole and final judge of the qualification of "teachers and officers" to impart "religious instruction," and of what are "the proper times" at which such "religious instruction" should be given. It occurs to the undersigned that no theological a function as that would not be pleasantly assumed by a Minister of State in Canada. Ethical training being wisely recognized as essential in Indian education by the Government of Canada from the very beginning of its relations with Indians, Indian schools were put under the auspices of different religious denominations carrying on missionary work among them to make it impossible the clash which might occur between the views of a minister of the Crown as to the nature and scope of the ethical training that should be imparted and the tenets of the church to which the particular Indians to be so trained belonged. Indeed this provision of Clause 9 seems to the undersigned to have been intended rather for undenominational than for denominational schools, and to have been drafted by one holding the view that religious instruction can be adequately imparted irrespective of ecclesiastical dogma. From that view the undersigned must, of course, most unhesitatingly and most emphatically dissent.
The undersigned are convinced that you will readily agree that it is the part of wisdom to obviate all possibility of conflict as to religious teaching in the administration of the contract system of Indian schools; and that to that end it would be advisable to have an explicit provision in the contract securing the teaching of religion in the school in accordance with the tenets of the church under whose auspices the school is conducted.

They would, therefore, suggest that the said Clause 6 be amended by adding thereto the following proviso:

"Provided that no such regulation shall prohibit, or interfere with the teaching of religion in the said school in accordance with the tenets of the church under the auspices of which the said school is conducted;

4. By Clause 8 of the contract it is covenanted

"Not to employ, except on probation for a period not exceeding six months, at said school any teacher or instructor until evidence satisfactory to the Superintendent General has been submitted to him that such teacher or instructor is able to converse with the pupils under his charge in English, and is able to speak and write the English language fluently and correctly, and possesses such other qualifications as, in the opinion of the Superintendent General, may be necessary."

That is a hard and fast provision, compliance with which is practically impossible; yet its violation in any respect would vitiate the contract.

It is not only required that every "teacher" and "instructor" shall be able to speak and to write the English language "fluently and correctly", but the party responsible for the conduct of the school under the contract must furnish the
with evidence satisfactory", and within "six months" of the date of the employment of every teacher and instructor, that every "such teacher or instructor.... is able to speak and write the English language fluently and correctly."........

It is required by Clause 9 of the contract that "gardening, farming, and care of stock..., cooking, laundry-work, needle-work, general housewifery and dairy-work" shall be taught.

Therefore, the farmers, gardeners, and stockmen, the cooks, laundresses, and seamstresses, the house-keepers and the dairy-women must be able to speak and write the English language fluently and correctly;" for each of them is an instructor under the contract, and the party of the second part covenants that each shall "instruct the pupils of the school" in his or her line of work.

Now, everybody knows that there are cooks and dairy-women and house-wifery experts, laundresses, and seamstresses, gardeners and farmers and stockmen, competent in their various callings, and good, practical instructors in the work thereof, who, while they speak English well enough for properly training others along their own vocational lines, cannot "speak and write English fluently and correctly." They are exceptions who do.
We understand that something has already been done by the Department to mitigate the rigor of the clause we object to. Therefore our considerations in the first edition of this memo are no more relevant, and we suppressed them. Still we believe that something more should be done to make things less stringent. For instance, we suggest the elimination of the word instructor.
If it be necessary to convenant to secure the teaching of English in schools where the force of necessity compels its being learned, let the following be substituted:
"8. To duly provide for the pupils of the said school being taught to speak, read and write the English language to the same extent that pupils are so taught in the ordinary schools of the country."

Such a provision would secure, if special security in that respect be required, adequate teaching to Indian pupils. If in addition, they hear and become in some measure familiar with French, no danger to the commonwealth will result therefrom, nor will they be thereby the less well equipped for the battle of life.

5. The conditions intended to be imposed by Clauses 12, 13 and the first part of 18 should have been more aptly, clearly and comprehensively expressed. They are as follows:

"12. To keep and maintain the school buildings and premises, to supply proper sanitation and sanitary appliances, and to keep the buildings free from flies, insects and vermin"

"13. To maintain the buildings at the said school and the school premises when they are the property of the (blank) in good condition and repair, the whole to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General."

"18. To make any change or alteration in the school building or premises......."

In considering those provisions reference must be made to the "Memorandum" which appears immediately before the draft the contract in the blue booklet entitled "Correspondence and Agreement relating to the Maintenance and Management of Indian Boarding Schools."

The following are excerpts therefrom:
SCHOOL BUILDINGS CLASS 'A'.

The buildings owned by the church which would entitle the school to a per capita grant of $100.00 in the eastern division and $125.00 in the western division should conform to the following general specifications:

1. Substantial building either of brick, stone, cement or wood in good state of repair.

2. To be built on a stone or cement foundation with a light airy basement of full size of main building with cement floor.

3. Pure and plentiful water supply distributed throughout the building.

4. A proper system of sanitary water-closets, drainage, and disposal of sewage.

5. Hospital accommodation for the isolation of pupils ill with infectious disease or tuberculosis.

6. Modern system of ventilation in dormitories and class-rooms and sufficient air space in dormitories and class-rooms for the number of pupils accommodated.

7. Modern heating apparatus, hot water, steam or hot air.

8. Sufficient area of land for farms and gardens and practical industrial work, where such work can be carried on.

SCHOOL BUILDINGS CLASS 'B'.

The buildings owned by the government which would entitle the management to $90.00 per capita in the eastern division and $100.00 in the western division class must conform to the requirements of clauses 5, 6, and 8, of class 'A'.

SCHOOL BUILDINGS CLASS 'C'.

Buildings owned by the churches which do not in all particulars conform to the specifications in class 'A' and 'B' and which are nevertheless sanitary and kept in a good state of repair, and which would entitle the school to $80.00 per capita in the eastern division and $100.00 per capita in the western division. The buildings in this class must conform to the requirements of clauses 5, 6, and 8, of class 'A'.
The specific re-statement in the paragraph dealing with schools in Class C of the requirements of Class A which have to be met by them makes it clear that the general statement in that paragraph that the schools coming within Class C are to be "nevertheless sanitary and kept in a good state of repair" can not fairly be interpreted to mean that those schools are to be called upon to meet in regard to sanitariness the specific and costly requirements of Class A, the schools of which class, in consideration of the more costly and extensive improvement required, are paid $25.00 per capita more than the schools Class C. The buildings to be scheduled in Class C are described as "buildings owned by the churches which do not in all particulars conform to the specifications in Class A," what of the specific requirements of that class are to be provided in their case being the things described in section b, c and d of the paragraph describing the requirements of Class A, namely, isolated hospital accommodation, modern system of ventilation, sufficient air space, and adequate land for farms and gardens, where farming and gardening can be carried on. As to sanitariness, all that can be insisted upon is that such school buildings shall be made and kept sanitary as similar buildings are ordinarily made and kept sanitary, without "light airy basement," "water supply distributed," "system of sanitary water-closets, drainage and disposal of sewage," all of which requirements specifically set forth as necessary for Class A, but are not so set forth as required for Class C. And the reason for their not being set forth as requisite for the latter classification is quite obvious; for, if these costly things had to be provided for entry into Class C, and to secure the per capita grant of $100.00 payable to schools in that class, it would be the veriest improvidence not to meet the other
requirements of Class A and secure the per capita grant of $125.00 especially as, in a climate marked by severe cold in winter, "modern heating apparatus", a requirement of Class A which is strangely not insisted upon, as are the other things mentioned for Class C, would be essential to a system of water distribution, water-flushing closets and pipe drainage throughout buildings, which are insisted upon, on the reports made on certain schools by a sanitary expert employed by the Department last summer to examine the buildings, after they had been, under special instructions from the Department, examined, not by the School Inspector, but by the regular Inspectors of Agencies, and on their reports classified for the purposes of the contract by the Department.

The changes and improvements ordered are, in almost every case in which the undersigned have been advised of the said experts' specifications, so vastly out of proportion to the building itself as to be quite absurd. Take, for instance, the school at Selma. It has had, since its establishment, never more than an authorized attendance of twenty. It is classes C. Yet it is required that the building shall be done over and entirely remodelled. Stone foundations are to be changed, ceiling made higher, windows enlarged, and hard wood floors laid and oiled and finished in shellac. Each dormitory is to be provided with "one water closet...automatic low tank combination operated with push button" and "one cast iron enamelled bath." Galvanized iron tanks are to be put on the second floor, from which water is to be distributed throughout the building by gravitation; and the floors and walls are to be strengthened to sustain the tanks. A sewage system, with septic tanks, is to be installed.
And all those things are in addition to the specific requirements of Class C., as to isolated hospital et cetera.

The undersigned know of only one school classed C., in the territory toured by the said expert that would warrant the assuming of such burdens. That school is Ermineskin's at Hobbema. And because certain of the improvements called for have been made and the others are to be gone on with, its classification should be changed to A.

Over and above the objections herein made to the extensive and costly improvements demanded, on an unwarranted interpretation of the official description of the requirements of Class C., the undersigned regard the requirement of isolated hospital accommodation as excessive.

An isolated hospital, a building standing alone and devoted to the treatment of virulently contagious diseases, necessitates special provision for heating, special culinary arrangements, special provision for laundering, and an addition to the staff of the school to which it appertains.

Now a school with twenty or thirty, or even forty or so pupils, can not in reason be expected to bear the burden of building, equipping and maintaining such an hospital.

Where outside of the Indian Department is such a requirement dreamed of? How many hamlets, villages, and even towns of the west have isolated hospitals? And where there are such hospitals, the health regulations permit persons struck with certain infectious diseases being kept at their own homes if proper isolation can be effected. And for proper isolation, even in cases of scarlet fever and diphtheria, it is not necessary that the stricken ones
should be put under a different roof, and those suffering from
one disease separated by a doorless wall from those taken down with
another, as Dr. Lafferty insisted should be done at Crowfoot's
School on the Blackfoot Reserve.

The isolated hospitals demanded are to have accommodation
it is stipulated, for "infectious disease or tuberculosis." It
would be an unprecedented, and a dangerous and cruel proceeding,
to put tubercular cases with cases of scarlet fever, diphtheria or
small-pox. Phthisis is not virulently contagious. The best
medical opinion, the undersigned are given to understand, is that
it can be safely treated without isolation, if simple precautions
are taken; and, indeed, it is well known that very many suffering
from that dread disease are, under medical direction, so treated
in homes that, to say the least, have not better accommodation
than is afforded by the infirmaries already provided at the schools.

The Department itself did not provide in connection
with the Qu'Appelle Industrial School, which it built and owns, and
in which there are in residence some two hundred and twenty-five
pupils, any isolated hospital. The only hospital provided is on the
top flat of the main building and has not even a balcony, though the
open air treatment is the approved one for tuberculosis, and most
desirable as a means of affording a sunning to all convalescents.

Why, then, should the same Department insist that
church schools with an attendance of one or two score, and paid only
$100.00 per capita, shall have such isolated hospitals as have
been demanded?
All that should reasonably be called for is a special infirmary in the building, safeguarded to prevent contagion, and in area proportionate to the capacity of the school building, the same to be kept in readiness for the isolation of pupils who might contract infectious diseases. If such a disease spread, the school would have, as residential schools have had, to take on the circumstances of an isolated hospital.

It is important to have a clear description of what is required in the way of hospital accommodation. Schools have been submitted to vexatious requirements by physicians, whose interest therein appears to have been in large measure confined to making unnecessary demands. For sometime, indeed, it has been painfully evident that the Department's medical policy has been inspired by faddism.

The undersigned would be quite satisfied if the schools scheduled in Class C were only called upon to meet requirements proper to that class; for the increase from $72.00 to $100.00 per capita would warrant the necessary expenditure; and the improvements, with the increased yearly income, would enable those schools to better serve the purpose for which they are intended.

The description of the classes of schools, the undersigned respectfully submit, should have been incorporated in the contract. As they stand, it would not appear that they can be held to be part of it; and clauses 12, 13 and 16 are so loosely framed and capable of so broad and variant interpretations that almost anything in the way of alterations and improvements can be demanded. It seems to the undersigned to
be quite obviously in the interest of both parties there to that
the contract entered into for each and every school should
definitely and clearly set forth what improvements are to be
made and maintained in order to entitle the school to receive
a per capita grant of $100.00 or $125.00, as the case may be.
And to that end the undersigned would ask that the contract
be amended.

6. By clause 18 of the contract the party of the
second part is required—

(1) "To make any change or alteration in the school
building or premises, or (2) in the management or control of
the said school rendered necessary to comply with the intent
and spirit of the agreement, and (3) to remove for the cause from
the said school any teacher, officer, employee, or pupil when
required to do so by the Superintendent General."

To be properly canvassed this clause must be taken
apart and divided, as marked by the undersigned in the above
quotation of it.

Its first section should have been embodied in a
clause covering the matter of clauses 18 and 19.

But, apart from that, which is after all only a fault
in drafting, the first section is objectionable in that it de-
stroys finality in the matter of improvement, and enables the
party of the first part to demand, at any time after the changes
and improvements first required have been acceptably made, further
alterations, which may be extensive and costly and destructive
of expensive improvements made by order of the Department at
the time of entering into the contract. Under this provision,
managers of schools may find themselves embarrassed by
Departmental approval of the recommendations of Inspectors or
Agents with fads; and school managers, unfortunately, are not with-
out experience of such faddists.
The undersigned, therefore, respectfully submit that, in recasting the contract, it should be made clear that, when the changes and improvements called for by the requirements of the class in which the school is placed have been acceptably made and such improvements are being duly maintained, there shall be no obligation to make any further changes, alterations or improvements during the continuance of the contract.

7. The second section of Clause 18 is particularly objectionable and dangerous. It empowers the party of the first part "to make any change or alteration....in the management or control of the school rendered necessary to comply with the intent and spirit of the agreement", of which necessity the said party is to be the sole and final judge.

The word "management" means and is intended for "managers" the word used by the undersigned in their review of the contract to prevent confusion with the word management as used in the title and generally throughout the contract. But, if there were room for doubt as to the sense in which the word "management" is used in the clause now under consideration, it is entirely removed by the addition of the word "control" which is sufficiently comprehensive to be inclusive of the meaning of "auspices" as that word is used when it is stated that a certain school is conducted under the auspices of a certain church. The provision is certainly very wide and far reaching.
The undersigned can find no provision in the contract for the school being conducted under the auspices of a particular church. If such a provision be not within the four corners of the contract, then it would not be contrary to its "intent and spirit", and, indeed, might be found necessary thereto, to change the auspices.

That may be regarded as quite unlikely to happen, and too far fetched a contingency to guard against. However that may be, this might happen:

A school might come to be regarded by an Inspector or Agent as being too religiously conducted, and, on his report, the ecclesiastical "management or control" thereof might be changed to lay management and control.

Or it might come to be considered that the "management" was not sufficiently Anglicized or too Frenchified, and that it was, therefore, necessary to due compliance with the "intent and spirit of the agreement" to change or alter the management and control.

The undersigned respectfully submit that each contract should set forth the designation of the church or religious denominations under whose auspices the school is conducted; that, in the case of each school conducted under the auspices of the Catholic Church, the designation of the order or community of priests or nuns the school is managed or controlled by at the time of the entering into the contract should be set forth therein; and it should be provided that no change shall be made in such management or control without the consent or concurrence of the Ordinary of the diocese or vicariate in which the school is situated.
8. The third section of clause 18 empowers the party of the first part to have removed, "for cause", from the school any teacher, officer, employee, or pupil.

The term "for cause" is dangerously indefinite. It is not difficult to allege a cause. The question always is as to its sufficiency. Under the section a teacher, officer or employee might be removed because he or she used, even in English, French idiomatic forms of expression, or spoke with too French an accent, or conversed or prayed with pupils in other than the English tongue. A teacher might be removed because he or she did not hold a certificate from one of a certain number of Normal Schools. A child might be removed and placed in a school conducted under other religious auspices.

The undersigned respectfully submit that the clause should be so amended as to set forth the causes for which removal may be made. In the cases of teachers, officers and employees the grounds for removal should be confined to incompetency, unbecoming conduct, and violation of the terms of the contract or of Departmental regulations not inconsistent therewith. Pupils should only be removed, before the full period for which they entered, for serious offenses in the nature of crimes under the law, or on account of incurable disease or of disease inimical to the health of the other pupils, or because of utter intractability; and it should be provided that a pupil so removed shall not be placed in a school conducted under religious auspices different from that under which the school from which the removal is made is conducted.
9. In the part of the agreement which sets forth the obligations of the Superintendent General under the contract, he covenants, under Clause 2 thereof, "to provide the pupils of... the school with medicines, school-books, stationary, and school appliances."

It is the practice to also furnish medical attendance; and the undersigned respectfully submit that the clause should be so amended as to include it.

10. Under Clause III the party of the first part takes power to "cancel and rescind" the contract on his sole judgment that "any of the covenants and stipulations" therein have not been complied with, on giving six months notice.

The undersigned regard that as rather an extensive power to take without the right of appeal on the part of the other party to the contract, who, in virtue of it, incurs large outlay and assumes serious responsibilities; and they would, therefore, suggest that the clause be amended so as to give the party of the second part the right to appeal against an order of cancellation to the Governor in Council within six months of the date of such order, it being provided that such order shall set forth the grounds of cancellation, so that the same may be attacked if an appeal be made.

11. By Clause V it is provided that there shall be no liability to make any payment to the school under the contract "should the amount voted by Parliament and applicable towards payment... be at any time expended during the continuance of this contract."
The Indian educational appropriation, the undersigned understand, is voted in bulk, and not for particular schools or classes of schools. Through over expenditure in one direction there might be lack of funds to meet payments due in another. Or there might be neglect to estimate for monies payable under the contract. There is no expressed obligation under the contract to estimate for payments to the school the maintenance of which by its managers is contracted for, or to ask Parliament for the necessary money for the per capita grant stipulated.

It seems to the undersigned that those obligations should be expressed in the contract. Indeed, they venture to think that it would not be going too far to ask that it be agreed that the name of the school and the amount provided for it, be set forth in the Supply Bill. That would give Parliamentary sanction to each contract, would ensure that no money voted for the school could be diverted, and would stop any demands for additional payments to the school.

If you, Honorable Sir, should find the contract sufficiently faulty to warrant its recasting, it would, the undersigned respectfully suggest, be well to have it so recast that no room for doubt might remain as to its movements and conditions, its spirit and intent. In the recasting, it should, the undersigned venture to suggest, be borne in mind that the Indian educational system has now proceeded "from status to contract". In the former condition there was nothing hard or fast. Variant conditions and unforeseen contingencies could be at any time taken into consideration, and
an unpropitious financial situation might at any time be ameliorated by aid other than the per capita grant. Claims could be made for the meeting by the Department or certain expenditures; and such claims were often met. No such aid can be looked for, no such claims are entertainable under the contract system. It is right.

It crystallizes a policy. There is no room for give or take. It is, therefore, of the utmost importance that the conditions should be clearly expressed and that no room be left for misunderstanding. It is of the very essence of a contract to aptly describe the things contracted for. And, when a public policy of import assumes contract form, it is as already observed the part of wisdom to have it sanctioned by the highest authority of the State.

We beg you, Honorable Sir, to accept the assurance of our high esteem, and to be us,

Your faithful servants,

(Signed) Adelard

AGREEMENT IN REGARD TO THE MANAGEMENT OF INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOLS AND CORRESPONDENCE RELATING THERETO

Extract from letter, dated Ottawa, November 25, 1910, sent to the representatives of the several religious bodies in Canada interested in Indian education.

Sir,—Herewith I beg to inclose a memorandum of information relating to Indian boarding schools, and draft of contract which it is proposed that the authorities responsible for the maintenance and conduct of Indian boarding schools shall become a party to in order to entitle such schools to government aid.

The memorandum and draft contract in question are the result of a conference held in Ottawa on November 8.

The circumstances which led to the conference may be briefly outlined.

When Indian education was taken up seriously in western Canada in the eighties, the policy of the government was to establish industrial schools, erected at the cost of the government, to be conducted under the auspices of the several religious bodies interested; the government contributing to the maintenance of the schools a fixed sum per head. In pursuance of what was then believed to be sound policy, these schools were, generally speaking, located at points distant from Indian reserves, and for this reason there was frequently considerable difficulty in securing a sufficient attendance of Indian pupils to earn the grant adequate for their upkeep.

To meet the educational needs of the Indian children who could not for one reason or another be provided for in the industrial schools already mentioned, from time to time boarding schools were established on a number of reserves at the charge of the various religious bodies. It was a fundamental principle in the case of the industrial schools that the government erected the buildings at government cost, while in the case of the boarding schools the church erected the buildings at the cost of the church. In recognition of the efforts towards Indian education by the erection of these boarding schools, and to substantially assist the churches in their work, a grant per head was made by the government towards their support.

As time went on, it became more and more apparent that the boarding schools were filling a want that the industrial schools had not filled, and for this reason instead of the number of industrial schools having been increased, the number of boarding schools has been increased. With this increase in the number of boarding schools, the burden of their support upon the various churches has correspondingly increased, and as the buildings which were erected in the first place by the churches have required repair or enlargement the government has from time to time, and in many cases, been called upon to provide these enlargements, improvements, and repairs. Besides, there have been occasions when the difference between the contribution of the government and the actual cost of maintaining the school was greater than the church interested in the school felt itself able to provide, and the government was called upon to meet the deficiency.

This was not a desirable condition from the point of view either of the church or of the government. If there had been a prospect of these conditions being improved, there might not have been need of change, but all reports tended to show that, far from the probability that this condition would improve, it was likely to become aggravated year by year. Realizing the importance of the educational work being done by

For the purpose of deciding upon a proper geographical division of the boarding schools to serve each of the railway sections of Ontario, it is proposed to divide the province into Eastern, Western and Northern divisions. The Eastern division (850) will include all the following schools, which are located within 300 miles from a railway station:

- Almonte, Moose Factory, Rat Portage and Cecilia Jeffery.
- Lac la Biche, Whitefish Lake, Slave Lake, Spruce Lake, Fort Frances, Rat Portage and Cecilia Jeffery.
- Lake Nipigon and Fort Providence.
- The Western division (800) will include all the other boarding schools in Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta and British Columbia, including the three Ontario boarding schools mentioned above, i.e., Fort Frances, Rat Portage and Cecilia Jeffery.

The number of children to be accommodated in each school is to be fixed by the contract. The limit is to be fixed by the government, but it should not exceed 500 cubic feet per child. In the case of new schools, the limit is to be fixed by the government, but it should not exceed 500 cubic feet per child. In the case of existing schools, the limit is to be fixed by the government, but it should not exceed 500 cubic feet per child.

SCHOOL BUILDINGS, CLASS "A."

The buildings owned by the church which would entitle the school to a per capita grant of $100 in the Eastern division and $125 in the Western division should conform to the following general specifications:

1. Substantial building, either of brick, stone, cement or wood, in good state of repair.
2. To be built on a stone or cement foundation, with a light airy basement of full size of main building with cement floor.
3. Pure and plentiful water-supply distributed throughout the building.
4. A proper system of sanitary water-closets, drainage and disposal of sewage.
5. Hospital accommodation for pupils ill with infectious disease or tuberculosis.
