MEMORANDUM

Hon. Dr. Roche -

By memorial dated at Regina, Saskatchewan 24th. of November, 1911, addressed to the Hon. Robert Rogers and signed by His Grace the Archbishop of St. Boniface and several other dignitaries of the Roman Catholic Church, and by a supplementary document dated 15th. November, 1912, similarly addressed and signed, copies of which documents are enclosed herewith, representations are made at length concerning the conduct of Indian schools and certain reasons set forth why important modifications should be made in the policy and contract governing the administration of Indian schools. Particular reference is made to the contract for the conduct and management and maintenance of Indian boarding schools, although the industrial and day schools come in for some measure of consideration.

The principal points of the documents above
referred to are:-

(1) The representatives of the churches had not been previously advised of the tenor of the contract and the consideration which the undersigned have given compels them to the conclusion that the said representatives had not that opportunity of deliberating it which the importance of the contract demanded.

In answer to this it is to be borne in mind that for some years there had been considerable discussion through interviews and correspondence between the churches and the Department with a view of reaching an arrangement whose terms will be reasonably definite and satisfactory to both the Government and the churches. The result was that on the 8th November 1910 the Hon. Mr. Oliver, then Superintendent General held a conference with the bishops, clergymen and laymen representative of the churches engaged in Indian educational work. At that conference were present representing the Anglican Church:

Most Reverend S. P. Matheson, Archbishop of Rupert's Land, and Primate of all Canada.

Rt. Reverend G. Thorneloe, Bishop of Algoma.

Rt. Reverend J. G. Anderson, Chapleau, Bishop of Moosonee.
Ven. Archdeacon Tims, of Calgary, representing the Bishop of Calgary.

Ven. Archdeacon McKay, Prince Albert, representing the Bishop of Saskatchewan.

Representing the Roman Catholic Church:

Rt. Reverend G. Breynat, Bishop of McKenzie River.

Rt. Reverend G. Charlebois, Keewatin, representing Bishop Legal of St. Albert.

Rt. Reverend D. J. Schollard, North Bay, Bishop of Sault Ste. Marie.

Reverend Father Poitras, Winnipeg.

Reverend Father Magnan, Winnipeg.

Reverend Father Gauvreau, Procurator General, Ottawa.

Reverend Father Gabillon, representing Bishop Pascal of Prince Albert.

Reverend Charles Belanger, Wikwemikong.

Representing the Methodist Church:

Reverend Dr. T. H. E. Shore, Superintendent Missions.

Reverend T. Ferrier, Brandon, Man.

Representing the Presbyterian Church:

Hamilton Cassels, K.C., Toronto, Ontario.

Reverend J. H. Turnbull, Ottawa.
The matter of Indian education was pretty generally discussed at this conference and the draft contract was read there and approved by the delegates. On the 25th November of that year a copy of the contract was sent to everyone who had been present and to others who were interested. So far as I have been able to discover, the contract met with general approval, and I know of no objection being raised to its terms between the 25th November and March of the following year, the time the contracts were being executed by the churches and the Department, so that the question of not having ample time for considering and protesting against its terms, if such were deemed necessary, would appear to be settled by the facts as stated.

(2) The contract, it is alleged, lacks statutory authority and Sections 9, 10, and 11 of the Indian Act are quoted in support of this allegation. These Sections are as follows:

"9. The Governor in Council may make regulations, either general or affecting the Indians of any province or of any named band, to secure the compulsory attendance of children at school.

"II. Such regulations, in addition to any..."
other provisions deemed expedient, may provide for the arrest and conveyance to school, and detention there, of truant children and of children who are prevented by their parents or guardians from attending; and such regulations may provide for the punishment, upon summary conviction, by fine or imprisonment, or both, of parents and guardians, or persons having the charge of children, who fail, refuse, or neglect to cause such children to attend school.

10. The Governor in Council may establish an industrial school or a boarding school for Indians, or may declare any existing Indian school to be such industrial school or boarding school for the purposes of this and the next following section.

11. The Governor in Council may make regulations, which shall have the force of law, for the committal by justices or Indian agents of children of Indian blood under the age of sixteen years, to such industrial school or boarding school, there to be kept cared for and educated for a period not extending beyond the time at which such children shall reach the age of eighteen years.

II. Such regulations may provide, in such manner as to the Governor in Council seems best, for
the application of the annuities and interest moneys
of children committed to such industrial school or
boarding school, to the maintenance of such schools
respectively, or to the maintenance of the children
themselves."

It has not been made clear by the documents
now under consideration why these sections are quoted
in support of a demand for statutory authority for the
Superintendent General to enter into this contract.
Sections 5 and 6 of the Indian Act are as follows:

5. There shall be a department of the Civil
Service of Canada which shall be called the Department
of Indian Affairs, over which the Superintendent
General shall preside.

6. The Department of Indian Affairs shall
have the management, charge and direction of Indian
affairs.

It is quite clear that the Superintendent
General as the head of the Department is authorized
to administer the affairs of that Department and to
deal with the expenditure incurred in connection
therewith, in accordance with the statute or the
appropriation of Parliament, and if he considers it to
be in the interest of Indian education that a contract
should be entered into with reference to the school buildings and to the expenditure of money therefor as provided by Parliament, there is no question as to his right to do so unless there is some statute preventing it, and more especially is this the case when both the Department and the churches agreed upon the terms of the contract. If, however, there is any doubt as to the Superintendent General's power to enter into this contract, I take it that the question is one not for the schools to raise, but for Parliament. Parliament, however, has practically ratified the action of the Superintendent General by voting last session and the session before, the moneys necessary to carry out the contract's terms.

The contract is for 5 years, and has been in operation since the 1st April, 1911. During the two years that it has been in operation, the churches and the Department have worked in harmony, and the terms of the contract have been observed both by the churches and the Government. If, at the expiration of the 5 years, there are any material objections to the contract, these may be submitted for consideration.
(2) The admission of half-breeds to Indian schools:—

It is contended that the stipulation "That no Half-breed child shall be admitted... unless Indian children can not be obtained to complete the number authorized by Article I., Section 1., and Section 4 (a) of this agreement, in which event the Superintendent General may in his discretion permit the admission of any Half-breed child; but the Superintendent General will not pay any grant for any such Half-breed pupil provided under Article II., Section 1., of this agreement, nor any part of the cost of its maintenance or education whatever," is a very drastic provision and pregnant of much evil, that it is contrary to the policy which long obtained, and against which no reasonable objection has been or can be urged, and in a measure that it is obviously ultra vires.

It is stated that the half-breeds may be divided into three classes:—

1. Those who live, in varying degrees of conditions, the ordinary settled life of the country.

2. Those who live, in varying degrees, the Indian mode of life.

3. Those who - and they form the most unfor-
fortunate class in the community - are the illegitimate offspring of Indian women, and of whom white men are mainly the begetters.

The question of opening the doors for the admission of half-breeds to Indian schools is a very serious one, and if favourably considered, would be of far reaching consequences. Of course, half-breeds who are recognized members of the band are not excluded from participation in the benefits or privileges of the Indian schools, and consequently the discussion on that point is unnecessary, but it is to the half-breeds who are not members of the band that the privileges of Indian education are to be extended. Half-breeds are not Indians in the eyes of the law; they come under provincial jurisdiction and are entitled to the benefits, privileges, etc., arising from the provincial educational system.

It is quite possible in the early days the lines were not drawn so strictly, as they have been in late years, but this can be accounted for by the fact that organization was not so complete in what are now the western provinces; the administration of affairs generally was largely Dominion and the line was not so strictly drawn between Indians and Half-breeds: but the conditions have changed and it would be out of the question, I take it,
to permit the funds placed at the disposal of the Indian Department to be expended in the education of children who do not come within the class of children over whom the Indian Department exercises control.

This question came before the Department less than a year ago by reason of the admission of about 66 Half-breeds to the industrial school at Qu'Appelle, and in connection therewith I made an extended report to the Hon. Mr. Rogers, dated 2nd May, 1912, copy of which is herewith enclosed, also copy of letter dated June 1st., 1912 to the Reverend Father Hugonard advising him that the Department would expect these Half-breed children to be out of the school by the 30th June, 1913. It will be seen that in Mr. Sifton's ruling, which is referred to in the memorial and dealt with in my report, he goes no further than to extend the privileges of the Indian schools to the children of mixed blood who live upon a reserve and whose parents on either side live upon a reserve. In the contract under which the schools are managed at present, Half-breeds may be admitted to the schools when Indian children cannot be obtained, but even then they are not eligible to draw the per capita grant.

With reference to the objections to the
Government retaining power to make such regulations from time to time as may be considered advisable, it is, I think, quite clear that the Government should control, and if at any time the regulations were considered oppressive or unworkable, there is no reason to suppose that they would not be modified. The heads of the Departments, the deputy heads, and the chief officers are not, so far as I know, faddists in the administration of Departmental matters, as might be inferred from some sections of the memorial, and there is no reason to believe that fair and equitable consideration will not be given upon the merits of any proposition presented to the Department.

(4) Reference is also made to clause 8 dealing with the use of the English language in these schools, and an endeavour is made to show that the requirements of this clause as to knowledge of English are too comprehensive to be workable. I presume, that it will not be difficult to see that the meaning of this clause is that English shall be the language of the institution where language is fundamental to the teach-
ing or instruction given, and it would apply more particularly to the academic side of the work. It is quite true there may be instructors in gardening, farming, care of stock, cooking, laundry work, needlework, general housewifery, and dairying, but I do not suppose that it is very material whether the garden is dug and planted, the fires lighted, the food cooked, the clothes washed and dried, garments made and mended, and the dairying done in English or any other language. I take it that the meaning of clauses 8 and 9 is that the principal language of the institution shall be English, and reading these two clauses together, I do not see that very much objection can be raised to them.

(5) Objection is raised to building clauses 12, 13 and 18; a perusal of these clauses will show that there is nothing unreasonable in their stipulations. The objection that is raised would appear to be chiefly leveled at prospective trouble on the one hand, and of the placing of too much power in the hands of the Superintendent General, on the other. As to the first, I presume that if trouble arises, it can be dealt with on its merits, and as to the second it is certainly right and proper that the Superintendent General should be clothed with the necessary power to see that the
terms of the contract are observed and in doing so accept the full responsibility of a representative of the Government.

(6) A somewhat diffuse argument is made as to the word "cause" for which removal may take place. In the understanding of the Department the cause must be some reason, some justification, a circumstance, or a set of circumstances, which determine the Superintendent General's mind in the direction of removal, and this reason, justification, or circumstance will determine the sufficiency or insufficiency of the cause. I think there is no doubt that the section is sufficient so far as that is concerned.

(7) The memorial of the 15th November, 1912 deals more particularly with the age of admission, and advances reasons why the residential school is preferable to the day school. There are today in Canada 251 day schools, 55 boarding schools, and 19 industrial schools, and while one may be able to pick out cases here and there throughout the whole of the educational system where the day schools have not succeeded, it is quite possible also that instances of failure may be found in cases of residential schools. As a matter of fact, we
have closed not only day schools but residential schools time and again owing to failure to obtain either teachers, pupils or money sufficient to warrant these schools being carried on. A great deal can be said in favour of the residential school, and such has been pretty thoroughly recognized by the Department, but at the same time there can be no doubt the day school has been and is a very important factor in the educational life of the Indian, and more especially it may be said, in the older sections of the country where the Indian has given up his nomadic life, and adjusted himself to the settled life of the community.

The adjustment of these matters, however, is a matter of slow progress and can only be brought about by due observance of changing habits and conditions. So far as the school age is concerned, the regulations referred to in the memorial, deal more particularly with the age at which Indian children may be committed to school; the contract deals with the age when they can be admitted, and it was well understood and agreed to at the time of the conference.

I submit then that in the interest of the Department and the churches, the contract should be allowed to run its course; so far it has worked with
comparative smoothness, and there is no reason to anticipate that the conduct of the schools and the relation of the school authorities with the Department will not be as satisfactory as they have been since the contract was entered into. Hon. Dr. Poche -

In forwarding the memorandum to Council to you dated the 12th January, accepting the lowest tender for the construction of the Roman Catholic Boarding school building at Cross Lake, I beg to point out that this school is to provide for the children of the Roman Catholic Indians in the diocese of Neewatin, and that the activities of the church so far as they are aided by the Government, are to be limited to this school. As the Department is constantly being pressed for the erection of buildings for residential schools, principally in remote districts, where the Indians have not at present such educational advantages, I think it well to endeavour to fix a policy for the department with reference to future grants for educational purposes. So far as these demands are concerned, the educational field may be divided into two classes:

(1) Schools which are already established in more or less settled districts. The requisitions made upon us for building expenditure for this class of schools are for repair and enlargements, and in some cases complete rebuilding. It should be remembered that most of these schools were erected by the church authorities or by the department without any attention to sanitary arrangements. In many cases they have fallen to disrepair and are not suitable for
the work which is carried on within their walls.

(2) Schools which are intended to supplement the missionaries' efforts to evangelize the Indians. The majority of these applications must necessarily come from remote districts where the Indians earn their livelihood by hunting and fishing.

It seems clear to me that our first duty is to meet the needs which arise in class 1, and to consider it our first object to thoroughly equip the old institutions.

When the question of Indian Education was being considered by your predecessor in office in the autumn of 1910, and when the per capita grants were increased and the schools standardized, we stated on the authority of the Hon. Mr. Oliver that the government was willing to spend a moderate amount from year to year in establishing new and modern buildings, but would not undertake to furnish modern buildings in all cases where they are required within a short space of time.

Our main Estimates for the current year provide for $342,000.00 for buildings for residential schools and $10,925.00 for buildings for day schools. It seems to me that that annual expenditure is a fair expenditure for some years to come. At that rate of expenditure we should be able in two years to meet all the requirements of the older institutions.

I trust this outline of policy will meet with your approval.

In reference to the education of Indian children I respectfully beg to offer the Department my opinion for whatever it may be valued at. And whether considered of any value or otherwise it is not given with any malice or condemnation towards any person, denomination or institution, but is given with a desire for a common sense uplifting of the Indian which is a part of the policy of the Department I have the honour of trying to serve.

I have been an interested observer of Indians and Indian affairs including education, for the past 25 years, and have become gradually convinced that under the present unfinished system of industrial schools a cruelty instead of a benefit is being imposed upon the Indian.

I have seen young men and women, well educated and well behaved, good mechanics and good housekeepers returned, at a very susceptible age, to their reserves, in locations at the best upon the outskirts of civilization, where it is an impossibility for them to profit by the education they have received while in the industrial school; and their last state is generally worse than the first.

Unless the work of the industrial schools can be carried on upon industrial farms or in factories it would be better to leave the children in the reserves, for when taken away for a few years they are unfitted to get a living as an ordinary Indian and have not sufficient stability of character to compete with the white people.

I should think an industrial farm or trade for the employment of graduates from industrial schools would in a short time become self-supporting and a source of revenue, instead of an expense.
Until some continuation of the work commenced in the industrial schools is obtained for the Indian children, that they may keep advancing, it would be better for all concerned that the children are left in the reserves and the day schools receive greater attention.

The present system of the day schools in Indian reserves is also sadly inefficient. At present they are not under the management of the Department or the Churches. I think that either one or the other have the sole management of the day schools, and it would appear just and proper that the Department have the management.

In most reserves there are Indians of different faiths whom it would be impossible to please by the establishment of schools under the management of their Churches. All Indians, being wards of the Government receive, in most matters, the same consideration and treatment irrespective of their religious belief; and this impartial justice should be most prominent in education.

I firmly believe that the day schools in the reserves are the best and only proper method of education for Indian children.

I am afraid that many earnest but mistaken people forget that the nature of an Indian cannot be altered in one generation, and one should not blame too severely the Indian, who cannot have any appreciation of education, when he neglects to send his children to a school, without which he has been able to live.

A comfortable school, a sensible teacher who will not condemn any whose religious belief is different, administered by a Department just and therefore impartial, is all that can be given, the balance time will accomplish.

I have the honour to be your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,
Fisher River agency

Sir,— I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of November 9th re schools; and to say that I am pleased to receive this circular as it fellows along lines that I have endeavored to put into operation here the last six months with some measure of success; and further it opens an opportunity of allowing me to give expression in more extensive form to my idea of the faults and failings of our schools and the resultant deficiencies of the training practised, ideas which heretofore I might not be acceptable to the Department.

After careful observation in the schools and in the homes of ex-pupils on the reserve, I am convinced that much of the energy of our schools is misdirected; and a proper education under the conditions is not being given these Indians; that is an education and training conducive to their best advancement.

The prime object of our schools at present seems to be, the making of as many adherents as possible to the religious body under whose auspices the school is conducted; the greater the number of adherents the greater the success claimed for the school by the staff. While not in any way wishing to belittle the efforts expended in making Christians of these Indians or belittling the advantage of a religious education, I beg to suggest that the policy pursued at present is a short sighted one; even the missionaries acknowledge that after 25 years of religious instruction there is not one single Indian on the Blood Reserve who has any real conception of the Christian faith and the morality it teaches.
The schools and missions as at present conducted have a tendency to make petty grafters and public beggars of many of the Indians, by issuing them large quantities of free clothing, the giving of meals on Sundays and on festive occasions, the giving of begging letters to Indians; the giving to school children about to be discharged an extravagant idea of the amount of assistance the Department owes the Indians and is willing to give; giving extra privileges in the way of absenting their children from schools to Indians who profess to be the best friends and adherents to the respective churches; The above methods while probably intended in a good cause make indolent many able bodied Indians, make them agitate makes parents fell free to barter his child to the school that will give him the most.

Children in the schools are required to spend too much time in purely religious instruction; more time than their present state of mental or moral development warrants. Children are not being taught along lines of natural development and not with an idea single to their future well being and usefulness on the reserve,

The elementary principles of education are neglected and too much time spent on lines made for show purposes. Many are not able to speak English intelligibly; few if any have any power of deduction; the teaching of girls in homemaking; care of children; sewing; growing and cooking of vegetables; care of fowl; and the teaching of the boys mixing the elementary principles of soil culture; carpentry; harness mending; use of machinery and care of stock; all the above is sadly neglected. These Indians would adapt themselves readily to the above lines of instruction. While I am cognizant of the limitations in carrying out the above program yet I am convinced far more could and should be done.
I have never seen any children that a teacher's characteristics affects so strongly. It is an easy matter to pick out the children that have graduated from the respective schools. It is an easy matter to separate every pupil of outstanding teachers. Five of these teachers I have in mind, they have left an eradicable impression on the boys or girls. These teachers taught the children by example, how to use their head and their hands, taught them character. They have been of more benefit than all other teachers combined.

The schools have not been all to blame; they have had great difficulty in recruiting, have not received enough assistance from the agency staff, in this direction. There has been an apathy on the part of parents to send the children to school and often children were not placed in school until after they were too old to learn English.

Some of the faults have been corrected, the schools are filled beyond the required numbers, 75 children of school age in school could be placed in school inside of three months if the accommodation were available. Disinclination on part of the parents seems to be disappearing, and a healthy tendency for better attendance. With the filling of the schools some of the undesirable features are passing out. I am hoping for more practical and thorough instruction by more efficient teachers.

Given increased accommodation, more practical methods of instruction, more efficient instructors; compulsory attendance; the problems we have to deal with on the reserve will be simplified and many solved just as surely as the public schools have solved the problems in civilized communities.

I have the honor to be

Sir

Your Obedient Servant

Hon. Dr. Roche -

In November 1910, a meeting of the representatives of the churches interested in Indian Education was held in the office of the then Superintendent General of Indian Affairs. The object of this convention was the establishment of a definite financial policy in regard to the Indian boarding schools conducted by the different religious denominations engaged in Indian educational work. The result of the conference was embodied in an agreement which was signed by the management of Indian boarding schools and which went into effect on the 1st of April 1911, for a term of five years.

Although the time limit of the agreement expired fifteen months ago, the schools are still paid at the same per capita grant which formed the basis of the agreement. It is conceded that this grant was not at any time in itself sufficient to meet the cost
of maintenance and it was supplemented from denominational sources to a considerable extent. The different societies affiliated with the churches and interested in home mission work have found their funds in recent years greatly diminished, and there has been a consequent reduction in the grants for Indian school purposes; in some cases they have been wholly withdrawn.

Owing to the increased cost of food, clothing and wages the Churches maintain that the grant at present paid does not meet the due proportion of the cost assumed by the Department and there is no doubt that this contention is correct. The financial statements received from the schools show that, with one or two exceptions, the expenditure has exceeded the receipts from all sources. This fact, coupled with the difficulty of collecting funds as above referred to, has lead the Church authorities to ask for a readjustment of arrangements governing boarding and industrial schools.

Recognizing the justice of their claim, it is suggested that an all round increase of ten dollars be added to the per capita grant to the boarding and industrial schools for the current fiscal year only,
to assist the Churches in meeting the financial difficulties they have to contend with.

The suggested increase of ten dollars to the present per capita grant can be met out of this year's school appropriation, as savings can be effected in many of the items of expenditure, such as installation of new buildings (no new buildings to be erected this year), house-furnishings, implements, provisions, transportation of pupils, field-matrons, etc. The amount required to meet the increase will be about $38,000.00, based on last year's average attendance.

Ottawa, July 11, 1917.

Sir,

The Department, after careful consideration of the increased cost of maintaining the residential Indian schools conducted by the different religious denominations occasioned by the war, has decided to increase the per capita grant at present allowed to these schools by the sum of ten dollars, such increase to date from the 1st of April, last, and to be for the current fiscal year only.

To meet the increase out of the depleted funds at the disposal of the Department the strictest economy will have to be exercised in the expenditure of the school vote and it is expected that the principals in charge of the residential schools in your agency will co-operate with the Department in keeping down expenditure. The Department is confident that much can be done by careful management to reduce the cost of maintaining these schools and I trust that you will impress upon those in charge how absolutely necessary it is that the cost of maintenance should be kept within the grant.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

One of our chief difficulties at these large schools is to prevent the pupils from being exploited as mere wage earners, and to ensure that they should be taught English by persons who have a thorough command of the language. In connection with another large institution I was constrained to write the other day to this effect:

"The Department is of the opinion that the extensive farming operations carried on there entail too much work on the pupils, which causes dissatisfaction among the parents, who complain that the children are over-worked and their studies neglected.

"The same rule should apply to the stock raising carried on at the school.

"The Department is not in favour of more cattle being kept than are absolutely required for school purposes. In the past this industry has taken up much of the pupils' time at the expense of their education.

"The Department must insist upon the employment of teachers who are thoroughly qualified to give instruction in English, so that the pupils may have an opportunity of obtaining a thorough English education and learn to speak the language fluently."

I am sure you will agree with me that these demands are by no means exacting.
To provide an increase of $10.00 per capita in the Grant to Residential Indian Schools .............. $35,000.00

To enable the management of the residential schools to meet the increased cost of food, clothing and other expenses of maintenance it is necessary to augment the per capita grant allowed to the various schools of this class. Urgent requests have been made by the various religious denominations, under whose auspices these schools are conducted, for an increased grant as it is found impossible for them to carry on the work without incurring further deficits under the existing grant allowed.

There is no question as to the raise in the cost of food, clothing and wages during the past two years, and as no increase in the grant to the residential schools has been made during that period the management finds it difficult to carry on the work and maintain the present standard of efficiency without further assistance being granted. It is, therefore, necessary that the Government come to their support and augment the grant to enable them to meet the increased cost in the expenditure required to carry on the work.

The main estimates provide for a total enrolment of 3,561 pupils in the residential schools and to increase the grant by $10.00 per capita for that number, will require the above amount.

KENORA ONTARIO, AUG.12th,1920.

TO Board of Trade,
Kenora, Ont.,

Gentlemen:

I beg to ask that you would help us to obtain from the Department of Indian Affairs, a more suitable grant for the maintaining of our schools. I believe you are in receipt of a like request from the Principal of the Cecelia Jeffrey School, as we both are in a like position, that is -- both our schools would have to be closed unless we get a raise in the per capita grant in proportion with the raise of the cost of living. We apply to you, because you are aware of the work we are doing, and we feel sure, that your influence would help us to have our request granted.

The churches, I am sure will have to take the matter up with the Department in behalf of all the schools, but what the other schools could be satisfied with, would not enable us to live on account of the distance we have to travel to recruit the expenses in bringing our children, and in boarding the parents who come to visit their children, but especially, because we have not as the other schools have, farm lands to get a part of our support from. Now I feel sure that with the help of your powerful influence the Department will readily grant our request, it will, I believe, be sufficient to call the attention of the Honorable Gentlemen to the facts and they will understand our position.

Now a little while before the war the Department agreed to give us a grant of $125.00 per capita (34¢) per day, since then we have been raised to $145.00 (40¢) per day or a raise of 16% now when this is compared with the increase of the cost of living it is easily understood, that this raise is not sufficient, in fact, I believe, it is hardly more than enough to pay the different taxes.

Now as figures speak better than words, I will give you the amount received by this school from the Department, and the resources belonging to the school and what the church had to do to maintain us:

In the year 1918 - 19 the Gov. Grant together with the natural resources of the school, amounted to $8325.57. To enable us to meet our obligations the Oblate Fathers had to subscribe $5200.00. In 1919-20 the expenses were $15148.77. The Gov. Grant combined with the earnings of the school amounted to $8455.75. The Oblate Fathers Corporation allowed me $7000.00, but notified me that I had not to count on an ever increasing allowance and even that, this year I would have to do with half that amount as they have serious obligations to meet they cannot do more. Now, you Gentlemen, know how I try to spare, and a few know how I work myself in every line of manual labor, and you understand that further curtailment of expenses would have to be at the expense of the children's comfort, what I am sure is not the intention of the Honorable Gentlemen of the Department.

Begging for this communication your favorable attention I remain, Gentlemen, your obedient servant

C. Brouillet
Principal.

P. S. After conferring with the Principal of Cecelia Jeffrey School, we came to the conclusion that we could not very well maintain our Schools unless we are granted $250.00 per capita.

C.B.

The Honorable Sir James Lougheed,

SIR:

Enclosed you will find a letter, to the Kenora Board of Trade, from the Rev. Father Brouillet, Principal of the Kenora Indian Industrial School, asking us to lend our support to having the Government Grant increased. While this letter is from the principal of the Roman Catholic School the Presbyterian School on Shoal Lake is in just as sad a plight, as witness a letter from John T. Ross, Principal of the Cecelia Jeffray Indian School, and both are well worthy of special consideration.

These schools have made their presence felt among the Indians in no small manner. The writer well remembers the Indians of this District eking out a miserable existence by peddling fish or berries in summer and living heaven alone knows how in the winter. Then comparatively few of them could speak the English language or were able to write. Today these conditions have changed, partly no doubt by the constant contact with white people but we believe largely by the growing up of the children who were educated in these schools. Today the Indian who cannot speak English is very hard to find and the penmanship of many of them is excellent. Instead of eking out a miserable hand to mouth existence the younger men work in the lumber camps and on the drives. The manager of our largest Lumber Company states that without the assistance of the Indians it would have been impossible to carry on during the war.

The Indian girls at these schools are taught not only to read and write etc., but are given lessons in cooking and housekeeping. The sharp contrast between the civilized method of living and the makeshift of the Indian cannot help but have its influence with the younger ones.

The education afforded by these schools was chiefly responsible for many young Indians going overseas and rendering excellent service in France.
Speaking more directly of the schools. The Kenora Indian Industrial School is located just outside of the Town of Kenora. It is a large brick building equipped with electric light, water and sewage. The Presbyterian School is located about forty-five miles from Kenora on Shoal Lake. At both these schools the Indian children are given every attention by those in charge. Two years ago the then principal of the Presbyterian School gave his life during the influenza epidemic. Father Brouillet's devotion to his work is almost a by-word in Kenora.

When interviewing us at the Board Meeting, Father Brouillet stated that the total payroll of his school during the past year was $550.00 which sum in its entirety went to the five nuns working there with him, both he and the man of all weak getting only their board and room. We feel that such devotion is worthy of your consideration.

We would also draw your attention to the fact that neither school has any farm to draw upon and that their position is unique in this respect.

The members of the Board are entirely in sympathy with the work done by these schools. No person who has spent many years in Kenora can help but appreciate it. After hearing Father Brouillet, the Board unanimously passed the following resolution:

"That the Secretary write strongly to the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa pointing out the peculiar conditions under which the two Indian Schools in this District are operating and the necessity of further financial assistance and that this Board do unqualifiedly endorse the application of these two schools for an increase in the Government Grant to 75¢ per day per capita."

Trusting that you will be able to oblige us in this matter, we are,

Yours truly,

The above item represents a bonus at the rate of $30.00 per capita for the 5,000 pupils provided for in the Residential Indian Schools. This amount will increase the total estimate for Indian Education from $1,227,805.00 to $1,327,805.00.

A joint deputation representing the various religious denominations waited upon the Superintendent General a few days ago, and urged that this amount be granted as a bonus for the current year only. They are satisfied with the present per capita rate, which was increased by $10.00 in 1916 and by a further $10.00 in 1919. They state that while they have been able to maintain the schools on the government grants plus increased revenue from their own resources, they have been unable to make good any repairs, carry out any improvements in their buildings or to meet any incidental deficits from their current resources. Financial statements submitted to the Department show that during recent years the churches have contributed approximately 25% of the cost of maintenance of these schools. It will thus be seen that the partnership existing between the Government and the Churches relieves the former of a large expenditure which would have to be met if a State system of Indian Education prevailed; and at the same time the State would lose the moral and civilising influence of the Churches in its ultimate design of advancing the Indians towards full citizenship. The Churches confidently assert that if this bonus be granted for one year, they will be enabled during the following year to conduct the schools without any call upon the Government for maintenance beyond the authorised per capita grant.

It is interesting to compare the financial assistance given to our schools from Parliamentary Appropriations and like grants made to similar institutions in the United States from Appropriations by Congress.

In the United States the responsibility for Indian Education was some time ago assumed by the State. Previous to 1918 the per capita grant allowed by the United States Government for residential schools was $107.00. In 1918 this was increased to $200.00 for schools with a pupilage of one hundred or over, and $225.00 for schools with a pupilage below one hundred. During the fiscal year 1919-20 the average grant to Residential schools in Canada was approximately $137.00. During the year 1919-20 the average appropriation made by the United States Government for the education of Indian children in residential and day schools was $211.75 per capita, while in Canada for the same year the per capita appropriation was $141.37.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

I have read the attached letter from the Rev. J. B. Beys, Provincial of the Oblate Order, requesting that the Department assume the ownership, upon payment, of the Indian Boarding schools at Cowessess, Pine Creek, Muscowequans and Kenora.

It would certainly be in the interest of our work if all these buildings were owned by the government, as well as other boarding school buildings owned by the Roman Catholic Church and the Protestant Churches who are interested in Indian education. The union of the Church and State in this matter of Indian education is well recognized, and in 1911, when we made a new arrangement with the schools, the then Superintendent General, the Hon. Frank Oliver, laid down as a principle that we should own our own school buildings, although he did not pledge the government to acquire the existing boarding school buildings owned by the Churches. One can readily realize that individual capital expenditure and the upkeep of these buildings are a serious drain on Church funds.

As a matter of general policy, I am in favour of the acquirement of all these buildings. As you are aware our Estimates do not contemplate any building operations for the approaching fiscal year, but it might be well, and I would propose with your concurrence to do so, to submit supplementary estimates for the value of these buildings, (which seems to me would be fair) and to include the necessary buildings for the other Churches which are now on requisition, in order that the denominations may be treated fairly and equitably, and that the whole matter may receive the careful consideration of the government.

(Sgd.) Duncan C. Scott.

Deputy Superintendent General.

IMPRESSIONS OF THE INTERVIEW
BETWEEN THE CHURCH REPRESENTATIVES AND THE SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL
APRIL 13, 1922.

Dr. Chown, General Superintendent of the Methodist Church, who introduced the delegation, mentioned the State's obligation arising out of the treaties with the Indian people of Canada.

Canon Gould, of the Church of England in Canada, spoke at some length of the urgent need for funds for the erection of residential schools.

Father Guy, of the Roman Catholic Church, enlarged upon the remarks of the previous speaker and made the suggestion that Indian trust funds be applied in a more extensive way to the problem of Indian education.

Dr. Edmison, of the Presbyterian Church, explained the financial condition of his organization, and asked the Government to recommence taking over the responsibilities in connection with buildings and equipment. He requested a new school for Cecilia Jeffrey, on a site to be chosen, and suggested that the Government take over the Presbyterian residential school property in the near future.

Dr. Manning, of the Methodist Church, commented on the unity among the various societies doing Indian work, and asked that there be included in the Supplementary Estimates for 1922-23 the several requests already made to the Department. He referred to the immediate needs of the Methodist Church at Edmonton, Coqualeetza and Muncey.

The Hon. Charles Stewart, Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, in reply, stated that there was great need at the present time of economy in connection with State expenditures. He mentioned that, if his efforts to obtain funds for new residential school buildings were abortive this year, the Department would at least keep the old buildings in repair during the interim before such time as funds could be provided. He stated that the possibility and advisability of taking Indian trust funds on loan for the purpose of erecting residential schools had been, and would continue to be, a matter of serious consideration. Mr. Stewart realized the unique position of the unfinished plant at Edmonton, and stated that this particular school and its needs would receive due attention.
Dr. Edmonson thanked the Minister for his interest in the work and promised that no undue pressure, in connection with new buildings, would be brought to bear at this time. He was personally gratified that the Minister had admitted the principle that the State should assume the responsibility for buildings in connection with residential schools, and was pleased that the Government was prepared, even this year, to do the repairing that would be found necessary from time to time.

Canon Gould inquired if the Government would make any distinction between church-owned and state-owned property in connection with the temporary programme of upkeep.

The Hon. Mr. Stewart, in reply to Canon Gould's question, stated that the Department would endeavour to keep the church-owned buildings in state of good repair, until such time as new buildings could be provided.

Dr. Chown thanked the Minister for the hearing and for his evident interest in the education of the Indian people.

The schools marked (1) are modern, up to date buildings, in good condition and are adequate for the purpose of Indian education. The Provincial of the Oblate Order in Winnipeg (Father Boys) has urgently requested that these 4 properties be purchased. In the supplementary Estimates for 1922-23 there is an item of $48,000 to provide for the purchase of the Kenora Boarding School, after an adjusting - of the valuation -
of the valuation. If this amount is voted, the principle involved, i.e., the gradual acquisition of all residential school buildings owned by the churches, will be acknowledged; and from time to time, as Parliament provides funds, the other institutions marked (1) and the schools in British Columbia marked (3) could be purchased. These 2 institutions in British Columbia and a third one, the Squamish Boarding School, owned by the Sisters of the Holy Infant (R.C.), have been offered to the Government at a valuation (not stated) by the Church authorities in the Western provinces. Beauval Boarding School, Sask., marked (2), has been named by the Oblates as the last school the purchase of which is desired.

I wish to refer to the possibility of future requests on the part of the Roman Catholic Church that the State purchase the other church-owned residential schools. Those marked (4) are north of the main lines of communication and could be considered largely missionary activities for some years. The institutions marked (5) are either in poor condition or are not modern and would likely be turned over to the State from time to time, at practically no cost. As you are aware, it has hitherto been the policy of the Department to substitute modern, up-to-date buildings in place of the original residential schools erected with church funds which, owing to lapse of time and the development of the work, become dilapidated and inadequate. At the time of the transfer, the monetary consideration is generally nil.

5 Roman Catholic church-owned institutions have not been listed above. This Department would never purchase the Fort William Orphanage, Ont., or the St. Albert Boarding School, Alta., as these are primarily convents for the education of white children. The Squamish Boarding School, B.C., should not be considered, as the property is entirely inadequate for Indian residential school purposes. The Christie Industrial School, B.C., is modern, and the possibility of taking it over, at a valuation, must be considered. The last named institution is owned by the Basilian Order. Deputy Superintendent General.
The familiar "Red Man" of History and Romance is fast becoming a figure of the past. In his stead, we find the Indian of today once again a virile, strong type that is being assimilated rapidly into the composite Canadian race. Association with the White Man has won a partial immunity from the diseases that played such havoc with the health and population of the Indian at the time of his initial contact. The Indian population has been slightly increasing for some time; and in many parts of Canada, we have a flourishing group of natives - fast adopting our methods of earning a livelihood and clamoring for an education.

The Dominion Government realizes the importance of providing proper educational facilities for its wards; and increasing appropriations for Indian Education are being made from year to year. The Department of Indian Affairs is responsible for or is associated in the maintenance of about 750 teachers to the Indian youth. Most of the workers are missionary teachers; the churches and State are working side by side in the effort to prepare future Indian men and women for broader citizenship.

Some 12,900 Indian children are enrolled today in the 330 day and residential schools. These schools are not under the control of the Departments of Education in the different provinces, but are financed and managed jointly by the Department of Indian affairs and the various churches engaged in the work. In each province the Indian schools are inspected regularly by qualified school inspectors and the work done by Indian pupils already compares favourably with white schools in the same localities.

In the day schools, in addition to the regular curricula, prescribed by the Departments of Education, emphasis is placed on hand work, gardening, hygiene and group games. The residential schools give still further training in the manual arts that will assist the pupil in later life. The boys are trained in farming, gardening and the care of stock; the girls are systematically taught all household duties. Parliament annually provides appropriations - amounting last year to $1,568,420.45 - from which the expenditures for the maintenance of the various institutions are made. The churches are interested not only in the conduct of schools but provide further funds to finance the schools. These grants are supplemented from Indian bands' trust funds when they are available.

Further training or assistance is offered to the promising graduates of the day and residential schools. About 90 young Indian men and women are attending high schools and colleges in Canada. Financial assistance and careful supervision for these special pupils are arranged for by the Department of Indian Affairs. Other energetic
graduates are given grants for stock, implements, household equipment or building material. This training and assistance has been a great stimulant to progress and has resulted in early independence.

An important factor in the general scheme is field work. In addition to nearly 40 field matrons and graduate nurses who are working on the reserves, day school teachers, Indian agents, missionaries and farm instructors take an active interest in the affairs of the Indian in his own habitat. Housewives and mothers are being trained and clean living is promoted.

Indian education has many discouraging features: yet, in spite of reactionary elements, the forces of Church and State combine to create sure progress in Christian civilization.
Sept. 22, 1922.

Ottawa, January 5th, 1923.

Sir,

I am directed to acknowledge your of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the plans of this Department for the development of the education of the Indian peoples of Canada.

There has been no radical change in the policy of the Department with reference to Indian education. As you will understand our activities are strictly limited by the appropriation which Parliament places at our disposal each Session. While the constant wish of the Department is to expand and in every way improve the system, the need for general economy which the Government finds so pressing at this time, has to be considered. It is our wish to rapidly conform to the programmes of studies laid down by the various Provincial Departments of Education, and when possible to improve the method of instruction and the personnel of the teaching staffs. We are already utilizing the services of the public school inspectors in seven provinces, in an effort to bring the Indian schools, from an academic standpoint, up to the standard of the public schools.

The Department intends to continue to cooperate with the various denominations in the educational work.

REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON INDIAN AFFAIRS

Your Committee on Indian Affairs have during the past year met and discussed various phases of Indian life in Canada. They wish to submit resolutions dealing with the following subjects:

1. Education.
2. Preservation of the Race.
3. Thrift.
4. Defective and Delinquent Children.
5. The Outside Service.
6. Disturbances among the Six Nation Indians.
7. The British Columbia Land Question.

I Education:
Whereas in the matter of Indian education results do not seem to be commensurate with expenditure incurred this Council respectfully suggests:
A more earnest effort on the part of Indian Agents and truant officers in securing regular attendance at local Reserve Schools.

II Preservation of the Race:
There has been brought to the attention of your Committee this year as in former years, the problem of the continuance of the custom of allowing trial marriages to take place on the Indian reserves. When a trial marriage occurs, no special rite is observed except the complimentary exchange of gifts, and nothing is done which is calculated to give the couple a realization of the responsibility of their position. A spirit of irresponsibility is in fact encouraged by a certain public opinion which supports the action of couples, who, after living
together some months as man and wife, grow tired of one another and separate, to enter perhaps very soon afterward into new marriage relations. This custom is the cause of much looseness and profligacy among Indians on reserves. There are few reserves in Canada which are free from the menace to the Indian race which such looseness constitutes. Your Committee therefore submit the following resolution:

Whereas we conceive the objective of Government and Church work among Indians to be their inclusion in Christian citizenship, and Whereas the home is the fundamental unit of national life, and Whereas looseness in domestic relationships on the Indian Reserves is causing much concern among many of the missionaries of the various churches engaged in Indian work, and Whereas much of this looseness has its roots in the trial marriages practised by the natives, and Whereas immorality produces disease, physical decay and race degeneracy, and Whereas the Indian Agents have already rendered excellent service in this matter in their own Agencies,

Be it hereby resolved that we respectfully suggest to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs that a letter be sent out to all Indian Agents, setting forth the facts and asking them to use their influence to persuade the people under their care to forsake their old practices in this regard and to adhere more closely to Canadian laws and Christian teaching concerning marriage, for the purpose of preserving and improving the race.

III Thrift:

Attention of the Committee has been called for many years to the effect upon treaty Indians of the annual dole. Frequent instances have been reported of interruption to profitable pursuits by Indians, who lose days and much outlay in order to go to the meeting place where the annuity dole is to be given. In some cases, the loss of time and income exceeds the amount of annuity. Moreover inducements are often found at the meeting place to squander unprofitably their Treaty Bounty.

Your Committee consider that it would be well, as an incentive to industry, thrift and enterprise that recommendation be made to the Department of Indian Affairs that reasonable meetings through Indian Agents on Reserves, or through the League of Indians, which has the confidence of our native Indians, to influence Indian public opinion favourably to provision being made whereby Indians may give instruction to have the amount of their annuity become an annual deposit in the Indians' Savings Account to the credit of the individual Indian. The funds of the Savings Account should be available on easy terms, on recommendation of the Indian Agent of the Band or Reserve, to Indians engaged in farming or other profitable industry.

IV Defective and Delinquent Children:

Your Committee also submit the following resolution:

Whereas we greatly deplore the present necessity for placing defective and delinquent Indian children in the same schools with normal Indian children,

The Social Service Council of Canada recommends that the Indian Department undertake at the earliest possible moment the establishing of institutions for delinquent and defective children, such institutions to take the form of industrial farms, and to be at least two in number, one for Eastern and one for Western Canada.

V The Outside Service:

Since the abuses arising out of the practice of partisan political patronage were nowhere more
obvious than when Indians were the victims of the inefficiency of appointees, your Committee submits this resolution:

The Social Service Council of Canada notes with gratification the marked improvement in the Outside Service of the Department of Indian Affairs since the abolition of the patronage system, and would deprecate greatly any tendency toward a return to this system.

VI The Six Nation Indians:—

Your Committee has considered the disturbances fomented recently among the Six Nation Indians by agitators and others whose activities have brought about a grave situation, and have placed in jeopardy the best interests of the Indians concerned. The disturbance, where it flourishes most, is leading back to paganism and unbridled immorality, and even in the localities where it has not found fertile soil it has brought considerable inconvenience to the Indians who are loyal to their government and to their country as a whole.

The following resolution, it is therefore felt, should receive hearty adoption by the Council:—

The Social Service Council of Canada expresses its deep concern at the discussion raised by a certain section of the Six Nation Indians and their claim that they are not subject to the laws of Canada in general, whether Provincial or Federal, but rather are an independent nation in the midst of our country. The situation developed as a result of this contention would be impossible alike in law and in morals.

The Council therefore calls upon the Churches and the other bodies federated in the Council to uphold the hands of the authorities in maintaining law and order on the Reserves concerned. Meantime the Council expresses its confidence as well as its hope that every claim of the Six Nation Indians will be decided by an impartial body and full justice done alike to the Indians and to Canada.

VII The British Columbia Land Question:—

To the long-standing dispute on the subject of Indian title to British Columbia lands your Committee have devoted the major portion of their time and attention during the last year. It will be recalled that for many years the British Columbia Indians have been seeking recognition of their title, never ceded to the Province, or to the Dominion as had been done long ago in consideration of certain compensations by the Indians in other parts of Canada. Until quite recently it was felt by many who were interested in the welfare of the Indians of British Columbia that the claim of these Indians should be submitted to a competent court for settlement. This was, in fact, among the recommendations adopted last year by the Social Service Council of Canada. The situation, however, has recently altered. The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, after consultation with representatives of the British Columbia Government, has conceded the main point in dispute, by his statement of July 24th, 1922, that the Indians of British Columbia possess aboriginal title to the lands of the Province.

The following is an extract from the notable speech made on that day by the Honourable Charles H. Stewart in the presence of representatives of the Dominion Government and of various Indian tribes of British Columbia:

"Shortly after taking office I discovered that there were some difficulties in the Indian Department, but I think there is a possibility of settling the grievances in an amicable way. The thing for the Ministers to do is to meet the people who are subjects of our Country and discuss..."
these questions with them. As I mentioned to Mr. Pauli, when he was in Ottawa, I wanted today to hear a discussion of these questions, as we are greatly interested in these matters.

I do not want to go into detail, but to say that you are the aboriginal owners of this Province, as no treaty was ever made with the Indians of British Columbia.

The Province turned over control of certain interests to Ottawa when they entered Confederation and one of the agreements was that the Federal Government should take over the management of the Indians of British Columbia. Now this question has never been settled since British Columbia entered Confederation.

I have held conferences with Premier Oliver and other Provincial Officials and they are willing to meet the Federal Government half-way in the question of reserve lands and reserve rights in those parts of the Province where the Indians are engaged in farming and fishing for their living; that is, Indians who have no new lands will have to be purchased for this purpose.

I agree with Mr. Kelly that we will have to meet in a Royal Commission Conference to discuss these matters in detail. I am authorized to say that the Federal Government is prepared to give the Indians of British Columbia everything that has been given to the other tribes of Canada, who, unlike you, have treaties with the Government. There had been some talk after many years of promises and discussions resulting in nothing, that the issues should be referred to the Privy Council. When I entered this conference I stated my intention of trying to arrive at an amicable understanding without the necessity of putting the Indians to the cost of court proceedings. It was my opinion, and I am confirmed by the events of the day, that these things could be settled by a Government which would get about seriously considering them in a systematic and highly important manner.

I agree with Mr. Kelly that the Indians have to adapt themselves to new conditions in order to adapt themselves to new living as previously they earned all their rights to the white men who came into the country. I would like to see not only in British Columbia, but throughout Canada, the Indian put on a footing with his white brother in every walk of life. Let me close by saying that we want to have a settlement of all difficulties in the near future.

In consideration of the changed aspect of affairs thus indicated your Committee submit the following resolution for adoption by the Council:

The Social Service Council of Canada expresses its satisfaction at the announcement of the Dominion Government, conceding to the Indians of British Columbia the aboriginal title to lands in that Province, and with its expression of its hope of an amicable settlement without the necessity of putting the Indians to the cost of court proceedings.

REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON MOTION PICTURES

The Committee appointed by the Social Service Council of Canada to consider the subject of Motion Pictures wishes to submit the following report:

It will be recalled that at the last Annual Meeting of the Social Service Council of Canada, this Committee was asked to correspond with the Provincial Councils with a view to arriving at the best method of conducting a Commission of Review.

In view of this decision the Motion Picture Committee of this year has found the scope of its deliberations considerably diminished, and asks the Council after hearing reports from the various Provincial Councils to come to a decision as to what the work of this Committee shall be during the year 1923.

Meantime, the Committee submits the following resolution:

"Whereas the responsibility for cutting episodes from films which have been prepared only at the expenditure of much time and money is a great one, and

Whereas the weight of this responsibility is greater than one person should be called upon to carry, and

Whereas at present in some of the provinces of Canada it is customary for films to be viewed by only one censor,

Be it resolved that the Social Service Councils of the various Provinces be asked to recommend to the governments concerned that in future the Provincial Board of Censors consist of at least three members, so that at no time, in the ordinary course of events, will any censor be called upon to make decisions alone, and on his or her own responsibility."

Dear Mr. Learns:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, requesting certain information regarding the Indian residential schools that are maintained or assisted by this Department.

You will find enclosed a list of government-owned schools, showing the religious denomination, the pupilage and per capita grant allowed. Church-owned schools are grouped under denominations and also show the pupilage and grant allowed. In explanation I wish to state that the amount of per capita grant for boarding schools is determined on three bases: 1. ownership - government or church; 2. geographical situation - west, east and north; 3. type of building - well equipped and modern or otherwise. Two schools in the Yukon receive a higher grant than any others, because of the costs of food, clothing and other staple articles. Industrial schools each receive a per capita grant of $150, except in the province of Ontario, where they are classified in the same manner as boarding schools. In the industrial school class there are two exceptions to the general rule - the Mohawk Institute in Ontario, and the Lytton Industrial School, in British Columbia, which are financed solely by this Department and without assistance from any missionary society or order. I am hopeful that these two institutions will be able to finance on per capita grants of $160 and $180, respectively, during the fiscal year 1923-24. The information contained in the attached list is for the fiscal year 1922-23.

From time to time, it is necessary to increase the pupilage at those residential schools whose applications are numerous and whose accommodation can be provided. The pupilage figures in each case are those that obtained at the close of the fiscal year 1922-23. Occasionally, when a school is accommodating its full quota of pupils, and the Department finds it necessary to admit orphan or destitute children, we allow supernumerary grant for them, until such time as vacancies occur among the regular grant-earning pupils.

Relative to the second paragraph of your letter, I have to state that the per capita grant is to enable the principal to meet current expenses: food, clothing and salaries are the major items in this connection. Equipment and equipment replacements, repairs to buildings, pupils' travelling expenses, medical and veterinary services and supplies, and postage are the chief expenses at residential schools.

W. Learns, Esq.,
Assistant Auditor General,
Ottawa, Ont.
schools that are met by parliamentary appropriation, independent of the per capita grant. When funds are available, this Department meets expenses of every kind, with the possible exception of those incurred for food and clothing. The religious organization under whose auspices a school is operated may give grants to the principal, for salaries, to meet deficits and for any other purpose it sees fit.

There are some government-owned schools where church missionary societies or orders make special grants amounting to thousands of dollars per annum, in an effort to permit the school to give the type of instruction and residential care upon which we insist, and to keep the institution in a solvent condition.

Dear Mr. Scott,

At intervals during the past few years I have drawn your attention to the very poor instruction that our Indian boys are receiving at many of our training schools. My complaints have referred to both the technical training and that of the classrooms, but particularly to the former. Instead of improvement taking place there has been a steady retrograde movement, and I think steps should be taken by the Department to insist on better instruction being given to our boys.

A large percentage of the ex-pupils on leaving many of our Industrial and Boarding schools today know little or nothing about the care of stock and do not display as much intelligence along these lines as do many Indians who have never attended school, neither can they be entrusted with a team of horses in the majority of cases. Losses of Horses due to neglect on the part of these young men is, to say the least, startling, and I wish to point out that these losses take place in the face of the fact that only those graduates who are considered to be worthy to receive them are entrusted with these animals; that is to say only the best of the ex-pupils received them. If we gave such assistance to all who graduate our losses would be three times as great as they now are.

It is not only along these lines that the training received is of no real value because of its

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
in inefficiency; in regard to farming operations also, about fifty percent of the graduates leave school with a very limited knowledge of how to carry on this important work and many of them cannot do so any better than Indians who have never been at school. Of course there are exceptions where the training they have received at school has been of great benefit, but in such cases the Indian is usually an intelligent man who would probably have done fully as well with the ordinary supervision that is given by the Agents and farming Instructors on reserves.

I make these statements partly from personal observations and partly after hearing the opinions of Inspectors and Agents who have had to deal with this problem on the reserve. Particularly during the past two years I have been repeatedly told that ex-pupils are more careless of their property and less able to manage their affairs and work than those Indians who have not attended school. Most of these opinions I respect because they have been expressed by people living and working among the Indians and who know whereof they speak. In most instances where the graduates make good on their farms it is as a result of careful and helpful supervision and instructions by the Farm Instructors and Agents and not because of the training they have received at school.

You have had an opportunity of judging the training that is being carried on in the class-rooms of our schools and the class of teachers that is being employed to teach the Indian children. In very many cases the comments of the Public School Inspectors would lead one to believe that we are neglecting the children; wasting time and spending large sums of money and getting no results. Many times I have complained that our graduates on leaving school can hardly speak English, certainly many of them could not be employed as interpreters because of this lack of knowledge. I am continually receiving complaints from parents of the pupils regarding the poor education they are receiving at the schools and
and we must admit that in many cases the reports of the Public School Inspectors would go to prove that such complaints are not without reason. I can understand why they do not wish to send their children to some schools.

The schools of late have had a free hand in regard to the matter of employment of teachers and Instructors and you can judge from the reports you have had from the Department's own officers and the Inspectors of the Provincial Governments the kind of people that have been employed. One of the Provincial Inspectors is of the opinion that the employment of teachers in our Indian Schools should be left with them. The inference is that the heads of our Institutions are not competent to make a selection for themselves, and if this be true, it indicates a sad state of affairs.

I am not going to single out any particular school but I will say that we have men at the head of some of our important institutions at which they are supposed to teach practical farming, care of live stock, etc., who do not know the first thing about these essential branches of the work; men who could not begin to make a living at farming and who, nevertheless, have the responsibility of training our Indian youths in these important matters upon which most of them depend for a livelihood during the years thereafter they leave school.

In writing this letter to you I have in mind what you said at the time I referred to these matters when interviewing the Honourable, the Superintendent General just one year ago. Since then you have had reports from an independent source as to the class-room work, which bears out what I said. My remarks at that time were directed more particularly to the technical training of the boys. The subject under review was the Qu'Appelle Industrial school, the outcome of a report made by Inspector Christianson. I have not been advised what was done, if anything, so far as the technical instruction is concerned. Changes were made in the teaching staff but the new teachers were very little better than the ones they replaced and they too, have been removed, following a report from a Public school Inspector. One of the men reported
reported on by Mr. Christianson has been re-engaged to teach at another Indian School.

I hope I may be pardoned for saying that this Department is coming in for a great deal of criticism by the Public for the manner in which many of our schools are conducted, and I am satisfied there will be little improvement until such time as your officers in the field can feel that they will get support from the Department and that their recommendations will be given more consideration than has been the case in many instances in the past. You have two Inspectors who have made almost a life study of the various problems regarding the management of Indians and Indian Schools. Their reports, in my opinion, should be of the utmost value to the Department and should outweigh reports received from other sources. At present there is a feeling that these outside influence carry more weight.

The Department has spent a great deal of money and is going to spend more in building and re-building Indian schools, and all I can say is that unless there is a complete change in the methods very little will be achieved for the vast amount of money spent.

The Department's outside staff on all the reserves throughout the Three Prairie provinces has undergone an almost complete change in personnel. We have an entirely different type of men as Agents and Clerks and Instructors. We also have Travelling Nurses and resident matrons. These men and women have been chosen with care and there has been hearty co-operation between this staff and myself. Our Farming operations have increased one hundred percent during the last five years and there is no reason why our schools should not be brought up to a higher standard and do what is expected of them. The fact that Churches contribute to the maintenance of our schools is often used as a reason for dealing leniently and making allowances in regard to the staffs appointed. This has always been a handicap, but when it goes so far as to be responsible for almost a failure of our work, it is time to consider seriously the finding of some

some method by which the Department may have a free hand in making appointments and managing the various departments of the schools.

Yours very truly,
