Dear Mr. Graham:

I have given consideration to your letter of March 23rd, which appears to deal generally with the question of Indian education and the policy of the Department therein.

Dating from the establishment of the schools, there has been cooperation between the various religious denominations interested in this problem and the Government. There is no intention to alter this policy, and the Department does not intend to assume greater responsibility for appointments to the staff of the various schools than it has at present. As you must be aware, the appointment of teachers and instructors at Indian residential schools has rested with the church authorities, and your remarks that of late they have had a "free hand" is misleading. The Department has always exercised pressure upon the missionary societies to appoint persons properly qualified for all teaching and administrative functions. We shall continue to insist on the employment of properly qualified officers and, where it is reported that competent persons are not on duty, changes will be made through the proper channel.

The difficulties surrounding Indian education are well known and the problem of ex-pupils is no new one. We have always depended, as you seem to acknowledge, on the supervision of ex-pupils by farming instructors and agents. The whole tendency in your letter is towards the abolition of the schools or taking them away from the control of the churches, and the Department does not intend to do either the one thing or the other. The intention is to combat the difficulties which are inherent in the situation, and with

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
the loyal support of the Churches interested, to continue a system which has not been unproductive of good results. It is presumed that the Indian agents and farming instructors understand what their duty is with reference to ex-pupils; section 30 of the general instructions to agents deals with this important matter, but if you have any doubt in your mind on the question, they will be again instructed from headquarters.

I observe your remarks respecting your own harmonious relationship with the staff.

As you have been informed, the Department cannot give an unqualified undertaking that it will accept the statements of its officers and carry out their recommendations without question. I may state with pleasure, however, that it has been found that the judgment of our officers in the field from coast to coast is good, that they for the most part loyally agree with the policy of the Department and therefore receive, in return, encouragement and support.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

In concluding my report on the schools I wish to point out the necessity of giving our Indian boys more attention at both schools in the way of outside work, that is farming and the proper care of stock. I have mentioned this matter to you personally in conversation on several occasions, also in my reports for the last two years. I have tried to point out that most of our boarding schools lack in my opinion, this essential work. As I have often stated before, it is just as important that the boys receive this kind of education as that received in the class room. The trouble I find, not only here but in other places, is that the farmer at the school is not the class of man competent to give instruction in this line to the boys under his charge. I informed the Principals at both schools that now that the Department had spent a lot of money on the schools and in that way had given the churches what they asked for, in future the Department would inspect the schools often and that the work outside of the school would be considered just as essential as the work in the class room.

I sincerely hope that the Department will insist on the church authorities placing only men in charge of schools who have had actual experience along agricultural lines. Not only at these schools but in most of the schools I have visited they have certainly got to get a different class of man as farming instructor, and my argument in this matter can be borne out by the results that the Brandon Industrial school obtained with their stock this winter. There is no reason if the other schools were properly managed, why they could not do the same and it would certainly encourage the boys who are now attending school and I am quite sure they would be a different proposition to handle when finally discharged from the school.

(Sgd.) M. Christianson.
Inspector.
Dear Mr. Scott,-

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, acknowledging mine of the 23rd ultimo, in which I tried as best I could to bring to your attention for serious consideration the difficulties that your officers in the field are experiencing in handling many of graduates from some of our training schools.

You state that the Department has always exercised pressure upon the missionary societies to appoint persons properly qualified for all teaching and administrative functions, and that you will continue to insist on the employment of properly qualified officers. The Department is laboring under an entirely wrong impression if it is of the opinion that the pressure that has been exercised has had the desired effect in a great many cases. In these three provinces many of our schools are staffed by persons who are not qualified to teach or instruct our Indian children in the various departments over which they have charge. A great many of our teachers would not be allowed to teach in an ordinary country school. In support of this statement I need only refer you to the reports you have received from the various Inspectors of the Department of Education in these provinces. Have not these reports shown that in many cases the teaching and methods in our schools are very poor? Have not some of the reports gone so far as to say that we are depriving the Indian children of an education? It could not be otherwise with the unqualified men and women we have employed in our schools. The proportion of qualified teachers in our employ is very small.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General
Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
As far as the technical training is concerned, who is better able to judge of this than your own officers who have had long experience and years of actual contact with conditions as they exist? The reports of your Inspectors do not show that the training has been beneficial to any great extent, and I can assure you the results have not been what might have been expected, in view of the expenditure in connection with this training.

I take strong exception to your statement that the whole tendency of my letter was towards the abolition of the schools or taking them away from the control of the churches. I fail to see how my letter could possibly be construed as advocating or even suggesting either of these courses. I am in favor of the schools being carried on under the auspices of the churches; some of them are giving excellent results, but in those successful institutions they have properly qualified teachers and instructors.

I note your remark in the last paragraph that your officers in the field for the most part loyally agree with the policy of the Department and therefore receive in return encouragement and support. By past experience I have had reason to realize the truth of that remark and also to know that on the other hand, those who venture to point out defects and suggest improvements are not encouraged for the interest thus shown, but rather the reverse.

You refer in your third paragraph to the duties of Indian Agents and farm instructors towards ex-pupils. It was not to the duties of these officials that my remarks were directed, but I merely referred to the failures among ex-pupils to point out that many of them leave school and are handed over to Agents and Instructors without having had the training they should have had during the ten years at school, and consequently not so apt to make a success at farming. The necessity for competent instructors for the expupils is very real and they have an important work to do, but that is apart altogether from the experiences the young Indians should gain at school and which, in many cases, they do not get. The aim of my letter was to bring to the Department a realization of the necessity of insisting on properly qualified teachers and instructors being appointed in all the schools, by pointing out some results of the non-exercise of this prerogative.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Indian Commissioner

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

For the past five years a bonus has supplemented the per capita grant to Indian residential schools. The special grant has been made to relieve the financial burden of the Churches, which have been spending large sums of money, in an effort to maintain and educate the Indian children as well as was done before the war on the Government grant. Delegations, representing the Churches engaged in Indian work, have intimated on several occasions in the past few years that the continuance of the increased per capita grant is, from their standpoint, absolutely necessary, if the degree of efficiency that now obtains is to prevail.

This bonus has amounted to $20 per capita for each of the past three years, and I shall be pleased, with your concurrence, to incorporate it in the general per capita grant. Such action will result in simplified bookkeeping and a clear understanding on the part of principals and church workers as to the amount of their earnings.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

In reply to the inquiry from one of your constituents, whose letter I return herewith, I have pleasure in giving you the following information:

The Indian Residential Schools are conducted by the religious denominations interested, who receive a per capita grant for each pupil in attendance. The grant varies with the class of school and the ownership of the building. We pay a higher rate where the buildings are owned by the Church. Our grants run from $120.00 to $240.00 per annum. These grants have to be supplemented by Church funds. The staff is engaged by the Church, with the approval of the Department, and the schools are inspected by Inspectors of this Department and by the Inspectors of the Provincial Departments of Education.

Dear Mrs. Horne:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo and I note that you are interested in new fields for the evangelizing and education of our Indians. There are many pagan Indians in Canada, but they are either nomads in the northern parts of the provinces or are in zones where churches are already active. I am directing to you, under separate cover, our last Annual Report, and on page 28, et seq., will be found a census of our wards showing the religious denominations.

If, after a study of groups shown as aboriginal in belief, you are interested in any reserve or locality, you might write to me and I will recapitulate the history of church efforts, if any.

I regret that, at the present writing, I cannot encourage any schemes for the extension of our educational programme in Ontario or the Prairie Provinces, where the great majority of pagan Indians are found. The Department is now associated in the conduct and financing of over 150 day schools and 55 residential schools in these four provinces. The physical equipment at some of these institutions is below standard, and, for a few years at least, the Appropriation for Indian Education for Ontario and the Prairie Provinces will be required entirely for replacements. I am, therefore, not hopeful that funds will be available for the establishment of new educational centres where pagan Indians are to be found. It may be necessary to open one or two new residential schools in British Columbia during the next ten years, but the Indian fields in that province have been debated and largely divided by the churches interested in the work. Only 2% per cent. of the Indian population of British Columbia is known to be of aboriginal belief.

It may be necessary to erect a residential school for the Indian children of the Maritime Provinces. There are, however, no pagan Indians in these three provinces.

I will give careful consideration and any help possible, if you will make definite suggestions for activity in the immediate future; and later, when funds are available for the extension of our educational programme, you may rest assured that the Department will cooperate when suitable fields can be found.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Dear Mrs. Horne:

There are many pagan Indians in Canada, but they are largely nomads of northern localities or are in zones where churches are already active. If, after a study of groups shown as aboriginal in belief, you are interested in any reserve or locality, you might write to me and I will recapitulate the history of church efforts, if any, and describe local conditions.

As you are well aware, the Department, in cooperation with various missionary societies, has built up a system of day and residential schools for the education of Indian children. It is the intention of the Government to continue this policy of cooperation, and we are cordial to new interests and new offers. At the present time, the Department is providing new buildings and better equipment at schools already established. The completion of this work is considered of first importance. We have also long standing applications for new establishments and the possibility of meeting the needs of the situation is governed by the action of Parliament in providing appropriations and thus implementing the general policy.

When your Provisional Board has had an opportunity of discussing the question, I shall be very pleased to receive further communications from you.

Yours very truly,

I must say that the impression I have is that the officers of the Department are very often placed in most awkward positions through the Department not upholding them when they are in the right. The Department too often rely entirely on the information they get from one side, even going so far as to instruct the carrying out of repairs and alterations that are unnecessary, and when your officers in the field point this out they are brought into conflict with the church authorities, which is not at all satisfactory.

According to the Inspector, he is of the opinion that a lot of this work that we are called upon to do, if not all of it, could be done by the school authorities. Instead of that, it would seem that they will not move a foot in this direction, but call upon the Department for everything. This is such a contrast to Portage la Prairie, where they appreciate any little assistance that the Government give them, and where it is possible for them to get the work done themselves they do so. This unsatisfactory situation has sprung up within the last three years, and while my understanding is that the schools are to do as much as they can to keep their buildings in repair, the authorities at this particular school are certainly not under that impression.

It is unpleasant for me to write a letter of this kind, but I see matters getting worse all the time and our Inspectors being placed in a position which they should not be placed in. I am prepared at any time to show the Department where its weaknesses are in the management of Indian schools.

Sir:

I have your 304-11 of the 20th ultimo, with reference to principals of Indian residential schools absenting themselves from duty without permission from the Department. It is the practice of principals to acquaint the local Indian office and church authorities to inform the Department if a principal is to be away from his school for more than a few days during the academic year. There have been no complaints of late from any of our officers in Canada, except yourself, in this connection and it may, therefore, be considered that the present arrangements are satisfactory in the main.

It must be remembered that principals of Indian residential schools are employees of the various churches more than of this Department and more discretion and tact must be exercised in the prescription of rules and regulations than if they were on the staff of the Department.

The Department is not prepared to ask principals to acquaint us concerning absences during the holiday months of July and August. At this season, principals quite properly feel themselves more or less free from their more onerous duties; and as all responsible gentlemen, I feel it can safely be left with them to make satisfactory arrangements for the management of the schools during the vacation weeks.

If your office has in hand during the summer any activity which requires the presence of the principal of a school, it would be well for you to acquaint him with your plans and to ask that you be notified as to who will act as principal when he is not on duty.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Macdonald,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

The more important phase of the matter, however, has not been dealt with. The real trouble arises when principals of the residential schools are away at a time when it is important that they should be at home. Cases have occurred lately in which an Inspector of this Department has arrived at an institution of this kind expecting to transact important business, only to find that the principal is away. It is not necessary for me to point out that our inspectors are much too busy to make long, expensive trips, only to be handicapped in this way when they arrive.

I do not think the Church Authorities under whose auspices these schools are operated would have the slightest objection to their appointees being required to arrange with the Department when they desire to be away. It is not my wish to approach the matter in an arbitrary or domineering spirit - I merely wish to secure their cooperation with a view to greater harmony and efficiency. The point I wish to make particularly clear is that a great deal of valuable time has been wasted and work has been delayed on account of my not knowing that this, that, or the other man was not on duty at a time when his presence was necessary. This can be avoided by the Department requiring that leave of absence be arranged for through this office and I trust this will be done.

MEMO FOR FILE:

On January 19th, the Honourable the Superintendent General received a delegation from the churches interested in Indian educational work. His Lordship Bishop Williams (Huron) and Canon Gould represented the Church of England; Father Guy, the Roman Catholic and Dr. Edmison and Rev. Mr. Watts, the Presbyterian Branch of the United Church. The different speakers pointed out that the increase in the per capita grants since 1913 was not commensurate with the increase in wholesale prices and wages. Canon Gould pointed out that the Church of England average per capita grant in 1913 was $122 and for this year, $162. He pointed out that his Church and, he believed, the others were encountering huge deficits.

Father Guy thanked the Minister for assuming the major portion of the capital expense and seconded the requests of the others for a larger per capita grant. He also urged reclassification and that the necessary funds be placed in the Supplementary Estimates and submitted to the present session. Father Guy made a special plea that all work agreed upon by the Department and the Churches be actually carried out and that no local officer be given the power to veto these decisions.

Dr. Edmison drew attention to the fact that the Presbyterian Church were expending approximately $32,000 per annum for seven small schools and that a reclassification, which would mean an increase in per capita grant for the small institutions, should be considered.

The Honourable Mr. Stewart promised that he would give earnest consideration to the representations of the delegation.

Memorandum:

Referring to your memorandum hereunder, I wish to suggest that the following be substituted for the earlier instructions to agents concerning education:

EDUCATION.

27. Educational advantages are provided for Indian children in day and residential schools. The annual report of the Department shows the number and locality of these institutions by agencies. Agents should give careful attention to the administration of the schools and should bend every energy to increasing their efficiency. Department representatives should familiarise themselves with Sections 9 to 11 of the Indian Act, which relate to the education of Indian children.

28. Agents should report monthly on the work of each day school, using the form provided for the purpose. There will be found on the cover of classroom registers detailed instructions to teachers concerning the routine of the day school. The attention of agents is also drawn to the printed matter on the quarterly return form of this type of school. Agents should give special consideration to the matter of regular attendance of pupils. Truancy and lack of interest has, in the past, seriously militated against the success of day schools on Indian reserves.

29. Residential schools should be visited as often as is necessary in the conduct of Department business. Agents are asked to make a careful study of the conditions at each institution and to report from time to time concerning the activity generally. Please read the printed instructions on the quarterly return form for residential schools. Your special attention is drawn to circular of November 9, 1914, concerning recruiting pupils for the residential schools. This activity and the return of delinquents is an important feature of the duties of Indian agents. Circulars dated November 9, 1922, and February 23, 1925, have reference to applicants for admission to Indian residential schools and agents are asked to make a careful study of these writings. Circular dated May 20, 1926, concerning the annual leave is also drawn to the attention of agents.

30. The Department assists deserving ex-pupils of Indian schools whenever there is assurance that such assistance will be of permanent value. Grants are given for more advanced academic or vocational training and material assistance is granted to young couples who are establishing a home. Whenever an agent believes that a tuition grant or assistance should be allowed, he should correspond with the Department, giving full details. Agents, by advice and supervision, should assist young Indians to become economically independent.

31. The Department urges its field officers to make suggestions for improving any phase of the educational programme.

Dear Colonel Neary:

I thank you for your initial reply to my correspondence regarding the proposed site for the Mounted Police barracks on Walpole Island.

So far, I have had no further approach from any of your officials regarding this movement on the part of the Mounted Police, yet still I am receiving disquieting reports from the Island itself. Only this week my information was to the effect that the police authorities are still planning to build the barracks on Church property, south of our Rectory and slightly beyond the site for the new Medical Centre, which was arranged satisfactorily between us some months ago.

Let me once again make quite clear our position in regard to this land, which has been held by the Church of England for over 136 years. My information is that some members of your Indian Department are now claiming this land as public property. I am sure that you are not a party to this claim, and nothing in the relationship between ourselves and your department through the years that are past, will either substantiate this claim on the part of your subordinates or indicate that in any way your department wishes to act in this arbitrary fashion.

Let me emphasize that in the event of the Mounted Police taking the action that is now contemplated, we shall immediately seek redress through representation to the senior Members of the Government or in the Courts of the land. I cannot believe for a minute that you would tolerate this treatment of us, and I am confident that a word from you will set this matter in its proper light for those who are now disturbing us.

With grateful thanks for your many past kindnesses,

I am,

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Dear Major MacKay:

Re: Residential School teachers' salaries

You are acquainted, I am sure, with the difficulty the Administration is experiencing in hiring competent and qualified classroom teachers. The difficulty arises primarily from our inability to meet the salaries paid teachers in community and Indian Day schools. Another difficulty is that we cannot afford a pension or superannuation scheme for our workers.

Recently I had the pleasure of spending a day at the Mohawk Institute where the Indian Affairs Branch is responsible for payment of teachers' salaries. The Principal reported that the scheme was working out very well indeed and was a vast improvement over the old method whereby the teachers were paid from the per capita grant receipts.

I have discussed our problem with Colonel Neary and he has suggested I take it up with your office. It would be appreciated if we could have a discussion of this whole matter and its side issues, with a view to the possibility of instituting the same practice in I.A.S.A. schools, at a relatively early date. At your convenience a telephone call would suffice to set a time and date.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Colonel Neary:

Re: Per Capita Grants

On 6th March, 1950, I wrote you on the above subject in relation to the data tabulated in my letter on the advance in Cost-of-Living Indexes from 1st April, 1948 (the date from which our present scale of Per Capita Grants was effective) to 1st February, 1950.

Today we received the official Price Movement Bulletin, dated 4th April, 1950, of the Dominion Bureau of Statistics giving the Dominion Cost-of-Living Indexes as at 1st March, 1950. An examination of these figures show material advances since 1st February, 1950, in the Combined Index (2.1 points) and in the items that represent a great part of our normal school expenditure, viz Food (2.7 points) and Fuel & Light (.4 points). It is also noted that this bulletin states that the Combined Index of 163.7 on 1st March, 1950, "marked a new post-war peak, exceeding the previous high point of 162.8 for August 1, 1949".

It will be seen that from 1st April, 1948, to 1st March, 1950, cost-of-living indexes have increased as follows:

(a) Combined Index from 151.6 to 163.7, a point increase of 12.1 and a percentage increase of 8.

(b) Food Index From 186.8 to 204.0, a point increase of 17.2 and a percentage increase of 9.2.

(c) Fuel & Light Index from 121.3 to 136.3, a point increase of 15.0 and a percentage increase of 12.4.

I am certain that you will agree that the above data emphasizes the urgency of very early consideration of the proposals contained in the penultimate paragraph of my letter of 6th March, 1950.

Yours sincerely,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

Dear Major Mackay:

Re: Per Capita Grants

On Monday (4/11/50) when a delegation was so graciously received by Mr. Harris the matter of per capita grants was discussed. During the exchange of opinions on the subject you made mention that one item to be considered in an adjustment of grants was inefficiency in the operation of a school. I agree that it is an important item. However, during the last few years the administration has paid special attention to this factor in the operation of its many schools and to the best of my knowledge all of our schools are now operating as efficiently as circumstances at the school will allow.

I feel it only fair to point out that the government owns many of the schools we operate and, as owners of the buildings, the government is responsible for many of the "circumstances" under which we are expected to operate. If equipment is outworn or staff and pupil accommodation inadequate the Church or no other organization can be expected to operate efficiently under such circumstances.

I would respectfully point out also that it is hardly fair to compare the operational expense of a Church of England School with that of a Roman School. The latter denomination have many non-paid workers on their staffs (some of whom draw government salaries in the name of the school) which practice is foreign to Church of England methods of operation. Such comparison therefore ought not to enter into any consideration of the re-adjustment of grants to Church of England residential schools.

It would be appreciated if you would let me know of any school or schools under this Administration in which you consider the operation to be inefficient. I can assure you that once given the information the matter will be examined thoroughly.

Yours faithfully,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

With reference to your memorandum of November 8th enclosing copy of a letter received by the Minister from the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, I submit the following comments:

1. Per Capita Grants

Very careful consideration is being given to the representations received regarding an increase in these grants. However, a definite decision in the matter has not yet been reached.

2. Purchase of Buildings

(a) Moose Fort - Funds are available in the current year's appropriation for the purchase of this building, but we are still awaiting arrangements for obtaining proper title to the land on which the school is located.

(b) Fort George - A valuation of this building was obtained, but funds for its purchase are not available in the current year's appropriation.

(c) Wabasca - During the fiscal years 1948-49 and 1949-50, the Department expended an amount of slightly over $200,000.00 in the erection of a dormitory block. This building is now in use. At the present time we are giving consideration to purchasing one or two of the buildings still owned by the M.S.C.C., but we have not finally decided which buildings we require.
(d) Whitefish Lake - With the concurrence of the M.S.C.C., the Whitefish Lake School ceased to operate as a residential school effective June 30th, 1950. From September 1st, 1950, we are operating a two-room day school in the former residential school classrooms and we are also using the log building next to it for the teachers' living quarters. A small rental is being allowed for the use of these buildings, and the teachers' salaries are being paid by the Department.

(e) Aklavik - The situation at this point was reviewed by Departmental officials, and it was decided that it was not advisable for the Indian Affairs Branch to purchase this building. However, the Northwest Territories Branch of the Department of Resources and Development might be interested in purchasing it, and further negotiations regarding Aklavik should be directed to that Branch.

3. New Residential School Accommodation:

(a) Carcross - It is our intention to erect a new residential school to replace the present building. However, before proceeding with construction we are awaiting definite assurance that the area in the vicinity of Carcross will not be inundated as a result of possible commercial projects.

(b) With reference to the other five areas in which the M.S.C.C. considers residential school accommodation is lacking, it is noted that they will make further representations later.

Dear Mr. Harris:

We were very glad of the opportunity of discussing with you yesterday some of the problems relating to the management of the Indian Residential Schools. As we pointed out to you, the Church of England has for many years been operating a number of these schools in partnership with the Government.

Our purpose in seeing you yesterday was to lay before you three current problems relating to this partnership.

1. Per Capita Grants.

During the past ten years the costs of operating these schools have steadily increased - especially for such important items as food, clothing, wages and equipment. From time to time the churches concerned have both individually and collectively made representations to Government regarding this matter and asked for increase in the grants. We have always found the Government sympathetic and responsive to these requests. In 1946, 1947 and 1948 the grants were increased. In each case, however, there has been a serious time-lag between the increase in costs and the increase in the grants. As a result my Society has incurred an accumulated over-draft of over $180,000.

The last increase in the grants was made as from 1st April 1948. Since then the cost of living index has increased by 19.1 points or 12.59%. The attached memorandum, a copy of which was given to you yesterday, indicates what this means in the operating costs of the schools.

When the increase was made in 1948 it was based on

a. Cost of living index

b. Auditor's report of each school.
On this same basis, therefore, we ask

a. That the per capita grants to the several schools be increased commensurate to the increase of 12.5% in costs;

b. That the increase be made retroactive; and

c. That in future they be adjusted to rising costs, and therefore be reviewed quarterly.

As we pointed out to you, this increase would be entirely absorbed in maintaining necessary reasonable standards of food, clothing, wages and so forth.

We also pointed out that our auditor's statement shows that for the maintenance of the schools which we operated in partnership with the Government in 1949, the per capita grants were insufficient to meet the total expenditure by £96,000. This deficit had to be made up from the very slender resources of the church.

2. Purchase of Northern Schools.

During the years of the depression and the war, new buildings were needed for four of the northern schools - Moose Factory, Fort George, Carcross and Aklavik. As Government was unable at the time to assume the expenditure for these, it was undertaken by the Church.

In 1947, our Board of Management decided that request should be made that these school buildings be purchased by the Government. The proceeds would be used in the first instance to liquidate the over-draft of £160,000, referred to above, incurred in the operation of the schools.

The schools were inspected and valuated by Government officials - together with the two other Church-owned schools at Wabasca and Whitefish. The total valuation, £321,237, as set out in the attached schedule, was approved by my Society.

In September 1948 we were informed by your predecessor, the Honorable J.A. MacKinnon, that provision had been made for the purchase of the four northern schools. Later, in April 1949, the Honorable Colin Gibson, wrote that the matter was receiving the attention of departmental officials, and that it was hoped that a satisfactory conclusion could be reached in the near future.
As no part of the purchase has yet been completed, and as the annual meeting of our Board of Management will be held on the 21st November, we asked that we might have a definite report by that date.

3. The need of increased accommodation in residential schools for Anglican Indian children.

Although our Society is now carrying a heavy over-draft, and although the per capita grants are not commensurate with the present cost of operating existing schools, we drew your attention to the need for greatly increased accommodation. We referred particularly to six areas where necessary residential school accommodation is lacking. They were:

a. The James Bay Area. There are many more Anglican children in this area than the present schools at Moose Factory and Fort George can accommodate.

b. Northern Manitoba. Although the replacement of the McKay School at the Pas has been mooted from time to time, no school has yet been provided in this area for the many Anglican children.

c. Northern Saskatchewan. There are 450 children in the two schools in Prince Albert - probably the maximum capacity, yet there are many more children in the area for whom provision is needed.

d. British Columbia Coast. The school at Alert Bay is already overcrowded, yet there are other Anglican children - about 100 in the Naas country alone - for whom accommodation is needed.

e. Yukon. A formal request has already been made by my Society for a new building at Teslin to provide for the children now at Carcross - and others.

f. Mackenzie Delta. The accommodation in the Aklavik School is insufficient for the Anglican children of the area.

Mention was made in passing that the Roman Catholic Church was also feeling the need of increased accommodation for Roman Catholic children, and that Government was at present erecting three new schools for them.

You asked us to indicate the order of priority in which we would place the needs of the six areas. The need of the children in Yukon is at present the most urgent; we should welcome a favourable reply to the formal request we have already made on their behalf. As for the other five we shall have occasion to make requests on their behalf later, but are not prepared to do so immediately.
These then were the three matters which we wished to bring before you. It is our understanding that you will let us have your replies after you have had opportunity to enquire into them. We should greatly appreciate hearing from you in time for the meeting of our Board of Management on the 21st of this month.

Yours sincerely,

L. A. Dixon
General Secretary.

Dear Canon Dixon:

I wish to inform you that the responsible officers of Indian Affairs have given most careful consideration to the various points raised in your letter of November 7th, and while I regret that the Department is not able in all cases to arrive at a definite decision in respect thereto you may rest assured that we will continue to actively engage these problems in the hope that satisfactory solutions may ultimately be found.

The question of the per capita grant is, I know, of great importance to you. I know, also, that you will appreciate that there are many points of view and alternate proposals which must be carefully considered before the Department is in a position to decide on a firm policy which would be fair to all. Suffice it to say that while the Department is not at the moment in a position to make a definite statement it is a problem for which a solution must be found soon and to this end we are moving.

In regard to the purchase of buildings, the following Departmental views are placed before you.
**Moose Fort**

Funds are already available in the current year's estimates for the purchase of this building, and its finalization awaits only the registration of plans in order to secure title.

**Fort George**

Consideration will be given for purchase at a later date, and initial steps have already been taken towards that end.

**Wabasca**

You will appreciate that the Department has already, in the past two years, spent in excess of $200,000 in the erection of a dormitory block at this location. A decision has not yet been arrived at in respect to the purchase of Church-owned buildings at this point.

**Whitefish**

The Department will give consideration only to the purchase of such buildings as may be necessary for the operation of a day school.

**Aklavik**

This Department is not prepared to give consideration to the purchase of buildings, but it is a matter which might be referred to the Northwest Territories Administration for consideration at a later date.

**Carcross**

It is the intention of the Department to proceed with the erection of a new school at Carcross, or other suitable point, as soon as the necessary funds are available.
The matter of a suitable site is being reviewed and is at the moment clouded in that the prospective site may be required for commercial purposes.

I hope that the foregoing may assist you in your deliberations, and, in closing, I would point out that the Department is not unmindful of the historic and active role of the Church of England in Canada in the scholastic field among our Indians and, wherever possible, it is our desire to be of practical assistance.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Harris:

Re: Residential School Accommodation

This morning's post brought the following (an extract from his letter) from Principal Wickenden of the Shingwauk Home, Sault Ste. Marie.

"Miss Mandl came to me this morning and, with expressions of regret, announced that she was setting no satisfaction out of her work and after careful thought had decided to resign. The announcement came as a decided disappointment since Miss Mandl has achieved very good control over her junior boys in a short time and has shown skill in handling them. Her chief interest seems to be the teaching and training of young children, while here, of necessity most of her time is taken up with domestic chores in the dormitory, washroom, playroom etc. I may say that, in this connection, she has had every consideration from Miss Spinney who, with the assistance of Miss Titley, has relieved her of the bulk of the boys' supervisor's duties in the care and maintenance of clothing in order that she might have opportunity to get to know her boys and be with them. Miss Mandl feels frustrated in her efforts by lack of facilities for keeping her juniors together, and it so happens that this year we have quite a number of very small children on either side who need special care. As you know we have only one playroom and this is meant to accommodate all the boys, from pre-school to Gr. 12. Furthermore there is the usual single washroom for everybody and inadequate lobby space for clothing. Some supervisors succumb to the rough and tumble and reconcile themselves to dirt and untidiness. Some fight against it and fret continually. Some, like Miss Mandl, feel that..."
proper standards are impossible of attainment and will not accept a compromise. In short this lady feels that we have insufficient workers to care properly for the children and inadequate quarters."

It is the sort of thing with which we are constantly confronted. We hire into our service trained and competent workers who soon become disgruntled and frustrated because accommodation in the schools does not allow for decent care of the children. During the past few years we have lost a great many trained and experienced-in-other-institutions workers for the reason mentioned above.

Of recent years, Indian Affairs and health authorities have demanded of our schools higher standards not only academically but in the health and care of these Indian children. It is a case of expecting us to "make bricks without straw" - decent citizens without the means to make them such. Sometimes government officials intimate that our operation of Residential is inefficient and that our operational costs are too high. With the facilities given us we cannot begin to administer the schools any better. Our staff turnover is high and costly because we are not given the necessary equipment and accommodation to retain decent standards.

I would plead most strongly that when Indian Affairs creates any new policy in regard to Residential School work we in turn be given the facilities to carry out the extra work required. Or, on the other hand, that no new policy be created that will not fit in with the facilities at our disposal.

Once again I urge that Indian Affairs Branch create some sort of consultative committee made up of representatives of the Church organizations operating these Residential Schools for government and Indian Affairs officials so that changes of policy, equipment of schools and location of schools may be decided upon by all concerned. Long before the government took an active interest in the education of Indian peoples the Church operated Residential Schools and we are, by no means, without experience. Such a committee would, I am sure, be beneficial to the Government, Church and the people we try to serve.

Yours faithfully,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.
December 26, 1950.

Dear Canon Cook:

Residential School Accommodation

I have for acknowledgement your letter of December 1 concerning accommodation at Indian Residential Schools.

I have noted the extract from the letter sent you by Principal Wickenden of the Shingwauk Residential School at Sault Ste. Marie. Our records show that there are two playrooms in this school, one for the boys and one for the girls. Each is 29 ft. wide and 41 ft. long.

As you are aware, the Shingwauk Residential School is of a standard type and a similar shortage of playroom accommodation exists at other Residential Schools. It is unfortunate that this is so, but these schools were erected at a time when such play space was thought to be adequate.

Now we are faced with the need for adding to this play area, and at the same time we are faced with the need for providing initial classroom accommodation for over 6,000 children who have no educational facilities of any kind.

You can, therefore, understand why, at the present time, we are giving priority to the erection of schools to serve areas where no schools have previously existed.

In other words, we realize that several of our Residential Schools need additions to provide playrooms, classrooms, etc., but we must first face the need for providing schools for those Indian children who have never had any previously,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Harris:

We greatly appreciated the sympathetic and understanding hearing which you gave our joint deputation last Tuesday.

The memorandum which the deputation left with you set out in brief the requests which we made jointly. By way of support and confirmation of those requests I am directed to send you the following information relating to schools administered by the Church of England.

1. Per Capita Grants.

The audited statement of our Indian School Administration (Anglican) for 1949 reveals the following:

a. Total expenditure $581,598.34

This is made up of

(1) Cash expenditure $528,935.75
(2) Clothing supplied $52,662.59

b. Revenue from Dominion Government $481,009.33

This is made up of Per Capita Grants, staff grants, and special grants.

c. Excess of expenditure over revenue $100,589.01

d. Average Pupilage 1,496

e. Average expenditure for pupil $389

f. Average revenue per pupil from Dominion Government $322
While the Church of England has met the deficit of $100,589.01 for the year 1949, it has done so only at the expense of other branches of its work. We feel therefore that it is not unreasonable to ask that the grants be increased immediately and that the increase be made retroactive.

2. Buildings.

The following are the needs of the Church of England under the three classifications mentioned in the memorandum:

a. Buildings needing to be enlarged:
   (1) Moose Factory.
   (2) Fort George.
   (3) Sioux Lookout.
   (4) Aklavik.
   (5) Gleichen (Old Sun).

b. Buildings to replace those destroyed:
   (1) Northern Saskatchewan - Lac la Ronge.
   (2) " - Onion Lake.
   (3) Northern Manitoba - McKay School at The Pas.

c. Buildings required in new areas:
   (1) Southern Yukon - To replace present school at Carcross.
   (2) Naas River, B.C.
   (3) York Factory - Hudson Bay

We would emphasize the fact that because of the great lack of building accommodation, literally hundreds of Anglican Indian children are at present deprived of the opportunity of education.
3. Joint Advisory Board.

Our experience leads us to point out that such a board is necessary in connexion with problems arising out of the equipment and maintenance of the schools. We have reason to believe that we have much to contribute in consultation as a result of many years of experience; and further, that such consultation is decidedly preferable before action is taken than after.

4. Special Indian Curriculum.

Since so many of the children in our Anglican schools are nomads of the North, we are only too well aware of the fact that the present curricula for primary grades are capable of great improvement.

We are encouraged to know that you felt that the requests in the memorandum were not unreasonable. We devoutly hope that they can be granted at an early date.

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian Residential Schools - Payment of Teachers' Salaries.

At the recent meeting of our Executive Committee a letter from Colonel B. F. Neary, dated 26th December, 1950, on the above subject was presented for consideration. As a result I have been instructed to send you the following statement which the meeting approved:

"That in view of the dissatisfaction of our Indian School Administration with the recent experiments at Alert Bay and Moose Factory, the General Secretary be asked to notify government that M.S.C.C. favours the system of government paid teachers as at present constituted, but would make the following recommendations regarding such a system:

(1) That the government take over the paying of teachers only after separate classroom and teacher accommodations are provided by government outside the residential school.

(2) That all Churches operating residential schools come under the same system, and that the qualifications of all teachers in all schools merit the standards of the Department of Education of the Province or territory in which the school is located.

(3) That adjustments be made in the number of teaching days and holidays to allow for the children to have the two month holiday period away from the residential school. This would not apply to orphans and children from broken homes."
(4) That representatives of the Churches operating such schools comprise a committee with governmental representatives to formulate general and overall policy and to give guidance and advice in specific cases.

(5) That per capita grants be retained at a sufficiently high figure to allow for the hiring of extra supervisors and staff members."

Yours faithfully,

Dear Major Mackay:

In a number of our schools across the country we are finding that the number of pupils held in residence over the holiday two month period is increasing considerably. This is due mainly to two reasons - (a) The establishment of day schools has changed the type of child entering these residential schools. Where formerly we got youngsters from progressive Indian families interested in their children getting an education we now get more orphans and children from so-called "broken homes". The former are now attending day schools to an increasing degree while the latter have no place to go during the summer. (b) Many agency superintendents are asking us to keep certain pupils all summer in an effort to allow them to escape the unsatisfactory social conditions of their home village or reserve.

While we are glad to render this service to the Indians peoples it is nevertheless imposing on our schools an abnormal financial burden. We have to retain larger summer staffs and that costs money also the ever increasing price of foods is an item that cannot be overlooked in this regard.

In that the per capita grant system was incorporated with the understanding that the children would be in residence ten months of the year it would be appreciated if Indian Affairs branch could institute a form of bonus payment, over and above the regular grant, for youngsters retained in residence during the summer months. I'm quite sure you'll see the justice of this request.

Yours faithfully,

I have reviewed the files to which reference is made hereon, in view of the questions raised in Canon Dixon's letter to the Minister dated June 4, 1951.

(a) AKLAVIK

The Director's letter of March 23, 1950 stated that the matter of purchasing the Aklavik School had been shelved by the Sub-committee on Education for the Northwest Territories. It may now be proper to suggest to Canon Dixon that the M.S.C.C. communicate with the Commissioner for the Northwest Territories. You will note that in his memorandum to the Director dated March 17, 1950, Colonel Neary doubts that the Northwest Territories Council "ever considered this matter". On file 160-2 under date of November 18, 1950 the Director suggests to our Deputy Minister that the M.S.C.C. should address the Minister of Resources and Development regarding this purchase.

Agreement was reached with the M.S.C.C. that in lieu of purchase (as the Residential School was closed on June 30, 1950) the Department would pay $50.00 a month for accommodation to be used as classrooms and as living quarters for the teachers. A review of the correspondence and memoranda confirms the need for buildings additional to the dormitory block which the Department erected. Dear Mr. Harris:

We are grateful for the time which you gave to Canon Cook and myself when we called to see you on the 28th May, and for the sympathy and understanding with which you received the several questions which we laid before you.

1. Per Capita Grants.

We are duly grateful for the recent 5% increase. As we explained to you, it has been very acceptable, but has not been adequate.

As an indication of the practical difficulty confronting us we pointed out that whereas our expenditure for food in 1948 had been $133,000, in 1950 it had been $182,000, an increase of 36%. The corresponding increase in the per capita grant had been approximately 6%.

For 1951 we estimate that our expenditures will exceed those of 1950 by $80,000. Toward this, the recent 5% increase in per capita grants will amount to $20,000, leaving an estimated net excess of $60,000. This presents us with one or more possible alternatives:

a. To reduce staff salaries - and so impair the quality of the work;

b. To reduce the standards of management - food, clothing, etc. - which are already none too high.

c. To incur a deficit and so add to our already heavy overdraft - which our Society refuses to consider.

In view of the above, our request to you was that the present 5% increase be further increased by 15% as from 1st January 1951.
2. Sale of Northern Schools.

On the 7th November 1950, I wrote to you confirming our talk with you the previous day. In my letter I referred to the negotiations which were initiated in 1947 with reference to the purchase by Government of six northern residential schools which had been erected with church funds. As there pointed out, the proceeds from such sales would be used in the first place to liquidate the overdraft of $160,000 incurred by our Society during the war years.

In your reply of the 20th November 1950 you referred to the existing situation in the case of each of the six schools. To these we referred as follows:

a. Moose Fort. We have been informed that the cheque for this school has been issued but has not yet been released. We have written to the Director about the furniture and equipment in the school, and also about the former hospital building, now being used as a residence for the principal, but have not yet had reply.

b. Fort George. In your letter you stated "Consideration will be given for purchase at a later date, and initial steps have already been taken toward that end". Since then we have had no further word. Could you kindly let us know what further action has been taken?

c. Wabasca. The new Government building has been erected on our Church property. Government still finds it necessary to use some of our buildings. We have enquired about the purchase or renting of these buildings but have had no reply.

d. Whitefish. You have written "The Department will give consideration only to the purchase of such buildings as may be necessary for the operation of a day school". We should be glad to know what further action has been taken.

e. Aklavik. This building was erected by our Society in 1936. In 1949 the appraiser from the Department of Public Works valued it at $124,600, an estimate which our Society approved. On 23rd March 1950 the Director wrote that it had been decided to take no action with regard to purchase. We feel that this action would not be fair to our Society, and we therefore ask that the matter be given further and favourable consideration.

f. Carcross. You have written "It is the intention of the Department to proceed with the erection of a new school at Carcross, or other suitable point, as soon as the necessary funds are available".
As we explained to you there are extenuating circumstances which make the situation at Carcross particularly urgent. The present temporary building, erected with Church funds during the war, is now inadequate. As a result Anglican children are being admitted to other non-Anglican schools in the area.

If provision has been made in the current estimates for a new building, we should like to know for what total pupilage there will be accommodation. We should also like to know what action the Government is taking regarding the purchase of the present Church-owned building.

As I mentioned above, this whole question has been under consideration since 1947. It has been presented successively to your predecessors Dr. Keenlyside, the Honorable J. A. MacKinnon and the Honorable Colin Gibson. In each case it has been favourably received, but as yet no part of the sale has been completed. We should appreciate it if early action could be taken and the completion expedited.

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Survey of the Interior Economy of Church of England Indian Residential Schools

Since the time that you first mentioned this matter I have given it some thought and have discussed it briefly with Mr. School Inspector Mingay.

It would be helpful, I think, if the Director were to look over this memorandum so that any misapprehensions on my part at least may be avoided.

It is understood that this project will be assigned to committees comprising departmental officials and church representatives. The Department has a greater choice of representatives than the Church although, with the exception of Major Davy, our own school inspectors have so far had very limited opportunities to study the operation of Indian residential schools. The committee to study each school might accordingly comprise the Regional Supervisor, Agency Superintendent and School Inspector concerned together with a representative of the Anglican School Administration and the Education Division, the last two supplying the necessary integrating and unifying element. The Principal of each school is, presumably, the star witness at each inquiry.

The terms of reference may be stated as "to discover whether there are any practicable changes in the interior economy of Anglican residential schools whereby such schools may be operated at a lower per-pupil cost to the Anglican Indian School Administration."

In arranging a schedule for the inquiries it seems necessary that the members of the committee (especially those who are not fully acquainted with the workings of any school) should visit the
schools when the institutional routines are operating at a fair approximation of the normal potential. This consideration would retard the beginning of the survey until late in August. Probably the Fort George School will be operating at full potential by the 25th of August.

The desirable composition of committees (i.e., the same representatives from Ottawa working with each local authority so as to unify and integrate the procedures and results) will require the survey to be spread out over several weeks, and some fairly flexible schedule of visits to the schools involved will have to be planned. This schedule may be adjusted so that those schools which are habitually slow in gathering momentum may be the last visited. In Ontario, for example, the two James Bay Schools get under way first and Sioux Lookout is possibly the slowest starting. In Manitoba there are no schools to be considered. In Saskatchewan the Principal of the newly reorganized school at Prince Albert should be allowed part of September to experiment with procedures in the new organization. In Alberta, St. Paul's School is likely to be running a poor second to Old Sun's. In British Columbia, Alert Bay offers several problems that should receive the fullest attention of all concerned. There is at several schools the need to regulate the relationship of departmentally paid teachers to the operating authorities.

Some preliminary steps are indicated as necessary or desirable. I think that those who are to make the inquiry should first review the audit reports on the schools to be surveyed. The Anglican School Administration should be requested to direct each Principal to prepare a statement of the manner in which his school is operated including mention of any changes he has made in procedures and the effect thereof and any changes that have been suggested and not made and the reasons for not making them. These statements by principals are to be regarded as privileged documents to be shown to the investigating committee without previous censorship by superiors in the church or department, and it must be understood that the principal or any member of his staff may speak frankly to the committee without prejudice to his or her employment and prospects. This procedure should, I think, be discussed with and understood by the Reverend Canon Cook and the church representative on the committee.

As such investigations require some criteria to give the results validity, I suggest that the officials who are to undertake
this project should make some attempt in the near future to acquaint themselves with procedures and costs in institutions of a comparable nature. At this time of year provincial institutions for difficult children are probably the only comparable institutions operating at full potential. We in Ottawa might economically spend a few hours at the St. Joseph's (R.C.) Training School for Boys at Alfred, Ontario - 41 miles away. If time and funds were available it would be desirable to get the reactions of the church representative to procedures at Mohawk Institute and possibly the Ontario Training School for Boys at Guelph and for Girls at Cobourg. Similarly, the inspectors concerned in other provinces might in the meantime get some acquaintance with comparable provincial institutions in Western Canada.

As soon as possible it would be well to inform all those officials who will be concerned just what the terms of reference are and to give them some guidance in orienting their thinking. They may also be able to furnish us in advance with material that will be helpful to all who are undertaking this inquiry.

C.A.F. Clark,

In a letter addressed to the Honourable W. E. Harris, Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, dated November 7, 1950, the Reverend Canon L.A. Dixon, General Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, mentioned the following areas where he stated their Society considered necessary residential school accommodation is lacking:

(a) The James Bay Area

In the Appropriation for the fiscal year 1951-52 an amount of $100,000.00 is provided for the erection of a new building in connection with the Moose Fort Residential School. The Engineering and Construction Service has not yet completed the plans and specifications but it is intended to provide dormitory accommodation and use the present building for classroom purposes.

(b) Northern Manitoba

Replacing of MacKay School at The Pas

The MacKay School was destroyed by fire on March 19, 1933. Since that time a number of day schools have been erected in the area from which this school formerly recruited its pupils. The Departmental field officials have not urged the replacement of the former MacKay Residential School.

(c) Northern Saskatchewan

The Reverend Canon Dixon wrote as follows:

"There are 450 children in the two schools in Prince Albert - probably the maximum capacity, yet there are many more children in the area for whom provision is needed."

The Residential School at Onion Lake, Sask., was destroyed by fire on December 1, 1943, and another residential school, also under Church of England auspices, at Lac la Ronge, was destroyed by fire on February 2, 1946.

Neither of the above schools has been rebuilt.
To provide accommodation for Church of England children in Saskatchewan the Department rented from the Bishop of Saskatchewan the St. Alban's School located in the town of Prince Albert, and also took over several buildings in the former military camp located on the outskirts of Prince Albert. Considerable renovations have been made in the buildings that have been used in the military camp and at the request of the Missionary Society of the Church of England it has been decided to discontinue the use of St. Alban's School in Prince Albert and provide additional accommodation in the military camp. To carry out this work we have recently awarded the tender of $59,592.04 mentioned on page 2.

The Department also owns the Gordon's Residential School located near Punnichy, Saskatchewan. The use of this building had to be discontinued four years ago owing to the water supply giving out. The Departmental engineers have made several attempts to secure water but so far without success. A departmental engineer visited Saskatchewan several weeks ago and at the present time another attempt is being made to locate water. If this is successful there will be accommodation for approximately 100 children in the Gordon's School, which is a first-class building.

(d) British Columbia Coast

The Reverend Canon Dixon wrote:

"The school at Alert Bay is already overcrowded, yet there are other Anglican children - about 100 in the Nass country alone - for whom accommodation is needed."

Arrangements are being made with Indian Commissioner Arneil to have a survey made of the district in the near future with a view to determining if another residential school should be erected.
(e) Yukon

Reverend Canon Dixon wrote as follows:

"A formal request has already been made by my Society for a new building at Teslin to provide for the children now at Carcross - and others."

As stated on page 2, it is the Department's intention to replace the present Carcross School.

(f) Mackenzie Delta

Canon Dixon wrote:

"The accommodation in the Aklavik School is insufficient for the Anglican children of the area."

This building is owned by the Church of England and Indian Eskimo and white children are enrolled.

As a result both the Northwest Territories Administration of the Department of Resources and Development and the Department of Citizenship and Immigration are interested and it has been decided to delay consideration of providing funds for additional accommodation until further information is available.

I would like very much to see him in our service, and I am sure that he would be an excellent man for the principalship of one of our residential schools, for which he has a good background. Whether or not this would interest him, of course, I do not know. The last time I saw him I asked if such a job had any attraction for him when he left Fairbridge, but he seemed to have another prospect which was more attractive. However, I would appreciate it if you could give me his address, as I would like to sound him out again on that idea. I am afraid that any proposal will reach him too late, as I realize that he will have to indicate definitely in a short time his intention with regard to the principalship which you are offering him.

I hope that this finds you and Jean and the family well. There is no prospect of our getting west for a few years, but perhaps you and Jean will be able to take a summer trip east in the near future and we will have an opportunity of seeing you. Very best wishes.

Revised Memorandum Re: Problem of admittance to Residential Schools of Indian children of uncertain Religious Affiliation.

The old Indian Act, in Chapter 98, Section 9, Paragraph 2, stated...

"Such school shall be the nearest available school of the kind required, and no Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school under Protestant auspices."

During the period of the revision of the Indian Act Bill 267 was presented for first reading in Parliament June 7, 1950. Section 118 of Bill 267 - bearing on the subject of this memorandum read....

"Every child who is required to attend school shall attend such school as the Minister may designate, but no child who is in the care or legal custody of, or whose parent or guardian is a Protestant, shall be assigned to a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices; and no child who is in the care or legal custody of, or whose parent or guardian is a Roman Catholic, shall be assigned to a school conducted under Protestant auspices."

Bill 267 was not accepted and so on February 27, 1951 Bill 79 as "an Act Respecting Indians" was tabled in Commons. In Bill 79 the section corresponding to 118 of Bill 267 was renumbered as section 117 and changed to read....

"Every child who is required to attend school shall attend such school as the Minister may designate, but no child whose parent is a Protestant shall be assigned to a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices and no child whose parent is a Roman Catholic shall be assigned to a school conducted under Protestant auspices, except by written direction of the parent."

It is evident from a reading of the three quotations immediately above that, in substance, they mean the same; however in 117 of Bill 79 the clause "except by written direction of the parent" has been added.

After studying Bill 79 the I.S.A. Superintendent wrote Colonel Fortier (Deputy-Minister of Citizenship and Immigration) on March 2, 1951 in part as follows:

.....2
"I have gone through the portion headed "Schools" and am disappointed to find such a change in the wording of section 117 which corresponds somewhat to section 118 of Bill 267. I think the interpretation of the new section is open to much more misunderstanding than the section in Bill 267. I'm quite sure it will only add confusion when put into practice in the field."

The Deputy Minister must have discussed the letter with the Honourable Walter Harris (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration) as the Superintendent, Indian School Administration, was asked to call on Mr. Harris on 7/3/51 to discuss the section on "Schools".

Stated briefly the questions discussed are recorded below (q), with the Minister's replies summarized in the (a) sections.

q - 1. Questioned the wisdom of the removal of the words "or guardian" from section 118 Bill 267.

a - 1. "Guardian" was removed because it was felt that a guardian might be of a different religious affiliation from the parent and if the guardian were free to determine the denomination of the school it would add to confusion generally.

q - 2. Questioned who would determine the school to be attended for a child of mixed R.C. and non-R.C. parentage.

a - 2. Each questionable case would be decided upon by the Minister or Director after examination of all available facts and circumstances.

q - 3. Questioned wisdom of "except by written direction of the parent" section 117, Bill 79.

a - 3. This phrase was added chiefly to allow Indian children to attend Indian Day Schools or Provincial Public Schools if accommodation in such was conveniently possible. The Minister gave assurance that where evidence showed that bribery or persuasion by a religious body had been used to influence the parents the written request of the parent would be ignored and the Minister decide where the child would attend school. The Minister also stated that, if evidence was found of using this phrase as a lever in proselytizing the section would be amended.

q - 4. Pointed out that as Section 117 stood in Bill 79 - children might be changed from school to school on the slightest
provocation.

a - 4. On this point the Minister reiterated his stand that the Minister or Director had the final say and that neither would tolerate any evidence of proselytizing.

When Mr. Harris reviewed Bill 79 with a representative group of Indians at an Ottawa meeting the Indians made no protest on any section dealing with "Education" save that they all favoured Government Day Schools over Church operated Residential Schools.

Eventually Bill 79 was passed through Commons and became "The Indian Act" (Statutes of Canada 1951) on September 4th, 1951. Section 117 of Bill 79 was incorporated into the New Indian Act unchanged in any way.

For years past the Administration has had to face the problem of Church of England children being taken into Roman Catholic Schools. Wherever possible and wherever documentary proof of religious affiliation could be produced the Administration has protested such action and, quite frequently, with success. However since the New Indian Act came into effect the tempo of Church of England pupils being admitted into Roman institutions has accelerated. It is apparent that the Roman authorities feel that all that is required to allow Church of England pupils into their schools is a written statement to that effect from either one or both of the parents. Then too the Romans seem to contend that if either parent of a child is or has been a Roman Catholic they have a claim on the youngster.

The experience of the I.S.A., over the last few months in particular, is that the Indian Affairs Branch authorities appear to favour the Roman Catholic Church wherever decisions have to be made as to which school a pupil, of disputed religious affiliation, ought to attend.

The following examples summarize some of I.S.A.'s recent experiences in this connection.....

Fort George: Upon receiving intelligence from Principal Shepherd that 10 children, whose respective parents are both Church of England, were enrolled as pupils at the R.C. Residential School, I.S.A. wrote Major Mackay, under date 5/3/51, pointing out that such was inconsistent with the Indian Act. In the same letter Indian Affairs Branch was asked if these particular pupils were grant earners for the R.C. School and if so, why?
During an interview with Major Mackay in his office on 5/10/51 he stated that he had no knowledge of I.S.A. letter of 5/3/51 and Mr. Phelan asserted that he knew nothing of the letter. On 6/10/51 a copy of the letter was posted to Major Mackay.

On 16/10/51 Mr. Phelan informed that 8 of the 10 children mentioned in I.S.A. letter of 5/3/51 were grant earners at the R.C. School as there was no indication on their application as regards religious affiliation.

Later investigation showed they were recorded as "Christian".

Bishop Marsh took up this matter with Colonel Fortier on 17/10/51 and Colonel Fortier stated to the Bishop that the matter would be corrected and the children taken from the R.C. School.

On 21/12/51 Colonel Fortier informed I.S.A. that their office had no definite proof that the children under discussion were Church of England and that Indian Affairs Branch was writing their agent on the subject. (The information as to children's religious affiliation on file by I.S.A. is copied from the parish register at Fort George.) (Note the time between dates - during which time I.A.B. apparently made no attempt to find out religious affiliation of pupils concerned.)

On 10/1/52 Canon Shepherd gave the names of 9 children of Church of England parentage, at that time, in the R.C. School at Fort George. The list did not correspond with the former list as supplied by the Canon which gave evidence that there was a rotation of Church of England pupils into the R.C. School.

On January 15/52 Bishop March and I.S.A. Superintendent again visited Colonel Fortier, Major Mackay and Mr. Phelan and discussed the problem. At this meeting Mr. Phelan informed that 5 of the children mentioned in I.S.A. letter of 5/3/51 were still in the R.C. School. He did not state how many other Church of England pupils were in the R.C. School but Canon Shepherd's letter gives the names of 4 over and above the 5 mentioned by Mr. Phelan. A copy of I.S.A. letter to Major Mackay on this phase of the matter is quoted below.

Still another case exists in the Yukon in connection with a Church of England lad named "Clyde Blackjack".

The story behind this case, (on information gleaned from various sources roughly, is as follows - Bishop Coudert (R.C. Bishop of Yukon) apparently wrote Indian Affairs that as Clyde aged 14 years of Carmacks had no family to look after him he ought to be sent to the Lower Post School. Mr. Phelan instructed Mr. Meek to admit the boy to Lower Post if the case warranted his being taken care of in an institution. As the lad lives at Carmacks with an uncle and as Mr. Meek was unable to go to Carmacks for quite a time after Mr. Phelan's letter no action was taken. However during the time of no action the J.P. from Carmacks wired Mr. Meek asking if the boy Clyde could be put into either Mr. Lee's or the Carcross Schools as he was Anglican. Mr. Meek - in light of Bishop Coudert's letter - thought it wise to check religion and was assured by the uncle of Clyde - Clyde's older brother who is a patient in Whitehorse hospital, and the Indian census that Clyde was Anglican. This was explained by Mr. Meek in a letter to Mr. Phelan - giving quotes of telegrams between Carmacks and Whitehorse on the subject. Mr. Phelan apparently instructed that the lad was to be entered at Lower Post and admission forms forwarded to Ottawa.

Apparently Ottawa I.A.B. Head Office is trying to lay the blame for the removal of the pupils from Old Sun to Crowfoot on the Agency Superintendent though the instructions in the communications (quoted above) of February 29 are perfectly clear.

On May 2, 1952 Mr. Phelan wrote Mr. Pugh (with copy to Old Sun School) "With reference to the Yellowhorse children..."
it is presumed that these children are back in the Old Sun School.

In reference to the Yellowhorse children Principal Cole wrote I.S.A. Ottawa office under date May 11, 1952 -

"Ever since Mr. Phelan gave the "go sign" to the Principal of the Crowfoot School to take the children the Yellowhorses simply have not been in School (the R.C. School). They positively refuse to stay in the R.C. School."

On May 13 Principal Cole wired Ottawa I.S.A. Office -

"DAVID YELLOWHORSE RETURNED SCHOOL THIS DATE PERCY YELLOWHORSE COMPOUND FRACTURE CALGARY HOSPITAL"

By all accounts it appears the Yellowhorse boys ran away from Crowfoot (R.C.) School to Calgary. Fr. Charron apparently was unsuccessful in getting them back to Crowfoot and Percy was run over by a taxi as he was sleeping in a Calgary back lane.

On May 22, 1952 I.S.A. Head Office received the following information from Principal Cole -

"Marie and Sylvia Yellowhorse returned to this School 5 p.m. 17-5-52.

Phyllis & Bert Nelson Mayfield have not returned as of 11 a.m. 18-5-52"

This information was passed on to Indian Affairs Head Office by 'phone (May 22) with the request that early action be taken to return the other children to Old Sun School. Major Mackay and Mr. Phelan were not up to date on the situation and stated communication would be made with the Agent.

On May 26, 1952 Mr. Davey 'phoned to say -

"Mr. Pugh had advised that Mrs. Mayfield was to bring Phyllis and Bert to Old Sun on May 26th."

On June 2, 1952 the following letter concerning the whereabouts of the Blackfoot children mentioned above was received from Principal (letter written 31-5-52) -

Incidentally both the letters of February 29th were typed and bear the date of the meeting (mentioned in section Fort George of the memorandum) of the Superintendent and General Turner and Major Mackay and Mr. Phelan. The copy of letter which the Superintendent saw in the Yukon, i.e., the James children, as coming from Indian Affairs Branch Ottawa Office also carried the date February 29th. The meeting in Major Mackay's office was held during the afternoon of February 29, 1952, at which time Major Mackay informed the I.S.A. delegation that a decision on all the disputed children would be made soon. The date on the letters indicate that at the time of the meeting the decision had been reached. The assumption is that Major Mackay and Mr. Phelan were loath to discuss the decision.

Special Grants: Each year Indian Affairs Branch makes special grants to Church-owned Schools towards repairs, equipment and maintenance. These expenditures are recorded, by schools, in the annual auditor general's report "Public Accounts of Canada". For the past three years the following figures are given:

1949 Special Grant to 6 C. of E.-owned Schools = $5,142.72
1949 Special Grant to 19 R.C.-owned Schools = $42,659.01

1950 Special Grant to 5 C. of E.-owned Schools = $3,451.06
1950 Special Grant to 18 R.C.-owned Schools = $55,870.50

1951 Special Grant to 5 C. of E.-owned Schools = $1,866.99
1951 Special Grant to 17 R.C.-owned Schools = $39,844.76

Broken down on a per pupil basis (for the schools receiving the special grant) the figures reveal (in dollars):

1949 - C. of E. schools received $12.00 per pupil.
1949 - R.C. schools received $19.00 per pupil.
C. of E. Schools received 65% of that allotted to R.C. Schools

1950 - C. of E. Schools received $10.00 per pupil.
1950 - R.C. Schools received $27.00 per pupil.
C. of E. Schools received 38% of that allotted to R.C. Schools.

1951 - C. of E. Schools received $5.00 per pupil.
1951 - R.C. Schools received $20.00 per pupil.
C. of E. Schools received 25% of that allotted to R.C. Schools.

In August of 1950 I.S.A. brought the 1949 figures to the attention of Indian Affairs Branch but no satisfactory reply was received as to why the R.C. Schools were favoured in the allocation of special grant expenditures. Since then, as the figures show, the expenditure of the special grant, increasingly, has been in favour of the R.C.-owned Schools.

There is, on file in I.S.A. Head Office, record of other incidents, where the action of Indian Affairs Branch appears to
favour the Roman Cause. Enough material however is given above to show against the odds the I.S.A. and our Indian missionaries are working.

Of vital concern to the I.S.A. is an understanding with government on the interpretation of section 117 of the New Indian Act. Is government to practice the policy of the Roman Church and claim that a child, either of whose parents is Roman or whose guardian is Roman, is, in turn, Roman Catholic despite statements signed by the parents to the contrary? Is the religion of the father or that of the mother to determine the religion of the child? Indian Affairs appears to choose in favour of whichever parent is R.C. In out-of-the-way-areas is the Roman Church allowed to take in obviously Church of England pupils and retain them until the Church of England protests? Answers, by the Minister, to these questions to all concerned are of vital importance to the Indian School Administration.

The I.S.A. recommends that the Minister be requested to review, in the light of Section 117 as interpreted by him, the specific cases outlined in the foregoing pages and to notify the M.S.C.C. of his decisions.
